business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9 a.m. and read prayers.

debateinfo.title: AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (EXPORT CONTROL) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Truss, and read a first time.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1997 and the Export Control Act 1982 to introduce tighter regulation across all aspects of the livestock export trade.

The amendments in the bill will ensure that the legislative framework is in place to carry out the $11 million package of reforms to the livestock export trade announced by the Australian government on 30 March 2004 in response to the recommendations in the report of the Keniry review into livestock exports. The report was provided to the government in December 2003.

The government's package of reforms, with accompanying funding, recognises that the livestock export trade is important to Australia. The trade contributes significantly to the Australian economy, generating about $1 billion a year in rural economies and supporting approximately 9,000 jobs. However, the trade is also controversial because of the community's concern that the welfare of the animals is not being properly addressed.

The Keniry review found that, although the industry has made genuine efforts to address animal welfare issues, the improvements have been incremental and the pace has been too slow to restore community confidence in the trade. The government has, therefore, decided to take the lead to drive change at a faster pace through legislative and other means.

The main thrust of the bill is to achieve improvements in animal welfare outcomes by moving from a co-regulatory environment and providing government with clearer powers to require the livestock export trade to meet more rigorous standards.

The move away from co-regulation for the livestock export trade is highlighted by an amendment to section 9 of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1997 which removes the requirement for the secretary to have regard to any broad policies formulated by livestock industry bodies in exercising certain powers under the act.

The Keniry review identified a need for the creation of a set of nationally consistent principles that focus on the health and welfare of livestock during the whole of the export chain. The bill gives the minister power to determine the principles and states that they are to be known as the Australian Code for the Export of Livestock. These principles will influence all aspects of the regulatory regime applicable to livestock exports.

The Keniry review also proposed closer integration between the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act and the Export Control Act. Currently, the acts are integrated to the extent that a person must hold a licence under the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act to be able to export livestock under the Export Control Act. The bill provides for further integration of these two acts.

The success of the government's reforms and the continuation of the trade will depend to a large extent on the integrity and competence of the industry participants. Industry participation is controlled through the granting, renewal, suspension and cancellation of licences under the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Act. The Keniry review identified a loophole in this act that allows an exporter to simply rely on the licence of an associate if a decision is made to deny the exporter a licence or to suspend or revoke his/her licence. To prevent frustration of the act by this behaviour, the bill provides the secretary with the power to take action, such as suspension or revocation, in relation to licences of the associates of the exporter.

Veterinarians engaged by exporters undertake an important role in the export chain for livestock, as well as for other animals and reproductive material. Under current practices, exporters engage veterinarians to undertake certain veterinary functions, such as testing of livestock to meet importing country requirements, before the livestock are loaded onto the vessel for the export journey. These veterinarians are currently accredited by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service under an administrative arrangement. The Keniry review recommended that the responsibilities of accredited veterinarians should be referenced in legislation with suitable penalties for breach.

The review also recommended that veterinarians should, in certain circumstances, accompany livestock on voyages to overseas destinations and be required to report to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service on specified matters, including any matters relating to the health and welfare of the animals. In response to these recommendations, the bill contains amendments to the Export Control Act to provide a legislative basis for the accreditation of veterinarians to undertake roles both in Australia and on overseas vessels which are carrying livestock. The bill also contains offence provisions. The accredited veterinarians will continue to be engaged by the exporters.

The bill responds to current widespread criticism of the live animal export trade both in Australia and internationally. It represents an important step in the government's overhaul of the livestock export trade and reflects the government's strong commitment to rectifying the problems with the trade as a matter of urgency. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr McClelland) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Ms Julie Bishop, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The amendments in the Aged Care Amendment Bill 2004 are not extensive. They are however important measures which need to be considered in the context of the 2004 budget initiatives in aged care, which in turn, should be considered in the context of our ageing population.

As the number of Australians over the age of 65 increases, so will the demand for aged care. The challenge is to find the appropriate balance between public funding and government regulation, the responsibilities of the aged care providers and individual responsi-bility. Older Australians have worked hard, they have raised families, paid taxes and contributed to our community. They deserve to be cared for and supported as they age.

The majority of older Australians want to stay in their own homes, in their own communities, or with their own families for as long as they can. If the time comes where staying in their homes is not possible, we need to ensure older Australians have access to the best available care delivered by qualified people. This care must be of high quality, affordable and accessible.

Growing demand, as the population ages, means that we must ensure that the aged care sector is sustainable over the long term. The challenge is to balance cost-sharing with equity of access, while continuing to improve the quality of care.

The Australian government is committed to meeting the challenge. We have made strenuous efforts over the past eight years to improve the quality of care for older Australians, introducing accreditation, improving access to residential and community care, boosting support for carers, and paying special attention to needs in rural and remote areas.

Funding for aged care has increased from $3 billion in 1995-96 to more than $6 billion today. Since 1996 the Australian government has allocated more than 55,600 new aged care places and is on target to meet its commitment to 200,000 places by June 2006. Funding for community aged care packages has increased by more than 820 per cent.

The government, providers of aged care services and the community must ensure older Australians continue to receive a high standard of care. This care must include choices in accommodation and services that are well resourced, well run and well staffed.

Every element in the government's 2004 budget package, Investing in Australia's Aged Care: More Places, Better Care is designed to maintain and improve access for older Australians to high quality and affordable care.
Over the next four years, the government will provide an extra $2.2 billion to build on the progress we have made since 1997 in establishing a world class system of aged care.

The budget package will bring the Australian government's total investment in the care of older Australians to $30 billion over the next four years—$6.7 billion in 2004-05 rising to $8.2 billion in 2007-08.
By the end of the four-year span of these latest initiatives, the Australian government will have spent $67 billion on securing better aged care since coming to office in 1996.

The budget funding and initiatives are a detailed response to Professor Warren Hogan's Review of Pricing Arrangements in Residential Care. This extensive review, commissioned by the government in 2002, examined the longer term prospects of residential aged care with particular reference to private and public funding, performance improvement in the industry and longer term financing.
The government has responded to all of the recommendations for immediate action and has fast-tracked its response to some of the medium term recommendations to create a sustainable industry.
Through Investing in Australia's Aged Care: More Places, Better Care, the government will encourage a cooperative working partnership with both aged care service providers and the community at large.

A central element of this partnership is working with aged care providers to ensure the most efficient use of aged care funding. Greater efficiency holds the prospect of lower costs. As the Hogan report noted:

quote.para: If all residential care services were to operate at optimal technical efficiency then the combined public and private cost of residential care could be reduced by 17 per cent ($1.1 billion in 2002-03).
In the alternative, the level of output of the sector (the number of people cared for) could be expanded by 17 per cent (23,100 in 2002-03) at no additional public or private cost.

speech.para: The government's package provides a firm foundation from which the aged care sector can grow and increase their efficiency and sustainability while ensuring that older Australians can receive the care they need—at the right time and in the right place.

We will provide $877.8 million over the next four years for a conditional adjustment payment which will increase residential care subsidies by seven per cent by 2007-08, in addition to the annually indexed basic care subsidy.
The average annual Australian government subsidy per resident, currently $30,500, will rise to around $35,380, including the effect of indexation, by 2007-08.

The payment is conditional on aged-care providers meeting certain requirements, including encouraging work force training, making audited accounts publicly available annually, and participating in a periodic work force census.
It will give homes an immediate boost in income so they can continue to improve the quality of care they provide, including assisting in paying more competitive wages to nurses and other staff.

The government recognises the unique problems that homes in rural and remote areas often face. We will pay an extra $14.8 million in viability supplements over the next four years from 1 January, after aspects of the viability supplements are reviewed.
The government is increasing the number of aged care places it subsidises—from 100 places to 108 places per 1,000 people aged 70 or over.
We will do so at a cost of $468.3 million over the next four years, including $58.4 million in new spending provided in the budget package.
This is the first increase in the aged care provision ratio since it was introduced in 1985.
This will double the number of places offered in community care to 20 per 1,000 people aged 70 or over, reflecting the preference of older Australians to receive care in their own homes.
In total, around 27,900 new aged care places will be allocated over the next three years, including 13,030 this year.
These are on top of the 35,371 places allocated over the past four years.
Among the total are up to 2,000 transition care places over three years to help older people return home after a stay in hospital.
Investment is needed over the next decade to ensure the supply of aged care homes grows in line with the increase in the number of older Australians who need care.

As well as building new homes, existing aged care homes need to be upgraded to provide quality buildings, furniture, fittings and equipment that are needed for the comfort and safety of residents. To ensure that services deliver high quality care in appropriate surroundings, homes will be expected to meet the new privacy, space and amenity standards, developed in consultation with the aged care sector, by 2008, and appropriate fire and safety standards.
The Hogan report noted that significant levels of investment in new buildings and upgradings were being undertaken.

It was reported that in 2002-03, $821.4 million of new building, refurbishment and upgrading work in aged care was completed, involving an estimated 22.8 per cent of all residential aged care services.
A further $941.7 million of work was under way as at 30 June 2003, involving about 11.7 per cent of services.

The government recognises that over the next decade there will be a continuing need for capital funding so that existing homes can be well maintained, new homes built and existing facilities refurbished.
To address these medium-term needs, the government will provide $438.6 million over the next four years to increase its capital contribution to the providers of care.
We will lift the top rate of the concessional resident supplement from $13.49 to an indexed $16.25 per resident per day from 1 July this year.

Other concessional resident supplement rates will be increased proportionately from the same date. The rates of the respite supplement will be increased in line with the residential increase—that is, by $2.76 per resident per day. The transitional resident supplement rate will be increased to match the new concessional resident supplement rate.

In addition, this financial year the government will make a one-off payment of $513.3 million to aged care providers, amounting to $3,500 per resident, to ensure that all homes have the means to meet 2008 certification standards, in particular fire and safety requirements.

In line with the principle that those who are able to make a contribution to the cost of their accommodation should do so, the government will increase the maximum rate of the accommodation charge for new high-care residents who are able to make such a contribution.
This means that the maximum accommodation charge for new residents from 1 July will be no more than $16.25 per day.
We will also remove the five-year limit on accommodation charges for new high care residents, so that a capital contribution is made for the duration of time spent in a residential care service.
We have also invested in the aged care work force. The government recognises that the global shortage of nurses and other care staff makes a major investment in education and training imperative.
In order to attract and retain staff, it is important that staff receive training and that caring for the aged is a rewarding career path.
A recent census and survey found that Australia's residential aged care sector employs over 116,000 direct care workers who are, overall, highly skilled and motivated.
It found that around 12 per cent had not had sufficient education and training opportunities.
New funding of $101.4 million over four years in this budget will significantly raise the skills and career opportunities of the aged care work force.
We will fund 400 more undergraduate nursing places each year, rising to 1,094 in the fourth year. This will enable 1,600 students to commence nursing education over the next four years.

Funding will also assist 15,750 aged-care workers, up to enrolled nurse level, to obtain formal qualifications, up to 5,250 enrolled nurses to be trained in medication management; and up to 8,000 workers to improve language and literacy skills.

One of the critical issues we have identified and addressed is to ensure that caring for older Australians in aged care homes is made easier for nurses and care workers by simplifying administrative requirements. This will allow them to spend more time caring for older residents and less time on paperwork.
Funding of $81.9 million over four years will be used to simplify administrative requirements.

The Hogan report recommended a single assessment service for community and residential care, and increased funding for Aged Care Assessment Teams to help people access the services best suited to their requirements. As part of the budget package, the government will boost funding for the ACATs and extend their role so that they can continue to give older people support to access suitable care.
Further, the government will introduce a single assessment service for residential and community care.
The resident classification scale funding tool will be simplified from eight categories to three, making it less complex, with two supplements for dementia and palliative care.
A new $2.1 million web based information service will simplify choosing a residential care home, and encourage providers to consider the particular needs of older Australians.
We will introduce progressively e-commerce for funding and information transfers between government and providers.

After 1 July 2005, providers will no longer have to undertake asset testing for new residents. This function will be carried out by Centrelink and the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the case of veterans.
We will also provide additional funding of $36.3 million over the next four years to maintain the activities of the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency.

Although ACATs provide a `gate-keeping' role to ensure that the individual care needs of older Australians are met, there will no longer need to be an ACAT assessment as the care needs of a resident remaining in the same home increase. This means residents will more quickly receive care matched to their needs. This initiative responds to a specific recommendation in the Hogan report and requires an amendment to the Aged Care Act 1997, in particular the repeal of paragraph 28-1(3)(b).

Residents and their families and the providers entrusted with their care will benefit from this amendment. Removing the need for an ACAT assessment will allow residents to move quickly from low to high care within the same aged care home as their care needs change, meaning that people will receive the higher level of care they need more quickly. There will be appropriate funding review processes.

The second amendment to division 57A of the Aged Care Act 1997 gives effect to the government's response to the Hogan report's recommendation on the removal of the five-year limit on payment of accommodation charges.

It will affect only those residents who enter high-level care after 1 July 2004 and who can afford to contribute to the cost of their accommodation. This amendment recognises that it is reasonable for residents who can afford to make this contribution to pay a charge for the duration of their stay in an aged care home. Existing residents and new concessional residents will not be affected nor will those going into low-level care or extra service homes.
Existing accommodation bond arrangements remain unchanged.

In addition, the Australian government will ensure that residents who are in need can access a hardship allowance. Further, we will be reviewing the existing hardship allowance guidelines to ensure assistance is available to those who need it.
Both amendments are part of our overall aged care package that builds on a solid platform of reforms and our commitment to care for older Australians.

Every initiative in the new $2.2 billion Investing in Australia's Aged Care: More Places, Better Care package is designed to further the Australian government's long-term vision for world-class, high-quality, accessible and affordable care. We are determined to ensure that we continue to meet the individual needs of older Australians and their families, by:
investing in better care
providing more aged care places
building better aged care homes
increasing skills and training and
ensuring the right care is delivered in the right place at the right time.
I commend these amendments to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Hardgrave:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr McMullan moved by way of amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) notes the failure of the Government's `practical reconciliation' agenda
(2) condemns the Government for:
(a) failing to consult or negotiate with indigenous Australians on the provisions of the Bill;
(b) failing to explain how the proposed abolition of indigenous representative organisations and mainstreaming of in-digenous programs from 1 July 2004 will address endemic Indigenous dis-advantage;
(c) failing to develop a new legislative and administrative model that restores the right of indigenous Australians to be responsible for their own future; and

(3) notes Labor's support for the abolition of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and creation of new legislative and administrative arrangements that restore responsibility and opportunity for indigenous Australians”.

talk.start.para: —In addressing the House this morning on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004 I say at the outset that, on the face of it, it would seem that there is a fairly simple debate before the chair. It is about giving effect to the Howard government's decision to abolish the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. However, as with any piece of legislation, I think it is very important—and, if anything, it is incumbent upon the House and the community—to actually look behind a bill and assess why it is before the House at a given point in time.

speech.para: I argue today that the bill is not just about abolishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission; it is also about putting in place a long-held desire especially of the Prime Minister to dismantle every means available to the Indigenous community in Australia to actually participate in decisions going to their future. I must say that really worries me. We are talking about the most disadvantaged community in Australia. On every social indicator, the Indigenous community in Australia is missing out—in employment, health, education and nutrition. You know the issues as well as I do, Mr Speaker. The Indigenous community is suffering, and suffering badly.

I think it is about time that we faced up to the fact that the debate is perhaps more important than the abolition of ATSIC. Unfortunately, it is also, I believe, a debate about the politics of race and the desire of the Howard government to pursue ATSIC for political purposes. It reminds me of the Prime Minister's dog whistle approach to a range of issues since he won government in March 1996. I suppose the first issue that he used for political purposes was the debate about One Nation and Pauline Hanson. Even today, in terms of potential political wedges, we are confronting not only the future of ATSIC but also whether or not we treat the gay and lesbian community in Australia as second-class citizens. I refer to the debate later today about the Marriage Legislation Amendment Bill 2004, which I also intend to contribute to.

I do not deny that there are problems with ATSIC. I also do not deny that we have to do better in coming to terms with the needs of the Indigenous community with respect to the issue of governance. But that is not to say that we should throw the baby out with the bathwater. The Indigenous community is looking for a helping hand, not ongoing criticism that is often without foundation just because there are a few bad apples. There are a few bad apples in the parliament too, but we do not propose to abolish the Commonwealth parliament.

talk.start.para: —That is a bit of an untimely analogy from the member for Batman!

—Yes. We commit ourselves to working jointly to try and improve the performance of the parliament. It is for those reasons that the opposition, under the name of the member for Fraser, Mr McMullan, a former shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, has correctly moved a second reading amendment. That second reading amendment notes our concerns about the bill. Not only do I support the second reading amendment but also I support the decision by the Labor caucus which effectively means that we will not allow this bill to pass through parliament without due consideration of its provisions. That is the right of the parliament. Just because the Howard government has a view that we should simply abolish ATSIC does not mean that there are not other views in this parliament. I think it is appropriate that, with any bill before a parliament, there is a proper debate and if need be, in the other chamber where we have the capacity, we actually inquire into the provisions of the bill and report back to the parliament about not only the provisions of the bill but also the intent of the government with respect to the bill.

speech.para: That takes me to the issue of ATSIC. It is fair to say that ATSIC has been subject to fierce criticism from day one. It has also, unlike a lot of other areas of government activity, been subject to unrelenting scrutiny since its inception. As I look back over the role of the Commonwealth with respect to Indigenous affairs, it has been one marked by the chopping and changing of policy directions by governments. I recall the referendum of 1967, as a result of which the Commonwealth assumed some direct responsibility for Indigenous affairs from the states. That was a huge achievement, because I think we have a major national problem and there is a major role for the Commonwealth in trying to assist our Aboriginal community and to work in partnership with them to make some advances.

Since that referendum of 37 years ago, a series of governments has, for whatever reason, brought up alternative approaches to try to do a better job on Indigenous affairs in Australia. Initially, as a result of the 1967 referendum, there was an Aboriginal advisory council under Dr Nugget Coombs—a person who had a proud history of service and understanding of the needs of the Indigenous community. It also saw the creation of a small office of Aboriginal affairs within the Prime Minister's department—a statement by the then Prime Minister who actually regarded Indigenous affairs as exceptionally important, as he allocated the office to his departmental responsibilities.

That was followed by the election of the Whitlam Labor government in December 1972 and the decision in 1973 to establish a Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Its responsibilities were to administer the Commonwealth's Indigenous policy and programs. Whitlam also correctly established the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee. That is important because that was about the Commonwealth saying, `Not only do we want to try to do the right thing for service delivery but also we believe that Indigenous representatives ought to be consulted about the direction of Commonwealth government policy.'

The Whitlam government came and went, and then we had the Fraser government. It dismantled the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee and replaced it with a new representative body, the National Aboriginal Conference, in 1977. Whatever, we still had a process of consultation. The Fraser government also established, in 1980, the Aboriginal Development Corporation, which was about—and I emphasise this—managing a limited number of Indigenous economic development projects. In 1983 there was another change in government. The Hawke government brought Nugget Coombs back into the realm of Aboriginal and Indigenous affairs. His responsibility was to review the performance of the advisory council, the National Aboriginal Conference, established by the Fraser government in 1977. This eventually led to a decision by the Hawke government in December 1987 to establish ATSIC. The then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, entered into a huge national process of consultation to try to get it right. I think it is fair to say that the eventual legislation passed by the parliament was not really what was sought in the original decision leading up to the establishment of ATSIC in December 1987. It was a different model to that which was originally proposed by Gerry Hand.

So we have had a rather chequered history. On each occasion there has been an acceptance that the Indigenous community had to be properly consulted and had to have a voice in government for the direction of Indigenous affairs in Australia. The problem is that, since the establishment of ATSIC, for a variety of reasons, it has been subject to major public and political attack, and I do not think it has been given the support on some occasions that it should have been given by governments of both political persuasions. There were people in the Labor government, from 1983 to 1996, who actually wanted ATSIC to fail because it did not suit their view of life with respect to Indigenous affairs. Alternatively, there were members of the combination of Hawke and Keating governments that were absolutely committed to trying to make ATSIC work, and I commend their best endeavours. The problem was that, with the election of the Howard government in March 1996, there was a clear determination to dismantle ATSIC because it did not suit the Prime Minister's view of what he believed was in the best interests of Australia and, perhaps more importantly, his own political interests.

So we confront today a bill which, yes, proposes the abolition of ATSIC but, more importantly, does not propose how we as a community commit to making further process in overcoming disadvantage in the Indigenous community in Australia. With respect to the criticism of ATSIC, I want to make it very clear today that it has not had prime responsibility for delivering programs aimed at overcoming discrimination and disadvantage in Indigenous communities. ATSIC's programs have been limited to CDEP, which is a former Work for the Dole program, initiated and pursued by Labor in government from 1983 to 1996 and then pursued by the Howard government. Over and above that, it has had some responsibilities for housing and infrastructure but it has not, for example, responsibility for fundamental services such as health, education and employment. I think we should think about that because, every time ATSIC is attacked, it is attacked for not delivering to the Indigenous community and not making progress in overcoming disadvantage in the areas of health, education and employment. But the truth is that ATSIC has not had responsibility for those areas of government delivery.

That brings me to the point of the role of government. As an alternative to ATSIC—as a stepping stone to abolishing ATSIC—the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, actually started to promote a debate about practical reconciliation. The Howard government suggested that it had the solution to Indigenous disadvantage in Australia and that is what it regarded as a practical approach to solving problems in Indigenous communities. It talked about how it was going to make progress as an alternative to trying to prop up ATSIC in areas such as employment, education, income, housing and health.

I want to simply say today that the Prime Minister's program of practical reconciliation has been a dismal failure. This is what today's debate ought to be about—not just abolishing ATSIC but also focusing on the problems that exist in Indigenous Australia and what we are going to do about putting in place an alternative to ATSIC following proper consultation with the Indigenous community and to actually come to terms with some of the issues that I am now going to refer to as examples of primary disadvantage that we ought to be ashamed of in Australia in the 21st century.

Let us talk about practical reconciliation and where we are at 37 years on from when the Commonwealth actually assumed responsibility for doing something more on Indigenous affairs. There are a couple of indicators which I think speak for themselves. Firstly, Aboriginal children in Northern Australia suffer rates of malnutrition comparable to or worse than any developing countries such as Eritrea, Nepal and Vietnam. Secondly, throughout the period 1999-2002, for example, the rates of children diagnosed with malnutrition in the Northern Territory increased by 25 per cent. Aboriginal children under three years of age are 120 times more likely to be admitted to hospital with nutrition related illnesses than non-Aboriginal children of the same age. Thirdly, we can talk about the cost of living and the huge achievements of the Australian economy and how, as the Prime Minister said, we are all going to share in the benefits of economic growth. Let us just go to the cost of living of people in these communities. The cost of fresh food in remote Aboriginal communities is much higher than the cost in southern cities, averaging between 150 per cent and 180 per cent more expensive. Community stores—which is a topic related to this debate—are generally poorly managed, lack best practice and, in essence, have all too often existed to rip off the Indigenous community.

I must say I have seen some examples of where we are making progress on overcoming some of the problems of store management and improving nutrition in Indigenous communities. But that progress is not being made by government. It is actually being made by non-government organisations such as the Fred Hollows Foundation in Katherine, in partnership with the local Indigenous communities. I commend those programs. They are examples of what we ought to be talking about today and how government, rather than abolishing ATSIC, should be debating an alternative to ATSIC that is about general improvement in governance in Indigenous communities in Australia and how they will have a greater say at a regional level in making progress with respect to the fundamental problems that confront their communities.

Let us talk about another indicator: the limited employment and training opportunities in remote communities. I am someone who has frequently visited Indigenous communities over the last quarter of a century, because I have had a long involvement in the union movement in the Northern Territory, formerly as a union official and more generally since I came into the House as part of my responsibilities as a shadow minister—and I am pleased to say that those responsibilities have frequently taken me to Indigenous communities. In terms of employment and training, I support CDEP. The Aboriginal communities want CDEP because it assists them on a variety of social and economic fronts. Yes, it is about Work for the Dole, but it is also our responsibility, in addition to CDEP, to try and work out how, at a local level, we create sustainable employment opportunities which are focused on improving attainment of education and access to tertiary education, be it university or TAFE.

Practical reconciliation speaks for itself. It has failed—the social indicators show that in no uncertain terms. I simply say today that the government desires to have its way on the ATSIC bill, but it is also about time that we as a community try to force the government to have a real debate about the alternative. That alternative has got to firstly provide opportunity and responsibility for the Indigenous community to assist in creating a new framework as an alternative to ATSIC. Abolition of ATSIC is an easy decision for the Howard government. Consultation and developing an alternative model is about good policy and decency in government.

I am very firmly of the view that you cannot overcome the problems of the Indigenous community through programs directed and implemented from Canberra. I am prepared to take a risk because I trust and respect our Indigenous community. I believe that, as part of an alternative to ATSIC, we have to give full support to regional delivery. That is about making sure that people at a local level have the capacity to do the job—give them the chance to do it, provided it is dependent on a genuine partnership between local, state and federal government, the private sector and the Indigenous community.

Give advice and support accountability but also say to the Indigenous community, `We have sufficient trust in and respect for your capacity to make genuine practical improvements as part of a national consultative process that fingers state and federal government on performance of service delivery, but in the primary instance we are going to give you the green light to do the job locally. We have failed, so let's try and work out how we give you the capacity in a practical way to do it yourselves.' That is what I, in my regional responsibilities, say to the broader Australian community. You cannot solve the problems in Canberra. You have to do it at a local level. If we are prepared to say that to the Australian community generally, then it is time we said it to the Indigenous community in particular. I commend the second reading amendment to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I too rise today to speak on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004. In doing so, I register my continuing support for Indigenous Australians and pay my respects to them as the original owners of and carers for this land we all share. This week is National Reconciliation Week, a week that spans two of the most significant dates in the history of Australia's engagement with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. The week began on 27 May, the day that 91 per cent of Australians voted yes in a referendum that granted Indigenous Australians formal recognition as our citizens, an indication that this was the land of the fair go. The week ends on 3 June, the day that the Australian High Court delivered the historic Mabo decision, which put an end to the legal fiction of terra nullius. I also register my disappointment—for Indigenous Australians and for this nation—that during this week of national reconciliation we see this racist government presenting a bill which proposes changes to the administration of Indigenous affairs that extend well beyond the abolition of ATSIC. This is legislation that strikes at the heart of Indigenous Australians' autonomy and attempts to stifle their national voice.

speech.para: This bill is part of the Prime Minister's longstanding push to mainstream all services to Indigenous Australians. John Howard is well known for his fierce opposition to the principle of self-determination. The basic idea that Aboriginal people should have a significant say in the management of policies and programs that affect them is something that this Prime Minister has never agreed to. This bill is the final step in Mr Howard's ongoing quest to remove executive power over Indigenous affairs programs from a body controlled by Indigenous people, transferring it to mainstream bureaucratic agencies. He opposed ATSIC's formation and in eight years as Prime Minister he has managed to diminish its performance and demonise the organisation itself.

Apart from concentrating in the hands of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs much of the power previously invested in ATSIC, this bill makes a number of consequential amendments to the act. They include provisions that transfer ATSIC's assets and liabilities to the Commonwealth; establish a new housing fund to replace the ATSIC housing fund; transfer money held in the Regional Land Fund to the Indigenous Land Corporation; and expand the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit to include the undertaking of evaluations and audits of Indigenous programs and individuals—and of organisations that receive funding under any Indigenous program. They abolish the Office of Torres Strait Islander Affairs and the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board. They also vest the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs with new powers for the proposed life of ATSIC regional councils, including the power to approve staff engagements and convene meetings.

What does that mean in plain English? It means the assets will be removed from ATSIC and transferred back into consolidated revenue for our Treasurer to play with; a few special funds to be managed by organisations that are acceptable to the government will be set up; the government bureaucracy will audit its own performance and that of funded Indigenous organisations and groups; and the minister will be put in charge of hiring and firing within regional councils and of deciding when they will meet. That all sounds like a return to the colonial era to me.

This bill also makes so-called consequential amendments to another 10 acts of parliament, which I will not list here, but just think about the fact that 10 acts of parliament are involved. ATSIC was part of Indigenous Australia's development. It was part of their community development. It was part of their operations in every way. It will take a lot of change to dismantle this organisation.

Other amendments in this legislation remove a requirement for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to consult with any Torres Strait Islander organisation prior to the appointment of a Torres Strait Islander to the board of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. There is obviously no say for Indigenous Australians there.

The bill also removes a requirement for the Minister for the Environment and Heritage to inform an Indigenous representative organisation of any proposal received under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act or to invite them to comment on that proposal. So forget Indigenous people having a say in what happens to Indigenous lands. It also removes a requirement for a nominee of an Indigenous representative organisation to sit on the National Health and Medical Research Council. It is always much easier to cover up poor performance if no-one is watching on the inside. It provides the Secretary of the Attorney General's Department with new power to determine grants to native title representative bodies—more paternalistic control and less Indigenous participation.

Just what did ATSIC do? I would like to tell the House a little about what it did on the ground in my region. The ATSIC New South Wales East Zone takes in an area from the Tweed River to the Hawkesbury River, along the coast and west to just past Mungindi, Gunnedah, Merriwa and Cessnock. It includes my electorate of Newcastle and other major centres such as Coffs Harbour, Tamworth and Gosford. That zone has two regional councils: Many Rivers and Kamilaroi. Kamilaroi occupies the inland part of that region and Many Rivers takes in the coastal strip, including Newcastle. Together those two regional councils represent the region that is most densely populated by Indigenous people in all Australia. Throughout the zone there are some 50,000 Aboriginal people—35,000 in the Many Rivers region. About 60 per cent of the individuals who make up the identified Aboriginal population in the ATSIC New South Wales East Zone are under the age of 19 years. The government thought it was going to be easy. No, it is not going to be easy—what an immense challenge.

A substantial number of Aborigines in this region are educated, employed, healthy and prosperous. However, there are many more who still suffer the dire effects of the past 220 years of European colonisation—homelessness, poverty, family violence and breakdown, substance abuse and sickness. There is also some racial tension in some towns within the zone. ATSIC has a regional office in Coffs Harbour for the Many Rivers region and one in Tamworth for the Kamilaroi region. Each office employs some 17 individuals, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. There are about 200 independent Aboriginal organisations, funded and unfunded, that operate within the zone, including land councils; sports, arts and cultural heritage groups; and economic and business development organisations. Yet this government, with one stroke of a pen, can attempt to wipe all that out. ATSIC plays a very important role in providing a link between all those organisations.

Aboriginal unemployment is high—as much as 50 per cent in some communities within the zone. The CDEP operates in both regions, and in the Many Rivers region it has 13 programs, ranging in size from 50 to 256 participants, with 1,770 participants altogether.

In my region, ATSIC's home loan program funds 470 home loans to the value of $9 million. With an average of $20,000 for each loan, we are not talking about luxury housing. Housing availability in my region has become an issue because of the problems of affordability. There are still 120 eligible borrowers on the waiting list in the Many Rivers region alone. The Community Housing Infrastructure Program maintains about 60 community houses throughout the region, offering employment opportunities for Indigenous people.

In addition, ATSIC administers the funding for the various Aboriginal Legal Services that operate in the zone. Those legal services are seriously underfunded and cannot possibly meet the demands of the people in that zone. The number of lawyers available to meet the needs of 35,000 people in the whole of the Many Rivers region is equivalent to 2½.

A program that is threatened by this legislation is the CDEP scheme. As the previous speaker, the member for Batman, mentioned, it is a program that does provide work opportunities, particularly in rural and regional Australia. It is an employment, training and community development program, and it began in 1977. In June 2002, there were 270 Indigenous community organisations and 34,182 Indigenous people were actually participating in the CDEP nationally. That accounts for approximately 25 per cent of Indigenous employment. I am not sure what the government says that it can do in its place—by removing ATSIC.

In Newcastle, Youloe-Ta, our local registered CDEP, is funded for 266 participants at present. It has grown from Yarnteen, which was set up in 1993, and has continued to have outstanding outcomes. One particular success of Yarnteen was the granting of $100,000—not by the Australian government but by Microsoft USA—to network all CDEPs across New South Wales. It is an outstanding program with outstanding achievements. In our region, there is also a registered training organisation at Yamuloong, a bush tucker tourist site of great renown as well as an education and conference centre.

Why does the government want to dismantle all of that? What did ATSIC do wrong? Much of the criticism which ATSIC has faced has focused on its expenditure of government funds. At the same time, one of the central misconceptions surrounding ATSIC relates to the amount of funding that ATSIC actually received—and what it could and could not do with that money. As the peak Indigenous body in the country, ATSIC is often the prime target for blame games. The issue of funding is also the focal point for debate about ATSIC's effectiveness. While ATSIC is not the primary service provider in most portfolio areas, particularly health care and education, it is often blamed when not enough is seen to be done in these areas.

One of the other misconceptions about ATSIC's funding that this government conveniently perpetuates is that ATSIC is responsible for all Commonwealth spending on Indigenous affairs. This is not—and never really has been—the case. ATSIC has only ever administered around half of the Commonwealth's total identifiable expenditure on Indigenous affairs. The other half, about $1.3 billion in the last financial year, is spent through various agencies in other areas, including in the employment, education and training portfolio, the social security portfolio and the health portfolio. In recent years under this government, ATSIC's share of the total Indigenous funding pie has continued to decrease. The mainstreaming of Indigenous-specific programs is usually—and has often been—at ATSIC's expense.

ATSIC does not have responsibility for many of the areas in which its performance is often criticised. ATSIC has always argued that its programs are only designed to supplement funding and programs provided by other Commonwealth, state and territory agencies. However, there is often a gap, particularly in rural and remote Aboriginal communities, between what should be provided to Indigenous people through mainstream service delivery agencies and what actually is provided. For example, part of ATSIC's expenditure through CHIP goes towards the provision of basic services such as running water and electricity in remote Indigenous communities—services that we would all expect to be provided to us by our government agencies. Subsequently, as a recent Commonwealth Grants Commission report commented, the failure of mainstream programs to address the needs of Indigenous peoples effectively means that Indigenous-specific programs are expected to do more than they were designed to do.

In order to illustrate how inadequate the levels of government have been in responding to the needs of Indigenous Australians, I will refer to the Social justice report 2003. In doing so, I pay tribute to Bill Jonas, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Bill, a Worimi man very well-known in the Newcastle region, presented the Social justice report 2003. The report showed that there has been no significant increase in Indigenous household income; the increase in individual income for Indigenous Australians was less than the increase for non-Indigenous people; employment participation was at 54 per cent, against 73 per cent for non-Indigenous people; and the unemployment rate for Indigenous Australians was three times higher than that for non-Indigenous people.

In education, the report states that 69 per cent of Indigenous people are progressing to year 11, against 90 per cent of non-Indigenous people; home ownership for Indigenous people is at 13 per cent, as opposed to 40 per cent for non-Indigenous people; and Indigenous people make up 20 per cent of the total prison population. If you are an Indigenous Australian, you are 16 times more likely to be imprisoned than a non-Indigenous Australian, while Indigenous juveniles have made up 42 per cent of all incarcerated juveniles since 1997—and that rate has been consistent. Life expectancy for Indigenous females is 62.8 years. Life expectancy for Indigenous males is 56.3 years. Those figures show a slight improvement, but I do not think the government will have to worry about aged care costs or senior pensions for Indigenous males. Indigenous babies have twice the chance of having a low birth weight, and the infant death rate is 2½ times that of non-Indigenous babies.

As I said last week in this House when I shared these facts in an adjournment speech, it is very sad to repeat the outcomes from that report. For many non-Indigenous people those figures are just statistics, but for Indigenous people they are the everyday, real life struggles and personal tragedies that they experience. Their sons and daughters are represented by those figures. It is their babies, their frustrated youth and their family members and leaders who are struck down in their prime.

But John Howard lacks any sensitivity to the emotional burden Indigenous Australians carry with them every day—the burden created by a white history in this country that has been less than kind. John Howard has no understanding of reconciliation either and, more importantly, there is no apology to Indigenous people that, on every indicator of quality of life and socioeconomic status, this government over eight years through the departments it administers has failed to achieve significant progress of any kind. But of course this `blame everyone else' government would have us all believe that the failure is someone else's fault—the fault of Indigenous people themselves and the fault of ATSIC, they would allege. We all know that is just another white lie. The figures are shameful.

John Howard suggests that by abolishing ATSIC and mainstreaming all programs his government is actually showing more respect for Indigenous Australians—by treating them the same as non-Indigenous Australians. If we are all equal, he would purport, then why do we need to do anything differently for Indigenous Australians? Get real, Prime Minister: stop hiding behind some conservative class system that measures success by status and wealth and start looking at the quality of life indicators for Indigenous Australians, because there is not much equality there.

Another perception that John Howard would feel comfortable with in his conservative world would be the perception that ATSIC was a `corrupt shambles', as was stated in a media article. But the discussion paper on the ATSIC review, when commenting on ATSIC's structure—in particular its current responsibilities for advocacy, policy advice and program delivery—noted:

quote.para: Adoption of such a structure—

speech.para: as the one ATSIC has—

quote.para: for the delivery of political advocacy and publicly funded services and programs would never be contemplated ... for mainstream Australia. If groups of backbench Members of Parliament across Australia were personally making public funding decisions over `work for the dole' schemes, sporting clubs etc, there would be, at least, perceptions of a corruption-ridden shambles within months.

speech.para: Let us think about that comment and relate it to the actions of backbenchers and frontbenchers in the current government. I cite the Envirofund, where 76 per cent of those funds went to coalition seats—$20 million of government pork-barrelling. I cite the recent budget, from which 90 per cent of the people in my electorate will not gain any tax cuts because they do not earn over $52,000 per year. That is more targeted policy to gain votes. What about the disgraceful way public moneys were wasted on the `Strengthening Medicare' advertisements? That was another $21 million of Australian public funds up in smoke—smokescreens. No wonder the people of Australia are cynical about politicians and no wonder Indigenous Australians have so little respect for this mean-spirited, hypocritical government that looks after its own and shows no mercy for those it has little electoral use for.

While we are talking about poor governance, I do not see the government abolishing NAB for their woeful mismanagement, and I am still waiting, along with the rest of Australia, to see anyone in HIH face a court for the destruction of so many people's lives and assets through corporate greed and mismanagement. I have not noticed David Flint getting the flick either for questionable conduct on the public payroll. But we are here today debating legislation that would totally dismantle ATSIC as a punishment for not always getting it right. Such double standards by this government are unacceptable. But we should be used to that after eight years.

Not everyone here in parliament has contact with Indigenous people. Personally, my contact has been limited. But 30 years in education and 6½ years as a principal in a school where one-third of the student population was Indigenous gave me a wonderful opportunity to gain some insight into the lives of Indigenous people in my electorate of Newcastle. For those people, particularly those I met whilst principal at Carrington school, I will be forever grateful—grateful that they let me share their dreams, their frustrations, their sorrows and disappointments, their pride and their determination. I have one key message for the Prime Minister from that learning experience: you can try to take away from Indigenous Australians their identity and their self-determination, but you will fail. Indigenous Australians will survive and eventually they will thrive, and this country will be a better place.

I will never forget an Aboriginal student who used to say to me, very often, `It's too hard, Miss,' and I would look into her deep soulful eyes and know she was right. For her, it usually was too hard, given some of the struggles that were part of her everyday existence. But when I saw her compete in races when it was not as hard—when there was a more level playing field—I saw a strength and determination that was unstoppable. It was not unusual to see that courage and determination repeated in all the Indigenous students as they provided support and encouragement for each other. It was also usual to see Indigenous children adopt ways to creatively express their Aboriginal identity—another unstoppable force. In education, I was also privileged to work with many Indigenous people employed under ASPA programs and Aboriginal education programs. I pay tribute to their dedication.

As the member for Newcastle, I have also had the privilege to work with Indigenous leaders in our community—people like Jimmy Wright and the Smith family, who built an Aboriginal community in a place that had no members of the original Awabakal people surviving; people like Ray Kelly, who managed the Awabakal centre in a way that developed a community further—he is now with the Arts Council putting all his performance skills into work that benefits all Australians; and people like Leah Armstrong and Sean Gordon, who are involved with our CDEP programs. Without ATSIC though, few of these people would have been able to make a difference. Finally, I join my Labor colleagues in expressing my contempt for this legislation and support its full review by the Senate processes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Late last year I launched an initiative called Wedge Watch, because we were keen to put the media and the Australian public on notice that an increasingly desperate Prime Minister would resort to the same sort of wedge politics he adopted in the lead-up to the 2001 election with the infamous Tampa incident, which was coloured most particularly by false claims by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and other ministers that asylum seekers had thrown their children overboard. We know from a Senate inquiry that it became clear to the government that that in fact had not happened, but at no time did the government take the opportunity during that election campaign to enlighten the Australian people about the truth. As a consequence, the truth was thrown overboard by the Howard government and since then it has never been rescued.

speech.para: With that in mind, I wanted to alert the Australian community to the very high likelihood that in an election year an increasingly desperate Prime Minister would embrace wedge politics in a way that we have not seen in Australia for a very long time—if ever. It is therefore no coincidence that on today's Notice Paper we have two bills containing wedge issues: one is the bill we are debating now, which is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004, and the other is the Marriage Legislation Amendment Bill 2004.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—I am sure the honourable member will not go—
—I will not go to the substance of the debate on the Marriage Legislation Amendment Bill—
—I thank the honourable member for not pre-empting the debate.

—as I am fully aware of the anticipation rule. I simply point out that both of these are wedge issues—one in relation to the Indigenous community and the other in relation to the gay community. In fact, I foreshadowed the prospect of the Prime Minister using both of these communities to advance his political interests in my `wedge watch' speech last year. And here we are in June 2004, in the lead-up to the election, and the prophecy has been fulfilled.

speech.para: The announcement of the abolition of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in an election year has caused uncertainty for Indigenous people in our community and has once again caused division in the nation. It was done purely for political purposes—not for the national interest but for the political interests of the Prime Minister and his party. Yesterday the Labor caucus voted not to allow this bill to pass until all its provisions had had careful consideration in the Senate and there had been an opportunity for Indigenous communities and other interested Australians to come forward and express their views. Labor certainly does not support the denial of a voice to the Indigenous people of our country.

I met with elders of the Indigenous people of Logan, in my electorate, in my office on 22 April this year. The meeting was planned as a follow-up to an earlier meeting held in December of last year, but it happened that it was just days after the Howard government had announced the abolition of ATSIC. Consequently, interest and participation in the meeting was very strong. Representatives in attendance at that meeting included ATSIC Commissioner Robbie Williams, Vanessa Kirk, Elwyn Hill, Margaret Perry, Paddy Jerome, Reg Knox, Ida Collins, Jim Collins, Peggy Tidyman, Sigrumb Nilsen and Frederick McCoy. From that initial meeting, which was very successful, a new group representing the Indigenous people of Rankin has been formed. It is called Logan Elders. It is planned that they will represent the Indigenous people of Logan through this transition period. They want to ensure that they have a strong voice and that they do not see Indigenous issues absorbed into mainstream departments.

From the meeting in my office and two subsequent public meetings which I proposed, I have been asked to make known to the parliament the views of the Indigenous community in my electorate. I will set them out now. First, the Indigenous community through Logan Elders has expressed great concern at no Indigenous voice being heard at the national level. The government's decision to abolish ATSIC effectively takes away the Indigenous voice on issues of concern to Indigenous people. Logan Elders support the ATSIC commissioners being their elected voice at the national level. They have indicated that Australian governments have had more than 200 years to improve the lot of Indigenous people and to address the issues concerning the Indigenous community but have failed. They point out, too, that the government gave ATSIC 15 years and took it away because of the actions of a few. Government departments are still failing Indigenous people today. The elders ask: how will it possibly improve by handing ATSIC funds over to Commonwealth government departments to deliver services to their people?

The second major point that they have asked me to raise in parliament is that of the mainstreaming of Indigenous services. They feel that this will mean that Indigenous people will be further disadvantaged. Staff will not be prepared for the influx of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues and concerns. Staff are not trained in cross-cultural awareness to prepare them for the delivery of culturally appropriate services. Logan Elders and the broader Indigenous community tell me that mainstreaming of services such as legal services and CDEP will have a huge impact on Indigenous communities, sending them back 30 years. If legal services are taken out of the control of Indigenous people it could mean an increase in the Indigenous population in jails.

The third major issue that Logan Elders have asked me to communicate in the House of the Australian parliament and, through the parliament, to the people of Australia is their concern that funding to urban Indigenous communities has been reduced, with a diversion of funds to compensate what is in fact a lesser number of Indigenous people in rural and remote communities. I say without qualification that Logan Indigenous people support the provision of services to rural and remote communities, but they point out that there are a lot of Indigenous people in urban areas. Certainly there are a lot of Indigenous people in Logan City and surrounding areas. They do not want to be disadvantaged as a consequence of being in urban areas. They point out that Indigenous people in urban areas are being further disadvantaged by the lack of services to their families and young people in particular. They estimate the Logan Indigenous community at 7,000 to 10,000 people, but Indigenous organisations are slowly disappearing in our local area. Logan Elders call for an Indigenous community centre to enable them to form their own Indigenous identity within Logan City and not be identified as part of a multicultural community. They are happy to play their role in a multicultural society but they point out that they are the original Australians and have their own identity.

The fourth major issue is the failure of government departments to provide effective services to Indigenous people in Logan City. This is a major concern for the local Indigenous community, as expressed through Logan Elders. The newly formed Logan Elders Committee is not a traditional elders group but a community based elders group made up of elders from many different areas who have settled in Logan City. Logan Elders Committee is committed to working with government departments to ensure that Indigenous families and young people are being serviced appropriately by all relevant government departments. To date Logan Elders have met with Desley Scott, the state member for Woodridge, and with the police, Logan Youth and Family Services, Logan TAFE, Logan City Council, the Queensland Department of Housing and the Department of Corrective Services. Logan Elders Committee has indicated that it wishes to work towards developing partnerships with these organisations.

The fifth major issue is that the Logan Indigenous community do not accept the Howard government's decision to abolish ATSIC and calls on the Labor Party to reject the bill when it is tabled in parliament. It calls on the Labor Party to give Indigenous people of this country a voice at the national level and to put in place a structure that is acceptable to Indigenous people. Labor, in the Senate, will refer this bill to a committee for inquiry and report. This will give Indigenous Australians the opportunity to be heard in this debate and to have a say in their future. As the representative of Indigenous people in Logan City, I am absolutely committed to ensuring that our local Indigenous community do have an effective voice, through me, in the Australian parliament. It is important that they have an effective voice that will be heard and that they have a role to play in shaping their future, their destiny, and in improving their lot and that of the young Indigenous community in Logan City.

I support the work of such elders as Paddy Jerome, a dear friend of mine, who is working very hard to ensure that local young Indigenous people understand the culture of the Indigenous community in our area and more broadly. Once they understand the culture it certainly contributes positively to self-esteem, giving them a sense of identity and a feeling of having a truly strong place in our community. Paddy Jerome and others feel that that is the key—and I certainly think that there is a lot of merit in this argument—to giving self-esteem to young Indigenous people. We need to ensure that they can be a real part of our community, that they can receive all of the benefits of growing up in the Australian community. We need to ensure not only that they are not deprived in any way because of their Indigenous background but that, in fact, with that knowledge of their own culture, they are able to explain to non-Indigenous people the culture that they have inherited over 40,000 years.

I am very proud of our local Indigenous community. Having received this news about the Howard government's decision, they have not just said, `We'll have to lie down and take it.' They have risen up and have organised themselves into a very active, strong group which now is very well coordinated through Logan Elders. It is a tribute to their determination. They have been kicked in the guts so many times that you could understand that local Indigenous people, particularly under this Howard government, might just say, `It's time to give up.' But they will never give up. They want a strong voice in parliament, which I will give them. They want a say in their future, and that is vitally important from the point of view of the Labor Party.

In closing, I condemn the Howard government for yet again embracing wedge politics and for seeking to set Australian against Australian to divide our community at the expense of the Indigenous people of Australia. We have come to expect this from the Prime Minister. It is sad when we see it actually happening, as we do here today with this bill and also with the marriage bill. I condemn the Prime Minister for these tactics. I think they are grubby tactics, but we are now familiar with them. It will be a great pleasure to play my part in the Labor Party to ensure that this Prime Minister is removed from office later this year and to celebrate the election of a Labor government, which will give the Indigenous community in this country a real voice, a real say in their future and a decent standard of living.

talk.start.para: —Whatever one says about the effectiveness of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission—and there are many differing views on that—the organisation has effectively done two things. Firstly, it has been a one-stop, administratively convenient government organisation for Aboriginal people and those concerned with Aboriginal affairs. Secondly, it has been an attempt to adopt a principled approach to relations between Aboriginal communities and the Australian government. That being so, the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004 needs to focus on the worthwhile aspects of ATSIC and the lessons learned from ATSIC to encourage government in the future to take the good parts of what ATSIC represented and move forward.

speech.para: I want to say a couple of things about administrative convenience and to refer to two incidents. As the member for Wentworth, I have worked closely with the La Perouse Aboriginal community. La Perouse is the well-known landing place and indeed a place of a famous Aboriginal community in Sydney. Kenny Rodgers, who is one of the elders of that community, has worked with me on a number of different projects.

One of those projects has been the development or potential development of Aboriginal owned land and publicly owned land in the La Perouse area for the benefit of local Aboriginal people—in particular, for housing and development. The Aboriginal community there does not take a negative approach to commercial development. It sees that as having potential for the Aboriginal people in that area. It was on that basis that I was able to approach ATSIC and, ultimately, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to see what could be done to assist that process. Having a one-stop shop was critical to helping the local people.

The second example I want to refer to with regard to administrative convenience concerns the Block at Redfern. When I was Chair of the Australian Heritage Commission, I was involved in the listing of that place on the Australian national register. Whatever happens to the Block in Redfern in the future, in accordance with Commonwealth, state and local government arrangements there will be an interpretive centre to ensure that people of the future understand the struggles of the people in Redfern and the importance of the cultural heritage, such as it was, to the people living there. But, from a practical point of view, it is now virtually impossible for people who are trying to do their best to redevelop the Block area in Redfern, which has effectively been razed, to approach that in a coordinated fashion—as one organisation—so that they can seek funding and put in place administrative arrangements that may assist them in the future development of that important place.

These are practical matters. We are talking about grants. We are talking about approvals. We are talking about planning relationships between local and Commonwealth agencies and so on. That is why, from an administrative convenience point of view, it is necessary and appropriate to have an organisation—not the same as ATSIC, but one that has fulfilled that role in the past. I urge government to ensure that there is a one-stop shop for Aboriginal people and those concerned with Aboriginal affairs so that they can conveniently access Commonwealth largesse, such as it is, to Aboriginal people.

I also raise a point about the importance of a principled approach. Here I want to concentrate on three matters. It seems to me that, for the future, the following considerations need to be taken into account. The first principle is the need for Aboriginal involvement in the delivery of better outputs and outcomes for Aboriginal people. I am talking not only about health and education but also about housing and the many other services that are delivered by government to Aboriginal people. The second principle that ought to be taken into account is shared governance. By that I mean that Aboriginal people should have a continuing involvement in the governance of their various communities.

Let me give you an example as to why that is important. At Lockhart River in North Queensland, there is a very vibrant community. There they have a wonderful vegetable garden. That vegetable garden was developed as a result of a CDEP—a Community Development Employment Project. In 2002-03, the CDEP program contributed about 50 per cent of the $1.1 billion from government in Aboriginal funding. The reason for the success of that particular project was that local people, the local Indigenous organisation and the CDEP people were able to work together.

The third principle is accountability to the Australian people. One suggestion I have in this regard is that, whatever future organisation is established, there ought to be a representative of the Aboriginal people in this place. Whether that is in the Senate or in this House, as occurs in countries such as New Zealand and Canada, is a matter for government but, unless there is that accountability, the Australian people and taxpayers will feel that they do not have a stake in the future of their involvement in this process. As Patrick Dodson said the other night in his lecture in this place, it is important that we proceed with a shared involvement and a shared stake in the future—that is, not only the Aboriginal people but also the Australian people. It is with some regret that I support this bill, but I do so on the basis that we are looking at better outcomes in the future, adopting the principles that I referred to.

talk.start.para: —I listened with interest to the contribution by the member for Wentworth and I must commend him on his somewhat visionary approach to some aspects of Aboriginal and Indigenous representation. For a long time, I have also believed that we need to think seriously about moving to a situation where we examine the New Zealand example. From, I think, 1867 there was temporary Maori representation in their parliament, which turned into a permanent arrangement, and that has continued under proportional representation in recent years.

speech.para: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 2004 raises more questions than it answers about Aboriginal and Indigenous policy in this country. Few doubt that ATSIC as it stands is flawed but, as someone said earlier in the debate on this bill, we seem to be throwing the baby out with the bathwater here. It raises a whole series of questions. What exactly is the new structure and what is the process that will replace ATSIC in the longer term? What will happen with the regional representation once the regional councils are abolished in 2005? What exactly is happening with the assets of ATSIC—which assets are to be subsumed by the Commonwealth? Why has there been no consultation with those bodies and those people who were affected by the abolition of ATSIC?

There is no doubt that a framework which ensures and demands answerability and transparency in programs and funding is needed. The current structure of ATSIC certainly did not meet those criteria in all cases, but nor do many areas of public administration—and we do not have to go outside this very parliament to find them. The Productivity Commission's report last year showed that the root causes of Aboriginal disadvantage remain. Key indicators such as health, longevity, education, employment and the rate of incarceration remain at shameful levels. But that will not be solved by simply abolishing ATSIC and mainstreaming services.

The member for Wentworth again mentioned the positive sides of ATSIC, and indeed there are positive sides. They are so often overshadowed by the publicity about rorting or political plays within the administrative structures—exactly the sorts of things that we hear from organisations within the non-Indigenous community, but somehow they get focused out of all proportion and that denigrates the importance of the good work that is being done on the ground by ATSIC.

I think of the Binaal Billa Regional Council, which operates out of Wagga Wagga. One of the problems in dealing with the Indigenous communities of my electorate is that they do not feel that they see enough of the organisation to deal with their particular problems. I know, having met with the Binaal Billa people in this place on a reasonably regular basis, that some of their proposals and plans that they had in place—includ-ing the working parties that they are working on within the communities to try and establish workable community based organisations that are not based on, if you like, nepotism, mob or family influences but a more representative model—seem to be working very well. That is a grassroots model that has developed out of the needs of the local community and is dealt with at a regional and local level. That is but one example of the positive work that is happening. I despair, and I think the community despairs, of that sort of organisation being replicated or administered by a mainstreamed Aboriginal affairs process.
