debateinfo.title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (MEDICARE LEVY AND MEDICARE LEVY SURCHARGE) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Ross Cameron:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2004 simply indexes the Medicare levy low-income threshold. The threshold ensures that no Medicare levy is payable for low-income individuals and families where taxable income does not exceed a threshold. Above the threshold the Medicare levy shades in at a rate of 20c in the dollar.

speech.para: Every year since its introduction in 1986, the Medicare levy low-income threshold has been indexed to CPI. The amendments in this bill will increase the threshold for individuals to $15,529. The bill also indexes the Medicare levy surcharge low-income threshold. Where a family's combined income is above the Medicare levy surcharge threshold, each individual with a taxable income above the Medicare levy surcharge low-income threshold must pay the Medicare surcharge of one per cent—that is, of course, if the family does not have private health insurance. The Medicare levy surcharge low-income threshold has historically been set at the same level as the Medicare levy low-income threshold. The bill increases the Medicare levy surcharge low-income threshold in line with the increases in the Medicare levy low-income threshold.

It would be unforgivable for me not to point out that these amendments represent the only relief from tax in the budget for individuals earning less than $52,000. All they got was what every government has given them for almost 20 years: an indexation of the Medicare low-income threshold. What they deserve is a government not determined to destroy Australia's universal health care system by stealth. They deserve to know that their children can gain a university place based on merit and not be priced out of a degree by students with wealthy parents. What they deserve above all, and what only Labor will deliver, is relief from Australia's highest taxing and highest spending government.

When we are looking at indexation of tax thresholds, we should also look at the related issue of whether the government's tax cuts have returned bracket creep to most Australian taxpayers. Of course, they have not. By bracket creep I mean explicitly the cost of returning the tax scales to their inflation adjusted equivalent as at the introduction of the GST.

The Access Economics Budget Monitor shows that the value of bracket creep is $2.5 billion in 2004-05 whereas the tax cuts are worth only $1.925 billion. Bracket creep in 2005-06 is $3.9 billion, which, again, is more than the value of the tax cuts of $3.8 billion. In 2006-07 bracket creep will top $5.3 billion, which is almost $1 billion more than the value of the tax cuts of $4.25 billion. Access Economics has supplied me with an estimate of bracket creep for 2007-08 of $6.7 billion, which is almost $2 billion more than the value of the tax cuts in that year of $4.75 billion.

Over the forward estimates period, the tax cuts fall almost $4 billion short of what Australians have every justification to expect would be the minimum benchmark for the value of tax cuts in this budget—that is, giving back bracket creep over the period. To be absolutely precise, over the budget year and the three forward estimates years, the Access Economics estimate of bracket creep is $18.4 billion. The value of the tax cuts as set out in the measures table in the budget papers is $14.725 billion. That is almost $4 billion of bracket creep being used to maintain a Commonwealth budget surplus.

The same story can be repeated using other estimates of bracket creep that are routinely published around this country. I have done the same exercise with the estimates of bracket creep that have been provided to me by the Melbourne Institute. You get a very similar picture. If the Treasurer does not like the Access Economics estimates of bracket creep, he might like to look at the Melbourne Institute's estimates. They are, as I said, within a few hundred million dollars of the Access Economics estimates. If he does not like either the Access Economics or the Melbourne Institute estimates of bracket creep then I challenge him to publish the estimates of the Commonwealth Treasury. I know that he will not because, if he did, he would be admitting that his tax cuts are giving back only a part of what has been taken in bracket creep.

The tax cuts in this budget were less than the bare minimum expected by Australian voters. For four out of five taxpayers, last year's sandwich and milkshake tax cuts now look like a bit of a feast because four out of five Australian taxpayers this year are getting no tax cuts. The sandwich and milkshake tax cuts of last year fell short of giving back bracket creep since the GST was introduced. There is no meaningful measure of bracket creep before that because of the effect of the tax mix switch that accompanied the introduction of the GST. All of these tax cuts are less than the bare minimum that Australian taxpayers could reasonably have thought they had a right to expect.

This time around, 80 per cent get no return on bracket creep at all. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have been quick to remind them that they got the sandwich and milkshake tax cut last year. But, of course, that was not enough to hand back bracket creep. Those people who did not get a tax cut at all this year and who got an inadequate tax cut last year are two-time losers. The government has published tax scales for the following year. They are in the process of being legislated for by the parliament and they will pass. The government will give those same taxpayers on less than $52,000 no tax cut in 2005-06. So, in terms of the return of bracket creep, those taxpayers will be three-time losers.

In this bill we have the only measure in this budget which does anything to provide any tax relief for those taxpayers—and that is only to a small proportion of them, namely, those with incomes under $15,529—by indexing the Medicare low-income threshold. That is all those people are getting in this budget. I think they are going to be, and already are, very annoyed. The government is going to come to regret the way that it has treated them.

The Labor Party will be presenting an alternative tax policy before the election. People will have a full opportunity to examine it. It will be broader and fairer in the tax cuts and will be accompanied by policies which will at least give those people who are totally reliant on Medicare and bulk-billing a much greater opportunity to have free medical services. We are specifically targeting measures that will increase the proportion of services that are bulk-billed. We believe that our policy will lift bulk-billing rates back to 80 per cent of services. That will be a real relief for people on low incomes. With the exception of this single, small measure that we are passing in this legislation today, this government has given absolutely nothing by way of tax cuts for people on incomes of less than $52,000.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2004, which again demonstrates how this government is supporting individuals and families with low incomes in the area of health. The bill itself will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the Medicare levy low-income thresholds to ensure that low-income individuals and families are exempt from paying the Medicare levy. It means that the Medicare levy low-income threshold for individuals will increase from $15,062 to $15,529. For families, the threshold will increase from $25,417 to $26,205. For those pensioners below age pension age, it will increase from $17,164 to $18,181 to ensure that they do not pay the Medicare levy while they do not have an income tax liability. This is just one example of how this government is working with communities and supporting them in health, but it is a very important one. It reinforces the government's belief that all Australians should have access to high-quality health care while promoting choice in the health care system.

speech.para: Labor's scare campaign to save Medicare is a fraudulent farce. This government has strengthened Medicare. Earlier this year the government announced MedicarePlus, a $2.85 billion program to strengthen Medicare, now and for future generations. Some of the initiatives in the MedicarePlus package include an additional payment to GPs of $5 for every bulk-billed medical service provided to Commonwealth concession card holders and to children aged under 16 and $7.50 in regional and rural areas. There was the rollout of the HIC online technology to doctors surgeries, so that where patients are not bulk-billed they can have their Medicare claim lodged at the surgery and their rebates paid directly into their bank accounts. This removes the need to visit a Medicare office or an Easyclaim facility.

We have introduced a safety net to help people cope with the costs of out-of-hospital procedures, such as MRIs, CT scans, ultrasounds, blood tests, X-rays and radiation oncology. The safety net will pay 80 per cent of the out-of-pocket costs for Medicare services provided for families and individuals covered by a Commonwealth concession card or receiving family tax benefit A once their expenses reach $300 and $700 for other individuals and families. We have also introduced a new MBS system for the services of allied health professionals like psychologists, physiotherapists, podiatrists, dieticians and chiropractors—a multidisciplinary care plan for people with chronic and complex health conditions. This can involve at least two allied health professionals and includes dental treatment for patients with chronic or complex conditions. I am impressed by the fact that 1,500 more doctors and 1,600 more equivalent practice nurses will be introduced by 2007. There will be funding of up to $8,000 per GP who provides services to aged care residents who do not have a regular doctor, including after hours and in an emergency, and who participates in the in-home quality improvement. It is an outstanding package which looks to the future needs of our community and which bring improvements to our health system.

Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for Labor's Medicare plan and their hot spot teams, which doctors in my local area of Paterson have dismissed lock, stock and barrel. Dr Chris Boyle, Chairman of the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice, was quoted in the Port Stephens Examiner as saying:

quote.para: I was very interested to read what the ALP policy on the Medicare bulk billing team is. It does not involve new GPs. It simply involves moving GPs from private practice to public service—not one new GP ...

speech.para: Dr Arn Sprogis, who is the CEO of the Hunter Urban Division of General Practice, told radio 2HD:

quote.para: I think it's one of the most bizarre notions I've seen in the 12 or 13 years I've been in this game. I think the Labor Party's lost the plot completely to be quite honest ... it seems now if you're poor turn left and sit in the emergency department ready for your hot spot Medicare team and if you're working then turn right and go to your GP.

speech.para: Regardless of the ridiculous plans the ALP put forward, I have always believed that actions speak louder than words. You only have to look at the successes we have had in attracting doctors to Karuah, Medowie and Lemon Tree Passage to find a local example of that. Most recently, we were successful in obtaining a provider number for Dr Falah Sharrad to practice in Medowie. I have met with Dr Sharrad, his wife, Kate, and his family on a couple of occasions now, and they are absolutely delightful people who are committed to the care of their patients. The best news for the community of Medowie is that Dr Sharrad is bulk-billing in his new practice at the Medowie Medical Centre.

We were able to obtain an overseas training provider number for Dr Hazim Dhahir so that he could practice in Karuah. The good news for the people in Karuah is that Dr Dhahir is also bulk-billing. He took over from the much loved Dr Stan Wiekmann, who passed away in December 2001. Following his death, the community in Karuah rallied together and were able to get a successful outcome—what is now called the Karuah Medical Centre. I would like to thank both doctors for their commitment to the area and I hope they and their families enjoy living in this great part of Australia.

Aside from the MedicarePlus package and the changing of the Medicare levy threshold as contained in this bill, the government also announced a number of initiatives in the recent budget. Again, I remind people of the Labor Medicare scare campaign and how they opposed the safety net package in MedicarePlus. As of 29 May 2004, nearly 58,000 concessional family tax benefit A families and over 15,000 concessional individuals had incurred out-of-pocket costs of more than $300 for Medicare services provided outside of hospital. There were over 13,000 other families and over 6,000 other individuals who had incurred out-of-pocket costs of more than $700 for Medicare services provided outside hospital. This means that a total of nearly 22,000 individuals and nearly 72,000 families, totalling 232,000 individuals, have reached the safety net. Nearly $9,200,000 in safety net benefits has been paid. A total of 2,250,000 families are registered for the safety net. The only danger to Medicare, the private health insurance industry and private hospitals is the Labor Party. They are the party that voted to deny the safety net. They are the party that will abolish the 30 per cent private health rebate.

Like all communities, we have our champions in my electorate, and one of the great advocates for Diabetes Australia is Mr Ross Presgrave. I was delighted to be able to inform Ross of the government's plan to help those who find it hard to control diabetes with injections. The use of the new generation insulin infusion pumps allow these people to administer a steady flow of insulin through the day without injections. For anyone who needs to give themselves daily injections of insulin this can be a very difficult task, particularly for young kids. I have a number of young kids in my electorate, such as Aaron Moase and Bryce Chambers, who have to manage this problem on a daily basis. So I welcome this initiative to help those suffering from diabetes.

Another initiative affecting the Hunter region was the announcement of $5 million for the Hunter Medical Research Institute. This is Australia's only regionally based health and medical research institute and was established in 1998. It now employs over 350 researchers. This funding will assist the institute in constructing a clinical research centre on the campus of the John Hunter Hospital. The work that is coming out of the Hunter Medical Research Institute benefits not just the Hunter in terms of employment but also the whole of our society. The research that is coming out of this facility is quite remarkable. For example, researchers have discovered a placental clock that determines when a baby is born. Another example is the discovery of a particular compound found in green leafy vegetables which stops cancer cell growth. This amazing research, which is happening in our own backyards in the Hunter region, benefits everyone. The key areas of research include mental health, cancer, cardiovascular health research, mothers and babies, vaccines and immunity. The institute itself has warmly welcomed this funding and no doubt it will have enormous benefits when the central headquarters is finally constructed.

Another measure that was announced in the budget which will greatly assist my electorate is the increase in aged care numbers and funding. The government will lift the number of aged care places to be allocated in the next three years to 27,900, including 13,030 in 2004. The government will also provide a one-off payment of $513.3 million in 2003-04 to providers, or some $3,500 per bed in recognition of the forward plan for improved standards in aged care homes.

In my electorate of Paterson it means that a total of $2.77 million will be paid to these providers in this financial year for local aged care beds, as a part of the measures announced in this federal budget. These budget measures and the measures contained in this Taxation Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2002 demonstrate how this government is looking to the future of this country and providing support where it is needed. It also shows how Labor do not have a plan for local areas. They are more focused on making motherhood statements with no attention to actual detail or how they will implement their policies.

In fact, I had to laugh when I read a letter that my Labor opponent in Paterson has mailed out to the residents in Forster-Tuncurry in the last few days. She says in that letter that one of her top priorities is to ensure quality health care at our local hospital. It is quite obvious that this is a standard Labor letter, and I assume that all Labor candidates are sending it out. It does not actually address one of the key issues facing the residents in the Great Lakes region, and that is the fact that there is no public hospital in the Forster-Tuncurry area. We do have an outstanding hospital—it is a private hospital, the Cape Hawk hospital, and they provide outstanding services—but if people want to go to a public hospital they have to travel all the way to Taree. If the go to the private hospital at Cape Hawk, they will need private health insurance, remembering that the 30 per cent rebate is under threat from the Labor opposition.

I know that Labor's candidate has only just started hitting the ground in her campaign, but she certainly has not done her homework on local issues. How could you write a letter to residents about health and not talk about the most pressing local issue? It is a puzzle to me and it is also a puzzle to residents from Forster-Tuncurry who have called me and said how bewildered they are. Then again, perhaps she should have raised it with the area health community representative. That person, of course, is her former boss and the former federal member for Paterson, Mr Bob Horne. Mr Bob Horne is the area representative on the Mid North Coast Area Health Board. The only problem is that our local area health representative lives in Eumundi in the Maroochy Shire in Queensland. As expected, here we have his mate, the member for Hunter—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, a point of order on relevance: I draw your attention to the narrow scope of this bill and suggest to you that the member for Paterson is scoping rather widely. I ask you to bring him back to the terms of the bill.
(Hon. L.R.S. Price)—I suggest that the honourable member for Paterson try to link his remarks to the bill.

—These remarks are exactly linked to those on low incomes who pay a Medicare levy. The member for Hunter is scared of the fact that now the Labor Party in New South Wales have been exposed for paying $12,000 to a community representative for the Mid North Coast Area Health Board who resides in Queensland. New South Wales, the highest taxing state in Australia—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: even your best endeavours could surely not find a link between the matters being raised by the member for Paterson and those very narrow matters raised in this bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: without wanting to deprive the member for Paterson of his allocated time, the fact that the member for Hunter disagrees with the content of the member for Paterson's remarks does not make it any less germane to the contents of the bill.

—I will rule on the matter. The bill is a very narrow bill, but I have encouraged the honourable member for Paterson to link his remarks to the bill. I have not prevented him, as I can, from speaking further.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. This goes directly to the point: those on low incomes who have benefited from the increase in the tax-free threshold who need access to hospitals are rather concerned that there is no public hospital in Forster-Tuncurry.

speech.para: The fact that there is no public hospital in Forster-Tuncurry is perhaps because the people do not have a local area representative on the hospital board to push their case. It is a bit hard when you are living 500 miles north to understand and know the concerns today of those people. Here we see the member for Hunter protecting his former mate Bob Horne. (Quorum formed) It is obvious that the Labor Party do not want to hear how Bob Carr is paying off one of their Labor mates $12,000 a year to be a community representative of the Great Lakes region, living in Eumundi in Queensland. This is an attack on the taxpayers of New South Wales and the member for Hunter is trying to justify it by standing up for this fraud.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order again goes to relevance. It is quite clear that the member for Paterson did not get the opportunity to deliver all of his speech on the appropriation bills. He has attempted to rerun it here today. I have showed some patience, but his statements and the attack he is launching on a former member of this place have absolutely no relevance to the bill before the House.
—Order! I am happy to rule on the point of order on relevance. I have asked the honourable member for Paterson to link his remarks to the bill. He has done that.

—There is no greater link than taxpayers, benefits to low-income families and the fact that we have a fraud perpetrated on the people of New South Wales. Here is the member for Hunter jumping to his feet again, defending a fraudulent person who is ripping off the taxpayers of New South Wales. The people in my area will not accept it.
—Order! The member for Paterson will resume his seat or I will deal with him.
—What about the frivolous points of order?
—I warn the member for Paterson.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. As you know, these points of order are not frivolous. The member for Paterson is now defying your request that he return to the subject of the bill. I ask you to deal with him appropriately.
—I have ruled on a number of points of order. I invited the member for Paterson on a couple of occasions to link his remarks to the bill. He did so. I will not take any more points of order.

—Again the Labor Party are trying to gag the truth when it is put to this House. The Labor Party are trying to deny the taxpayers of New South Wales the representation they should be afforded. (Quorum formed) (Time expired)

—It is my pleasure to sum up the debate on the Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy and Medicare Levy Surcharge) Bill 2004, which has been very constructive from both sides—I suspect with the exception of the last 10 minutes or so. I understand the member for Paterson was simply trying to draw a contrast between the commitment of this Commonwealth government towards the low-income residents of Paterson and the apparent indifference of the New South Wales Labor government, which has apparently appointed a person who lives in Queensland to the board of the Mid North Coast Area Health Service.

speech.para: This bill contains a series of very practical—and, one might say, quite generous—measures, intending to ensure under our MedicarePlus package that the highest quality of health care is available to the largest number of Australians, particularly those on low incomes. The bill will increase the Medi-care levy low-income thresholds for individuals and families, in line with increases in the consumer price index. The low-income threshold in the Medicare levy surcharge provisions will be similarly increased. These changes will ensure that low-income individuals and families will continue to be exempt from paying the Medicare levy or surcharge.

From the 2003-04 income year the Medicare levy low-income threshold will increase to $15,529 for individuals, up from $15,062; and $26,205 for families, up from $25,417. The additional amount of threshold for each dependent child or student will also be increased to $2,406, up from $2,334. The bill also increases the Medicare levy low-income threshold for pensioners below age pension age, to ensure that where these pensioners do not have a tax liability they will also not have a Medicare levy liability. From 1 July 2003 the threshold will rise to $18,141, up from $17,164. This will ensure that pensioners below age pension age do not pay the Medicare levy while they do not have an income tax liability. I commend this bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (2004 MEASURES NO. 1) BILL 2004

cognateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (2004 MEASURES NO. 2) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Ross Cameron:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —In the Superannuation Budget Measures Bill 2004 debated in this place last week, the government introduced measures to extend the low-income co-contribution to individuals earning up to $58,000 per annum; increase the dollar-for-dollar government contribution to a government contribution of $1.50 for each $1 contributed by an individual up to $1,000; and to make the maximum contribution available to those earning up to $28,000, which is an increase of $500 on the previous amount of $27,500 per annum. In the debate last week, Labor raised its concerns about the targeting of the co-contribution, expressing the view that this co-contribution is most likely to be utilised by those who least need it: high-income-earning couples where one spouse is earning a low income. Since then, this concern has increased as Labor has become aware that there are unintended opportunities for tax avoidance inherent in the scheme. Labor also pointed out that most genuine low-income individuals earning $28,000—the highest income at which there is entitlement to the full government contribution—would be unlikely to be able to find the $1,000 after-tax contribution necessary to get the full $1,500 co-contribution.

speech.para: The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 addresses another aspect of the changes to the co-contribution: the change in the work test for eligibility for the government co-contribution. The bill makes two changes: one is to the work test, the other is to ensure that individuals receiving the co-contribution are not able to double-dip by obtaining a deduction for their personal contribution. The previous work test required an individual to already be receiving or entitled to employer superannuation guarantee contributions. This effectively excluded anyone earning less than $450 per month or under the age of 18 and working part time. Admittedly, this definition limited those entitled to participate in the co-contribution scheme, including the low-income self-employed. Unfortunately, although the new definition will mean that more individuals are entitled to participate, Labor is concerned that this measure will not effectively target those who could best benefit from this scheme.

The new eligibility criteria require that only 10 per cent of a person's income need be earned from employment in any one year. This will allow many earning less than $450 to participate who would otherwise not be entitled to the co-contribution. Unfortunately, reality tells us that those people whose only income is less than $450 are most unlikely to have any money to contribute to superannuation. Commonsense tells us that those who will benefit from this change in definition are most likely to be those who are receiving the most substantial part of their income in the form of passive income from family trusts, property and other substantial assets—not genuine low-income earners, in the ordinary sense of the concept. Who is subsidising this? The average working Australian who in most cases does not have the financial capacity to participate in the co-contribution scheme. As Labor pointed out in the debate on the Superannuation Budget Measures Bill 2004, the benefit will be used to subsidise low-income spouses in high-income households.

The second amendment is an integrity amendment to ensure that the co-contribution is not exploited by individuals obtaining a tax deduction for the co-contribution amount. Labor clearly supports such a measure because without this measure the co-contribution scheme could be used for tax minimisation purposes by those same high-income households that will be able to exploit the system under the proposed change to the work test for co-contributions. Labor believes this is not enough and that the eligibility test for the co-contribution should also take into account total household income, to ensure that the benefit of the co-contribution, which will be paid for by ordinary working Australians, does not go to those who do not need it.

While Labor supports these bills, it will be referring them to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for further investigation. Labor will be moving a second reading amendment condemning the government for not adopting Labor's approach of providing a superannuation tax cut to all Australians and for continuing to pursue its failed superannuation co-contribution scheme.

The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004 contains five measures largely designed to remove anomalies in the current superannuation legislation regime, some of which have been in need of change for some time. Labor supports these amendments, although it has some reservations about some aspects of the fourth measure standardising the superannuation guarantee contribution base. As a second reading amendment to that bill, I will move:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “while not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) expresses its support for the introduction of a simplified superannuation guarantee base definition from 1 July 2005, instead of 1 July 2010, with employers being given the right to argue before a Federal or State industrial commission for the simplified superannuation guarantee base definition to be phased in because of their incapacity to pay; and
(2) opposes any use of this legislation to remove any superannuation guarantee base that is more generous than the Ordinary Time Earnings Base”.

Of the five measures in this bill, the first measure will exempt superannuation funds from having to provide actuarial certificates for account based income streams. The requirement to provide actuarial certificates for income streams was introduced in a context where the most common form of stream was the defined benefit pension, which guaranteed a particular level of income. These funds needed to have sufficient assets to fund their liabilities; but there was also the risk that some funds would understate the assets that they needed to fund their liabilities in order to access the tax concessions associated with the assets backing these liabilities.

In the time since the introduction of this requirement, different types of pension income streams have emerged, such as allocated pensions, which do not guarantee a fixed income stream, and consequently the fund does not need to make provision for future funding of the income stream. The amendment to exclude these account based income streams from the requirements to provide actuarial certificates will be a simplification of the system and reduce the cost of the funds which provide account based income streams.

The second measure is an anti-avoidance measure which will ensure that those under 18 are not able to obtain a deduction for any contribution made—either the co-contribu-tion or any other contribution—that might otherwise have attracted a tax deduction, unless they meet a further work test, that of having to derive eligible employment or business income. This effectively prevents persons under the age of 18 from being used to obtain tax deductions for superannuation contributions when they are neither employed by nor actively involved in a business. Nonetheless, Labor note with some interest that the regulations setting out the new work test to which this anti-avoidance measure is to apply have not yet, according to our information, been drafted.

The third measure amends the maximum time allowed for a retirement savings account to act on an application to transfer an account from one year to a maximum of 90 days, bringing retirement savings accounts in line with other superannuation providers.

The fifth measure is designed to clarify that the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's power to cancel the licence of a registrable superannuation entity in writing is subject to the minister's relevant consent except where the registrable superannuation entity itself has requested the cancellation or the registrable superannuation entity has been disqualified. Although most employers are required to use ordinary time earnings as the superannuation guarantee earnings base, there are a number of exemptions set out in the superannuation guarantee legislation and there are some industrial awards where a different superannuation guarantee earnings base is permitted. In most cases this results in a lower SG earnings base and of course lower superannuation guarantee contributions. This is a particular problem for some industries where shift penalties make up a major part of the remuneration but are excluded from the superannuation guarantee base by either legislation or the industrial award.

We are aware that there are significant numbers of employees affected by this. Some examples of these are: coal industry workers, who have their superannuation guarantee calculated on their award rate of pay and not their agreement rate; workers under Queensland state awards, two-thirds of whom have weekend penalties excluded from the definition of ordinary time earnings; casual workers under the Queensland state clerical employees award do not receive superannuation guarantee contributions on hours worked outside 6.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. Monday to Friday and 6.30 a.m. to 12.30 p.m. on Saturday, even when they are employed in environments such as 24-hour call centres; Queensland public sector workers who do not receive the superannuation guarantee on shift penalties—this is a particular concern for nursing staff; and a large number of metalliferous miners in Tasmania and Western Australia. These are just a few of the workers missing out on full superannuation guarantee contributions.

Although Labor strongly supports the proposed standardisation of the superannuation guarantee base it has some reservations about the government's proposal and its motivation for the change. Firstly, Labor questions the need to wait until 2010 to implement the change. The employers involved have effectively had a substantial advantage, in comparison to other industries, for up to 12 years—in fact one could argue that it is quite unfair to give particular employers such a financial advantage. But the delay in bringing in these measures is even more unfair on the employees of these organisations as they prepare for retirement. Further delaying this change can only add to current community pessimism about the superannuation system. The message the government is sending is: `This is an unfair situation, but you are going to have to wait five years for it to be rectified.' That is a ridiculous position to take.

Labor believes that the date of implementation of the measure to standardise the superannuation guarantee base should be moved to 1 July 2005. A 12-year advantage is enough. There is no valid reason for the situation to continue, especially to the detriment of Australian workers dependent upon the superannuation guarantee contribution for their retirement savings. Labor recognises that there may be some employers who may have difficulty changing over immediately. With this in mind it proposes that employers who believe that they do not have the financial capacity to introduce the standardised superannuation guarantee base immediately be able to apply to the relevant industrial commission to have the standardised superannuation guarantee base phased in over time.

Labor also believe that no existing employee should be disadvantaged by the change to the standardised base. This may occur where an industrial award provides for a higher SG base than the standardised ordinary time earnings base. We do not anticipate that there will be many situations where this will happen, but the rights of these workers should be protected. In view of Labor's concerns with these bills, I move:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) its failure to adopt the alternative approach of offering a superannuation tax cut to all contributors, as proposed by Labor; and

(2) operating a system that fails to recognise the inability of low-income Australians to take advantage of measures to expand their superannuation while permitting spouses with wealthy partners to exploit the benefit”.

talk.start.para: (Hon. L.R.S. Price)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—There are two superannuation bills before the House today, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 and the cognate bill, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. The former bill is attracting the most attention and is the one that the previous speaker, the member for Kingston, spent most time on. It deals with amendments to the Superannuation (Government Co-contri-bution for Low Income Earners) Act. The bill is an innovation and it adds to previous innovations introduced by this government to encourage people into superannuation. The government believes that, since we have a declining contribution to pensions by an ageing population, people need to be preparing for their retirement. The previous government started on this with its superannuation guarantee proposals for all workers, but this government has been more innovative and more in tune with the needs of the community.

speech.para: Firstly, there was the capacity for parents to superannuate children from their day of birth. That process has attracted a fair bit of attention. It is a great savings mechanism and it gives young people the opportunity to set aside funds in a different format to savings in a bank account. It preserves funds for later in life, with the choice, if choice ever becomes a real feature of Australian superannuation, of adding during their working life to that superannuation investment taken out by their parents. It is encouragement that we are talking of here and encouragement that we are dealing with in these amendments to superannuation measures.

The proposals before the House extend the superannuation contribution by the government for low-income earners to include employees who earn below the $450 per month superannuation guarantee threshold. They also ensure that people who are now eligible for the co-contribution cannot double-dip. What is this about? The government is proposing that, for every $1 a person puts into a super fund, the government will put in $1.50. That is a pretty good deal. I have heard many commentators on talkback radio saying to people not of large means, `How can you walk away from a gift of $1.50 for every $1 that you put in?' That is the sort of investment that people should be making. They should be investing in super funds and taking advantage of this government incentive.

Of course there are limitations to it, both at the level of income and the amount that a person can put in. For a maximum of $1,000 the government will put in $1,500. That $1,500 goes to any person wanting to establish a super fund. As I said, when they change employment and their super fund continues to grow they will, we hope, be able to move their super fund to a place of their choice which offers the best returns and the best yield. In that way they will realise benefits at the end of their working life and have the certainty that they will continue to receive income.

The Australian Labor Party does not want choice and it has not thought about whether or not people ought to receive an incentive of this type. We hear today instead fringe type complaints about what the government is doing. The opposition would be better off spending its time focusing on real issues and letting the bills go through the parliament. Then people will be able to choose their super fund and have every successive employer contribute to that fund and they will not have a proliferation of small sources of revenue scattered in a series of superannuation funds as they change from job to job; it will all be consolidated and earning real benefits for them.

It is interesting to look at some of the tables relating to the manner of investment of super funds and the size of super funds over the last nine years. For instance, in 1994-95 the amount in corporate investment was $48 billion, and over the last nine years it has only grown to $55 billion. The public sector has more than doubled from $51 billion to $115 billion. The big growth has been in the small funds, however—the mums and dads who have sought to provide for their own superannuation. These funds are generally those of fewer than five members and they include small APRA funds, single-member approved deposit funds and self-managed superannuation funds, which are popular with small business. The growth in those small funds has been from $20 billion in 1994-95 to $127 billion currently. This indicates a willingness and an enthusiasm among small businesses to prepare for retirement. They are establishing their own super schemes, investing the funds to earn the best benefits they can and thereby ensuring a future as well as growth in the value of their businesses.

In December 2003 the superannuation industry indicated that 88 per cent of all workers have superannuation coverage. It indicated also that the employer contributions totalled $35 billion and that member contributions totalled $19 billion, making a total of $54 billion in the year ended December 2003. That demonstrates to me that employers are making a major contribution to the wellbeing of their employees and that members are also contributing, and that is the way it should be: employers contributing roughly twice as much as employees.

The amount of funds directly invested is $210 billion, the amount placed with investment managers is $196 billion and the amount invested in life office statutory funds is $160 billion. So there is almost an equal spread between direct investment, investment with investment managers and life office statutory requirement. That background indicates a growing interest in superannuation, and it behoves the government to be careful about changes to super and to make sure that the incentive processes stay and that the long-term plans of people who have invested in superannuation are protected so that their ultimate benefit plans are not recklessly interfered with. That applies to self-managed funds as indeed it applies to the proposals we are looking at today, because nobody wants to find that the certainty they thought was in their plan is suddenly removed because of government initiatives.

Within the proposed amendments to the superannuation laws which extend the eligibility for government co-contribution, I highlight announcements made on 14 March this year by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, the Hon. Senator Helen Coonan. The comparison between the proposed legislation and the current law can be summarised in this way: the current laws, until these bills are enacted, have among their eligibility criteria that, to receive a government co-contribution, an individual must be in receipt of or entitled to employer superannuation support and not eligible to claim a taxation deduction for their personal superannuation contribution. For example, employees earning less than $450 per month and employees under the age of 18 and employed on a part-time basis are currently generally unable to qualify for the government co-contribution.

In the new legislation, the eligibility criteria will be extended: an individual will no longer require receipt of or entitlement to an employer super contribution and an employee contributing at least 10 per cent of their income will qualify for the government co-contribution for the coming year and subsequent years. Previously, employees not in receipt of employer superannuation support were able to claim a deduction for personal superannuation contributions. In the new legislation, a person will not be able to claim a deduction in the coming year and subsequent years for personal superannuation contributions if they now qualify for a government co-contribution. That is a simple process: if you qualify for a government kick-along with your super, you cannot claim your own contribution as a tax deduction. I think that is a very sensible thing: the government is providing $1.50 for every dollar you put in, and I think that on balance that contribution should come out of your salary.

The transitional rules are these: a person is eligible for co-contribution made on or after 1 July 2003 if the individual has a total assessable income and reportable fringe benefits of less than $40,000—the previous member was talking about overtime and all the rest of it, but it is assessable income and reportable fringe benefits all wrapped up into one amount of less than $40,000—has at least 10 per cent of their total income attributable to eligible employment, and is under the age of 71. That is another innovation introduced by this government: the age at which you can contribute to superannuation has been extended. A number of people in my electorate have come to me and said, `We want to work beyond the age of 60 or 65 but superannuation is not available to us; we want to continue to contribute to it.' That is something that the government has observed and it has extended eligibility to the age of 71; previously it was 65. To be eligible, a person must be under the age of 71 in the income year that the personal superannuation contribution is made and must not be a temporary resident of Australia. That is basically the way it works. I think that is reasonable; I do not think temporary residents should have access to this offer of support in superannuation.

There have also been administrative changes to these laws. It is quite interesting that the administrative amendments specify that the interest rate to be applied for late government co-contribution will be prescribed in the legislation. So if the government is late in paying, the money earns interest. However, a person must make their contribution within 28 days of the co-contribu-tion payment being made—that is, a person's money must be in the fund no later than 28 days after the government dough hits the deck. So the government must pay within a set period. If it does not pay on time, interest is earned by the late payment, and the person must make their contribution within 28 days of the government money being in the fund. There is an imposition where the superannuation provided does not repay the government co-contribution amount within a particular time, and the requirements placed on the minister are also outlined.

So the interest rate and the time frame within which the provider must credit a government co-contribution are part of the new law. I think this is an excellent process, and the government is to be commended. I encourage people, both young and old, to take advantage of what amounts to a gift of a $1.50 for every dollar contributed towards a super fund. It is a great innovation—something that will encourage people to save for their retirement and it is worthy of our society.

The other bill before the House is entitled the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. This bill improves the practical operations of the retirement income system and its interaction with other areas of the law. I see this measure as something that assists in making retirement savings accounts—SRAs—more readily available and adjusts the way in which they are applied. There are changes in the law in regard to actuary certificates, which are part of the process for accounts based on income streams. Another proposal relates to funds paying pensions of the prescribed type—for the IT regulations, and no other type of pension, an actuary certificate is not required. Actuarial requirements and the under-18 superannuation contribution deduction work test are also part of the change in the law. Persons under the age of 65 will not have to satisfy a work test in order to make personal superannuation contributions. In addition to being eligible, in order to claim a tax deduction for these contributions, a person under the age of 18 will now have to derive eligible employment or business income in the income year in which the taxation deduction is claimed. That is a sensible tightening up of the system so that it is not abused.

In referring to the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority report for this year, it is disturbing to notice that there have been several enforcement actions taken by APRA within the superannuation field. Of the 388 enforcement actions that have been taken by APRA, 261 related to superannuation. Auth-orised deposit-taking institutions—super-annuation funds, general insurance companies, life insurers and friendly societies—are included in the supervision by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, and the amount of attention given to superannuation is of concern to me. I notice that within the last 12 months, the number of enforcement actions that have been taken have risen from 107 to 261. This indicates that APRA has been concerned about the way in which funds and personnel have been looking after the retirement benefits of a lot of people. The low returns, APRA says, are also of concern to many. It report states:

quote.para: The low returns in most superannuation funds have spurred interest by some trustees in investing superannuation monies in non-traditional assets, including hedge funds and instalment warrants.

speech.para: There are many people who are unhappy with the returns that superannuation funds are offering. The level of activity required by APRA for enforcement is also a matter of concern. The number of directions that have been given to super funds, the number of prosecutions for delayed contributions and the number of show-cause letters have increased significantly. A stringent application of the law regarding super funds is essential. The HIH fiasco is a wake-up call to everybody. However, I would like to remind the House that it was the failure of a large corporation. It was not one of the small corporations that failed; it was a large one. So I encourage APRA to apply their energy to making sure that large funds with lots of resources and personnel that are not showing a very good return are the ones that receive attention to make sure that there is not another instance like the HIH failure. In fact, the encouragement given by the government should be recognised. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last week the Superannuation Budget Measures Bill 2004 was debated in this House. This bill contained measures that included the low-income co-contribution to individuals earning up to $58,000 per annum and an increase in the government's former dollar-for-dollar contribution to a government contribution of $1.50 for each dollar contributed by an individual up to a maximum of $1,000. Like so many of this government's financial packages—and there are plenty of examples to demonstrate this—one wonders if this co-contribution scheme can correctly be labelled `low-income earners scheme', if it ever was a low-income co-contribution scheme in the first place.

speech.para: Don Watson in his thought provoking book Death Sentence—and I recommend it to all members—which is on the salvation of public language, highlights government doublespeak in giving names to pieces of legislation that often have the opposite effect if not intention. In fact the Howard government could fill a whole chapter of Watson's book with its doublespeak bill titles, let alone the AttorneyGeneral providing a personal chapter on `confuse-speak'. I note that, when the AttorneyGeneral utters his normal introductory phrases `the point of the matter is' or `the fact of the matter is', the listener knows it is Ruddock code for `There will be no facts that really matter'—and, if there are, we won't get to know about them anyway. However, I digress.

As I was saying—and putting aside the difficulty faced by the worker earning $28,000 or less per annum to find a spare after-tax $1,000 to make the voluntary contribution—an individual on $58,000 per annum can hardly be considered `low-income'. In researching ABS data related to my electorate of the north-west coast of Tasmania and King Island, I noted that in the 2001 census 62,595 individuals in the labour force received income under $52,000 per annum and 3,673 earned over that amount. Out of interest, the number that did not state their income was 4,687. Clearly the great majority of working people in my electorate earn incomes of well below $52,000 per annum. So, compared with these people, an individual earning $58,000 is much better off financially.

Labor raised its concerns about the targeting of the co-contribution in debate last week on the Superannuation Budget Measures Bill 2004. It expressed the view that this co-contribution is most likely to be utilised by those who least need it—that is, high-income households where one spouse is earning a low income—and not, I suggest, by genuine low-income households or individuals who struggle to find the money to get through the week let alone put aside anything: put simply, the majority of working people and families in my electorate. What is more, Labor's concern about the co-contribution has increased because it is becoming apparent that there are loopholes that can be exploited by higher income earners that give them access to the co-contribution scheme. I would like to remind the government of those reservations before I address the amendments proposed in this bill.

Noting that the measures to extend the co-contribution are tied to the government's proposed surcharge, I would point out that it is obviously the astute high-income household—with the low-income spouse able to access the contribution and the high-income spouse in that same household able to get a substantial surcharge tax reduction—that will benefit from the government's superannuation measures. So what does this mean? It means that the high-income household gets the best of both worlds while in electorates such as Braddon, Bass and Lyons in particular in Tasmania low-income families struggling to make ends meet get nothing. These families and individuals do not pay the surcharge, so there is no benefit from that measure. These same battling families and individuals are unlikely to be able to find the spare $1,000 after-tax cash to contribute to the co-contribution scheme. And certainly these people are unlikely to be in a position to exploit loopholes in the co-contribution scheme.

In reality, the great majority of working people in Braddon would be far better off with Labor's proposed contributions tax reduction: a reduction from 15 per cent to 13 per cent, which would benefit all members of superannuation funds and assist all to increase their retirement savings. It would not favour those on higher incomes, as proposed by the government's scheme and reinforced in its income tax cuts outlined in the 2004 budget.

Let me now go to the two bills under discussion today: the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. The first bill being considered, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004, contains further measures in relation to the co-contribution—namely, a change in the work test for eligibility for the government co-contribution. This bill introduces a new work test which is accompanied by integrity measures to ensure that individuals receiving the co-contribution are not able to double dip through obtaining a deduction for their personal contribution. Up until now, eligibility to participate in the co-contribution scheme was dependent upon an individual receiving or being entitled to employer superannuation guarantee contributions. This meant that anyone earning less than $450 per month or aged less than 18 years and working part-time was excluded. This test then effectively excluded many casual workers and low-income self-employed persons, many of whom live in my electorate. The new definition will mean that a handful more individuals are entitled to participate.

But Labor believes that the change will not be any more efficient in targeting those who would best benefit from this scheme than the previous definition. In fact, we contend that it will allow more of those who have no real need for government assistance with their retirement savings more opportunities to participate in the co-contribution scheme. Is this the intention of the government?

The new work test means that an individual will only need to show that 10 per cent of their earnings in any single year come from employment. The change does mean that many people earning less than $450 per month—that is, $5,400 per year—who previously would not have been entitled to the co-contribution can now participate. The government has stated that its justification for this significant change to the definition is to allow a greater number of low-income individuals—this number is unspecified, I would add—to access the co-contribution scheme. But I suggest it only needs a modicum of commonsense, which even the government must have, to realise that an individual earning less than $450 per month is most unlikely to have any money to contribute to superannuation. The people who will most likely receive the benefit from the change in eligibility criteria will be individuals who are receiving the most substantial part of their income in the form of passive income—for instance, from a family trust, property and other substantial assets—not genuine low-income earners who are struggling to make ends meet. The reality is that the beneficiaries of the scheme will be low-income spouses and children of higher income earning parents, and I believe this will be borne out later this year, when the extent of the takeup of the co-contribution for the first year of its operation, 200304, is published as required under the act.

As my colleague and fellow Forthite from Tasmania, Senator Nick Sherry, has pointed out in his analysis of this bill, it is interesting to note that the amendment provides for payment for the 200304 financial year despite the fact that the new measure was announced on 14 March 2004 and has not yet become law. Consequently, the claimed cost of $45 million for 200405 is highly questionable. Instead, it will be the tax paying struggler—the person who cannot take advantage of loopholes and who will not benefit from the cut in the superannuation surcharge tax proposed by this government—who will pay for this measure. The average working Australian is once again subsidising the more wealthy, subsidising the lifestyles of low-income spouses in high-income households. At least the government is giving a slight nod to integrity in relation to the change in the work test—that is, they are doing something to prevent double-dipping.

The second measure in this bill operates to prevent an individual from obtaining a deduction for any amount contributed in order to access the government co-contribution. Labor has no issue in supporting a measure that will prevent those in the community who are prepared to go to any lengths to minimise tax at the expense of the average worker—and one suspects that those will be the same high-income households that will be able to benefit from the poor targeting of the co-contribution scheme resulting in part from the change in the eligibility criteria which I just mentioned. But this is not sufficient to give these new measures real integrity. In order for the co-contribution to benefit those who most need it, it must use as an eligibility criteria total household income. This will ensure that the benefit of the co-contribution paid for by the ordinary working Australian goes to those who need it.

The second bill, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004—wow!—includes four amendments to remove some irregularities in the existing superannuation system and an anti-avoidance measure related to the change in the work tests for eligibility for the co-contribution scheme and superannuation guarantee contributions. The four changes to remove irregularities are well overdue and are acceptable to Labor, except that Labor believes that one of the measures, measure No. 4, which simplifies the superannuation guarantee base, does not go far enough. That argument has been eloquently outlined by the shadow minister for revenue and assistant shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kingston. I will briefly deal with the three amendments to remove irregularities and the integrity amendment before moving on to Labor's concerns relating to the superannuation guarantee base.

Measure 1 will remove the requirement for a superannuation fund to provide actuarial certificates for account based income streams. The requirement of actuarial certificates was a product of a pension environment, where the most common form of income stream was the defined benefit pension and an income stream which guaranteed a set result. As there was an opportunity for funds providing these pensions to exploit the tax exemptions available, actuarial certificates were required. Indeed, as the member for Kingston pointed out earlier, as the superannuation system has expanded, so have the different types of pension income streams available—for example, allocated pensions. These are income streams based on accounts which do not provide a guaranteed return and do not offer the same opportunities for tax avoidance. As a consequence, actuarial certificates are not required for these products. Further, this amendment, in removing this requirement for account based income streams, will result in less administration and lower costs for the funds administering account based income streams.

Measure 2, as mentioned earlier, creates a new superannuation contribution work test for individuals under 18. This is an anti-avoidance measure which will ensure that those under 18 are not able to obtain a deduction for any contribution made in relation to the co-contribution or any other contribution that might otherwise have attracted a tax deduction unless they meet a further work test. That work test requires that they must have derived income from eligible employment or business income, effectively preventing persons under 18 years of age from being used to obtain tax deductions for superannuation contributions when they are neither employed nor actively involved in a business.

Measure 3 and measure 5 are both technical changes that Labor supports. Measure 3 amends the maximum time allowed for retirement savings accounts to act on an application to transfer an account. The existing maximum time of one year will change to a maximum of 90 days, and this brings the RSAs into the same time frame as superannuation funds. Measure 5 is a clarification measure designed to ensure that APRA's power to cancel the licence of a registratable superannuation entity in writing is subject to the minister's relevant consent, except where the RSE itself has requested the cancellation or the RSE has been disqualified.

I would now like to spend some time speaking on measure 4—a measure to simplify the superannuation guarantee earnings base. Although most employers are required to use ordinary time earnings as the superannuation guarantee earnings base, there are some exclusions in the superannuation guarantee—SG—legislation, and there are some industrial awards where a different SG earnings base is permitted. In most cases, this results in a lower earnings base than that provided by ordinary time earnings. A lower superannuation guarantee earnings base means lower SG contributions and, ultimately, lower retirement incomes. I do not need to remind the House of the difficulties that would accompany this.

More often than not it is penalties that are excluded from the calculation of ordinary time earnings which cause particular problems for industries such as mining and nursing, where shift penalties make up a substantial part of these workers' incomes. These are significant industries in my electorate and involve many workers, Mr Deputy Speaker Price—which I know you are well aware of because you have visited Braddon many times. In some cases, weekend penalties are excluded from ordinary time earnings. In other instances, casework outside particular hours is excluded, which creates a serious problem for workers in industries that operate on a 24-hour basis, such as call centre workers—again, affecting a significant employer in my electorate with large call centres in Burnie and Devonport.

Labor strongly supports moving to the standardised SG earnings base of ordinary time earnings but it is uneasy about the motivation behind the government's proposal. Why does the government need to wait—as the member for Kingston questioned earlier—until 2010 to implement this change? Surely the employers presently avoiding the standard definition of ordinary time earnings have received a substantial benefit—a benefit not afforded most other employers—for the last 12 years. Is it fair to give them a further five years of advantage? I think not. As I have mentioned before, there are many hundreds of employees in my electorate who will be disadvantaged by this delay. Is the delaying of this measure not grossly unfair on these employees, expecting them to accept inferior superannuation guarantee contributions for another five years? I think Jack Hill the blind miner would have to say yes to that one. No wonder many Australians are cynical, let alone confused, about superannuation when the government permits this sort of inequity to continue.

Labor believes that the date of the implementation of the measure to standardise the superannuation guarantee earnings base should be moved to 1 July 2005, as outlined in the amendments set out by the shadow minister at the table. Surely, a 12-year advantage is enough. There is no valid reason for this situation to continue, especially to the detriment of Australian workers dependent on the superannuation guarantee contribution for their retirement savings. Labor recognises that there may be some employers who find it financially difficult to make the change, but it is prepared to support a mechanism that would allow employers who believe that they do not have the financial capacity to make an immediate changeover to the standardised superannuation guarantee earnings base to apply to the relevant industrial commission to have the standardised superannuation guarantee earnings base phased in over time. That is only fair and sensible.

In addition, in those very few situations where an industrial award provides a higher superannuation guarantee earnings base than the standardised ordinary time earnings, Labor strongly holds the view that those employees whose superannuation guarantee is calculated on the higher SG earnings base should not be disadvantaged, and that the law should allow an exception for any SG earnings base which exceeds ordinary time earnings. In summary, Labor supports the essential elements of this bill but it would like to examine it in a Senate inquiry to clarify some detail relating, particularly, to the new work test for eligibility for the co-contribution, and the measures to standardise the SG earnings base. I support the amendments put by the shadow minister for revenue and assistant shadow Treasurer as outlined earlier today.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise in support of the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. In addressing these bills, I want to put the whole question of superannuation and retirement incomes into the broader perspective. I believe that these bills take important steps forward. They take forward the measures outlined by the Treasurer in the 2004 budget to assist with low-income earners in co-contribution, and with other earners in a reduction of the surcharge rates on the superannuation contribution. However, it is critical to understand where superannuation fits in the broader challenge that Australia faces.

speech.para: Like all western societies, Australia has an ageing population. Other societies within Europe are ageing at a faster rate than Australia. Their natural replenishment is lower and the result is that those societies are facing a significant pensions crisis over the coming decades. Already, we know that in France and Germany there are critical problems that have actually led to significant social divisions. That is the consequence of mismanagement of planning for the long-term future of the country. The challenge which was recognised for Australia—and I pay respect to the opposition for this when they were in government—was to plan for Australia on a generational basis. That task is ongoing. We are always planning for the present and for the next generation. In that context, what we need to recognise is a very simple fact: as Australia ages, the number of people who will be working as a proportion of our population will decline. So, proportionately, fewer people will be supporting more people.

In that context, it becomes absolutely imperative that each of us of working age today prepares for our retirement and our future so that the next generation does not have to support us and we are able to support ourselves. There is a very simple principle behind this—that is, the notion of intergenerational equity. If this generation does not provide for itself, it will effectively be expecting another generation to provide for it. Taken to its extreme, if we are selfish, if we do not prepare and make our own contributions now at the societal level and at the individual level, we will be engaged in an act of intergenerational theft. Australia went through an act of intergenerational theft during the early 1990s. What we saw was one generation stealing from another.

Let me remind the House of the budget impact of one generation stealing from another. In 1991-92, the budget deficit was $11½ billion; in 1992-93, it was $17 billion; in 1993-94, it was $17.1 billion; in 1994-95, it was $13.1 billion; and in 1995-96, it was $10 billion. In those last five budgets of the previous government, one generation stole $68 billion from the next. The result was that a succeeding generation had to pay that back, and that is what we have been doing. Over the last five budgets, by comparison, we see that in 2000-01, this generation paid back $5.9 billion of the debt which was incurred by the previous Labor administration. In 2001-02, there was a deficit of $980 million; in 2002-03, there was a surplus of $7.4 billion; in 2003-04, there was an estimated surplus of $4.6 billion; and, in the current financial year, there is an estimated surplus of $2.4 billion. In essence, it is the difference between $68 billion of debt which a future generation has to pay and $19.5 billion of debt which this generation has repaid.

In that context, these superannuation reforms have to be seen, understood and included, because they are about preparing the current generation for the future, to make sure that we are not engaged in a similar act of intergenerational theft. This means that we are preparing so that, as a country as a whole, we can pay for and meet the requirements of our superannuants, retirees and pensioners and also pay for all the other social, economic and infrastructure requirements of our country over the next generation. So that is why these reforms are important at the national level. At the individual level, they are about ensuring that each Australian has the chance to develop a retirement income which will allow them and their families to move forward into retirement with security and to live a good, rich, full and whole life. That is what superannuation is about. In that context, this bill is part of a package which does two things. The first change of the 2004 budget is that it introduces, and extends the number of, people who will be eligible for the superannuation co-contribution. In particular, it does this by targeting low-income earners. That is a critical step forward.

I would like to explain to the House what that means. It will do three things. Firstly, it will increase the contribution made by the government from a maximum of $1,000, for a $1,000 superannuation contribution from a low-income earner, to $1,500. So the ratio changes: if an individual puts in $1,000, they will now get $1,500 in a matching contribution from the Commonwealth government. It ratchets up the amount of money that they will get. So for every dollar that they put in, $2.50 all up will be placed in their superannuation account. That is a very important increase, because money put in by people in the early stages of their working lives has a massive compounding effect over a 40-year working life. It does two things: it helps to provide the base, the nest egg and it builds the culture of contributing to superannuation. It gives people a stake in their own future. It gives them a sense that they can have a worthwhile superannuation base for the future.

The second thing that this bill does in relation to the superannuation co-contribution is that it increases the maximum income that somebody can receive before losing the matching contribution. That increase goes from $25,000 to $30,000. So at any point, somebody earning up to $30,000, will be able to contribute up to $1,000 a year and receive $1,500 back from the government. That is an important step forward because it increases the amount of money that they will have in their own nest egg, and it increases the number of people who will benefit from that.

Thirdly, what this budget also does in relation to the superannuation co-contribution is that it increases the upper threshold of earnings to qualify from $40,000 to $60,000. So each of those three changes is fundamentally important. They extend the number of people who obtain the superannuation co-contribution, they extend the amount of money which people will be able to receive for the superannuation co-contribution, and they extend the limits and the threshold at the lower end and at the higher end so that the maximum number of people will benefit from the co-contribution.

The second big change that the budget package brings is in relation to the threshold. It lowers the threshold to 12½ per cent for the maximum surcharge rate in 2004-05. It lowers the surcharge rate again in 2005-06 to 10 per cent, and it lowers the surcharge rate again in other measures which will be brought forward to 7½ per cent in 2006-07. These are important steps forward. In summary, the superannuation laws amendments, which are set out in these bills and which will also be accompanied by other measures, are very simple. They recognise that Australia has an ageing population. They recognise that what occurred between 1991 and 1996 was an act of intergenerational theft, where one generation effectively stole from another, and we have had to pay that back. That is what intergenerational theft is about, and these measures ultimately are designed to take care of the next generation, and I commend them to the House.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. Has the member for Flinders concluded his remarks?
—Yes.

—I inform the House that the Prime Minister will be absent from question time today and for the remainder of the week. He is visiting, as I am sure members are aware, the United States, the United Kingdom and France. I will answer questions on his behalf.

—My question is to the Acting Prime Minister. Is the Acting Prime Minister aware of concerns expressed at my community forum at Caboolture in Queensland that the government's failed policies in Iraq have added to instability in the Middle East and the problem of record high oil prices? What action will the government take—
—Order!
—This is what people are saying.
—As is self-evident, in common with all other members of the chamber, the Leader of the Opposition has a right to be heard.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: under standing order 144, I simply observe that the reference to `the government's failed policies' is clearly argumentative and inviting debate.

—Let me state for the member for Parramatta and to anyone who has an interest in question time that if the occupier of the chair were to apply the standing orders literally scarcely a question would survive. I maintain a balance in the application of the standing orders as they apply to questions and, I hope, to answers. The Leader of the Opposition is in order.
—What action will the government take in the domestic petrol market to assist the motoring public? Will the government now adopt Labor's policy of trade practices reform, in particular—
—Member for Sturt!
—The question is about high petrol prices right around Australia. I ask: will the government now adopt—
—The member for Sturt is warned!

—The question is about high petrol prices right around Australia. I ask: will the government now adopt Labor's policy of trade practices reform—in particular, guaranteeing independent wholesalers and retailers access to fuel supplies from the terminals of the major oil companies on fair terms?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I have not actually attended any of his community forums—I have attended plenty of my own—but I will take his word for it that people are concerned about petrol prices. I am too, but I am sure that, as a responsible leader on the Australian political landscape, he would have politely but firmly pointed out that there are a number of factors leading to increased petrol prices, not least of which is extraordinary economic growth in China, economic recovery globally and the onset of the driving season in the United States, as well as a whole range of other factors. I have no doubt that he would have sought to make some political points and to claim that his policy would have had an impact on petrol prices.
