If you have been following this debate at all, you will know that the 800th MP Brigade and the 205th Military Intelligence Brigade were not responsible for the catering; they were doing a few other things. Major O'Kane was directly engaged in Red Cross deliberations with these individuals. Another of Major O'Kane's visits dealt with the legality of the interrogation policy at Abu Ghraib. This came out at estimates yesterday, when we finally managed to extract from the government Major O'Kane's end of trip report. It states quite nicely in section C, paragraph 5, that meetings with the brigade et cetera at Abu Ghraib dealt with advice on the legality of interrogation procedures.

What we are finding here is that we are not at the margins of this exercise; we are actually close to the centre of this exercise in terms of the awareness of what was occurring. But it is not just Major O'Kane. Beyond Major O'Kane, there are six other Australian legal officers who visited Abu Ghraib and another prison facility, Camp Cropper, from June 2003 on. Evidence in estimates told us graphically that Australian officials in Iraq were deeply aware of and involved in the exchanges between the Red Cross and the CPA last year.

Remember that the Prime Minister's first firewall defence was that only one official was aware and that this was in relation to an ICRC report which, according to the Prime Minister, did not deal with any serious allegations of prisoner abuse. So we now have an avalanche of US lawyers on their way to Canberra to find out what exactly these Australian officials knew, because it is directly germane to a series of inquiries and legal cases on foot in the United States. So much for the first firewall, which I think most honourable members would now concede is in some state of disrepair. The first firewall is officials in Baghdad.

The second firewall is officials in Canberra. Regrettably, officials in Baghdad have communicated with officials in Canberra. A great string of situation reports has been sent from Baghdad to Defence, but also to the department of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who is sitting at the table. Estimates today is working its way slowly through the number of communications which went to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and also to the Attorney-General's Department. There are some terrific examples of how precise the information was that went through to the minister, including this situation report that was released to the minister's department on 29 February 2004, which refers to a meeting along the following lines. I am not quoting; I am paraphrasing. The meeting was facilitated by an Australian group captain and the ICRC and senior coalition officials. The response from the meeting was one of shock to the actual content of the ICRC report, and it reported on the removal of Brigadier Karpinski and other management changes at Abu Ghraib.

That report came back to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade here in Canberra. We have a steady list of these things coming back to Canberra. So the first firewall is gone. The second firewall in Canberra—Defence, Foreign Affairs and Attorney-General's—is collapsing. What about the third firewall? The most important firewall of all is that surrounding Minister Downer, Minister Hill and the Prime Minister. How is that going? Remember, the whole argument still hinges on the Sergeant Schultz defence that these ministers knew nothing. But here is the Prime Minister's problem. He stood up at this dispatch box last Thursday and told us that his advice was that only one officer, Major O'Kane, had been in Baghdad looking at an October ICRC report which did not deal with serious allegations of prisoner abuse.

When all that fell over yesterday in estimates, who did he blame? The defence department. He went out, did his doorstop and said, `Woe is me. Defence is terrible. I, the Prime Minister of Australia, am fine. It is just that rotten bunch of officials who have stuffed it up.' Here is the Prime Minister's problem, and he knows it. At this dispatch box yesterday I asked him a simple question: `When, Prime Minister, did you or your office or department receive a copy of the February 2004 Red Cross report?' Why did I ask that question? Because his remarks so far have been about the report from last year. The reason I asked that question was that if you go to the beginning of the February 2004 report it says specifically that it is addressed to coalition forces, and it deals with a number of serious violations of international humanitarian law. These violations have been documented and sometimes observed while visiting prisoners of war in what period in Iraq? Between March and November 2003.

So when the Prime Minister stood at this dispatch box yesterday he had had in his possession—we think, because he has not confirmed it; he has refused to answer the question—for at least a couple of weeks, from the middle of May, this report which says that back in the last three-quarters of last year the Red Cross was visiting these places and reporting on prisoner abuses. And these, he now knows also from other reports, have been funnelled through Australian officials. The key thing is this: if you look at what the Red Cross have separately said about how they put this report together—this is a big problem in terms of this Prime Minister misleading this parliament last Thursday—the Red Cross, in a public statement on 8 May, said:

quote.para: It is important to understand that this report—

speech.para: that is, the Red Cross report of February this year—

quote.para: represents the summary of concerns that were regularly brought to the attention of the CF throughout 2003.

speech.para: That document has been in the public domain for nearly a month. This document has been in the possession of the Prime Minister, we think, for two to three weeks. Hence that is why he sniggeringly refused to answer the question that I put to him yesterday—because he knows it is a walking time bomb. What he has had in his possession, therefore, is clear evidence that the ICRC last year was looking at cases of prisoner abuse and that, courtesy of the ICRC's press statement, the report of February this year is a collation of all of that.

Surely, in the month that has gone by since 28 April when all this blew up in the public domain, you would think you would start to put two and two together about what actually was going on at the end of last year. That is the Prime Minister's key political vulnerability and he knows it. This material was in his possession. The report of 2004 was in his possession when he stood here and misled the parliament last Thursday. The press statement of 8 May by the Red Cross was in his possession when he stood here and misled the parliament last Thursday. There was one other thing as well. Remember the photographs which they all said that they were horrified about when they saw them and that that was their first knowledge of them. Surely, if you are a responsible government, you ask yourself this question: when were the happy snaps taken? When were they actually taken? If you had bothered to ask any of those questions and if you had bothered to look at the Taguba report done in the United States by the US military, you would see that it says that those photographs were taken during the relevant period of last year.

So what does the PM have in his possession? He has a Red Cross report of February this year, a Red Cross statement and information to the US military about the timing of when these photographs were taken. He stood at the dispatch box and he went out into the courtyard and said, `The defence department is my alibi.' My challenge to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, when he answers, is: did you have in your possession this information? What inquiries did you make of your department and what inquiries did the Prime Minister make of his department and his office as to what was known by the time he made the misleading statement last Thursday? Answer fundamentally to this parliament why, once again, you have been loose with the truth at a key moment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Before I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs, can I remind the member for Griffith to check the transcript and find out how many times he addressed the chair.

—First of all, the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the member for Griffith, runs this line about the truth. He often runs this line. This is an opposition which has been extremely loose with the truth for a long period of time. The Leader of the Opposition pretended he had briefings from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence on Iraq and he did not. He had no briefings at all. He claimed that intelligence briefings were briefings on Iraq. That was manifestly untrue, so excuse me if I just make that point. No more hypocrisy and cant from the opposition. While I am on the list of allegations of dishonesty made by the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the second thing he says is that we argued that there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. True. So did he.
—You briefed us!
—The member for Griffith had an opportunity to speak and will listen to the answer.

—He says, `Because you briefed us,' but he made this argument before he was ever briefed by us, so that argument that he just used then by intervention is also untrue. I just thought I would mention that. So this is a phoney issue, coming from an opposition of phonies.
—Why don't you address the issue?
—The member for Griffith will desist from interjecting.

—It is a phoney issue coming from an opposition that, up until now, has shown absolutely no interest at all in human rights issues in Iraq. It is only interested in human rights in Iraq because it thinks it can hammer Australian and American defence personnel. If there is an Australian or an American involved, it is an outrage, but if it is Saddam Hussein it is not worth raising in the parliament. Talk about phonies. It is phoney because the government has already made perfectly clear that the Australian Defence Force had nothing to do with the abuses—nothing whatsoever.
—Whoever said they did?
—I warn the member for Griffith!

—It is a phoney issue because the opposition ignores governments' repeated statements of abhorrence. It is phoney because the Labor Party ignores British and American action against the abusers. It is also phoney, by the way, because the opposition pretends that we are an occupying power, knowing full well that, on the basis of all the information provided to the opposition, we were not. And it is a phoney concern coming from a party which would cut and run and leave Iraq in the hands of terrorists. That is the Labor Party policy.

speech.para: The facts are important. On 16 January, the United States CENTCOM announced an investigation into abuses at Abu Ghraib. On 17 and 18 January, the United States took action against the commanders of Abu Ghraib and, on 10 February, the Red Cross handed a report to the CPA head, Ambassador Bremer—a report not addressed to Australian authorities and not passed to Australian authorities. On 23 February, the United States suspended 17 soldiers. On 24 February, the Red Cross met AusAID in Canberra. The prisoner abuse issue was not raised. On 12 March, General Taguba reported the findings of his investigation and, on 28 April, the CBS network aired the photographs.

These facts are kind of important because at the heart of this is the issue of the photographs of abuse and some sort of typical Labor Party contorted arguments about what the government may or may not have known. If you can find a major somewhere, then he constitutes the whole of the Australian government. It is a kind of unbelievable thesis that the Prime Minister himself, instead of running the country, should be down there in the defence department flicking through file after file and interviewing hundreds and hundreds of people. Only a few of the Labor Party's fellow travellers in the media think this is a serious proposition. The facts are a matter of inconvenience to the opposition.

The fact is this—and let us just think about this: despite the 16 January announcement made by the Americans, which was in the media, the opposition did not ask one question about this issue. They did not seek one briefing on the prisoner abuse issue, despite the fact this was publicly known after 16 January. It is only since April that they have sought even to raise the issue of human rights in Iraq. It is a pattern of course. All the opposition are interested in here is scoring political points on the back of human rights; scoring political points against the Americans, whom they hate; and scoring political points against the Australian government. I suppose, to be fair, they are paid to score political points against the Australian government.

Apparently, the opposition seek to say we had responsibilities on the February Red Cross report, despite the fact that it was not addressed to Australia because we are not an occupying power and we do not detain prisoners. Security Council resolution 1483 says that Britain and the United States are occupying powers. The opposition know more about who an occupying power is than the Red Cross apparently, because the Red Cross gave their reports to the occupying powers but did not give a report to us. Do you think anyone would work out who was right—the Red Cross or the member for Griffith—on this point?

The other thing which intrigues me is that the opposition expect the Australian government to have better knowledge of the abuses in Abu Ghraib than the British or the American governments. I think this point kind of exposes the fallacy of the argument being put by the opposition and the cynical party politicking on the back of human rights abuses. Of course, the ministers and officials in Australia did not know about the horrific detail of the Abu Ghraib abuses until after the 28 April broadcast of images. DFAT and my office only got the February Red Cross report on 10 May.

I just make this point: Prime Minister Blair, Foreign Secretary Straw and Defence Secretary Hoon have said that they did not know the details of the Abu Ghraib abuses until the photographs came out. But somehow the opposition—and, I have to say, a few of their fellow travellers in the media—seriously think that they can construct an argument that the Australian government would have known more about this, with a small number of personnel in Iraq and a very small number of personnel in the Coalition Provisional Authority, than the British. The opposition seriously expect the Australian people to believe that lie. I am afraid that will not wash.

In the case of the Americans—and I would have thought they had a few people on the ground, in the Coalition Provisional Authority, in the military and, of course, in the Abu Ghraib prison—I would have thought that American leaders were likely to know about this before Australian leaders. Does the opposition seriously believe that the Prime Minister, Senator Hill and I would have known about this before President Bush, Secretary Rumsfeld and Secretary Powell? I think not. I do not think any reasonable minded person in Australia would possibly believe that fantasy. The fact is that the opposition are engaged in a mighty muckraking exercise on the prisoner issue. Their interest in the welfare of others is, I am sorry to say, marginal to their cause. The crocodile tears from the opposition, I am afraid, will not work with us.

By the way, I noticed that whenever we say, `So the opposition are suggesting that there may have been Australians involved in these abuses,' the opposition say: `What an outrageous thing to say. How dare the government say that. What a shocking thing to suggest.' Some of their fellow travellers in the press gallery write the same thing. But, hang on, what did Senator Chris Evans say? I am sure nobody here knows who Senator Chris Evans is.

talk.start.para: —Who is he?
—Do you know him?
—No.
—I will inform the minister at the table. Senator Chris Evans is the opposition spokesman on defence. He was on AM this morning, and this is what he said:

quote.para: ... they didn't get the answers that revealed the involvement of Australian legal officers in the abuse scandal.

speech.para: So Senator Evans is saying, on the AM program, that Australian legal officers were involved in the abuse scandal. If ever there was a lie, that was a lie. Australian legal officers were not involved in the abuse scandal, and how dare the opposition sink so low as to suggest that.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Griffith, on a point of order. If it is frivolous, I will deal with him.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is highly offensive to refer to another member of this parliament as having lied. I ask the minister to withdraw that statement.
—The member for Griffith used the term on several occasions. I invite him to inspect the transcript.

—The member for Griffith is a phoney. He calls other people liars, but when somebody says that somebody has told a lie he wants it withdrawn. Always be forensic about the member for Griffith. I encourage members to read the Financial Review summary of him because, whatever we think on this side of the House about the member for Griffith, you would want to read what they think about him on the other side of the House. The fact is that Senator Evans's vile statement about the Australian Defence Force simply exposes the intent of the Australian Labor Party on this issue. They seek to besmirch the reputation of the Australian Defence Force by saying that Australian legal officers were involved in the abuse scandal. But the member for Griffith never lets the facts get in the way of his own hysteria. On 11 May he said:

quote.para: The key challenge, however, for Australia's international reputation on this matter, is to ensure that we have a clear accounting ... and regrettably, the story so far is a dismal one.

speech.para: The Australian Defence Force were involved in the Abu Ghraib scandal, were they? I think that is an outrageous allegation. You can mount the argument that the Australian government is somehow culpable only if you can prove that the Australian Defence Force was involved in this scandal. You have to be able to prove that proposition. That is a vile allegation against our very honourable Australian Defence Force.

What did Neil Mitchell ask? It is very interesting to read the transcripts of the member for Griffith. Neil Mitchell this morning asked the member for Griffith, `You haven't established the Prime Minister knew anything, have you?' What did the member for Griffith say? He said, `No, that's not the point.' So we had a whole speech about what an outrage the Prime Minister is, firewalls, cheating, lying and all that sort of thing, but he says he cannot establish that the Prime Minister knew anything about it. What an extraordinary argument. I always say this: if you are forensic with the member for Griffith, you will expose a pretty thin intellect; not a man, if I may say, with great legal training, like the Minister for Health and Ageing, the member for Mackellar—no, not the others.

talk.start.para: —No, not those two. So what is this all about? This is all about besmirching Australia, besmirching the Australian Defence Force and trying to sex up some yarn about how the Prime Minister or I knew all about these abuses. We knew about the abuses, but Tony Blair did not know about the abuses, George Bush did not know about the abuses, Geoff Hoon did not know about them, Jack Straw did not know about them, Colin Powell did not know about them and Donald Rumsfeld did not know about them. We knew about them because somebody in the Australian Defence Force was, as Senator Evans says, involved in the abuse scandal.

speech.para: This particular attack on the government by the opposition will soon be long forgotten because it is a pathetically weak attack. It attacks the integrity of very good people, including people in the Australian Defence Force. It deserves to be rejected. Once more it exposes the moral bankruptcy of a political party that want to raise human rights abuses by American soldiers—not, by the way, by Australian soldiers—in a prison in Iraq but never could lift a finger for the human rights abuses by Saddam Hussein. They never cared about that. That did not matter. You can slaughter people by the hundred-thousand load and the Labor Party will not care unless they can make a party political point. I think that is a little sick.

talk.start.para: —It has been said that the government, over this issue and many others, has adopted a doctrine of calculated ignorance. After listening to that very poor speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, all I can say is that there is another dimension now, and that is a bluster of ignorance. When the minister sank to the depths that he did, when he misquoted the shadow minister for defence, we knew that he was on about bluster. I will tell the House what the shadow minister for defence had to say today. I have a transcript of a doorstop interview that he did. He was asked some questions, and in his response Senator Evans said this:

quote.para: I don't think that the abuse of Iraqi prisoners is a minor technicality. What we know is that some of these people were tortured, they were treated very inhumanely, and to be fair to Senator Hill he admitted that that occurred and he has admitted that the Australian Government has known since October. I mean our responsibilities under the Geneva Convention are important to the Australian people. We want to be known as a people who observe international law and respect Human Rights. What happened in Abu Ghraib clearly was that those rights weren't protected, weren't respected and Australia has to stand up to its responsibilities. Some of those prisoners may have been ours. Some of those may have been prisoners taken by Australian forces. We have a legal and moral responsibility to them and we have a legal and moral responsibility to our officers who are attached as legal officers inside American headquarters, that they be allowed to act properly and in accordance with Australian standards.

speech.para: And of course it was these Australian legal defence officers that Chris Evans was referring to.

The ALP have pursued this government over the issue of their misleading the Australian parliament on the question of the abuse of prisoners in Iraq, and we have tried to get them to accept their political responsibilities for their failures in Iraq. We have pursued the government for many reasons, and I will go through them. Firstly, we have pursued them because we believe that, as a partner in the coalition of the willing, Australia has international obligations. The ALP believe that these obligations are important if we care about our international standing and, most importantly, our standing as a nation of honour in our region of the world—a reputation that many believe is being tarnished more and more, the longer this government stay in office. An example of that is seen at almost every question time, when the Minister for Foreign Affairs gets to his feet. Today was a prime example. I do not care how much of a fool the minister makes of himself, how much of a fool he makes of the Liberal Party or how much of a fool he makes of The Nationals, but I do care when he starts to make a fool of Australia overseas—and that is what he is doing.

Secondly, we have pursued this government because—as Kevin Rudd, our shadow minister for foreign affairs, pointed out just a couple of weeks ago in some detail—we are signatories to the Geneva convention and we have obligations and responsibilities as signatories to that convention. Surely, as part of those responsibilities, we need to be aware of the conditions under which prisoners are being held. Indeed, it is now apparent that the government did know, because a bevy of defence lawyers visited Abu Ghraib as early as October 2003 and reported on these matters. The PM claims that he is sorry because no-one told him. That sounds like the three blind mice defence: look no evil, see no evil and, above all, don't ask about any evil. Of course, that comes back to the latest doctrine of the government: the doctrine of calculated ignorance.

Thirdly, and most importantly, we have pursued this government because we on this side of the House care about the welfare and wellbeing of our troops who are on overseas deployment. We care about their reputations and their international standing, and we care about their safety in the event that one or more of them should ever be taken prisoner. Can we even begin to imagine how the mums and dads of Australian servicemen would feel if the images that we have seen of these abused Iraqis were, instead, images of Australian members of the Defence Force? The people of Australia have been absolutely sickened by what they have seen, and we do not want to be associated—and we do not want to have our Australian standards associated—with that sort of thing.

Fourthly, we are pursuing this government because we believe that truth and accountability in these matters are important. Truth, honesty and accountability have all been missing from this government and its senior ministers right from the initial stages of Australia's involvement in this pre-emptive strike as a partner in the coalition of the willing. At best, this government has been sloppy, recalcitrant and irresponsible over its handling of these events. At worst, it has just continued the lies, deceit and cover-up which have been a hallmark of the Howard government over both the `children overboard' events and this issue that we are dealing with today.

Fifthly, we are pursuing this government because we do not believe that the Department of Defence and our senior troops should be made scapegoats over the government's incompetence, dishonesty and lack of responsibility. It is patently obvious that this government do not want honesty or to take due responsibility; they simply want a public servant or an ADF member whom they can hang out as a scapegoat.

But it is the third reason that I want to return to—that is, our care, concern and respect for our troops. We in the ALP are outraged at the actions of the Prime Minister and his Minister for Foreign Affairs, who have attempted to slur us and the media when questions about the treatment of Iraqi POWs and the government's actions have been raised. Their slippery, slimy defence has been to say that we are trying to impugn the reputation of our troops by raising questions and asking for accountability from the Howard government. I call this the dingo defence, because it is about as low and as gutless as you can get.

We just heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs trying to hide behind our troops and trying to use them as his front-line defence—a pathetic, weak-kneed and gutless approach. That typifies this Minister for Foreign Affairs. And we see the Prime Minister doing it again as he blames the defence department and our senior troops, as he decides to cut and run to the United States—a timely trip to visit his American idol—no doubt in the hope that, on his return, Defence will have absorbed the blame, the scapegoat will have been hung out and all will be forgotten. We will not forget and the people of Australia will not forget. It needs to be said: we do not want much. We just want the Prime Minister and his government to conduct themselves with the same moral courage and commitment which we expect and receive from our troops as they go about their responsibilities in the field. Our troops do their job in the highest traditions of the Anzacs, and we want this government to accept their responsibilities with the same high level of commitment, the same high level of morality, and in the highest traditions of our parliamentary democracy. I do not think that is too much to ask.

If the government had any respect for the conventions and standards of this place and for our democracy they would take due responsibility instead of shying away from it—as a startled horse shies away from a venomous snake. This government shy away from doing the right thing and accepting their responsibilities.

I want to compliment the Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham; our shadow minister, Kevin Rudd; our shadow defence minister, Senator Chris Evans; and other senators on the way in which they have so doggedly pursued the Prime Minister and his government over these matters. What the Prime Minister and his Minister for Defence must explain to the people of Australia is why they hide the truth and why they refuse to accept any responsibility for these appalling events. As the West Australian said this morning, `PM admits nation misled over Iraqis'. It is one thing to admit it; however, it remains to be seen what responsibility, if any, he will take for misleading us—or whether he will simply hide behind the same people he blamed for the Tampa affair: the Australian Defence Forces.

talk.start.para: —I do agree with the member for Cowan that this debate is about responsibility. Let me start with the inescapable point that, had the opposition's policy on Iraq been followed, Saddam Hussein would still be in power today. Let me repeat that for the benefit of the House and for the benefit of the Australian people: had the opposition's policy on Iraq been followed, Saddam Hussein would still be in power today. The opposition may not have sought it and they may not have desired it, but that would be the inescapable, unavoidable and absolute conclusion of the path down which their policy would have taken this nation. I respect the fact that there are some people of good integrity and good intentions who would pursue that policy and who believe that the cost of action would have been too great. But it is the inescapable conclusion that Hussein, the Baathists and all of those associated with the legacy of human rights abuse would still be in power.

speech.para: I want to deal with three things in this debate. Firstly, the question of human rights abuse; secondly, the opposition's implications—because the opposition seek to work by implication rather than by direct allegation—and thirdly, the question of Australia's responsibility. In terms of abuse, there is a very general and critical principle. Prisoner abuse, human rights abuse and torture are never justified. It does not matter against whom, it does not matter by whom, it does not matter what alleged justifications there are. It is wrong, it is wrong, it is always wrong. Having said that, we know that, under Saddam Hussein, Abu Ghraib was a scene of incomparable human misery. Iraq is a country which, over the last decade, witnessed 300,000 lives—if not more—exterminated under a genocidal regime. Marsh Arabs, Kurdish minorities and Shiite communities were all damaged and destroyed, and lives were extinguished repeatedly, daily, under an ongoing regime of fear. That is the reality of abuse in the last decade under Hussein.

I previously said that I had one regret in relation to Australia's involvement in Iraq, and that is not that the world community acted but that it did not act sooner. I welcome this debate, because we should be focusing on these things. If it highlights the fact that, in dealing with those atrocities, there have been people who have acted in breach of their responsibilities within Abu Ghraib prison over the last year, then they should be punished, they should be brought to account, investigations should be completed, and there should be no holding back in the punishment meted out. The full force of the law should be brought. Those are the basic principles.

What we face is a great struggle in Iraq today: a struggle between the forces of the Baathists on the one hand and those associated with al-Qaeda and their desire to destroy democracy, to bring a reign of terror, and to open the gates of hell to split Iraq asunder. That is what they seek to do. We are involved in a difficult operation.

But what are the implications made by the opposition in this debate? What are the implications made by the Leader of the Opposition? What are the implications made by the member for Griffith? They cast three key implications. The first implication, which is inescapable and unavoidable from everything they say, is that Australia was involved or that it was complicit. That is the underlying implication in all of their work. Was Australia involved? Was it complicit? What did Senator Chris Evans, the opposition defence spokesperson, say today on ABC radio this morning? He said, `didn't get the answers that revealed the involvement of Australian legal officers in the abuse scandal.' `Involvement'—that is what they are seeking to imply; that is what they are seeking to show: that in some way Australia was involved. That is a dangerous and reprehensible implication, because the implication is pregnant, it is heavy, it is there, and it is directed against the government through the implication that, in some way, we were involved. That is the underlying assumption, and it is fundamentally wrong, and Australians throughout Australia know that it is fundamentally wrong.

The second implication which the opposition raise is that the Prime Minister knew of the abuse. But this would have had to have been in advance of the US President; the United Kingdom's Prime Minister, Tony Blair; the defence secretary of the UK, Geoffrey Hoon; and Jack Straw, the foreign secretary of the UK. That is the implication but, when questioned, do they agree with that? What did the member for Griffith say on Victoria radio this morning when asked:

quote.para: ... but you haven't established the Prime Minister knew anything have you?

speech.para: The member for Griffith answered:

quote.para: Ah, no, that's not our point.

speech.para: `It is not our point that the Prime Minister did not know'? That is their entire point. It is to imply and imply that the Prime Minister was aware and effectively failed to do anything.

The third implication is that senior officials knew—that if the Prime Minister did not know, senior officials knew and should have informed the Prime Minister; that there is a culture of being cowed. Let us deal with these implications expressly—because they are not stated; they are implied. Have the courage to come out and state them. What was the height of the implication in the member for Griffith's statement? It was simple. He went so far as to make the bold allegation that, after the Abu Ghraib incidents were aired on television, the Australian government might have received the ICRC report from February. That is the height: that, after the world community knew, the Australian government might have received the report. There is a sort of fantasy here which is extraordinary.

But let me go to another part of this debate. A difficult question for everybody involved—and I entirely respect the right of other Australians and other members of this House to have different views—is the question of what our responsibilities are as a nation to individuals within Iraq, to the course of human history as it stands now and to Australian troops and representatives? There are two great questions that we face. The first is whether or not we leave Australian troops within Iraq, because that is an unresolved question. What we have is a position from the opposition that says, `We should withdraw those troops at the very first opportunity that we in the opposition will have.' I respect their right to do that, but the consequence—and you can never divorce the consequence from the action—is simple to see. It will leave Australian diplomats, Australian aid workers and any Australian in Iraq exposed. It will leave them open to violence, to terror and to the worst forms of action—as we saw only last week. That will be the consequence of the action which the opposition prescribe—Australians will be exposed.

The second question that we face is: what is the deeper significance of what the opposition are advocating? Are they advocating that the West should walk away? What is occurring in Iraq now is one of the great civilisational challenges. It is a battle between forces related to the Baathists and to Saddam Hussein and his legacy and also those related to al-Qaeda and their desire—as we saw only last weekend—to destroy all of the existing Islamic societies and to replace them with a Taliban style world of utter and total oppression. There is a challenge that is alive today in Iraq; big history is being battled out—and the opposition say that we should pull out.

The consequence of that if taken to its conclusion—that the United States should pull out as well; that this is no place for the West; that this is no place for people to be dealing with the lives of ordinary Iraqis—is that the gates of hell will open on Iraq. If you care about Iraqi citizens, you could not pursue a more dangerous, a more destructive or a less concerned policy for the people of Iraq. It is a fundamentally flawed, a fatally dangerous and an inhumane policy, because it will open the gates of hell on the people of Iraq. That is what will happen to the people in that country. For the people in the rest of the world, we will see played out again and again the acts of terror and the attempts to break down our civilisation. That will be the consequence. That is the battle that we are facing. On every front, I reject the position put forward by the opposition today. It is a position based on an inability to deal with abuse, on false implications and, above all else, a failure to carry out Australia's responsibilities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Gates of hell indeed! I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution to this debate on the government's misleading of the Australian parliament and people on the question of prisoner abuse in Iraq. The way in which the government has handled the issue of torture of prisoners in Iraq is another example of the contempt in which it holds the Australian people. It is now clear that a number of people in the defence establishment were aware of the allegations and the government failed to discover the fact, preferring instead to adopt the stone-walling tactics of denial which have become this administration's stock response.

speech.para: I hope that the government has read the report of US Major General Anthony Taguba, and I hope it has read it closely, because one of the people named by General Taguba has strong links with our country. I refer to Steven Stefanowicz, who General Taguba found had:

quote.para: ... made a false statement to the investigation team regarding the locations of his interrogations, the activities during those interrogations, and his knowledge of abuses.

speech.para: Stefanowicz has been identified by the Philadelphia Daily News as a former public relations specialist for the South Australian government, though other sources suggest his field of work was really information technology, at which he was not particularly successful in gaining employment.

The Australian newspaper cast more light on this, confirming in a report of 8 May 2004 that Stefanowicz worked in IT sales in Adelaide for 18 months until October 2001. It appears he returned to the United States and joined, or re-joined, the US Navy Reserve, where he held the rank of petty officer and served somewhere in the Middle East.

How he came to be working as a civilian contractor for CACI International is unclear from the public record. Nonetheless, his position with that organisation was obviously one of some significant authority. You can glean that much from General Taguba's recommendation about him, and again I quote from his report. General Taguba's recommendation was:

quote.para: Stefanowicz, of CACI International, be fired from his army job, reprimanded, and denied his security clearances for lying to the investigating team and allowing or ordering military policemen who were not trained in interrogation techniques to facilitate interrogations by `setting conditions' which were neither authorised, nor in accordance with army regulations.
He clearly knew his instructions equated to physical abuse.

speech.para: Despite this his family—presumably his mother, Jean Campbell, who lives in Telford, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, near where Stefanowicz grew up in the Philadelphia suburbs—has confirmed to at least two major newspapers that her son remains in Iraq. And, despite that damning finding, the US Army has confirmed that he is still working at Abu Ghraib prison, the site of his gross abuses of human rights. According to that report in the Australian which I referred to earlier, he now intends to come back to Australia. He feels like Adelaide is home. Mr Speaker, I am here to tell you that this man must not—I repeat `not'—be allowed to re-enter Australia. We have seen how government stonewalling and denial delayed the truth about who knew what and what was going on in the Iraq prisons and when.

And that brings me to my final point. General Taguba's report reveals that US Major General Geoffrey D. Miller, the Commander of the Guantanamo Bay detention facility, reviewed the detention and interrogation operations in Iraq between 31 August and 9 September 2003 and, using the Guantanamo Bay procedures as a baseline, recommended that detention operations must act as an enabler for interrogation. Major General Miller was previously the Commander of Joint Task Force Guantanamo, and Taguba's report shows that he applied the Guantanamo protocols in his review. How can we be sure that there is not a report which the government can deny knowing about on the treatment of the Australian Guantanamo detainees David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib? How can the government be sure that the abhorrent techniques used on Iraqi detainees were not similarly used on them? And how can we believe them?

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the second report of the committee for 2004 relating to the proposed fit-out of new leased premises for the Department of Health and Ageing at Scarborough House, Woden Town Centre, ACT.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—This report examines the proposed fit-out of Health's new leased premises, currently under construction at Atlantic Street, Woden Town Centre. The estimated cost of the proposed fit-out works is $18.5 million. The Department of Health and Ageing has been situated in the Woden Town Centre since the development of the town concept in the early planning of Canberra. Over time, the department has expanded to occupy some 46,000 square metres of leasehold accommodation in Canberra, with 12 of its 15 leased premises being located in Woden. The need for the proposed work is driven by Health's objective of consolidating its Canberra activities into two buildings in Woden, one of which will be Scarborough House.

speech.para: Health anticipates that the rationalisation of its accommodation at Scarborough House will result in a number of organisational benefits, including cost and operational efficiencies derived from the collocation of fragmented leases and the provision of a modern working environment for employees. Work elements for the Scarborough House proposal comprise: integration of electrical, mechanical, security, communications, fire and hydraulic services into base building works; and general office fit-out to meet Health's requirements, including security and reception facilities, office areas, meeting rooms, utilities, stores, tearooms, a first aid room and conference and training facilities.

At the public hearing, the committee questioned Health on issues related to project costs, building amenities and consultation. We asked them to expand on the cost efficiencies to be realised from co-location, and Health stated that savings would be generated in a number of areas, including security arrangements, energy, repair and maintenance costs, venue hire and courier and freight charges. The committee expressed concern at what appeared to be unusually high relocation costs. The department explained that the relocation costs provided for a number of moves which were required to create greater cohesion through the realignment of business entities within the department.

The committee noted Health's tight project time line and queried the potential for cost escalation and the provision of appropriate contingency arrangements. Health replied that, while it was confident deadlines would be met, the building owners would be responsible for any costs incurred in the event of a delay. With respect to all cost matters, the committee requested that Health supply it with a cost savings analysis, a detailed breakdown of relocation costs and a project time line. The department subsequently provided that information.

The committee asked why Health had decided against the provision of child-care facilities on site. Health explained that employees were not moving outside the Woden area, where adequate facilities already exist. Furthermore, the building has insufficient external space to provide a suitable play area. Noting the open-plan layout of the office accommodation, the committee raised concerns about employees' personal work space environments. Health assured the committee that individual work space allocations would be within acceptable departmental ranges and that the issue of sound intrusion had been addressed.

The committee was also interested to learn more about Health's staff consultation process in relation to the move. Health described its communication strategy, which included staff information sessions and a consultative forum comprised of employees from each work area and union and occupational health and safety representatives. Health developed a process to encourage staff feedback and suggestions from staff and intended to incorporate these into the architect's brief.

Although Health's written evidence described a range of proposed energy conservation measures, it did not indicate that Health had consulted with the Australian Greenhouse Office to ensure compliance with the Commonwealth energy policy. When questioned by the committee, Health confirmed that it had liaised with the Greenhouse Office on achieving energy savings targets, and the committee welcomes that.

Having considered the evidence for the work, the committee recommends that the proposed fit-out for the Department of Health and Ageing at Scarborough House, Woden Town Centre, ACT proceed at the estimated cost of $18.5 million. I wish to thank all of those who assisted the committee with its inspections and the public hearing, particularly my committee colleagues—including you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins—and the secretariat, who did an outstanding job of completing this report. I commend the report to the House.

speech.para: In its report into the interim works for the site remediation and construction of infrastructure for the Defence site at Randwick Barracks, Sydney, the Public Works Committee has made three recommendations. Following the public hearing on 12 March 2004, the map showing the extent and distribution of contamination at the Randwick Barracks disposal site was placed on the web site.

The Department of Defence agrees that an appropriate regulatory body should be given responsibility for monitoring the execution of contamination remedial works to ensure that proper health, safety and environmental controls are exercised. However, there is no regulatory authority with the powers proposed. Defence will therefore appoint an independent coordination entity to independently monitor the development and remediation works, reporting directly to the Department of Environment and Heritage; coordinate the proactive identification and response to environmental and public health issues associated with development and remediation works; ensure focused and frequent communications of the responsible management development and remediation works to all key stakeholders as the works proceed to a satisfactory completion; and ensure a feedback loop for all issues raised in association with the development and remediation works, demonstrating how each issue was addressed, including direct response to those raising the issue.

The Department of Defence agrees that the remaining portion of the works referred to the committee will be subject to a thorough investigation by the committee at the earliest opportunity and prior to the commencement of any further works elements. On behalf of the government, I would like to thank the committee for its support. I commend the motion to the House.
