debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (2004 MEASURES NO. 1) BILL 2004

cognateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LAWS AMENDMENT (2004 MEASURES NO. 2) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Kingston has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

—The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 extends the existing co-contribution scheme, introduced in 2003, by altering the definition of a low-income employee. It thereby significantly extends the scope of the existing co-contribution for the low-income earners scheme. The change proposed is one part of a number of changes announced over the last few months in the superannuation area. The most recent were announced in the budget. The suite of changes includes this current proposal to alter the definition of a low-income employee, changes to the amount of the co-contribution from dollar for dollar to $1.50 per dollar for each dollar saved for those on low incomes, increasing the upper income limit for full access to this scheme from $27,500 to $28,000 per year and cutting the superannuation surcharge for those on high incomes.

speech.para: Under current law, eligibility for the government co-contribution requires that an individual be in receipt of or entitled to employer superannuation support in the form of superannuation guarantee contributions. This means that those earning under $450 per month—the amount above which SGC payments are required—are not eligible for the co-contribution. It also means that those under 18 years of age and working part-time are also ineligible for the same reason. The current arrangements also exclude low-income earners who are self-employed and those whose incomes are erratic, which is the case for many casual workers.

The changes proposed here mean that an individual is no longer required to be entitled to employer superannuation support to be eligible for the co-contribution. Instead, the requirement will be that 10 per cent of the individual's income is from employment. The reason for this change is to increase access to the scheme: that is, those who earn less than $450 per month—$5,400 per year—are now entitled to a co-contribution if they make superannuation savings. Also, those who earn their low income from activities other than employment are now also eligible.

One has to ask the obvious questions: why is the takeup of this scheme such that the government sees the need to act to improve it; and why alter the eligibility criteria in this way? The answer to the first question is obvious: not many employees on a low income can afford to make voluntary superannuation savings out of their own pockets. People on low incomes usually do not have much discretionary income. Most of their income is taken up with everyday living expenses. One can only speculate on the answer to the second question. A cynic would note that the most likely person on a low income able to make superannuation savings is the person who is at least partially financially supported by somebody else—someone like a spouse on a high income or a parent.

The change to the eligibility criteria that removes the need for all of the income to be from employment—in fact, reducing the income required to be from employment to just 10 per cent—is a huge change. Suddenly, it opens the door to households, for instance, where one partner is substantially supported by a high-income earner who has put the household investments in the name of the low-income partner. It is quite legitimate for households to organise their financial affairs this way, but I do question whether these are the households most in need of help in making superannuation savings. Many of these households will be receiving a tax cut as a result of the recent budget, a tax cut denied to those on incomes of under $52,000 per year. These households get to gain twice. They will gain three times if the high-income earner earns more than $92,000 per year and gets a tax break because of the cut in the superannuation surcharge.

If the government is serious about assistance to those on low incomes in the superannuation area, other things could be done that would be of more benefit. For instance, the government could have cut the superannuation tax for all employees rather than cut the superannuation surcharge, which benefits only a small section of our community.

The Labor Party over the years has done a lot towards ensuring employees have sufficient superannuation to see them through retirement. It was Labor after all who established a system of compulsory contributions for employees. This started from a modest three per cent of earnings and has gradually moved to nine per cent, where it sits today. The original legislation went further than nine per cent. It proposed an additional three per cent employee and three per cent government contribution—a total of 15 per cent. This was abandoned by the present government in 1997, which is seen as a backward step. Labor was interested in giving workers a real chance to build up their superannuation for a decent income in retirement. Instead of spending the money on a tax cut to those on high incomes—four per cent of superannuation contributors—the government could have followed Labor's lead and offered a superannuation tax cut to all superannuation contributors by cutting the 15 per cent super tax on all contributions back to, say, 13 per cent.

It would be better to offer Australians better security for their superannuation savings. Super is often the only asset a family has beyond their home. Despite this and despite the fact that super is compulsory, the government has not provided 100 per cent compensation for those who lose their super savings. Super can be lost through theft or fraud or where a business has failed and the employee superannuation guarantee contributions have not been paid by that business. Labor proposes changes to superannuation which include a ban on exit fees and commissions, a cap on ongoing fees and charges on the nine per cent compulsory superannuation guarantee, tougher enforcement of the law to ensure financial planners give independent and competent advice to consumers and full compensation for funds lost through theft or fraud.

On the face of it, this bill is all about helping those on low incomes to save for their retirement. But, like every other step taken by this government which appears to help those not so well off, it pays to be wary of the hidden agenda. This bill will benefit those on low incomes who have high earning partners: that is, those who despite their low incomes have discretionary income. It will be interesting over time to see how many beneficiaries of this bit of legislation have a partner who benefits from the income tax cuts for those on incomes of over $52,000 per year or who benefits from the other inequitable tax cut, the reduction in the superannuation surcharge. At best, this bill is misdirected. At worst, it is very well directed, but not to those purported to be the objective of this legislation.

I support the amendments moved to this bill, which point out the failure of the government to offer a tax cut to all superannuation contributors while offering one to those on high incomes and which point out that this bill is really only going to benefit those low-income earners who have a partner with a high income who is prepared to contribute to the low-income person's superannuation. It will not be of much use to low-income households at all.

The second bill being debated here is the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. This bill is largely technical in nature but it does have a sting, and that is a simplification of the earnings base used to calculate the superannuation guarantee entitlement. Most employers are required to use ordinary time earnings as the SG earnings base but there are a number of exemptions. This is a particular problem for some industries where shift penalties make up the major part of the remuneration but are excluded from the SG base either by legislation or by industrial award.

While I support the proposed standardisation of the SG base, I have to ask why it does not take effect until 2010. These employees affected by this situation have been disadvantaged for the last 12 years. Why should they wait any longer? Labor believes that this measure should be implemented from 1 July 2005. I understand that some employers might face difficulty in changing over immediately and we propose that employers in this situation apply to the relevant industrial commission to have the standardised GC base phased in.

Superannuation is critical to the security of everyone in retirement. We should be serious about offering real incentives and the capacity to those who rely on their hard earned wages to save for their retirement. The measures being brought forward over recent months do not help working families and people. They provide assistance to those already able to look after themselves—a tax cut for those earning over $52,000 per year, a super cut for those on over $95,000 per year and now a cash bonus from government for those on low incomes who can somehow afford to put aside $1,000 in superannuation savings. It is time this government got serious about superannuation and adopted some of our proposals for ensuring adequate and secure superannuation for all people.

talk.start.para: —The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004 give effect to changes made to the government's policy on superannuation contained in its most recent budget. As the Australian public well knows, we are in an election year and the current flurry of activity on several policy fronts, including this one, is motivated more by the political imperatives of the government than by any government desire to construct a longterm retirement policy to serve all Australians.

speech.para: The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 amends the Superannuation (Government Co-contribution for Low Income Earners) Act2003, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 in order to extend the government's co-contribution for low-income earners to some employees who at the moment do not qualify for it. It will also remove taxation deductions available for personal superannuation contributions made by individuals who, under this bill, will now qualify for a government co-contribution. In this way the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 will be amended to deny a taxation deduction in respect of personal superannuation contributions made by individuals who are entitled to a government co-contribution. Schedule 2 of this bill amends the Superannuation (Government Co-contribution for Low Income Earners) Act2003 to specify an interest rate to be applied to late government co-contribution payments, to require superannuation providers to repay government co-contribution amounts which are not credited to members' accounts within a specific time frame and to further outline the requirements for reports by the minister to parliament under the co-contribution act.

The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004 will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, removing the requirement for superannuation funds to obtain an actuary's certificate in order to qualify for exemption from tax. It will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to provide an additional condition in regard to taxpayers below the age of 18. Further, it will amend the Superannuation Guarantee Administration Act 1992 to simplify the earnings base of an employee for superannuation guarantee purposes. This legislation also seeks to address several key issues relating to superannuation. In particular, it will remove the complexity in determining the correct earnings base as well as the inequality in the level of contributions between equivalent employees. A lead time of six years will allow the changes contained in this measure to be considered by employers and employees in the wage bargaining process.

In press release No. 11, dated 25 February 2004 and entitled `A more flexible and adaptable retirement income system', the Treasurer set out the government's policy objectives. Let me for the benefit of the House go over those objectives here. They are, firstly, to simplify the operations of the superannuation scheme and reduce superannuation providers' compliance costs associated with administering the current super-annuation work test; and, secondly, to improve equity of access to the super-annuation system. These are indeed noble objectives and I do not think there would be anybody on this side of the House who would dispute those particular objectives as being important to this area of policy. But the government has had eight years to get on top of these two particular objectives and to give effect to them in its policy on superannuation, and I think it is indicative of the fact that superannuation has never been a priority of the Liberal and National parties in this country.

The electorate is very cynical about these preelection manoeuvres and I think the people of Australia can rightly be cynical of what the government is attempting to do with its superannuation budget measures and in this legislation. As I have said, super has never really been a priority of the Liberal and National parties, but we now have this flurry of activity in the preelection phase as the government tries to pretend it has an agenda beyond the next election.

I do not propose to canvass all government amendments contained in these two bills; however, I would like to make comment on two aspects that have given rise to the second reading amendments proposed earlier by my colleague the member for Kingston, who is in the House this evening. As my colleague has pointed out in debate—and I think it was last week in debate on the Superannuation Budget Measures Bill 2004—Labor has voiced some real concerns that the targeting of the co-contribution may lead to its being utilised by high-income earning couples where one spouse is earning a low income, and these are the very people who least need it. These provisions ought not to lead to situations where couples are able to utilise them to extract a tax avoidance benefit.

We on this side of the House all know the natural tendency of the Prime Minister to structure policy to assist the tax bludgers in our community. He has form; he has a history as Treasurer, with the bottom of the harbour schemes, of allowing tax rorters to run riot in this country. As he has a fair bit of form, we as an opposition have to be eternally vigilant to ensure that the Prime Minister does not slip back to his bad old ways. As Treasurer of this country, he left Labor with a deficit which in current terms would be in excess of $25 billion in any one year. And we know that, with regard to certain taxation practices, he allowed the tax bludgers to run riot. We as an opposition do not intend to allow the Prime Minister once again to introduce legislation that will allow high-income earners to milk the system for their own benefit and for that to be paid for by the ordinary wage and salary earners of this country.

We have also pointed out in this debate that most low-income taxpayers earning $28,000, given the household demands on their available income, are unlikely to be able to save the $1,000 after-tax contribution that is necessary for eligibility to claim this offer from the government. Labor have stated that we will support integrity amendments to ensure that the co-contribution scheme cannot be abused by tax rorters. In particular, we are of the view that the eligibility test for the co-contribution should take into account total household income to better target the assistance to low-income earners. Labor will pass these amendments but we will also refer them to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for further examination.

I want registered in Hansard my support for the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston in this debate—namely, that whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the government for its failure to adopt the alternative approach of offering a superannuation tax cut to all contributors, as proposed by Labor, and for operating a system that fails to recognise the inability of low-income Australians to take advantage of measures to expand their superannuation while permitting spouses with wealthy partners to exploit the benefit.

I turn to the second bill before the House, the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004. Rather then pick up on all the measures in that bill, I will just refer to that aspect of the bill that deals with the simplification of the superannuation guarantee earnings base. As we know, most employers are required to use ordinary-time earnings as the superannuation guarantee earnings base. However, there are a number of exemptions to this in the superannuation guarantee legislation and, as we know, there are some industrial awards where a different superannuation guarantee earnings base is permitted.

These particular exemptions and provisions result in a lower superannuation guarantee earnings base and, at the end of the day, lower superannuation guarantee contributions. We have noticed that this is particularly the case in industries where shift penalties make up a major part of the wages of workers. There are significant groups of employees that are affected by these exemptions. Workers in the coal industry, workers under Queensland state awards, casual workers under the Queensland state clerical employees award, Queensland public sector workers and miners in Tasmania and Western Australia are just a few of those that are missing out on the full superannuation guarantee contributions.

We support the standardisation of the superannuation guarantee base but we question the motivation of the government in bringing this legislation and this amendment before the House. In particular, we ask why the government has put in a time limit of 2010 to implement this change. That would effectively give many employees a substantial advantage over others. We are essentially saying to employees: `Yes, there is a problem. We think you have been disadvantaged and are in an unfair situation relative to other workers, but you are going to have to wait another five years to have this issue redressed.' We are of the view that the date of implementation of the measures to standardise the superannuation guarantee base ought to be moved forward to 1 July 2005. I think that is a reasonable amendment, and I support the second reading amendment that has been proposed, which gives effect to that particular proposition.

The Labor Party has a real vision for an ageing society. It is an inclusive vision which is rooted in the proud history of previous Labor governments, and it really does contrast with the rather exclusive approach that has been pursued by the Liberal and National parties, both in government and in opposition. Labor has always led the way on retirement incomes policy in this country, simply because it seeks to give the broadest coverage and the broadest security to the greatest number of Australians that it can. Honourable members might recall that in 1909 the Fisher Labor government introduced the first Commonwealth age pension for males at age 65, and that was extended in the next year to women at age 60.

Australia was fortunate enough to have the Chifley Labor government introduce a national compulsory contribution pension fund to pay for future pension costs. We know the reaction of the Liberal and National parties to that proposition in the early 1950s. The Menzies Liberal government ceased funding it in the early 1950s. It took until the Hawke Labor government in 1983 to increase pensions to 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings. This change meant that the age pension increased not just in line with inflation but in real value as the economy grew.

The next major achievement by Labor in government was the establishment of the existing compulsory superannuation system, which commenced in 1987. In that year Labor in government took the visionary step of establishing Australia's first compulsory superannuation system. This was a response to a long held belief of ours that security in retirement is a fundamental right of all Australians and a recognition by us that the retirement income system at that time did not provide all Australians with that security against the background of an ageing population. Since then, we have pursued a three-pillared strategy that now forms the basis of Australia's retirement income system—namely, the age pension, the superannuation guarantee and additional voluntary contributions to superannuation.

Since its introduction in 1987, when the Industrial Relations Commission decision required employers to pay a three per cent compulsory contribution to superannuation on behalf of each worker, coverage has expanded from 48 per cent of the work force to 80 per cent. I think that is one of the most significant social reforms that any government has introduced in this country in the post war era. It was not a Liberal-National government that created the superannuation scheme, because they have basically done very little on this retirement incomes front until recent budgets; since Federation it has been the Labor Party in government that has attempted to set up a viable retirement incomes policy for the people of this nation.

There is something instructive that I want all electors in Corio and the Geelong area to fully understand; that is, there is a very good reason the Treasurer wants them to work until they drop: it is, simply, because those workers in my electorate on average weekly earnings have been dudded to the tune of $100,000 as a result of the failure of this government to fulfil the promise it gave before it came to power that it would continue Labor's superannuation policies. In 1995 the Retirement Income Modelling Task Force estimated that Labor's plan would have increased by $100,000 the retirement income of an employee who was then aged in their mid 30s and on an average weekly income. So $100,000 would now be in the pockets of each of those employees on retirement if Labor had stayed in power—or if the Prime Minister had implemented the promise he gave to the Australian people.

I want to quote from the Liberal Party policy document called Super for all: security and flexibility in retirement: the federal coalition's superannuation and retirement incomes policydated 19 February 1996. It says:

quote.para: ...the funds earmarked in the 1995-96 Budget to match compulsory employee contributions will be provided in full, in a manner that is both efficient and equitable ...

speech.para: We now know that the Prime Minister ratted on that particular promise on superannuation. Workers in my community who paid into their superannuation during the years of the Labor government and who were given that great opportunity to improve their retirement incomes have been dudded by the Liberal Party and The Nationals out of $100,000 in their retirement.

So we know your priorities; we know exactly your priorities. You can spend $1 billion on a war in Iraq, you can spend $100 million on wasteful advertising, you can spend over $250 million on a dopey Pacific solution on refugees, but when it comes to keeping your promises on superannuation and when it comes to meeting the needs of Australians in their retirement, you certainly fall well short. We are going to support the measures contained in these bills, but we have moved a second reading amendment. I wholeheartedly support that amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to sum up debate on these bills, which I think in most cases has been most constructive, although the member for Corio seemed to run out of impetus about two-thirds of the way through his speech. The government would like to thank all honourable members who participated in the debate on the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill 2004 and the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004.

speech.para: Over recent years there has been a growing realisation throughout Australian society of the importance of retirement planning and saving for the years ahead. Superannuation is seen as a vital element in planning for a comfortable and secure retirement, providing a vehicle for people to secure a higher standard of living in retirement than would be possible on the pension alone. A key initiative introduced last year to provide greater incentives for voluntary superannuation contributions was the government's co-contribution scheme. The government has recognised that more incentives were needed for low-income earners to increase their level of voluntary superannuation saving.

The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 1) Bill gives effect to a proposal by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer on 14 March 2004 to alter the eligibility criteria for the government's superannuation co-contribution. This bill will amend the Superannuation (Government Co-contribution for Low Income Earners) Act 2003 so that individuals will no longer be required to be employer superannuation supported to qualify for the co-contribution. Rather, they will only be required to have at least 10 per cent of their total income as an employee. This change will apply for all co-contribution determinations made for a person for the 2003-04 and later income years.

To prevent double-dipping, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 will also be amended to ensure that these people now entitled to a co-contribution cannot also claim a tax deduction for their personal superannuation contributions. This will only be done for the 2004-05 and subsequent income years to avoid any retrospective effect on these new co-contribution recipients.

Other measures contained in this bill to ensure the smooth operation of the Superannuation (Government Co-contribution for Low Income Earners) Act 2003 are: specifying a time frame in which providers must repay uncredited co-contribution amounts to the Commissioner of Taxation and a further period of time after which providers will become liable to pay the general interest charge; outlining that, where the information is available, the minister will report on an aggregated and annual basis on the numbers of co-contribution beneficiaries and spouses of beneficiaries within prescribed income ranges; specifying the interest rate that will apply to late payments made by the Commissioner of Taxation; and inserting a previously omitted definition.

In response to comments made by the honourable members for Kingston, Braddon, Isaacs and Corio during the debate on this bill, let me make the following points. There is no evidence to support the claim that the new co-contribution test will primarily benefit low-income spouses of high-wealth households. However, as was also mentioned during the debate, amendments in this bill will mean that the minister will report to parliament on an annual basis about the number of co-contribution recipients and the number of spouses of those recipients by prescribed income ranges. Furthermore, let me reiterate that the new test is that a person must have earned at least 10 per cent of their total income as an employee.

Let me also say that this change means that employees will now not be denied a co-contribution just because they do not have employer superannuation support on their income earned as an employee. For example, this change will mean that employees without employer superannuation support who earn less than $450 per month or are under 18 and work less than 30 hours per week will be brought into the co-contribution measure if they make personal superannuation contributions. It should also be noted again that, whilst it is claimed that low-income earners will not be able to afford $1,000 to receive the co-contribution, people will receive a co-contribution for personal contributions of less than $1,000. Finally, more generally the co-contribution provides an opportunity for low-income earners to take advantage of a greater incentive than existed previously in order to improve their superannuation savings.

The Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004 gives effect to a number of the enhancements to the retirement income system announced by the Treasurer on 25 February 2004 in his statement `A more flexible and adaptable retirement income system'. The measures contained in this bill will simplify the superannuation guarantee earnings base arrangements, remove the requirement for prescribed pension providers to obtain an actuary certificate, align the portability time frame applying to retirement savings accounts providers with that of superannuation providers and introduce an integrity measure to require those under the age of 18 to satisfy a work test in order to claim a tax deduction for personal superannuation contributions. This bill also contains a technical amendment to correct a cross-referencing error in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 relating to the cancelling of registrable superannuation entity licenses.

In response to the points raised by the honourable members for Kingston and Braddon in relation to the Superannuation Laws Amendment (2004 Measures No. 2) Bill 2004, I would like to make the following comments. The first point raised by the opposition relates to the bringing forward of the date of effect for the simplification of the superannuation guarantee earnings base provisions from 1 July 2010 to 1 July 2005. The government considers that a start date of 1 July 2010 will allow for a smooth transition to a simplified superannuation guarantee system. The commencement date of 1 July 2010 will allow approximately two industrial bargaining cycles for employers and employees to consider and incorporate these changes into the bargaining process. The time frame allowed will ensure that the labour market is not undermined—which could potentially result in job losses—which is a possibility if implementation is rushed.

The opposition's proposal to require employers to appear before an industrial tribunal to put a case for a phased-in adjustment to an earnings base of ordinary time earnings would be costly and time consuming. A less cumbersome approach of having a reasonable time frame for implementation will allow both employers and employees to phase in the changes at a rate which is most beneficial to them, utilising existing industrial bargaining practices.

The second point made in relation to this measure was that the legislation would not remove any superannuation guarantee base that is more generous than the ordinary time earnings base. The superannuation guarantee requires employers to provide a minimum level of superannuation support for their employees. The proposed measure will remove references to all other instruments that can currently specify an earnings base for superannuation guarantee purposes—for example, industrial awards. This measure will not prohibit the specification of superannuation conditions in industrial agreements. Employers and employees will remain free to negotiate higher earnings bases or higher contribution rates in their industrial agreements. Where higher contributions are negotiated under industrial agreements, the employer superannuation guarantee obligations will still be determined with reference to the employee's ordinary time earnings. The obligation to pay the additional amount would need to be enforced in the same way as all other terms and conditions of the industrial agreement through the appropriate industrial dispute channel.

These changes will broaden the availability of superannuation and make it more adaptable to changing work arrangements. I am hopeful the government will receive support for both these bills, given the importance of increasing the attractiveness of superannuation and making the retirement income system more flexible and adaptable. I therefore commend the legislation to the chamber.

Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Mr Ross Cameron:

talk.start.para: —The measures contained within the Excise Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004 and the Customs Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004 should have been in place one year ago. Labor has previously indicated its support for the changes, particularly those which encourage the early introduction of ultra low sulfur diesel, known as ULSD. But, yet again, it has taken the government too long to implement them.

speech.para: The government first announced these measures on 31 May 1999 and it has taken five years for them to get this far. Meanwhile, refiners have been living with great uncertainty. At least one of them invested early and then found the incentives did not materialise as soon as was expected. Others have been waiting for security before they make the very large investment decisions to produce clean petrol and diesel. For them, time is fast running out as the deadline for the new fuel standards in 2006 rapidly approaches. Similarly, biofuel producers have faced years of uncertainty and backflipping under this government. It is not only fuel producers who have suffered as a result of the government's tardiness on these bills. Consumers should have been encouraged to use low sulfur diesel long before now. Cleaner diesel is better for the environment and better for public health, but Australia will struggle to meet its deadline for new clean fuel standards in 2006 because of the delay in the introduction of these bills into the parliament.

Further, Australia has been left behind in the vehicle technology stakes, with many advanced diesel engines not even available in Australia because our fuel quality is not yet good enough. This is just one example of the Howard government's disregard for consumers in the fuel sector. High petrol prices are putting financial pressure on Australian families. Most parts of the country are experiencing prices of at least $1 per litre and, of course, in many regional and remote areas the prices are much higher.

As Peter Costello has said, a big part of the problem is the war in Iraq and the instability in the Middle East—something for which the government surely must take some responsibility. High oil prices mean it is now the time to increase competition in the Australian petroleum industry and provide relief for consumers and their families. This is the best way of assisting motorists in the domestic market and that is why a Labor government will implement a six-point plan to put downward pressure on petrol prices. We want to break down the power of the big oil companies and help the motoring public. Conversely, this government has adopted a spectator approach to the emerging Caltex-Woolworths, Coles-Shell retail duopoly. This government is standing on the sidelines while retail petrol competition is being diminished and motorists are left even more exposed to the prospect of even higher petrol prices in the future.

Labor will ensure that consumers continue to have access to a competitive retail petroleum market. Our six-point plan will strengthen the Trade Practices Act and give the ACCC more teeth to take action against major oil corporations and their alliance partners misusing their market power to the detriment of the market and, consequently, the detriment of the consumer. A number of reports have recommended reform of the Trade Practices Act but the Howard government has refused to legislate them. Only Labor is committed to stimulating competition and, in this case, delivering lower petrol prices to consumers.

Minister Macfarlane claims, quite incorrectly, that Labor's plan would lead to the demise of the shopper docket scheme. Indeed, the ACCC has already undertaken a thorough investigation of the shopper docket scheme and found it not to be anticompetitive in any way. Labor's plan will encourage competition, not undermine it. But the point has to be made that the shopper docket scheme does, in turn, enhance the power of the major oil companies and their alliance partners—the supermarkets—and therefore, once again, makes it urgent that we get these most overdue reforms through this parliament. Minister Macfarlane's comments again demonstrate that the silly season has well and truly begun. Labor has no intention of moving against the shopper docket scheme.

There is also the longer term issue to be addressed in protecting consumers and ensuring access to reliable supplies and reasonably priced petrol and diesel. This government has had eight years to give Australia a national energy policy but it has done nothing. Its failure to produce a national energy policy that seriously addresses Australia's growing oil import dependency is leaving Australia increasingly exposed to external shocks, such as the war in Iraq, and motorists are increasingly exposed to higher petrol prices.

So far the only initiative the Howard government has taken is a token offering to the big oil companies to encourage more deepwater oil exploration. This is at a time when they have every incentive to explore and when oil prices are through $US42 a barrel. A Labor government will take the many steps that are needed to diversify the transport fuel mix and provide a buffer for Australian consumers and industry against global oil price shocks. This means doing more to promote biofuels, natural gas, LPG, CNG and synthetic fuels produced from technologies like coal-to-liquids and gas-to-liquids. All these fuels have environmental benefits as well.

Australia has an abundance of coal and natural gas and should be adding value to them, but the Howard government's only approach to energy policy is to export as much LNG as possible, even if the sale price undermines Australia's long-term interests. Even worse, the Prime Minister is now pretending to sell Australia's endowment of natural gas. Last week he told the parliament that he planned to visit California this week to lobby for a project which he hoped would result in the sale of $15 billion worth of Western Australian natural gas to the southern Californian market. Opening up new markets for Australia is a good thing, but there are a number of questions the Prime Minister must answer to convince the electorate that his meeting with the Governor is no more than a photo opportunity: (1) where will the gas come from, (2) where did the $15 billion figure come from, (3) what opportunities were other companies with gas interests in Australia given to put their case to build a receival terminal off the US west coast, and (4) given BHP has few gas interests in Australia, what guarantees has the government secured that any gas processed through BHP's facility will be Australian gas?

BHP has three gas interests in Australia. It has a one-sixth interest in the North West Shelf project and part ownership of the Scarborough and Scott Reef-Brecknock fields. The North West Shelf project is not marketing LNG to the US west coast. The Scarborough field is in deep water and distant from shore, 270 kilometres north-west of Onslow, off the Western Australian coast, and it is at such an early stage of appraisal that it is more than a decade away from development. The Scott Reef-Brecknock fields are also a long way offshore, some 350 kilometres north of Broome, and a long time from development.

The only two projects currently marketing gas to the US west coast are the Gorgon and Sunrise ventures, neither of which has any BHP equity. What lobbying is the Prime Minister doing on behalf of these Australian gas projects? It will be first in, best dressed, with respect to a receival terminal off the west coast of the US. There is likely to be only one receival terminal, and that factor of course will render the receival terminal that is eventually successful a monopoly project.

I just want to reinforce some of these points. The Howard government has had almost nine years to develop an energy policy in this country. This means not just dealing with electricity, gas and cleaner diesel fuels, as are addressed in this legislation, but taking an integrated national approach to energy policy, dealing with all the issues from upstream offshore oil and gas, right down through value-adding processing plants, through to transport fuels, right down to demand-side participation in our households and of course, along the way, reforms in the electricity and gas markets. We have seen very little of this.

We have seen the Parer report, which goes some way to addressing electricity and gas issues, but the government has moved on none of its recommendations. We have certainly seen no response from the government to the Productivity Commission's review of gas, the gas pipeline issue, access arrangements et cetera. Again today we see the Prime Minister rolling out, as his answer to an energy policy, going to see the Governor of California to talk about a receival terminal being proposed by just one company.

The House needs to be reminded that there are at least four companies vying to do the very same thing off the coast of California. It is right for us to ask the question: what opportunity have these other companies been given to secure Australian government support for their proposals? The Prime Minister might want to argue that BHP is an Australian company. That is a debatable point these days, and I would support that argument, but the Prime Minister has given the Australian community the impression that he is going to talk about a natural gas contract.

BHP does not have any gas in Australia—or certainly no fields in Australia that are currently being developed, outside its one-sixth interest in the North West Shelf project. As most members of the House would be aware, the North West Shelf project is pretty much committed, at least until a fifth train can be built, and that will be many years off indeed. By contrast, ChevronTexaco and Shell are partners in the Gorgon field—the field most likely to be the next big gas field developed off the coast of Australia. If ChevronTexaco and Shell, for example, were to secure a receival terminal off the coast of California, then they would be well placed to argue that they were in a position, in the medium term at least, to provide Australian gas out of Gorgon into that receival terminal and into California's huge energy market. But BHP cannot make any such claim. It does not have access to any gas. It does have an interest, as I said, in some fields well off the Western Australian coast, but they are at least a decade off development. So, if BHP secures the right to construct a receival terminal off the West Coast of the USA, how do we know that that gas will come from Australia? It is just as likely that that gas could come from other nation states.

But these are the questions that John Howard, the Prime Minister, is not able to answer. When asked yesterday, at a press conference before he left Australia, where the gas was coming from, he scratched his forehead and gave the wrong answer. He said that it was coming from BHP's existing fields. It cannot be coming from BHP's existing fields, and it was apparent from the look on the Prime Minister's face and the little scratch of the forehead that he had no idea what the proposal actually entailed. I saw him stumble again in a press conference held somewhere on the west coast of the United States, some time in the course of the last few hours. It seems that between his mistake yesterday and his press conference today he still has not been able to work out what in fact he has gone to California to do. These are the questions that the Prime Minister needs to answer.

I was having a look yesterday at a glossy BHP document which was designed for the consumption of US and, in particular, Californian residents. The glossy document showcased the receival terminal that BHP would build off the west coast of the US. Nowhere in that document was there any suggestion that the gas would be sourced from Australia. Indeed, nowhere in that document was there any indication of where that gas would come from.

These are important fuel measures that we are considering within the terms of these bills tonight—better late than never—but they are just one small piece of a wider jigsaw. You cannot just talk about clean diesel fuels; you also have to look at refining issues. You have to look at the retail petrol market and the wholesale market. You have to have a look at electricity and gas, and you cannot just be flogging LNG at every opportunity at bargain basement prices without some plan and some idea about what Australia's own medium- to long-term needs for fuels in this country will be. We do not have an energy policy in this country. We certainly do not have an integrated energy policy. We do not know where we are going, and it is about time the government put in place a plan to give some direction, because if they do not do it soon they will miss their opportunity—after 8½ years—and Labor will certainly do it for them.

talk.start.para: —Tonight we are debating two bills: the Excise Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004 and the Customs Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004. In brief, these bills propose changes to existing legislation in three key areas: one is the creation of a new customs and excise duty rate for ultra low sulfur diesel and high sulfur diesel, another is increasing the rate of both customs and excise duties on aviation fuels and, thirdly, these bills impose both customs and excise duties on biodiesel at the normal rate for ultra low sulfur diesel—that is, at 38.143c per litre.

speech.para: I would like to address each of these issues in turn. The first is the creation of a new customs and excise duty rate for ultra low sulfur diesel and high sulfur diesel. These changes impose both customs and excise duties of 1c per litre for high sulfur diesel on top of the normal rate from 1 July 2003 and 2c per litre from 1 January 2004. These duty rates were first announced by the Prime Minister on 31 May 1999 in the Measures for a Better Environment package. The new duty rates will give effect to the government's decision to encourage the early introduction of ultra low sulfur diesel, which will be mandated on 1 January 2006 under the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000.

Labor supports the initiatives to encourage cleaner fuels, there is no doubt of that; and we heard from the member for Hunter, the shadow minister in this portfolio area, about the importance of certain initiatives and about some of the things that the government should be doing. These initiatives are important; however, it is also worth noting that introduction of the ultra low sulfur diesel alone is not sufficient to achieve these results. The government must do more. It must actually have a full strategy and a full plan. As we heard from the member for Hunter, it has been a wasted opportunity of eight years—and it is not an uncommon story in this parliament that things that could have been done have not been done. Australia does not have an energy policy in terms of a national strategy, and it is something that I think is absolutely necessary and that Labor will take on in office. Other measures in this legislation include certain engine technology that is needed to achieve more satisfactory results.

It should also be noted that the timing of the introduction of these measures is interesting. It has taken well over 12 months for the government to introduce these bills. Again it is an example of wasted opportunities in terms of the government not acting and not taking advantage of the time when it is necessary but instead waiting for political opportunity and political timing to get to the point of introducing legislation. There is a raft of evidence—not just in terms of these bills—of the government acting this way in a range of areas.

The second issue that I want to go into is the increases in the rate of both the customs and excise duties on aviation fuels by 0.306c per litre. This measure was announced in the 2003-04 federal budget on 13 May 2003. The increased duty rate on aviation fuels is being collected to provide supplementary funding for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to ensure it is adequately resourced so that it can continue to carry out its safety regulatory responsibilities. The rate takes effect from 1 July 2003.

The third issue is the imposition of both customs and excise duties on biodiesel at the normal rate for ultra low sulfur diesel—that is, 38.143c per litre. This measure was also announced in the 2003-04 budget and forms part of the fuel tax reform arrangements to bring all currently untaxed fuels used in internal combustion engines into the excise and customs duty system. Both biodiesel and biodiesel-diesel blends will be taxed. Labor has previously indicated support for these arrangements, which in general encourage the introduction of cleaner fuels, particularly cleaner diesel. This should not be underestimated in terms of its impact and it is something that Labor recognises.

Some related bills have already been passed. For example, we have had the energy grants bills. These bills require early passage to implement administrative arrangements that should have been in place almost a year ago. The amendments proposed in relation to the diesel fuel excise and customs duty are designed to encourage production and use of environmentally friendly diesel fuels. This is important in order to encourage the right types of developments, technology, research and usage in this country, and it should form part of a broader national strategy. This is a key opportunity for government to act. This is where the government has the power at a national level to put in place the sorts of mechanisms that industries look towards and need. Again, I believe that this has been a wasted opportunity—eight years of wasted opportunity—for the government. This is something that Labor will deal with. This is an important issue and something that I am personally committed to.

These environmentally friendly diesel fuels are not just important for Australia; it really is an international issue and something that we as a nation should be taking a lead in and not just following. Whether the proposals can unfold to their full potential in the short term is yet to be seen. It seems that engine technology, especially catalytic converters, are necessary to actually achieve a reduction in harmful emissions—which is the primary goal of the policy.
The amendments in relation to aviation fuels are proposed to raise funds for CASA. However, the government has already foreshadowed in the explanatory memorandum that:

quote.para: The revenue from aviation fuel duty is estimated to be 11% lower than forecast as a consequence of cessation of Ansett operations, world-wide reduction in air travel demand and introduction of larger, more fuel-efficient aircraft.

speech.para: I suppose the latter part of that is actually a good thing—although there is going to be less revenue than was forecast. Certainly the introduction of larger, more fuel efficient aircraft and, I suppose, the reduction of air travel demand, are good; although I do not think that the reduction in air travel demand will last for too long. It is certainly not good that Ansett ceased to exist, but that is another debate for another time.

The amendments making biodiesel excisable are the result of the government's plan to create a homogenous excise system as suggested by the fuel taxation inquiry. The introduction of the EDR corresponds with the introduction of the Energy Grants Cleaner Fuels Scheme and should result in a zero excise rate for those qualifying for a grant. These sorts of bills give rise to the opportunity to talk not only about the specifics within these bills but also to look at the ancillary effects and the broader effects they will have. They also give rise to the issue—as has been stated clearly before—of the need for a national energy strategy. That is something that this nation can look toward as a plan for the future.

We in this place are often criticised—and I think rightly so—by people in the community who say that governments pass legislation or have policy to get them through to the next election. I think that sometimes is a fair criticism. We should be in here working as hard as we can to make sure we have long-term plans and strategies in place for the future, not just for the next election. Issues arising out of fuel—not just fuel excise, but refining issues; the reforms needed in the electricity industry; gas; liquefied natural gas, LNG; the way that the markets operate and a whole raft of issues that are intertwined into this kind of legislation—are, I think, essential in the debate.

I have spoken on a number of occasions about the market power of the major oil companies and the large corporates and also about the large retailers and the way they operate within the market. It is a matter of debate as to what should take place, but I think it is clear that there needs to be market control. There need to be mechanisms by which government has some enforceable power over predatory pricing policies within the oil industry and the market power of the major oil companies and retailers. This is an issue that was raised by the Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, in his address-in-reply speech to the budget, where he specifically referred to section 46 of the Trade Practices Act deals with issues of market power and market power abuse. I think this is critical and should form part of the thinking of government in coming to terms with how we deal with these bills and these issues.

The ACCC does have power to act in this area. I made some comments earlier this week in the parliament about my views, and I have written to the head of the ACCC to seek some guidance and advice on what the ACCC believes to be the case with market power of, particularly, the major retailers, Woolworths and Coles, and their association with the major oil companies. Certainly when talking about this, the shopper docket schemes come up. This has been a case of some investigation by the ACCC, who have determined that that in itself does not form anticompetitive behaviour.

The great concern I have is that, if we do not act in some way and look at curtailing the market power of the major oil companies, in the future there will be a time when the small independent fuel suppliers, the service stations and those related to that industry will simply close their doors because they will not be able to compete. It is a pretty simple equation if you look at what is going on. If you talk to the independent retailers and the suppliers, they will tell you that they cannot purchase fuel for a cheaper price than the majors sell it for at the bowser. You do not have to be a genius in business or mathematics to quickly work out that, if your competitor can sell it cheaper than you can buy it, sooner or later you are going to go out of business.

If this government is serious about supporting small business—if it wants to back its own rhetoric—and helping people, it ought to look closely at the market power of the big majors and how they are driving the smaller players out of the industry. I certainly believe that section 46 of the Trade Practices Act needs to be reformed to put a stronger emphasis on protecting small business from predatory companies, from predatory pricing policies and from abusive market power.

As I said, this government has had eight years to do something on fuel excise and a national energy strategy, and in real terms has done nothing. The government should not waste any more time. It should look at putting forward some legislation in the few months we have left before an election to try to make good some of its promises not only to small buiness but also to consumers. The government is quite prepared to take the credit when the prices are low, whether you compare it to international prices or local prices—and my view is that it is okay for the government to do that—but, on the other side of the coin, when prices are high it has to take responsibility. It cannot merely accept the credit when prices are low and push away the responsibility when prices are high—and this is something that we are seeing at the moment. Just as the government claims to be responsible when the prices are low, it is responsible when prices are too high.

Prices are too high for a number of reasons. Some may be out of the government's control—as it always says—but there is still some responsibility there. I will not get into the detail of why prices are high, because when people in the street go to the bowser they know why the prices are high: they are high because of the war in Iraq which has destabilised international markets and the fuel industry, causing the price of a barrel of oil to rise. There is no question about that; no-one can actually question that. Another reason is government policy. There is no question that government policy affects fuel prices. The government is always prepared to say that it is government policy when fuel prices are low—and I say okay, that is fine—but, when they are high, it has to be taken back the other way. The government is never prepared to do that; it is always prepared to push it away onto somebody else.

In summing up, these bills do a number of things that need to be done with fuel excise and customs. The government has certainly squandered eight years of opportunity to do something about a national energy policy. This is not a small issue; this is a big issue, a key area for this country and for the world. But we are just going to have to wait—hopefully not too long—for somebody to have the guts to get out there and do something about a comprehensive national energy strategy that not only deals with fuels and biodiesels but also looks at a whole raft of reforms and industries, not only LNG and gas but also LPG, and to look at trying to give direction to this country on fuel and fuel use in this country. This will certainly be the case under Labor. We have made our commitments clear, and I will certainly be continuing my campaign in making sure that we deal with these matters.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The government would like to thank those honourable members who have contributed to the debate on the Excise Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004 and the Customs Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004. It was interesting to listen to the contribution made by the honourable member for Oxley, who has now left the chamber. He spoke about the importance of small business. The coalition are the parties of small business. We strongly support small business; we make no apology for the fact that we recognise that small business is the engine room of the Australian economy.

speech.para: Quite frankly, if the member for Oxley was in any way, shape or form wanting to be sincere about the importance of small business, he would be encouraging his colleagues to pass the unfair dismissals legislation, which has been rejected by the Labor Party on so many occasions. That continuing rejection prevents people from getting jobs, and in fact has denied some 50,000 people nationally the opportunity of obtaining employment. I think that people get sick and tired of hearing members like the member for Oxley bleat on about small business. Small business is very important; the government recognises that but, unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party does not share our concern for that very important sector of the Australian community.

The amendments contained in the bills have previously been tabled as excise tariff proposals. The proposals now require incorporation in the Excise Tariff Act. The bill contains three government initiatives: the introduction of excise differentials between diesel with high sulfur content and ultra low sulfur diesel; an increase in excise duty rates for aviation fuels; and the imposition of an excise duty on biodiesel. The excise differential for high sulfur and ultra low sulfur diesel is part of the Measures for a Better Environment package introduced by the government to encourage production and use of cleaner fuels. I was pleased to hear the member for Oxley say that there are some very important initiatives in these bills, and the government certainly agrees with him on that particular point.

The production costs for ultra low sulfur diesel are higher than for high sulfur diesel. Without the differential, ultra low sulfur diesel would be uncompetitive in the marketplace, as users generally regard high and ultra low sulfur diesel as interchangeable and would not be prepared to incur the additional cost of ultra low sulfur diesel. The imposition of an excise differential is intended to even up the price between high sulfur diesel and ultra low sulfur diesel and reduce the price disincentive for the production of ultra low sulfur diesel. The bill amends the Excise Tariff Act to incorporate the excise differentials for high sulfur diesel and similar products with high sulfur content that may be used as diesel substitutes.

An increase in duty on aviation fuels is required to provide supplementary funding for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Duties on aviation fuels provide a substantial proportion of funding for CASA, which is estimated to receive 11 per cent less than the forecasted revenue due to reduced worldwide demand for air travel, cessation of Ansett operations and the introduction of larger and more fuel-efficient aircraft. The increase in duties will ensure that CASA is adequately resourced to continue its safety regulatory responsibilities and maintain Australia's enviable aviation safety record.

The imposition of excise duty on biodiesel was announced by the government in the 2003-04 federal budget—an excellent document, if I might say so myself—as part of the government's broader fuel tax reform arrangements that bring all currently untaxed fuels into the excise and customs duty systems. The reform establishes a broad, sustainable taxation framework providing increased certainty for investors, as well as establishing a fairer and more transparent fuel excise system with improved competitive neutrality between fuels.

You would recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that on 16 December last year the Prime Minister announced the final excise duty rates for fuels. Biodiesel will receive a discount of 50 per cent on the usual excise rate. This discount was set having regard to a range of industry, regional and other factors. Grants are provided under the Energy Grants Cleaner Fuels Scheme for the production of biodiesel fuels and biodiesel fuel blends. These grants will offset the excise duty, effectively providing an excise-free rate for biodiesel until 1 July 2011. After that date, the grants will be reduced by five even annual instalments until the final excise duty rate for biodiesel, 19.1c per litre—half the rate applying to conventional fuels—will be reached by 1 July 2015. Grants are similarly provided for imported biodiesel to offset customs duty. Complementary changes to the customs legislation are being addressed through the Customs Tariff Amendment (Fuels) Bill 2004.

Before I conclude though, I would like to touch on a couple of the matters mentioned by honourable members. The member for Hunter claimed that the government was lacking an energy policy. He made his comments in the context of the Prime Minister's visit to the United States and liquefied natural gas matters. I want to point out to the member for Hunter and to the member for Oxley, who also claimed that the government did not have an energy policy, that the Prime Minister has indicated that energy policy is a government priority and that he will be making a statement. I suggest that both honourable members examine that policy when released. They will find that the government is paying much greater attention to these matters than either of those members has expected.

The government does place a very high level of importance on the issue of energy policy—we are not going to apologise for that, and I think it is rather unfortunate that some persons in this place choose to assert propositions to the contrary, which could have the effect of misleading the Australian people. There was also comment in the debate on petrol prices and why they are so high. Let us just have a reality check. Members opposite should go out and take a cold shower and look at what the facts actually are. Of course nobody likes to pay higher fuel prices at the bowser or anywhere else, but we have to look at the reality of the situation. Australia enjoys the third lowest petrol and diesel prices among the 27 OECD economies surveyed by the International Energy Agency. Most people in the community understand that petrol prices in Australia are closely linked to international prices because domestic petrol producers have the option of exporting their product at world prices or selling it locally. Moreover, Australian refineries import over 60 per cent of their crude oil and other refinery feed stocks. Retail prices have risen as a result of rising prices for crude oil.

In November 2002, the average price of West Texas Intermediate, an international benchmark crude oil, was around $US26 a barrel. The price has risen to a high of over $US40 a barrel in May this year. Market analysts attribute the most recent rise in prices to concerns about hostilities in Iraq and the higher demand for petrol in China which has resulted in a general shortage of petrol in the Asia-Pacific region, including Australia. In response to community concerns over high fuel prices, the government reduced fuel excise by 1.5c a litre on 2 March 2001 and has abolished the half-yearly indexation of fuel excise introduced by the previous Labor government in 1983. Had these important initiatives not been taken, fuel prices in Australia would be much higher than they currently are. In other words, had the Labor Party policy been allowed to continue to be implemented, petrol prices and fuel prices generally would be much higher than they currently are. People ought to recognise that it was this government that had the courage to remove the half-yearly indexation of fuel excise and reduce fuel excise by 1.5c a litre on 2 March 2001.

I would also like to reassure anyone who is listening and, in particular, members of the opposition, that the ACCC continues to monitor fuel prices to ensure that this excise cut is passed on in full to motorists. The ACCC recently released its report detailing reasons for its decisions in relation to petrol discounting schemes and related arrangements.

It also ought to be recognised and noted that the Treasurer said on 17 May this year that the rising oil price has got nothing to do with a government policy or a tax. Nothing has changed in relation to taxation arrangements except that we cut the excise three years ago and it has not risen since. This is an international development and the current situation is caused by world international oil market prices. The member for Oxley claimed that the government should in some way, shape or form, take the blame for rising fuel prices. As I have indicated, the situation is related to the world situation.

The member for Hunter also claimed that there was some uncertainty for industry and consumers on standards. I want to put the record straight, in conclusion, by stating that the timely passage of these bills provides certainty, not uncertainty. It was the Howard government that put in place the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000, under which a standard for diesel has been made. After 1 January 2006, diesel with sulfur content greater than 50 ppm will no longer be allowed to be sold. The excise penalty on such high sulfur diesel contained in this bill encourages early introduction of ultra low sulfur diesel.

Both of these bills are very important. I do recognise that members opposite see that much of what is included in these bills is very important. We do reject the party political criticism that has been extended in our direction by honourable members opposite. I take this opportunity to commend both bills to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
