talk.start.para: —The opposition will be supporting the passage of the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2004 through the parliament. The purpose of the bill is to extend the government's Farm Help program. The bill extends the program to 30 June 2008. The bill also proposes a number of amendments that will tighten the administration of the Farm Help program. These changes to the administration of the program will shift its emphasis from welfare support to structural adjustment. The Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2004 follows the announcement contained in this year's budget that the program would be extended. The program provides up to 12 months income support at the Newstart allowance rate, a grant for professional advice to assist recipients in making decisions about their future in farming, and funding for re-establishment grants to assist people who have no option but to leave farming.

speech.para: The bill also introduces a number of administrative changes to the program that flow from a review of its performance and a report from the Australian National Audit Office in 2003. New requirements for income support and re-establishment grants mean that a person will have to undertake financial advice and develop their activity plan prior to receiving income support, except in cases of hardship prior to receiving a re-establishment grant. Farmers are currently required to arrange a financial assessment of their farm businesses within a three-month period. Under the new system, they must undertake the financial assessment of their farm businesses and develop an activity plan before their income support can commence. An approved financial adviser must now assess the farmer's prospects of getting additional finance.

These changes also provide for this assessment process to be varied for people in severe financial hardship. To qualify for this provision, the liquid assets of a person and their partner at the time of application must not be greater than the total amount of Newstart allowance that would have been payable in the immediately preceding six weeks. Hardship provision recipients will be provided with income support for a period of up to three months, while they undertake their financial assessment and develop their activity plan. Income support will cease if they have not done this within the three-month period. The recipient will then be assessed in order to qualify for the remainder of their income support.

The proposed changes will also enable reviews to be conducted of re-establishment grant recipients, to determine whether they are complying with their undertakings not to re-enter farming within a five-year period. There is also a provision to terminate Farm Help income support if a person or their partner is in receipt of an exceptional circumstances relief payment. The government is advised that this clause is designed to remove the possibility of a person receiving Farm Help income support and the exceptional circumstances relief payment at the same time. The re-establishment grant will also be increased to $50,000, up from the current $45,000. Labor supports these amendments to the program.

According to the minister, the underlying basis for these amendments is to shift the focus from providing welfare support to facilitating adjustment. I want to come back to that claim, in the context of the record of this minister in facilitating adjustment in regional economies, but firstly I want to have a look at the minister's management of this particular program. In this year's budget papers expenditure on the Farm Help program for this financial year is estimated at about $15.6 million. In last year's papers, the minister's forecast for projected expenditure in 2003-04 was $24.875 million. He has missed the mark by some $9.2 million—or nearly 60 per cent. The numbers in the budget for this coming financial year are back up to $34.44 million. So we now have a forecast for this coming financial year of more than double the estimated expenditure for 2003-04.

Through the Senate estimates committee hearings last week, Labor tried to get a fix on why all these forecasts have been so badly wrong. Part of the explanation given by departmental officers was the interaction of Farm Help with a number of other programs, particularly the 2002 sugar package. Members may recall that the 2002 package, the third of four packages put together by the government to carry this key rural industry through to better times, had an income support package with a limited life. When that household support program ended, canegrowers were expected to migrate to the Farm Help program. It is clear that they did not.

The income support component of the 2004 sugar package will end in March next year, and these budget numbers suggest that Mr Truss, the minister, again expects a large number of canefarmers will be forced onto Farm Help. I would like some advice from the minister on that, please, when he makes the summing up statement in this debate. I would also like some advice from the minister about the impact of income from the sugar package on the ability of canefarmers to access Farm Help—that is, farmers fail income and assets tests for Farm Help because of the assistance provided through the sugar package mark 4.

It is also important to note that you have to be in a very difficult circumstance to access Farm Help. Farmers must find themselves in the position where the banks are refusing to lend them money against their assets. If the minister's numbers for 2004-05 do turn out to be accurate, then there are certainly a lot of farmers out there who the minister expects to be facing very tough times indeed in the coming year.

The Farm Help program is a component of the Agriculture Advancing Australia package. This package has been around in various forms since 1997. The minister likes to call it his flagship. If you closely examine this particular program, you can get an understanding that this is certainly not a flagship at all. Currently the other components of this package include the Rural Financial Counselling Service, farm management deposits and the Agricultural Development Partnerships program, in addition to Farm Help.

Before looking at the administration of these programs, I want to make a few comments on the effectiveness of a key part of the Farm Help program—the re-establishment grants. At the end of 12 months, farmers on Farm Help support can seek assistance to leave farming by accessing this particular grant. The grant was originally $45,000. Through this bill, that will be increased to some $50,000, with an assets test applying. These exit grants have been a part of most industry restructuring packages developed by this government. In fact, they are available to qualifying farmers at any time, but the minister likes to add them in to industry support packages for a bit of political padding. In recent times they have proved to be little more than that—these grants are proving to be quite ineffective in assisting people to leave farming—and, therefore, in assisting the process of rural adjustment.

The 2002 sugar exit package contains such an exit grant. Those canegrowers accessing household assistance through the 2002 package—that is, those farmers able to meet tough income and assets tests—numbered in the order of 1,500 from an industry of some 6,000 farmers. That means that 1,500 growers were facing significant hardship. The minister had allocated some $30 million for exit grants in that package. He expected the number of exits to be 10 per cent of canegrowers—that is, around 600. That was the adjustment he considered was required to put this key sector of the agricultural industry on a long-term sustainable path. The re-establishment grant was the administrative tool he judged most appropriate to deliver that outcome. The result was just 16 exits, not 600. Minister Macdonald conceded in estimates last week that the quantum of the exit payments was based on the existing AAA package. In other words, no real consideration was given to what was required to facilitate adjustment. It was a case of just lifting the old program off the shelf, dusting it off and having another go. Of course, the result we got was no real adjustment at all. This was a real wasted opportunity by the government and by this minister.

Of course, the failure of the exit grants was not the only problem with this program. The whole 2002 package foundered. Now we have a new package and a new exit provision of up to $100,000 on offer. Again, the minister expects around 600 farmers to leave the sugar industry in 2004-05. Funding for this purpose for the coming year is set at $62.6 million. Around $1.4 million of that money will go in administration costs, including costs incurred by Centrelink.

I would appreciate some advice from the minister about the assets and income tests that will apply to the exit grants in this latest sugar package. I am also interested in whether the farm and the family house are included in the test and what the threshold number for the value of assets might be. I assume that once the income and assets threshold is reached, the farmer is excluded from accessing these exit grants, rather than there being a reduction in the grant as the value of the assets increase. I am also interested in what assessment has been made of how that test will impact on the access of farmers, particularly those with farms in coastal areas that would be worth a lot of money. All these matters are relevant to the bill, because, depending on the answers, the take-up of Farm Help will be higher or lower than the current forecasts that have been provided.

As I said earlier, this current sugar package is the fourth since 1998. If anyone wants to look at a monumental failure of government policy in eight years, it has been in the sugar industry. To add insult to injury, not only have they failed with the policy settings they have put in place for this regional industry, which is of such importance to northern New South Wales—including your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley—and to canefarmers in regional communities in Queensland, but in the US free trade agreement they have dropped it clear off the table. If ever there was an insult delivered to an industry, it was that one. If this latest sugar package fails to deliver adjustment, canegrowers and their communities will not be the only ones to suffer. The Australian taxpayer will suffer too, and it will be this minister who will have to be held accountable for the failure of policy in this industry.

If you look at the administration of the FarmBis program, you will find a similar sorry story, I am afraid. This program was designed to assist farmers through funding for education, training and skill development. It should be playing a very important role in upgrading farmers' skills, thereby steering them away from the path that would lead to Farm Help. There was significant funding for the program in the 2000-01 budget, but it was not spent. In the 2001-02 budget statement, the minister ripped some $41 million out of FarmBis. He put that money into the Agricultural Development Partnerships program—and I will come to that program in a minute. In the 2002-03 budget statement, the minister ripped another $9.2 million out of the Commonwealth-state component of FarmBis, to prop up funding for the National Food Industry Strategy. In the same year, he took money out of FarmBis again, for a southern bluefin tuna scientific research program. Last year the minister took another $2.5 million out of FarmBis, to fund an aquaculture initiative. In last year's budget, the funding allocation to the states for FarmBis was estimated to be $31.336 million. That number has been revised in this year's papers to $25.688 million. The allocation for next year is down by 50 per cent, to just $12.1 million.

Given that training is a very important part of improving on-farm productivity, you would have to ask why funding for this particular program has been so badly underspent. You would have to ask why the minister has chosen to raid this program every year to fund other projects, rather than fix it and get the money out to farmers on the ground. The minister always says that it is the fault of the states. That is his standard mantra when it comes to these particular issues. He says that about everything. The reality is that with most programs in this portfolio the problem is more to do with the ability of this minister to properly administer his portfolio. The maladministration of the FarmBis program is one shining example.

I now want to go to the administration of the government's Agricultural Development Partnerships program. We all know that this particular program was announced with great fanfare by the minister. It was another program that involved the states, and it was primarily designed to assist regional restructuring. But there was no expenditure at all in the program in 2000-01, nor was there any in 2001-02—and the next year again we did not see any expenditure in it. There was an allocation of funds in last year's budget paper of some $2.2 million—that was for 2003-04—and in the additional estimates we saw an increase in that allocation to $7.4 million. But we were told in the latest estimate round that the actual expenditure on this program for this financial year will only be in the order of $670,000—that is, 10 per cent of the funding allocation for this program will actually get off the ground.

This program has been around for years. It had a budget in the order of $25 million over four years when it was first announced—with, as I said, great fanfare by the minister. Its purpose was to fund, together with the states, regional restructuring initiatives. Now the minister has given up on the program. It is to be wound down and the funds will be used to plug holes elsewhere in the portfolio. Of course, as he did in the cases of FarmBis and other programs, the minister says that it is all the fault of the states. The minister cannot get on with Labor states.
Labor in government has had a long line of very good agriculture ministers. That goes back to Ken Wriedt—

talk.start.para: —Simon Crean?
—Yes, Simon Crean.
—Ha, ha!

—And it certainly goes to the great John Kerin and Bob Collins. The honourable member for Gippsland, the Minister for Science, scoffs at the fact that the honourable member for Hotham, Simon Crean, was a successful Labor agriculture minister. This is the thing that really sticks in the craw of The Nationals: the fact that the Labor Party continually throws up great agriculture ministers and The Nationals provide duds. That is the reality of it.

speech.para: Of course, this blame game is the one the minister always engages in. Federal Labor ministers were able to successfully get on with agriculture ministers from conservative states. Indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you would attest to this, I am sure, given your experience in the New South Wales government in your capacity there. But the sector has to continually put up with duds from an ever diminishing party that now represents the merchant bankers and lawyers in—

talk.start.para: —Collins Street.

—Yes, Collins Street, Melbourne. I find it extraordinary that the honourable member for Gippsland would come in here and interject at all. We certainly know that The Nationals represent farmers; they really do represent farmers. Indeed, they place their senatorial offices smack dab in the middle of the farming community—in Collins Street, Melbourne. Their hypocrisy knows no bounds. There is Senator McGauran, a Victorian senator from a rural area—the McGaurans, as I understand it, are well known in the Gippsland area—with his office smack dab in the middle of the farming community in Collins Street, Melbourne. That is not good enough. Indeed, we had the case of a Nationals senator in Queensland—and I will not mention any names here—who located his office on the 28th floor of a very prominent building.
—The 28th floor?
—Yes, the 28th floor, so he could look out on the cane fields in outer suburban Brisbane and watch the cane harvesters wafting through the suburbs. It is an extraordinary situation.

speech.para: There is another important program in the AAA package, and it is the Rural Financial Counselling Service. Funding for this program was scheduled to end this month. Members might recall that I asked the minister to advise 85 rural counsellors well before the budget whether funding and therefore their jobs were secure. Those representations came to me from farmers and rural communities, as well as the counsellors themselves. That certainty was also important for client farmers, who number on average 9,000 annually. But the minister made them wait until budget night to find out their fate.

Rural financial counsellors play a vital role in rural Australia, helping farmers, fishing enterprises and small rural businesses that are experiencing financial hardship. They have considerable skills and are well experienced in dealing with financial issues confronting people living in rural and regional areas—be they farmers or fishers. They have played a key role in ensuring many farm enterprises survive the worst drought in 100 years. They deserve certainty in their future employment, rather than being forced to wait until just a few weeks before their contract has ended.

While the minister could not find $5 million for rural counsellors prior to the budget, he had no trouble finding nearly $6 million for a pre-election advertising campaign. I want the farming community that is out there listening to this debate tonight to understand this fact: when I brought this matter to the government's attention—as did financial counsellors and rural communities—the minister could not find $5 million to fund the Rural Financial Counselling Service, which delivers a very important up-front service to farmers in difficulty at a very important stage in their particular enterprise. But the minister could find $6 million for an advertising campaign. Farmers are paying taxes to have the government line the pockets of advertising executives in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane.

I think that is an absolute disgrace. It is no wonder, of course, when you get National Party senators locating their offices among the Collins Street farmers. They slip down to the Melbourne Club. The Minister for Science ought not to try to deny this, because I have heard rumours that he is wont to walk the hallowed halls of the Melbourne Club with his brother, who is in the Senate. There they meet many Collins Street farmers—those who structure their taxation affairs as farmers to take advantage of the tax laws by minimising their tax. Of course, the honourable member for Gippsland and his brother from the Senate no doubt meet many Collins Street farmers there where they can chew the fat and pull the woollen shawl over their shoulders while they sit by the fire sipping their champagne and reds.

But, out in the farming communities, farmers really get upset at that. They get upset at the fact that National Party senators want to rub shoulders with the Collins Street farmers and then line the pockets of advertising executives to the tune of $100 million in advertising expenditure just before an election. Farmers are smarter than that: they do not buy the sort of political cynicism that says that you can create uncertainty in a vital rural program and then at the last minute meet the financial commitment to secure funding for that service and at the same time spend money on advertising like it is going out of style.

The minister has chosen to focus his efforts and his budget on the government's re-election by launching a taxpayer funded advertising campaign to massage public opinion over natural resource management. This advertising campaign, which involves the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Dr Kemp, is one of 18 campaigns to be run by the Howard government this year as part of its bid for re-election. Of course, the real value of funding to rural counselling services under the stewardship of this minister has continued to decline. It is a warped sense of priorities and the government ought to be condemned for it.

I want to make one more comment about the administration of this portfolio. There is an increasing concern both internationally and domestically about the administration of the quarantine regime in this country. I know the minister is receiving advice that the test that should be applied is whether or not decisions relating to import risk assessments would offend the WTO. The test is not the science but how the politics of the WTO can be best accommodated. We on this side of the House think that the science should be the test—not the threat of action through the WTO. We think the focus should be on getting the science right and then defending that position in the WTO or elsewhere. This is a very important issue, because if the minister or this government get these decisions wrong then it is certainly going to create an enormous demand for the resources and the programs that are provided in the measures that we are debating here today. As I said, we take issue with the government and with this minister on the administration of this scheme particularly, but we support the fact that it is part of the AAA package and we will support the passage of this legislation through the parliament.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak to the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2004. At the outset I want to pay tribute to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry for extending this scheme to help more farmers re-establish themselves in careers off their farms. In my electorate of Paterson, there are patches of farming communities which have over the years adjusted and changed what they farm or how they farm to improve their profits or re-establish themselves. Those who have been able to move with the times, read the writing on the wall and adapt to the changes in their industries have been able to weather the downturns. But there are some who for financial reasons could not adapt to change and these people may one day recognise that farming is not what it used to be.

speech.para: Last week my office was contacted by a dairy farmer called Brett from Gloucester. Brett's situation could not be any worse than it is today. Brett inherited the family farm from his father two years ago. Brett's father died somewhat early after a fight with cancer and left Brett with a farm and, of course, a mortgage. Struggling to make ends meet, Brett took out a loan from a finance mortgage company. This loan was tracked down and purchased by a person who could only be referred to as an opportunist. I prefer to use the term shark. This loan is now being called in, and Brett simply does not have the money to pay him back. Litigation is currently under way, so I will not go into any further detail on this matter today. But, needless to say, morally it just is not right that a loan company can sell a loan to a person intent on taking advantage of another person's weakened financial state. But selling such a loan is legal, and the situation could have been avoided if Brett had received sounder legal or financial advice on the situation and the style and unsecured nature of this loan.

Knowing that there is at least one farmer in my electorate who has been targeted because of his weakened financial position post dairy deregulation, in the midst of a major drought and also suffering the loss of the second pair of hands on the farm, makes this bill all the more important to me. Brett's situation paints a clear picture that this government should do all it can to help second-, third- and fourth-generation farmers find a way to earn a living off their farms. Things are different now from how they were 20 years ago, and they are extremely different from how they were 50 years ago. Often it is the philosophies and principles of today's farmers' grandparents which keep farmers on their properties for far too long. The idea that, as long as you have a farm, you will be able to make money is one that is no longer completely true. In Brett's case, Gloucester is currently facing the worst drought for 100 years, let alone 20 to 25 years. I know the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry is concerned that Gloucester is facing a crisis of a significant nature, and he will visit my electorate at the end of this week to meet with farmers to talk about this situation.

The simple fact is that if the rain does not come for three years in a row the grass does not grow. If there is no fodder for the cattle then the farmers must handfeed with manufactured hay. This drought, on the back of the deregulation of the dairy industry, has created a situation now where some farmers are asking `Why bother?' Some are getting out to ensure that their families have a better lifestyle. Farm Help could be of major benefit to Brett. Grants for legal, accounting and financial advice will help him to make correct decisions which are sound and which ensure that he does not take out another loan from a mortgage finance company—the type of loan that can be sold to opportunistic property developers and unscrupulously called in at a time when Brett can least afford it.

Retraining for someone like Brett will not be easy. All he has ever known is dairy farming, and he is only 40 years of age. Making a change at this time of his life will be very hard. He would be the first person to walk off the farm. But if he is deemed eligible for the Farm Help Re-establishment Grant he could benefit from up to $50,000 if he chooses to sell the farm and retrain in another field. As the minister rightly said in his second reading speech, a key component of this act is to refocus on adjustment, not welfare. It is appropriate that farmers have an obligation, when they receive assistance from the government, to undertake training or obtain advice which will prevent them from falling into a financial quagmire down the track.

The second provision is for people in severe financial hardship. Three months of financial support at the Newstart rate is paid to ensure that farmers do not have to truncate parts of the farm to pay for the everyday living expenses that they incur. They are given three months of Newstart and during that time they are expected to put together a financial plan which sets them on a path to self-sustainability again. The ongoing assessment of farmers in receipt of Newstart, to ensure that they are making plans which are sustainable, is also part of the scheme. This ongoing review is part of the mutual obligation component of receiving government assistance.

Extending the provisions of this bill through to 30 June 2008 recognises that, even apart from structural changes which governments introduce and implement over the next four years, farmers faced with natural disasters such as drought, fire and flood can access professional advice on what to do. This bill recognises that farmers who are making money today may not necessarily make money in a year or two years, and therefore an exit strategy should be there as an insurance policy for future natural disasters.

I have spoken about one farmer in the Gloucester district who has suffered a great deal due to the ongoing drought, low milk prices, a fallout from the deregulation of the dairy industry and the mercenary attitude of one local businessman. But there are many farmers in the Gloucester district who have not had the rain, their pastures are not producing enough fodder, and now they need assistance. Gloucester has suffered a comedy of errors. When the first application was submitted by the New South Wales government, this drought affected community was included with the Maitland City Council, which had received rainfall when Gloucester had not.

The second application, similarly, included areas which had received rainfall. The Gloucester Rural Lands Protection Board pulled out of that application. Instead, they worked with the New South Wales government to submit an application as a single shire or entity. This last application was found ineligible for assistance in April. The short story about Gloucester is that in every way they meet the hardship criteria to be deemed eligible for exceptional circumstances, but the problem is proving it. Their rain gauges are in the wrong location. In the first instance, they are outside the assessable area, in areas of high rainfall. Rain gauges have to be recognised by the Bureau of Meteorology, and there is only one rain gauge in the Gloucester application area that is recognised by the bureau. The others are outside the area.

In the second instance, Gloucester was measured for EC on a model that would be of use to Scone or Tamworth, but not Kempsey. So what is the difference? Kempsey needs more rain more often, as Gloucester does. Kempsey and Gloucester are similar types of areas. But Scone is a more arid area and can thrive on less rain than Gloucester. It pains me to stand up and criticise my own government's methods of determining hardship, but I will do it because I believe my constituents are in genuine hardship.

In this process, a local area must submit their application for assistance through the state government. We have to ask why. I understand that a shire or two shires may band together and prepare an application for exceptional circumstances, but surely there is no need for this application to be prepared by a state government. In the case of Gloucester, their application took 18 months—a good 12 months longer than it should have taken—to get the final answer. And, for expediency, the state department of agriculture combined Gloucester with two other areas nearby which had received regular rainfall. A system of Rural Lands Protection Boards has been established throughout Australia, and these boards have enough knowledge and expertise to put together an application for exceptional circumstances. They should be allowed to do this directly rather than by working through another layer of bureaucracy.

The other issue that I believe needs correcting is the need for an appeal process on the final application. In every other welfare scheme applicants have the option of taking their application to an appeals tribunal or panel to ensure that their particular circumstances are factored into their eligibility assessment. In the case of Gloucester, the positioning of the rain gauges has prejudiced the decision on their application against them. Gloucester being compared with Scone rather than Kempsey has prejudiced the decision. There must be an appeal process where Gloucester can argue the case of this hardship. Exceptional circumstances is about recognising that from time to time farmers face conditions which are extraordinary and prevent them from doing business. In the case of Gloucester, they have had as little rain as they have had in 100 years. There is no pasture to feed the herds and they are struggling to make ends meet. But, because the evidence presented on their behalf by the state government is flawed and not relevant to their particular situation, Gloucester has not been deemed eligible for EC status.

I have risen to speak on the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 2004, and I support measures which assist farmers to become more business savvy and aware of other options when farming becomes unprofitable for them. But there are times when we need to keep farmers on their farms and ensure they are able to keep going until the rains come again. I would hope that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry would look at the way exceptional circumstances assistance is applied for and granted. The lack of an appeals process needs to be looked at and a review of regulations and legislation for this scheme needs to be undertaken. At the moment, it is inefficient, ineffective and, in the case of Gloucester, unfair. As I said, this Friday the minister will be in Gloucester to meet with my farmers. We will put our case on why our farmers need this support.

It is no joy to read in the paper of family break-ups. It is no joy to read of yet another fatal road accident and have to ask the question: is that road accident an accident or is it suicide? These people are the very core of Australia—the foundation on which our society is built on. I am talking about people that put their backs and shoulders into the land to make it work to feed other Australians. They do what they do not because the money is there; they do what they do because they love the land that they live upon. I feel for a person like Brett, who is a fourth-generation farmer but the generation that has to look at walking off the farm. What will that do for his self-esteem? What will that do for his family's history? I will not let it stop there. We need to fight for the EC funding, and if change needs to be introduced in this House to allow an appeals process so that people can be fairly heard on the facts that pertain to their area then that needs to be done and the government needs to listen to what I have to say. I support my farmers. I will argue their case every day because I know and I believe they are right.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of this government's key program in delivering support to our farm sector, because this support is required to provide short-term income support to our low-income farm families. These are farming families who are experiencing financial hardship and who are unable to borrow further against their assets. This assistance in the form of professional advice will enable our farmers to make informed decisions about their future. An adjustment support assistance package will enable farmers who, through no fault of their own, have to leave the farming industry. It will make that transition that is so difficult that little bit easier on them and their families. In addition, it will enable access to skills retraining for an alternative career because, as the previous member who spoke in this debate has said, many of these people know nothing else but farming the land. Many of them have gone to university to ensure that the farming of their land is done in a more productive and efficient way but, unfortunately, the weather has beaten them. The circumstances are such that they are unable to continue in these areas and they do need alternative careers and advice on other employment opportunities should they choose to exit this industry that they love so much.

speech.para: The package is tailored to meet the needs of individual farming families, and that is something that I am very grateful for when I speak to many of my Riverina farmers who need various types of assistance. Some of them are in irrigation properties, they are smallholding properties, but the package does reward the farmer with some very good outcomes. Some of them are extraordinarily large properties and broadacre dry land farming properties but, because I have one of those electorates that has a diversity of areas, there is a very strong need for the government to provide individual choices and individual opportunities after the assets of farmers are depleted.

This program is flexible and, as I said, is currently tailored to meet the needs of each farm family. I am sure that all members are aware that farmers in my electorate and in rural communities throughout Australia have suffered enormously from the effects of this once-in-a-century drought. Life on the land presents many challenges, but this drought has tested many farmers, including many successful farmers, who have been forced to sell their stock, cart their water and watch their crops wither and die. Programs such as the Farm Help program that we have provided are so very important to our producers and also enable sustainability of the rural and regional communities which our farmers live, shop and work in. They are the basis on which schools, banks and a whole host of small businesses who service these farming families survive as well. This gives them an opportunity to have a choice as to how they want to exit the industry, if they need to, with some dignity.

It is important, particularly during these times in the farming sector, that programs such as Farm Help continue to provide ongoing support to the nation's farmers, and it is great to see this program being extended out until 2008. That is important. We are not nearly through this drought; this drought is going to be ongoing. In my electorate of Riverina, I do not believe that many of my farmers will get to plant their crops. Canola is being considered as one of the more lucrative crops in my electorate, but I am sure that many of my farmers are unable to plant canola for this season. This is coupled with the difficulty farmers had when Shepherds Producers were unfortunately brought to their knees, injuring an enormous number of grain growers in my electorate. Many of them will be looking forward to the extension of this program so that they can have, and retain, dignity in how they can move forward.

It is very difficult for farmers to move forward. Some of them are frozen in time. They really feel that they cannot make a decision one way or another about whether they should leave, whether they should stay, whether they should invest, whether they should borrow even more money or whether they should deplete their assets even further. It must be the most difficult position in the world.

Farmers are the backbone of the nation. I think they are the most underestimated and underrated people. My friends in the city think that, if they run out of milk, they can just go to the local Woolworths, Coles or delicatessen, open up the fridge and pull out a carton of milk with no knowledge of what it has taken to ensure that that milk is in that refrigerator for them to access. I sometimes think that maybe we need to have emaciated and naked people walking around before people recognise the great benefits that the farmers of this nation provide not only to this nation but also to the international program.

As I have said, this program is of significant benefit to farmers in the Riverina. It is a very tough industry, and the financial situation of a farmer and their outlook are dictated by those of us in this House who, like them, rely on the weather in order to determine whether tomorrow you are going to feed your family, educate your family or clothe your family. As I said, farmers are the backbone of the nation and should be treated as such.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The Howard government is failing in its responsibility to deliver real improvements to a sector that is one of the most undervalued professions in our society. I am referring to childcare workers—people who many of us leave our children with each day while we go to work; people who earn our trust and, therefore, deserve our respect.

speech.para: Childcare workers earn some of the lowest wages in the country. In Tasmania the over 1,000 childcare workers earn, on average, $12 to $13 an hour—so there will be no tax cut for them—and yet they have possibly one of the highest levels of responsibility within our community. Childcare workers are developing and educating children in what is recognised now as their most important stage of life: zero to five years. Despite what some people perceive, childcare workers are not babysitters and it is time that they were given the respect, the recognition and, most importantly in this debate, the remuneration that they deserve. The community and this government need to recognise that our perceptions of the work of childcare workers often lag behind the reality of the very complex nature of this industry.

The demands on the provision of this service have increased exponentially over the last few years. I believe the crisis in the child care industry is in part because the Howard government refuses to fund child-care centres appropriately. In Tasmania, community led organisations still remain the dominant management system in the child care industry, but this is in danger of following the mainland trend if something is not done urgently to rectify the funding predicament within the sector. Profit should not be the driving and motivating factor of child care. It is not fair to expect childcare workers to maintain their level of responsibility to properly mentor, shape and assist in our children's development when we effectively say to them that the work that they do is of no value.

Childcare workers must complete at the bare minimum a two-year full-time TAFE course. However, many childcare workers have also completed an optional extra year of study for an advanced diploma. There are also many more childcare workers who are actually trained teachers with degrees in early childhood education. These workers are not unskilled labour. They are highly educated and trained professionals who should be treated and paid as such.

Childcare workers spend a lot of their time planning individual programs for our children so that each child receives the best one-on-one care and attention to ensure that their cognitive and developmental needs are met. They do not spend the day playing in the sandpit or organising drinks. However, these individual programs take time and effort. At the moment, each worker is allowed one hour per week to develop individual plans for all the children in their care. This is on top of the increasing load of other paperwork childcare workers are now expected to complete—an expectation that is not built into any sort of increase in their hours or their remuneration. This extra paperwork is an added responsibility for an already overworked and underpaid industry, where the repercussions can really go in only two ways: an impact on the workers, who already have a massive and growing burnout rate, or an impact on our children.

The workers at the centre that my children attend are impeccable and my children adore them, but, like other parents, I do not want the childcare workers who work with my children to be so professionally stretched. I also want them to be the same workers day after day. Childcare workers are currently in the process of implementing a new curriculum based on the same curriculum that is being implemented in Tasmanian schools. The work the childcare workers do is as important as that of the teachers in the school system.

Labor is committed to highlighting the importance of early development and learning, and this is being done through policies like the early reading program. Childcare workers in Tasmania are equally committed to the early development of our children, but they need our support. They need our recognition of the work that they do and they need to be appropriately rewarded for this work. The Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union in Tasmania is currently embarking on a campaign—a campaign shared around the country by the excellent union workers—to highlight the situation of childcare workers. They can start the campaign, but it is up to us as legislators, community members and parents to support the people who support our families.

talk.start.para: —Last year I chaired the House of Representatives Select Committee on the Recent Australian Bushfires. That committee produced a report, A nation charred: inquiry into the recent Australian bushfires, with 50-odd recommendations. I think it is an excellent report. It certainly contains a substantial amount of information that came from predominantly volunteers—people who are out there on the ground; people who know their country and know how fire reacts. For a lot of them it was very difficult to give the sort of evidence that they did. They had been through a horrific experience in the 2003 bushfires.

speech.para: That report is with the government at the moment. I know the government is working on a response in conjunction with a report by a committee set up under the COAG arrangements. I hope that the government comes back to us very shortly with a response to the report, because many people out there on the ground certainly want to see some action in relation to the recommendations that we made. There have been some actions. Particularly New South Wales, Victoria and the ACT have governments that did not oppose our inquiry but certainly did not cooperate with our inquiry in any way and did not allow any of their public servants to appear. I think they have started to make some things happen but in very limited areas and without any recognition of the recommendations made.

We have seen a bit of a flurry in fuel reduction in a few places, but no overall planning, no long-term planning, for fuel reduction. It is certainly still the case that very little is being done with respect to access to forested areas and fire trails. I was in the Deua National Park—an area that used to be part of the state forest area—in my electorate recently. The original roads there were superbly built. They were built so well that they actually had concrete drop structures and drainage lines. But, since it has become a national park, a lot of these roads have been virtually destroyed. They have gone in there and built huge rollovers and things like that and have totally upset the drainage. You have table drains that were very well built being blocked by these sorts of rollovers to prevent access. Certainly there is no way in the world that you would get fire tankers into that particular national park if a fire broke out. So the things that happened in 2003 could happen again.

We have heard talk about changing insurance, and I know that the Insurance Council recently have said things similar to what we recommended in our report—that the levy on insurance policies should be dropped in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania and that it should be applied through the rates system. It is good to see the Insurance Council agreeing with that, and I think in New South Wales the Public Accounts Committee is currently looking at that aspect and is going to report in a couple of weeks. I hope that they also pick up on our report. I doubt that they will make any reference to our report, because once again the New South Wales government wanted to close their eyes to it.

I want to quickly say a couple of things about the ACT inquiry, the coroner's inquiry, that is still under way. I think most of the evidence coming before that inquiry is in line with the evidence that our committee received. I am very concerned about some of the evidence coming in about the cross-border cooperation—or lack of cooperation—which we highlighted in our report as well. The evidence coming forward calls into question the coroner's report in New South Wales. They actively discouraged people from putting in submissions for the New South Wales coroner's report. The coroner then brought down a finding saying that National Parks and the rural fire service did a great job. That is contrary to all the evidence that we received and it is contrary to the evidence that is coming before the ACT committee. I think there should be virtually an inquiry into that coroner's inquiry in New South Wales, because it would seem to me that there was some interference along the way, because there is no way in the world that you could come down with the recommendations—or lack of recommendations—that that coroner did. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Margaret Edgar is 71 years old. She continues to care for her 44-year-old son who has an intellectual disability and epilepsy. Kenneth has limited verbal skills and needs assistance with all areas of his life. Margaret's health is deteriorating—she has heart problems, osteoporosis, anxiety and depression. Kenneth is very demanding and takes up a lot of time and energy. If his mother cannot understand him, he will physically drag her to show her what he wants. She worries about finding supported accommodation for him. She worries about what will happen to him if she is no longer there for him. Caring for Kenneth is heavy work.

speech.para: Mrs Edgar, one of my constituents, is also one of many thousands of parents and carers in similar situations. In my home state of Western Australia, there are an estimated 300 people with disabilities and their families who are currently unable to access the accommodation support they critically need. According to 2002 estimates by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, there are 21,000 people nationally whose need for supported accommodation has not been met.

In their recent budget the government claim that they have `recognised the contribution of carers'. They herald their measures, but what is there for Mrs Edgar and carers like her? I note in the budget that the government have set aside $73 million over the next four years for parents over the age of 70 to access four weeks a year of respite care, of which Western Australia will get approximately $2 million—perhaps $3 million. While I am sure that the respite will assist to some degree, it really misses the mark when you consider that 70-year-old parents of severely disabled children are looking for supported accommodation long term, not four weeks respite a year.

I also note that a $255 million program will give a one-off carer's bonus to eligible carers in June 2004. A parent of a disabled child from my electorate summarised her thoughts on these two budget measures in an email to me shortly after they were announced. This is what she had to say:

quote.para: They miss the point, yet again. Ageing carers are looking for accommodation, not 4 weeks respite a year. Over 70s are usually on a low income and cannot afford to have a holiday. They need to know that their child is accommodated in a safe secure place. They need peace of mind not a break.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: WOW a whole $600 a year, to show how grateful the government is to carers that cant get the Carers payment. This is—

speech.para: less than—

quote.para: $50 a week, that is a packet of incontinence pads. I'm sure this will win votes. The $255 million would be better spent in urgently needed services.

speech.para: By `urgently needed services', the mother goes on to explain, she is talking about funding for supported accommodation.

The fact is that in Western Australia the state government has recognised the importance of providing assistance to parents of disabled children by addressing the biggest single issue: funding for supported accommodation. The WA government will be allocating 93.5 per cent of the growth funding for supported accommodation and related support services, compared to just a 6.5 per cent contribution by the Howard government. Over the five-year life of the Commonwealth-State-Territories Disability Agreement, the Howard government will provide only $3.4 million growth funding, compared to the WA state government contribution of $49 million. If the Howard government wanted to match the Western Australian government contribution, they would have provided an additional $12.3 million recurrent funding over the next four years just to keep pace with the rate of growth in state funding and the indexation provided.

How we treat people with disabilities and the people who care for them is important. How governments provide for these people speaks volumes about that government's values and character. Carers face higher costs of living, are underrepresented in education and employment, and face emotional and physical stresses that many of us here cannot even begin to imagine.

We have an estimated 2.5 million carers in Australia who care for family members or friends with a disability, mental illness or chronic condition or who are frail aged. A conservative estimate of the economic contribution of carers to Australia is that their care saves government $16 billion of expenditure annually. Carers are the major providers of community care services, delivering 74 per cent of all services to people needing care and support. The Home and Community Care program, worth over $800 million nationally, meets only nine per cent of this need.

Many members in this place endorse the notion of mutual obligation. These figures clearly demonstrate that the Howard government is shirking its responsibilities, free riding on the backs of people like Margaret Edgar. I urge government members to talk with carers, meet with them and listen to them. They do not expect governments to wave a magic wand, nor do they expect an overnight solution. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Shortly before 5 p.m. today, a division was called—as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, because you were in the chair—on a suspension of standing orders. I found myself in an unusual and probably invidious position, due to the fact that I was very engrossed in a conversation with the member for Mackellar on details for a standing committee hearing in my electorate of Barker, in Murray Bridge. We were going through those details and, because I was so engrossed, I did not realise the urgency of what was happening.

speech.para: I have tried to check with Hansard on this matter. I note that it is the only part of the `turns', as we call them, that is not on the Internet. You can go from turn No. 1 right up to No. 62, and that is on the Internet. Then there is no No. 63, which actually takes in that period; then there is No. 64 and right up to No. 73. So we have No. 1 to No. 62, no No. 63, and then Nos 64 to 73. I do not know what is happening here. I actually rang up Hansard twice and said that I wanted to find out what was recorded in the Hansard, because I think it is very important that, as politicians, we get it right. Unfortunately, I have not got the actual Hansard, because it is not on the web site yet, even though I have put in two calls to find it. I was actually promised that it would come through but it still has not.

I do not want to reflect on the chair; I have a very high respect for the chair and the position of the Speaker. But many people said to me afterwards that a one-minute division was not announced. It was just announced that the bells would ring but not that it would be for one minute. None of us is perfect. These things happen, and I suppose, because of that, I did not note the urgency of the matter. I was certainly unaware of it. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think the convention is that, unless a one-minute division is called, it is a division for four minutes. Whilst I do have great respect for the position of Speaker—and also for you, Mr Deputy Speaker—I certainly do not want to reflect on your ruling. Based on what was happening at the time, I do not think that I can argue with your ruling. I note that the member for Mackellar did ask for a recommittal of the vote, for which there are precedents, but that was denied. Because of the respect that I have for the position of Speaker, I remained in my seat as directed, even though I had no wish whatsoever to support this stunt by the Labor Party.

It was only a procedural motion to suspend standing orders—not a substantive one. It was certainly not a substantive motion on policy. I wish to have it recorded that, like the member for Mackellar, I did not and I do not support these Labor stunts. It may have provided some humour in an otherwise tense chamber, and for this I am sure that we welcome this minor diversion. I have accepted the general ribbing that has happened as a result, but I did want to record the fact that I did not support—even though I am probably down in the voting as supporting it—this stunt. I certainly did not wish to. I could have walked out of the chamber; but again, because of respect for the chair, I did not do that. As I understand it, my vote would have recorded the same way, so I did not know.

In the brief time I have left, I have another very important issue to raise: the Mount Gambier Hospital issue. The state budget has not increased funding for the Mount Gambier Hospital. It is still at the same funding as it was two years ago, even with extra funding of $10 billion, matched by the state government. With $20 billion extra going into health, that should mean another $1,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. In Mount Gambier they have not got that extra funding. The local member, Rory McEwen, has been asleep at the wheel, and it is about time this was raised in this forum.

talk.start.para: —This evening I would like to talk about access to public housing. This is an issue which is very important for many Australians—not least of all for many people in my electorate of Oxley. Australia currently faces a national housing crisis. There is a very serious shortage of low-cost rental housing in both public and private sectors. In relation to the private sector, housing affordability has been steadily eroding. It is estimated that more than 500,000 private rental households throughout Australia are in what I call `housing stress'—that is, they are paying more than 30 per cent of their income in rent.

speech.para: In the public sector, public housing waiting lists are growing rapidly. I am very concerned also about the lack of growth in public housing stocks in Queensland, the significant number of people on waiting lists and, of course, the homeless. Funds for public housing have declined rapidly in real terms. In 2003-04 the federal government will contribute just $930 million. This represents a decline in real terms of over $300 million since 1995-96. The federal government's contribution to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in 2003-04 is 25 per cent less in real terms than it was in 1995-96. The additions to the public housing stock are barely 5,000 dwellings per year, compared with an estimated 150,000 private sector additions, which has little impact on waiting lists.

Further, much public housing stock is aged, requiring significant maintenance, substantial replacement or refurbishment. It is evident, therefore, that existing housing policy approaches are patently inadequate. The Howard government has reduced public housing expenditure, transferring those funds to rental assistance. On the surface that might sound okay, because people are getting it through rental assistance, but it causes a range of problems. Increased rent assistance does not increase the supply of affordable housing. The Howard government's rental assistance policy is a dismal failure—leaving many Queenslanders without a roof over their heads. The Howard government has spent more than $3.4 billion in federal government rental assistance payments in Queensland alone, yet housing continues to be unaffordable for thousands of Queenslanders. This money would have been better invested in new public housing construction. Put simply, the Howard government's approach does not provide relief for those families signing up for public housing.

What Australia needs is a national housing strategy that specifically addresses this problem and restores the commitment to public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement. What we do not need is the politics of neglect and expulsion that is the Howard government's approach to housing. These are the real objectives upon which Labor are developing a national housing strategy to provide affordable housing for all Australians.

I would like to commend the Queensland state government for its efforts to address housing issues. The Queensland department of housing, through its community housing service area, works in partnership with not-for-profit organisations and local governments to provide community based solutions to local housing needs. Funds are distributed to organisations to provide crisis, transitional and long-term accommodation; information, advice and advocacy to residential tenants and people in housing need; and, importantly, it provides housing support information and assistance for older people and people with a disability living in their own home or renting privately. But with the Howard government ripping millions of dollars out of Queensland's new housing construction market, it is hard to meet the demand for public housing—an area very much under strain.

In the minutes I have left, I would also like to put on the record that there is a new public housing development of nine residential units in my old home town of Inala. Inala has come a long way in recent years. The success of Keith Brown Place is a tremendous story. This is a traditional public housing area where the state government has poured a substantial amount of effort in not only to refurbish public housing and make public housing more affordable but also to build new houses and units. State minister for the area, Henry Palaszczuk, councillor for the area, Les Bryant, and I recently opened the new housing development in Inala at Keith Brown Place. It really is a testament to Keith Brown, who has been serving the community in Inala for more than 50 years of his life. He is a great contributor to the community. I was very proud just to participate in and share the wonderful experience of having those nine housing units named after him. It is a true acknowledgment of his success as a community worker and also an acknowledgment of the need for public housing in Queensland. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Robertson Electorate: Ettalong War Widows Guild Club

talk.start.para: —I wish to pay tribute to the Ettalong War Widows Guild Club, which celebrated their 50th anniversary at a luncheon on Monday, 31 May this year—last Monday. It was held at the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club. Unfortunately, parliament was sitting and I was unable to attend this very important function. The Robertson electorate has a very high population of veterans and war widows, and it is very important that we have community organisations there to support our veterans, their families and the widows of veterans in our community.

speech.para: The Ettalong War Widows Guild Club was formed in 1954 due to the initiative of Mrs A. L. Watkins, the State President. Mrs Watkins invited Mrs Winifred Hopkins, Mrs Hounsell and Mrs Williams to become foundation president, secretary and treasurer respectively. The meeting was held in the old Army tin hut at Ettalong, the first quarters of the local RSL sub-branch on 24 May 1954 at 8 p.m. and was attended by 16 ladies. The first meeting was held at the home of Mrs Hopkins on Wednesday, 2 June 1954 at 8 p.m. and ladies from the Country Women's Association and representatives from the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club attended this meeting, and I believe that they have had representatives attending annual general meetings since that date.

Five years later this small band of ladies purchased a block of land, which was donated to state headquarters, on which Vasey Court was built to house war widows. This property is now owned by Brisbane Water Legacy. The Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club has had a close association with the War Widows Guild since its inception and has been most helpful in providing afternoon tea, a room, equipment and staff to assist them. They certainly appreciate the assistance of the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club.

Members of the guild take part in Anzac Day celebrations locally and also the Field of Remembrance held at St Andrew's Cathedral in Sydney, the annual War Widows Walk and the Members Christmas Party. Several members have represented the guild on the state council. Their patron, Mr Bill Hall, had been associated with them since 1971 as secretary-manager of the Ettalong Beach Memorial Club. He became their patron in 1980. After 23 years of loyal support and friendship, Bill passed away in February 2003. Bill Hall was someone I was very proud to be able to call a friend. He was a great veteran and he did a tremendous amount of work for the Ettalong and peninsula community. He has certainly been sadly missed since he passed away just over 12 months ago.

Mr Ruth Winser is the present patron of the guild. Their president is Mrs Joyce Davis; their vice-presidents are Mrs Gloria Parkes, Mrs Iris Sommerfield and Mrs Doris Wills; their honorary secretary is Mrs Dorothy Beardman; their assistant secretary is Mrs Dorothy Robertson; their honorary treasurer is Mrs Eileen Redrup, OAM; their assistant treasurer is Mrs Muriel Draper; their social secretary—a very important role—is Mrs Beryl South; the assistant social secretary is Mrs Mavis Rasmussan; their publicity officer is Mrs Betty Johnston; their hostess is Mrs Valerie Barnard; and their refreshments committee is Mrs Joy Howell and Mrs Irene White.

The Ettalong War Widows Guild has provided support and encouragement for war widows for the past 50 years—and, for someone who was born in 1954, this is my entire lifetime. Their role is becoming increasingly important as the years roll past and more and more of our veterans unfortunately pass on, many of whom are survived by their widows. I pay tribute to the Ettalong War Widows Guild for the support and the assistance they provide in our community for the war widows of the Central Coast.

interjection.para: (1) acknowledges the role of Australia's war correspondents in the wars, conflicts and peace-keeping roles in which Australian military personnel have served since the Boer War;

(2) celebrates the high standard of journalism, reporting, pictorial data and electronic material that has marked the war correspondent in keeping the Australian public well informed at times of heightened national concern;

subdebateinfo.title: Chisholm Electorate: Victorian Government Funding Initiatives

talk.start.para: —Residents in Melbourne's east and south-east will benefit greatly from expanded dental services and new school facilities, as part of new funding initiatives announced in the recent Victorian state government budget. Stage 1 of the proposed Glen Waverley Secondary College facilities redevelopment has been funded to the tune of $7.8 million. The college council has also allocated $1.8 million to the project, which will see the development of a new arts centre, a new library and a language centre. The senior students centre will be expanded and a new two-storey classroom block will be established to house a performing arts centre, an information technology centre and a range of reconceptualised learning spaces. The college community envisages that this redevelopment will place the college at the forefront of innovative curriculum based facilities design. This state school is already a fantastic resource, with over 1,900 students in attendance.

speech.para: Box Hill Senior Secondary College was allocated $4 million to complete the final stage of its facilities upgrade. The school's arts centre, main building and library will be upgraded over the next 12 months. This is a fantastic, innovative school that has a year 11 and 12 program only. Speaking of Box Hill Senior Secondary College, the Victorian government last week announced that a $1 million school catering specifically for young and upcoming elite tennis players would be built at the college. The school, for students from grades 5 to 9, will run a specialised tennis program, which will feature specialist classrooms, training facilities, tennis courts, flexible relevant curriculum and Internet based online learning for students. The concept of a tennis school for middle-year students expands on a successful sports programs developed already at the college. The college has a fantastic AFL program and a basketball program already in place. These are very innovative ideas.

The Victorian government has also announced that it will provide $1.2 million to fit out a new dental clinic in Box Hill and around $2 million annually to support its operation. This is a much needed and welcome service, as more than 4,000 people are currently on the Whitehorse Community Health Service dental waiting list. The new Whitehorse clinic will grow from having one dental chair to 10, when it is fully completed. Six of the chairs have been allocated for community and youth dental programs, two have been allocated for the school dental service and two will support undergraduate clinical experience of dental professionals from the University of Melbourne. This is fantastic for students who do not get to have much clinical placement. The clinic will operate on an extended hours basis, increasing significantly the number of hours of care to be provided and reducing waiting times. I want to acknowledge the fantastic efforts of the CEO of the Whitehorse Community Health Service, Andrew Fleming—it is largely because of his efforts that this has happened—and wish him well in his new endeavours. I also want to acknowledge the service's board in making this new dental clinic a reality in Whitehorse. It will greatly reduce the discomfort of many people within my electorate who have been waiting way too long to have their teeth looked at.

talk.start.para: —The community response to the government's budget allocation of $20 million for the National Community Crime Prevention Program can be taken as encouraging proof that this program has struck a chord with grassroots Australia and will be embraced positively by the community. The reason for the response is that, undoubtedly, it is seen as a crime prevention campaign that starts in the right place—at the grassroots level in communities themselves. Local grassroots community organisations in my electorate of Petrie are already signalling their approval and support, and they are ringing up to say that they think the program is exactly what is needed to fight crime before it begins. They are also thanking the Australian government for recognising the contribution that their organisations are already making towards the safety and security and the quality of life of the communities they serve.

speech.para: These organisations are the backbone of this nation. They are volunteer groups who look after the young and the lost, the elderly and the lonely, the vulnerable and the needy, and the hungry, the homeless and the people at the margins of our communities and society. They are worthy organisations, and they are running church welfare groups, our neighbourhood drop-in centres and our parish soup kitchens. They are the local sports groups volunteers who devote their time after work and their weekends to keep young people motivated and out of trouble. They are the caring friends who look after each other's property and the wellbeing of their elderly neighbours who may be living on their own.

They are organisations like the Red Cross; Neighbourhood Watch; junior soccer, football and swim clubs; and church based organisations like Aspley Care, which operates out of St Dymphna's Catholic Church. I have sent my own children there. Father Peter Luton of St Dymphna's was one of the first callers I heard from last week when the government's National Community Crime Prevention Program was announced and applications were called for in a series of advertisements in the Australian. Father Luton personally embodies the qualities and commitments on which the National Community Crime Prevention Program depends and the reason it works. No-one is better placed to understand the grassroots situations that give rise to community crime, petty theft, vandalism and random violence—which this program will tackle—than Father Luton. Parishioners have been inspired and they are channelling all their energies into doing something about looking after others. There are people who are at the fringe, Father Luton says, who do not have food, clothes, shelter or somewhere to sleep. They are people who are most likely to be pushed into crime out of sheer necessity. I am not saying that they are criminals; I am saying that their situation will lead to crime in most cases.

This is a nation of caring people. The government acknowledges the contribution they make to our communities, and that is why we are making a $20 million investment in the ability to do so. I think this will be a terrific program and I look forward to working with organisations such as the Red Cross, the Rotary Club and other organisations that will make daily phone calls to local elderly residents living alone, to check on their security and safety. I am already continuing to work with these communities to further expand the program. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On 2 June 2003 in the House I spoke on the death in custody of an Aboriginal person, Douglas Bruce Scott, that occurred on 5 July 1985. At the request of the family, I tabled a forensic report in relation to that death. Shortly I will seek leave to table two further forensic reports in relation to that matter. The first report is from Guy Nathan Rutty of the University of Leicester dated 5 April 2004. In his summary, he says:

quote.para: ... due to the lack of information forwarded to them—

speech.para: that is, the earlier forensic reporters—

motion.para: that “whether the manner of death is suicide or homicide cannot be accurately determined based on the submitted material”. I agree with this and in fact state that it would be wrong to assume that the contents of my report imply or should be used to only consider that this was a homicide. The recommendations of the international report go on to say that there were a number of inconsistencies and observations that raised the possibility that the death may not be suicidal. I agree with that.

speech.para: There is a further report from Cyril Wecht of Pennsylvania, dated 20 April 2004. He says:

quote.para: It is not possible to anticipate what the condition a body may be in following prolonged burial. If Mr Douglas' body has been well preserved, it could be possible to find evidence of some soft tissue injuries involving the head, face and/or neck that would be more compatible with a homicidal strangulation than a suicidal hanging.

speech.para: The widow of Mr Scott is seeking exhumation of the body so that further testing can be done. She has never accepted the original report of the royal commission into the death in custody. She believes that there were other possibilities. She has forwarded extensive material to forensic people around the world and they have submitted reports. Ms Scott has taken her case to the Northern Territory Supreme Court, but she is certainly in need of additional finances and resources to pursue a final investigation into her husband's death. This situation will not go away. On the material placed before them, the forensic reporters did not rule out the possibility that it was other than suicide. I think it is in the interests of justice that Ms Scott be given some assistance. I seek leave to table the two forensic reports that I have referred to.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I have shown them to my colleague. (Time expired)

—Several months ago, a man in my constituency died from electrocution while working near a swimming pool at his motel business. He had drilled a hole into a brick wall to gain access to wiring for a job he was doing to relocate a power switch. He was not an electrician but he had called a mate, an electrician, to get the job done. The electrician told him not to do anything until he could get there in a few days, but the tradesman, having confidence in his own abilities, went ahead anyway. After he drilled the hole, he inserted a metal wire probe to latch onto the wiring and to draw it out so that he could make the connection to the installation he was working on. Unfortunately, the wiring harness had perished over time, possibly through acid fumes from the pool chemicals. The live wire had become exposed, and when his metal probe made contact with it the electric flow grounded through his body and he died. His wife and teenage son found him in the evening, his body still smoking. It was estimated that he had been hooked up for about an hour. The man's mate was always on his case about having safety switches installed but, for whatever reason, he never got around to it. Now he never will.

speech.para: Relatively low voltages can be quite dangerous, and people do not fully appreciate the danger they are placing themselves in when playing with electricity. Often it is a case of good fortune rather than wise management that saves them. Some do not even appreciate how close they have come to being killed. At one milliamp, there is no sensation at all. Between one and eight milliamps, you feel a painless sensation of shock. Between eight and 15 milliamps, it starts to hurt. Between 15 and 20 milliamps, not only does it hurt but you lose muscle control as your body's neurones start to spasm and breathing becomes laboured. At or below 75 milliamps, breathing stops. At 100 milliamps, ventricular fibrillation sets in—the heart is not pumping and is in spasm. At and above 200 milliamps, you suffer severe burns and severe muscular contraction. So severe are these contractions that the chest muscles clamp the heart so tightly it stops altogether, and all this occurs instantly, without warning. It would be quicker and easier to duck a bullet.

The house magazine of the Occupational Health and Safety Commission reported that, between 1989 and 1992, 122 workers died as a result of electrocution in the course of their duties. The magazine describes an example of what can only be termed a `near miss'. A boilermaker was using an electrical welder in the engine room of a fishing boat when he received an electric shock. The ventilation system in the engine room was not turned on, and the boilermaker was perspiring due to the heat—about 45 degrees Celsius—inside the engine room. The perspiration ran down the boilermaker's arms onto the welding handpiece and made it conductive. I do not have enough time to continue, but I would like to say my thanks to Ian Boyd of Bomaderry for drawing this matter to my attention. Ian, may you never give up your fight to have safety switches become mandatory.

talk.start.para: —Recently I participated in a national action day on aged care funding sponsored by St Laurence Community Services at Lara in my electorate of Corio. My congratulations go to the CEO of St Laurence Communities Services, Michelle Plane, the staff of the Lara facility and the board of management for organising the day and for their ongoing activity in bringing this issue before the people of the Geelong region. St Laurence has been at the forefront of such community activity, motivated by a deep concern that chronic underfunding of aged care by the Howard government has, at the local level, put in jeopardy the capacity of not-for-profit providers to continue to provide access to affordable, quality aged care services for low-income residents in my electorate.

speech.para: Today, I present to the House a petition of 92 signatures from residents concerned about the shortfall in aged care funding. The government will of course argue that its budget announcement washes away its responsibility in this matter. It does not. Throughout 2003, the Howard government has starved providers under the guise of the Hogan review. Having received the report late in 2003, the government failed to act until May 2004, when of course it delivered its pre-election budget. Such cynical manipulation of the aged care funding issue and older Australians is to be condemned.

Significant elements of what is asked in this petition have not been addressed in the budget announcement, and the funding problems still remain.
