The Howard government can find $1 billion for a war in Iraq but cannot solve many of these aged care funding issues. It can waste $100 million in pre-election advertising and $200 million on the Pacific solution for refugees—a wasteful one at that—yet it cannot address the needs of older Australians. A government with such a warped sense of priorities simply has to go. I have raised this issue of aged care funding with the minister and on the floor of this House on several occasions. I will continue to do so until justice prevails on this matter and older Australians receive the care, attention and access to affordable aged care that they deserve.

quote.para: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

speech.para: concerned Australian citizens point out to the House of Representatives:

Due the increasing shortfall between the income available to deliver aged and community services and the rising costs of delivering those services, Australia is facing the imminent collapse of the aged and community care system as we know it.

quote.para: Your Petitioners therefore ask the House of Representatives to:

speech.para: Replace the current system of indexing pricing in the aged and community care sector with a system which reflects the true increases in the costs of running aged and community care services.
Immediately inject $10 per day, per bed to restore the existing viability of residential care services.
Provide a 10 per cent increase in the prices paid for community care to ensure viability of these important services, which help keep our elderly and disabled in their own homes.
from 20 citizens.

subdebateinfo.title: Herbert Electorate: Letter from the Leader of the Opposition

talk.start.para: —Yesterday in my electorate a letter from the Leader of the Opposition was distributed to some of my constituents, and I am alarmed at the inaccuracies that have occurred in the letter that the Leader of the Opposition has allowed to be distributed. In the short time available to me I can pick up on only two inaccuracies. The first one I would like to challenge is the Leader of the Opposition's claim in relation to pneumococcal disease—that is, that 50 babies a year are dying. The National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System reports that there were only five deaths for children under five in 2001, nine in 2002 and 10 in 2003. That is nothing like 50 babies dying each year. I would also be interested, as a member of parliament, to know whether these babies who did in fact die were from the high-risk group—that is, the high-risk group that is being covered by the government in any event.

speech.para: On the second page of the letter there is reference to better access to education and the Labor Party's `Aim Higher' package. The letter claims that the Labor Party will invest $2.34 billion to rebuild, reform and expand our universities and TAFEs. I am very concerned about that particular claim because it is clearly wrong. The federal Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson, has quite plainly indicated that there are incorrect figures in the Labor Party's policy, resulting in the Labor Party having only about $1.3 billion to invest in higher education. That is a long way short of the $2.34 billion claimed.

I ask residents in my electorate to challenge the information that is being presented to them and not to just accept it at face value. For example, the claim of `reversing the Howard government's unfair 25 per cent HECS hike' is going to cost the Labor Party budget something like $662 million—and there is little indication from the Labor Party as to how they might fund that particular cost. If the Leader of the Opposition is incapable of making correct statements to the electorate and correctly costing his policies, I ask my electorate to think deeply about how on earth the Leader of the Opposition would be an alternative Prime Minister of this country.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Mr Costello:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Crean moved by way of amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

(1) Condemns the Government for its cynical election driven spending spree which—while spending a record $52 billion over the forward estimates—failed to deliver crucial services to Australians, including:
(a) funding the pneumococcal vaccine for children;
(b) funding VET in schools so young Australians can either Earn or Learn;
(c) ensuring access to Higher Education without excessive fees or increasing student debt levels;
(d) ensuring all Australians can access bulkbilling services; and
(e) ensuring adequate measures to respond to Australia's skill shortage; and
(2) also condemns the Government for failing to present a strategy to adequately address the long term fiscal challenges facing the nation.”

talk.start.para: —Prior to the adjournment yesterday evening I was making the point that I have a genuine concern that the government is overselling its one-off family payment benefits and that, come 1 July, I am sure I will be getting a lot of phone calls from a lot of the families that I represent to say, `I looked at the table and the money that I thought I was getting is not going to be there.'

speech.para: As we all know, the first one-off payment will go into people's accounts before the end of the financial year. That $600 is much touted but, for the average family in Throsby that is carrying a debt of $711 under a flawed family payments system, getting $600 will be seen as some small recompense, due to the fact that the system, not the individual, has produced the debt and the system is at fault. Yesterday I mentioned the case of the Gaggins, a small local business concern and by no means wealthy. Mrs Gaggin did everything by the book and found that, because there was some discrepancy between the authority to lodge a late tax return and the processes under Centrelink, her family was in debt to the tune of several thousand dollars.

So I make the point that getting $600 in your bank account is hardly recompense for a system that is fundamentally flawed. It is a system that has seen 2½ thousand families in my electorate accumulate debt of $6.3 million since the inception of the scheme. So you cannot blame people if they feel that the government gesture of the first one-off payment is somewhat cynical in the lead-up to an impending federal election. Of course, we now know that the second $600 may not reach every family because it has to be offset against the continuing debts that the system throws up. On the evidence we already have about the failure of the system, one in three families—about 600,000 families—has an average debt of $900. The second $600 will be offset against the average debt. A lot of families in my electorate are still carrying debts. So the much touted additional benefit of $1,200 in family payments is illusory for many Australian families because many of them may never see a cent of the second payment, and I think that many will see the first payment as some small admission by the government of the flaws in the system.

In my view it would have been far better to get the system right. Families need assistance. No-one begrudges them extra financial assistance, but they need it every fortnight and not a one-off payment that looks so much like a cynical gesture just prior to a federal election. As I said, I am worried that a lot of families will find on 1 July that the financial benefits promised and advertised in the media will not materialise. The financial gains claimed in the tables that have appeared in local and national papers are grossly overstated at many different income levels. According to our analysis, the gross overstatement is because the tables of alleged benefits that have been drawn up by the Treasurer comprise components such as the $600 one-off family payment calculated as a weekly benefit whereas we know that it will be not paid on a regular basis but will be there as an offset to any debts in the system. The alleged benefits also include a round of tax cuts that will not be delivered for another year and, very cynically, a component of the super co-contribution. Low-income families—if they can afford to pay it; it has to be a minimum of $1,000—cannot draw on that until retirement.

The gains that are claimed are much more than will be flowing to the pockets of many families. Take, for example, the typical scenario of a family with two children, one of them under five, that has a single income of $55,000. If they look at the tables in the papers, they will believe that they will be getting $32.88 in the pocket. That is five times the actual weekly cash gain which, according to our estimates, will be $6.92. So I and many other people will be getting a lot of calls in early July because people have genuinely assumed that what has been printed is what they will receive. This can only backfire on the government, because people at least expect their politicians to be telling them the truth. They will be angry if they do not get what those tables show. As I indicated yesterday, 91 per cent of the people I represent are getting no relief from tax cuts, so it is their contribution that is funding the tax cuts.

talk.start.para: —Ninety-one per cent?

—It is 91 per cent of the people in Throsby. I can give you the figures. Around 8,000 people in my electorate earn more than $52,000 a year and 79,000 earn less than $52,000. So 91 per cent of the people in the electorate of Throsby will not receive one cent in tax cuts in this budget. I have the exact figures. Just under 8,000 constituents in Throsby earn more than $52,000 per year but 79,000 constituents get no tax cuts, and that is 91 per cent of the people I represent. If you go through the list, you will find that the figures are as high as that in many electorates.

speech.para: Overall in Australia, only four out of five taxpayers will get the benefit of the tax cut. In my electorate, the median weekly individual income is around $300 and the median weekly family income is $859. So you can see why people are going to be very angry—no tax cuts for 91 per cent—and come 1 July they will be looking at the tables, thinking they are going to get $600, without the explanation, of course, that this will be offset against debts in the system.

Families are struggling, and both sides of the political equation do not begrudge the average family assistance. It is a priority and they need relief because they have been struggling under the highest taxing government of all time. While they have been struggling to make ends meet, the cost of basic services has increased. I am very lucky in Throsby; I have very high rates of bulk-billing. But for those who do not get to see a bulk-billing doctor, the average cost, the last time I looked at the data, is in the vicinity of $13 to $14. Multiply that a couple of times if you have young children and you can see the problems there. Families are struggling under the pressure of child-care costs, which have risen by about 13 per cent in the last year. Education costs are up 7½ per cent. If families are covered by private insurance, we all know that the premiums continue to rise.

Not only will they find that on 1 July the claimed benefits may not be there, but also during the course of Senate estimates this week we now find that families will be putting in their tax return quickly—and many in my electorate will put in their tax return very quickly because they desperately need the money—and only finding out in the first weeks of September whether or not the system has thrown up debts for them in the family payment system. Here they are, on 1 July they open the paper, they are not getting the money they think they are going to get, they rush to get their tax return in, they get the cheque back, and then in September they may or may not be advised as to whether they now owe the government debts that have accrued under the family payment system. You cannot help but ask whether this is a re-run of the 2001 election when, knowing there would be a revolt from the average Australian family, the government agreed to the waiver of, as I recall, $1,000 and then let the faulty, flawed system continue on accruing debts that had nothing to do with the individuals who, in most cases I have dealt with, notified Centrelink immediately that there had been a variation in their estimated and earned income.

This week we have also learned from Senate estimates that the government has committed to a massive advertising blitz of $109 million—that is just in advertising placement costs alone, not in the cost of creating the advertising campaigns. I believe there are about 21 campaigns which for many people will rightly be seen as little more than the use of taxpayer funds for the free promotion of the Liberal Party and its policies in the lead-up to a federal election. The Medicare campaign placement cost alone is $15.7 million. How much better would it be to redirect the funds to the provision of free pneumococcal vaccines to all babies, which the government cannot afford to do and has not done but has this largesse of taxpayer funds of $109 million to spend on advertising alone? That advertising blitz of $109 million would provide huge relief for the almost half a million Australians languishing on waiting lists for dental care, many of whom are in my electorate and have waited years to get attention to their basic oral needs. This is a government of wrong priorities. It has a plan for the election but not a plan for the future on key issues of concern to all families. As I understand it, in the next six weeks or so, the Australian population will be flooded with the estimated $6 billion one-off spending payments in the lead-up to an election.

Well, you can fool some people some of the time, but not all of the people all of the time. As all the polls indicate, when people are asked about their priorities, they see investment in basic essential services like health and education as being much more important than the miserable $4 a week tax cuts that they saw last time, which were quickly squandered by increases in costs. When you look at the huge outlay of $52 billion we wonder how you can afford to do that when you ripped out almost a billion dollars in the last hospital agreements, when you have no plans for mental health, when you have no national dental health care scheme, when you have no plans to prioritise public education, when you have no plans for funding schools on the basis of need and when you have no plan for keeping tertiary education affordable.

Very significantly, as people would know—my region and the Illawarra region generally now has the highest rate of youth unemployment in New South Wales and the fifth highest rate in Australia—this government has no plan for addressing the critical issue of youth unemployment or indeed the numbers of long-term unemployed, which continue to grow. Those issues—health, education, training, employment, jobs—are fundamental. As I say, the government has a plan for seeing its re-election. It is costing a lot of money to do that. I think the people out there understand that a lot of this money could have been more wisely invested in the important national needs that confront our society. I started by quoting an economist's words that you might have thought were my words. I will quote them again:

quote.para: We all know the Treasurer's ninth Budget is cynical and unashamedly partisan. But let's be frank: with an election imminent, what did you expect?

speech.para: Those are not my words—although that is certainly a sentiment I agree with—but words from Dr Neil Warren, Associate Professor of Economics at the University of New South Wales. He goes on to describe this year's budget as not only cynically and unashamedly partisan, but one that uses `a truckload of cash to address politically chosen problem areas'. I think it would have been much more prudent for this government to address the real and genuine needs of the people that we represent, to make sure that services are well funded in order to improve their living standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2003-2004 and associated bills and, in doing so, to address some of the important national financial issues in the budget and, more particularly, to take the time to talk about how some of the benefits from this budget and from the government's budget approach over the last eight years are benefiting the electorate of Casey in a number of key areas. But before I do that I would like to briefly respond to the previous speaker, the member for Throsby, who really illustrated the dearth of the Labor Party's approach to the budget. Much of her contribution focused on the $600 family payment which she criticised as being too small, not enough. All her criticisms highlighted the fact that Labor have nothing to say for families. Whether she knows it or not, Labor actually did not have family tax benefits. They did not exist before 1996. She was talking about a $600 increase per child not being enough and she seemed completely ignorant of the fact that the Labor Party are actually going to take it away. That is what her shadow minister has announced. Labor will not commit to keeping the very payment that she is criticising. In the days after the budget, when Labor were scrambling to work out how many families there were in Australia, both the shadow finance minister and the shadow Treasurer confirmed within a week that Labor were looking at taking away that $600 payment over the next two years.

speech.para: An opposition member—That is an overstatement.

talk.start.para: —Does that mean you will take away half of it? If it is an overstatement, Labor should do what they have been unable to do every single day since the budget—that is, confirm that they will keep it. But they will not. The only public statement they have made on it is that those moneys are not quarantined. As soon as they get the chance, they will snatch them back.

speech.para: Dealing with the appropriation bills and debating services and the economic conditions in Australia has to be done in context. That context is that the services that are able to be offered today are far above what could be offered the last time those opposite brought down a budget, when government debt was $96 billion, interest rates were 10½ per cent on mortgages and income taxes were higher right across the board. The opportunities for families and small businesses and the sheer state of the Australian economy and what it provided were far less. If you go through some of the benefits that are now able to be provided in the form of tax cuts and family payments and look through the history of them, you see a focused, disciplined budget and a strong and responsible economic policy.

For families, the investment of $600 per child and everything that goes with that builds on what has been offered since 1996. As I said earlier, in 1996, prior to our election, we promised the introduction of a family tax initiative. Prior to that, a family tax initiative did not exist; there was no distinction for families. That was delivered in full and on time in January 1997. In 2000, as part of the reform of the tax system, we delivered even more help; we more than doubled it. Family tax benefits A and B were created out of 12 separate payments. The taper rates—which some of those opposite criticise so often—the rate at which assistance payments were lost as household income increased, were reduced, helping growing numbers of families with one partner in the work force. We also introduced an important concept—again, a concept that seems to have eluded the previous speaker—topping up where an underestimate occurs. If a family underestimates their income in a financial year, we top it up. When Labor were last in power, no top-ups existed. You can only assume that, if they are ever in power again, the top-ups that benefit so many families at the moment will, like the $600 per child payment that we have just introduced, be removed.

Building on these initiatives for families can only occur with the sort of responsible budget policy we have had. Paying off debt—paying off the massive budget deficits that those opposite left us—has provided increased resources. The reductions of interest costs on government debt alone have freed up in the order of $4 billion to $5 billion every year to be spent on the services right across the budget. Eight or nine years ago that $4 billion or $5 billion would have been spent on interest costs servicing that $96 billion debt. Every year, in every budget, that money can now be spent on services in the areas of health, family payments, education and the like.

Those opposite think that they can criticise the services that are now being provided and try and ignore the fact that they are services they could never provide themselves but could only talk about. Two million families will benefit from the $600 per child benefit that we are providing. In addition, the withdrawal rate between the maximum and base rates of family tax benefit A will be further reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. Families receiving family tax benefit B will benefit from a reduction in the income test withdrawal rate. Women who return to work part time will be big beneficiaries.

On top of that, to further help families we are introducing the maternity payment of $3,000 from July, which will rise by $1,000 over the next two years up to $5,000 in July 2008. This will be non means tested to reflect the fact that it is a cost that everyone bears with the birth of a child. Under Labor there were no top-ups in the family tax system. Just as they have done on so many issues since the budget, again yesterday in the House they failed to give an undertaking that top-ups would continue and that families would continue to receive their due entitlements should Labor win the next election.

That is no small thing for the member for Throsby, who talked about the number of families in her electorate she claimed rely on family tax benefits—family tax benefits that did not exist under Labor. In the order of 480,000 families receive a top-up, so many families in her electorate and those of other members opposite are receiving a top-up where they underestimate their income. It is not something you hear too many of the members opposite talk about, but where an underestimation occurs a top-up is paid. It is a top-up that will not be paid should Labor win the next election. Imagine the situation for families when they actually look at the reality. If they are getting a top-up it will be taken away. They are going to get $600 per child per financial year that will be taken away. And there is a new Medicare safety net that has been introduced and you are going to take that away as well. This might not be widely known by the public, but as the days tick by they will realise that Labor's words do not match the reality of what they are actually pledging.

Another area of the budget where there is increased assistance is the important area of child care. The budget funds an additional 40,000 places in outside school hours child care and provides for 4,000 more family day care places from July. This is an important service and an important program that this government has dramatically expanded. There are many local schools in my area providing out of hours care programs that very much suit the parents, as you would expect in an outer suburban area where there are long travel times and more often than not both parents are in the work force. Some of those schools that have benefited today are Mooroolbark Primary, Bimbadeen Heights, Lilydale West Primary, Chirnside Park Primary, Pembroke Primary, Ruskin Park Primary and Monbulk Primary.

Another area in which the budget includes a continuation of important funding that has been able to be maintained is firefighting. Part of my electorate takes in the Dandenong Ranges. For those people who live in fire-prone areas, as some members know, it is a constant struggle to keep the best firefighting capacity available. The Dandenong Ranges were the scene of the Ash Wednesday fires and there have been some dangerous fires within the last decade. The capacity to fight them has increased in recent years with some important aids like helicopters and the sky cranes—Elvis and the like. I was pleased to see that in the budget funding has continued for some of those welcome initiatives—$16.5 million will be spent in the coming years by the federal government on the provision of these crucial firefighting aircraft. This funding, in conjunction with expenditure by the Victorian and other state and territory governments, will help fund the leasing of a range of aerial firefighting assets that will be available for use in Victoria and other fire-prone areas of southern Australia.

In outer suburban and partly rural electorates, roads are of critical importance. The road and transport package in this budget—the $11.4 billion of funding—for the new long-term transport plan known as AusLink is very welcome indeed. With more details to come, AusLink incorporates the national highway system and projects known as the Roads of National Importance and other freight links which are important for our nation over the next decade or so. For outer suburban electorates and electorates like that of my colleague, the member for Kalgoorlie—where there is a high degree of tourism and agribusiness and growing exports—it is not just the roads in the immediate vicinity that are important, it is the national link; it is getting that important produce onto a link, be it road or rail. That long-term plan will have very important national benefits and local benefits as well.

At the local level, funding for roads has been massively increased under this government. Roads to Recovery, another program that simply did not exist under Labor, has provided $8.3 million in the shires within my electorate to fix, repair and upgrade 11 critical roads—some of the dangerous roads in the Shire of Yarra Ranges and some more of the congested roads in the Maroondah council area. I would like to take the opportunity to commend both the councils which have responsibility for picking the projects, overseeing them and ensuring that they are completed on time. The councils and the shires of Yarra Ranges and Maroondah have done a great job in ensuring that that program has been a big success. I know from talking with colleagues that it has been a success right across the country. The extension of that project, confirmed again in the budget and worth $1.2 billion nationally between 2005 and 2009, will mean that more roads will be funded to the direct benefit of the people of Casey.

In the area of schools, over the next four years the Howard government will increase funding by $8 billion to $32 billion in total. It will allocate $6.7 billion to schools and students for 2004-05. That is an increase of about eight per cent over the last year. That is important in providing funding for schools and buildings. In 2004-05, over $2.6 billion is being provided for state schools and students—an increase of 5.4 per cent over the past year. It is an increase since 1996 of 68.7 per cent in funding for state schools and students.

Another area where there is an important education and training priority is that of apprenticeships and the Jobs Pathway program. When Labor were in government, their entire concentration was on higher education. There was no concentration on apprenticeships or trades and consequently the numbers fell dramatically. That is why this government has had a renewed commitment to apprenticeships and trades. They are a critical jobs pathway for young people who do not want to go to university, and they are also critical for the local economy, which has a shortage of trades in some important areas, such as the automotive industry and agribusiness.

One of the great foundations of the trades area is the apprenticeship system, and it must be reinvigorated to give young people the message that a career in trades is not only very fulfilling but integral to the local and national economy. Many local organisations are doing a great job in this regard—for example, KYM Employment Services, which is moving around schools and assisting in the Job Pathway Program and Careers and Transition projects in Melbourne's eastern region, particularly in secondary schools in the Shire of Yarra Ranges.

Finally, I would like to touch on the area of health and families, where I began. The budget funds the massive increase in health spending that was announced just prior to the budget, with a 17 per cent increase in the Commonwealth-State Health Agreement and, on top of that, the Strengthening Medicare package, which is providing some real, tangible benefits as it begins to be used within the electorate. One area in particular which I referred to earlier is the Medicare safety net—the new rebate, whereby the government pays 80 per cent of non-hospital costs over $300 for eligible families and 80 per cent of costs for all other individuals and families once the threshold of $700 a year is reached.

The Minister for Health and Ageing has advised that 200,000 Australians are now enjoying these rebates. As of late May, around $7.5 million had been paid in rebates. These rebates were never part of the original Medicare. Families have always struggled with the out-of-hospital expenses. It has taken the Howard government to introduce this rebate system. It is a system that is going to be welcomed by families as they use it. Unfortunately, it is a rebate system which those opposite have already announced they will abolish. They will abolish the only Medicare rebate system that has been introduced, and they will abolish it to fund other things. Together with some of their quiet announcements on the $600 payment per child and what they plan for private insurance, that is very much part of what will be an evolving story over the next few months with their alternative budget strategy.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005. The 2004-05 federal budget is nothing more than old-fashioned, pre-election pork-barrelling. Instead of the increased spending on vital services which the majority of people said they wanted, the Prime Minister in waiting has squandered the money on tax cuts for people who are already well off. A Morgan research poll just nine days before budget night showed that 88.4 per cent of people wanted the budget surplus spent on health, education, aged care, homelessness and poverty relief rather than on tax cuts. All we got was a sop to aged care which is too little to really address the sector's problems.

speech.para: The latest CPI figures show that the cost of essential services has jumped by as much as 11 per cent in the last year. The government's decision to provide tax cuts only to people earning above $52,000 per year is a slap in the face for low-income earners, particularly the people doing it extra tough in my electorate of Cunningham. The government's neglect of the least well-off people in Australia is an affront to decency.

The government has hailed this budget as a budget for families, but it is not a family budget because it fails families in the long term. There is a handout to family tax benefit recipients which many families will not see. There are lump sum payments for new mothers that fall well short of a national, paid maternity leave scheme, but there is no action to support the overstressed public services that all of us, and families in particular, rely on. There is no real investment in public health, nothing for public schools, nothing for universities and nothing new for sustaining our environment. The Treasurer, a man who aspires to be Prime Minister, has failed to show any vision for our common future.

The Greens have a more optimistic vision and a more responsible plan for the investment of our public tax dollars—a vision of free, high-quality public education; nation-building investment in our environment and infrastructure; strengthening Medicare; boosting our overseas aid; and, at home, a fairer and more effective welfare system that guarantees an adequate income for all. These are the kinds of measures that Australians are crying out for in increasing numbers, because these are the kinds of ideas that, unlike election oriented tax cuts, people recognise as offering a concrete path to a better, brighter and healthier future for all Australians.

Services, not tax cuts—that is what people want. Both Newspoll and the Morgan poll have found that over 70 per cent of Australians are in favour of investment in services over tax cuts. An ANU study found that a clear majority think the standard of health and Medicare has declined over the past two years, and a near majority think the same of education. Voters want these services looked after, and this is not the priority they see reflected in government policy. That is because the Howard government is failing in one of the main responsibilities of government: providing essential public services. This government has shifted the spending on these services from the public sphere, in which all Australians contribute to the cost and share the benefits, to the private sphere, where those with private financial resources buy essential services based on their capacity to pay, rather than their need. It is the poor and the vulnerable who are the biggest losers.

The Senate report into poverty released in March revealed the extent of need in Australia, estimating that 3.6 million people—that is almost one in five Australians—live on a weekly income of $400 or less, lower than the federal minimum wage. Some 700,000 children live in a household without a wage earner, and a million Australians do not make enough from their paid work to live above the poverty line. These are the people who most need government investment in our public services. Their voices are some of the loudest calling for services, not tax cuts.

The Australian Council of Social Service identified $4.6 billion of urgent spending needed on health, education, housing and child care. The Treasurer says that the government has increased spending on services, including health and education. But the money has gone to private schools, to privatising higher education, to private health insurance and to privatising health services. The $2.4 billion per annum private health insurance rebate adds around seven per cent to health spending, but it does not pay for health services. It pays for insurance.

Higher education spending has fallen as a share of total government spending from 3.9 per cent to 2.5 per cent of the budget. When people call for services rather than tax cuts, public education and public health are at the top of their lists. This government has failed a generation of young Australians by not investing in their education and the nation's future. Australia lags behind comparable countries on its public investment in preschool care and education, public schools and tertiary institutions. This government has pursued an ideological agenda of pouring money into the private school sector at the expense of public schools.

In contrast, the Greens are committed to building a high-quality public education system and, in doing so, turning around the worrying growth trend in private schooling that is dividing our communities. The Greens would scrap the appallingly unfair SES model that funds non-government schools. In doing so we would redirect the $1.5 billion earmarked for the wealthiest private schools over the next four years into priority public schools funding programs. The Greens would freeze the funding of private schools at 2003-04 levels in order to direct those savings into urgently needed catch-up funds for the public sector. Through these and other measures the Greens will continue working to ensure that every child can be guaranteed that an education at a local government school continues to be the best educational, cultural and social experience on offer.

The forgotten one million Australians who are enrolled at TAFE must also be resourced. TAFE has been a world-leading provider of low-fee postsecondary education, and the Greens would build on that record by returning growth funding to TAFE. A return to free university education is the best way to guarantee that all Australians who are academically qualified to study at university can do so, thereby drawing on the full potential of this nation's talent. The Greens advocate abolishing the HECS system and forgiving all HECS debt, returning Australia to a system of free public tertiary education. This measure would cost just under $2 billion, the same amount of money the Treasurer is spending next year on tax cuts for the rich.

In the area of health, the Howard government has squandered public funds and a critical opportunity to improve our public health system. Instead of strengthening Medicare, the government has moved Australia closer to a situation where the health care you obtain depends on what you can afford to pay. The government refuses to accept that people happily pay for Medicare through their taxes. They pay for a quality public health care system that provides quality care for all Australians when they need it. The Greens have proposed a number of measures to strengthen Medicare. Abolition of the $2.4 billion of public money going into the private health insurance rebate would allow the redirection of funds to public hospitals, to increasing the bulk-billing rebate for GP services, to mental health services, to preventive health care and to Indigenous health care.

The Greens would allocate additional funding to have medically necessary dentistry covered under Medicare. Currently, around half a million low-income earners are waiting for dental treatment through public schemes with waiting periods as long as four years. Millions more Australians who do not qualify for a health care card and do not have private health insurance simply miss out on dental treatment. We could fund these kinds of initiatives if we opted for services, not tax cuts.

We are surrounded by the evidence of the damage that we are doing to the earth—the planet that provides for all our needs, including spiritual nourishment. The Pentagon report on climate change, released earlier this year, should have dispelled any doubts about the threats that we face if we fail to reverse global warming. The Measures of Australia's Progress 2004 report, published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics last month, confirmed the extent of the challenge. That report painted a disturbing picture of the deterioration of our natural environment and highlighted the urgent need for us to address major problems. Surface water and groundwater are being extracted at unsustainable rates. Almost 3,000 ecosystems are listed as threatened. In the decade to the year 2003 the number of terrestrial bird and mammal species listed as extinct, endangered or vulnerable in Australia rose by 40 per cent. There were 248,000 hectares cleared in 2001 alone, and 70 per cent of this was in Queensland. Almost six million hectares of land were at risk from salinity in the year 2000.

The damage we wreak on the earth's natural systems has an economic cost. Using our natural resources wisely and protecting our precious places and wildlife is at the heart of the Australian Greens' work. Climate change is one of our biggest priorities. The Greens propose a carbon levy, as many European countries have, as the best way to encourage the switch to sustainable energy. The proceeds would finance energy conservation, renewable energy and measures to protect low-income earners from higher electricity prices. We also propose a $35 billion, 10-year investment plan to build a sustainable future. By using the government bond market to offer green bonds to green Australia's essential infrastructure, we can help transform the nation, bringing social, environmental and economic benefits. This scheme proposed by the Greens offers a secure investment, guaranteed return and the opportunity to invest in a greener future for this country.

Greening Australia's infrastructure is only one essential component of making it sustainable. We also need a mindset change to focus on reducing consumption of energy and materials, eliminating waste and improving the quality of services to meet people's needs. The decision to de-fund environmentally beneficial research shows that the Howard government has no commitment to the task of addressing global warming. It has allocated $92 million to fossil fuel cooperative research centres for coal, petroleum and geosequestration, compared with just $10 million for renewable energy, and it has just rejected an application for a solar CRC whilst approving a CRC for the so-called clean power coming from brown coal.

The government's budget also fails to provide enough funding to restore the health of the Murray River by ensuring that the 1,500 gigalitre minimum increase in environmental flows is achieved within a decade. This is an urgent task that the government has failed to address. Eighty-five per cent of Australians want the federal government to intervene to protect Tasmania's old-growth forests and their wildlife. The Greens have an industry transition strategy that would save the forests and create 500 new jobs, but there is zero allocation in this budget towards such a win-win outcome.

In this budget the government continues its abysmal record on assisting the world's poorest people. Under the Howard government, Australia's overseas aid has fallen well short of the UN recommended level of 0.7 per cent of gross national income. This financial year, Australia gave just 0.26 per cent. Lifting Australia's official development assistance to the UN recommended level would cost approximately $5,740 million next financial year. Improving the living conditions and life opportunities for the poorest people on the planet is one of the best investments we can make to secure a safer world.

Let us target the causes of terrorism—that is, global inequality, instability and imperial foreign policy—rather than go to war on the symptoms. Every bomb we drop and every war we fight creates the conditions for more terrorism, costing us in lives and money as the cycle of violence continues. We need to withdraw our troops from Iraq and instead put resources into reconstruction and humanitarian aid managed by the Iraqi people and their future government. Appallingly, Australia's civil aid to Iraq has been almost halved, going from a piddling $40 million to $27 million in this year's budget.

The Howard government is depriving the poorest nation in our region, East Timor, of billions of dollars in royalties from the exploitation of oil and gas reserves in the Timor Sea whilst cutting direct aid to the East Timorese. Australia refuses to allow independent arbitration of the sea boundary dispute that sits at the heart of this robbery. East Timor's Prime Minister, Mari Alkatiri, says the funds that under international law belong to the struggling nation are needed to pay for schools and health care. `It is,' he says, `literally a matter of life and death.' The Greens support East Timor's internationally recognised claim and call on the Howard government to meet it. Our global responsibilities include providing asylum to refugees. The Greens continue to call for an end to mandatory detention and for savings to be redirected to help asylum seekers live in the community while their claims for asylum are being assessed.

The cost of housing has skyrocketed in many cities in recent years, pricing many people out of buying or renting a home. The ACTU has calculated that the average house price rose by 70 per cent in the five years to 2003, compared with average full-time wage rises of 26 per cent in the same period. Housing as an investment is driving up prices. The Productivity Commission has identified negative gearing as a factor in this investment trend. The 50 per cent capital gains tax discount introduced by the Howard government has seen people pour millions of dollars into property, but it has not delivered affordable housing. The Greens believe that affordable housing is a right and that governments have a responsibility to facilitate it. We want the capital gains tax concession reversed and negative gearing phased out, with funds redirected to public housing—that is, to public housing with energy and water efficiency features that not only benefit the environment but also save on ongoing expenses.

The budget contains nothing to promote employment and training for workers who are unemployed. While the official unemployment rate is 5.7 per cent, the real level of unemployment is at least double and possibly higher than this. In my own electorate of Cunningham overall unemployment is stalled at 9.7 per cent while teenage unemployment is over 32 per cent. Those figures are a disgrace. The growth in casual employment—that is, in insecure work with low pay and no standard conditions—and the increasing reliance on part-time employees are major causes of poverty. One in four workers is now employed as a casual, whilst the wages of the lowest paid workers fail to provide a decent living. This is in addition to the hundreds of thousands of Australians and their dependants who do not have paid work.

The government's maternity payment is no substitute for a proper paid maternity leave scheme. It does not ensure women's rights to return to work nor will it cover the minimum 16 weeks off work that is recommended by the World Health Organisation. Unless a scheme ensures a continuing attachment to the work force, Australian women's rights to engage in paid work will continue to be restricted. The Greens have developed a scheme to deliver replacement income to 75 per cent of women for 18 weeks, with a further 34 weeks of unpaid leave, a right to return to work part time and a right to share the leave period with a partner. This scheme can be funded by redirecting the baby bonus, which the government has abandoned in this budget. Australia can afford a scheme of this kind and Australian women deserve it. Until the government provides practical assistance of this kind to families it has no credibility in claiming to support families.

Unmet demand for child care, high fees and pay levels as low as $12 an hour for child-care workers are major problems the Howard government has failed to address. The drive for private child care will only exacerbate these problems. The Greens welcome the government's provision of more child-care places in this budget, but the measure only meets one-quarter of the unmet demand in this area. The present federal funding regime has led to the growth in the corporate child-care sector, arguably at the expense of quality care. As at June 2000, some 67 per cent of long day care centres around Australia were privately owned and several child-care companies have now listed on the stock exchange. Taxpayers are effectively subsidising the huge profits being made by corporate operators. The measures announced in the budget will do nothing to curb this alarming trend towards the commercialisation of early childhood care.

The Greens call on the government to provide funding that prioritises the local government based and community managed child-care sector. This includes a commitment to provide operational and capital grants to establish and develop community based not-for-profit centres—a commitment the government abandoned in 1997. Child care is fundamentally about the nurture and education of the youngest members of our society. We do not allow schools to be run for profit, so why child-care centres?

A government that is fair dinkum about helping Australian families would invest in public services for families, not in tax cuts. Taxation policy should be used to redistribute wealth and generate it for the future. Under the Howard government, taxation policy has become less progressive. This means that the greatest burden falls on those least able to pay. The Greens support progressive taxation. As part of this we call for the abolition of the GST. The company tax rate should be returned to the 33 per cent it was at before this government gave corporations a tax break before the last election.

The Australian Council of Social Service, ACOSS, has identified tax loopholes worth $8.2 billion a year which benefit only the very well-off, including a loophole which allows diverting income to a private company and executive perks such as salary-sacrificing for a company car or extra superannuation. These loopholes must be closed and the savings redirected to public services. The Treasurer's tax cuts will cost the Commonwealth $14 billion over the life of the next parliament. Add to that the tax cuts from 2003 and the tax loopholes that have not been closed in the projected surplus, and a massive $71 billion of public money has been wasted by this government. This pool of money could have achieved a fully funded, free tertiary education system, more teachers and better resourced public schools. Together with the abolition of the private health insurance rebate, it could also have paid for the expansion of Medicare to cover such things as necessary dental care, a boost in bulk-billing rates for GPs and the establishment of new community health centres. It could do all this with money left over.

Instead, we have public schools that are struggling, university students who are being slugged by higher fees, and doctors fees that are rising. The question that the Greens ask is: do we feel richer? The answer is no. The public has a right to expect the government to provide quality public services. When it chooses to give tax cuts instead of providing these services, the public quite rightly feels cheated. When existing services are left to degrade whilst money is poured into rival private schemes, the public feels betrayed. And when governments cry poor with regard to teaching children, saving our rivers and increasing bulk-billing and then spend billions of dollars to illegally invade and occupy another country, the public gets angry. By putting services before tax cuts, the Greens would set Australia in a much better, much fairer policy direction. We will take these progressive policies to the election and ask the Australian people to join us in supporting public services, peace, the nation's environment and a better investment for its future generations.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and associated legislation and to inform the House how my constituents in Deakin stand to benefit from the multifaceted assistance the budget includes. In doing so, I will make a marked contrast to the contribution from the member speaking before me. Firstly, it is worth noting that this budget builds on the hard work and vision of the government since it came into office in 1996. Most importantly, this budget tackles serious local issues and represents a major investment into one of the previous Labor government's greatest shortfalls: aged care. It is also a budget that delivers direct financial benefits to tens of thousands of families, while at the same time ensuring that spending on vital services is maintained—services such as health, education, aged care, defence and, in my part of the world, roads.

speech.para: This budget is a reminder of the excellent economic stewardship that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have given to our country. The government has been able to rein in Australia's debt legacy from the Hawke-Keating era. By providing a stable and strong economy, we have been able to weather the international economic and security crises of the late 1990s and recent years.

talk.start.para: —The people of Deakin—and the people of Melbourne Ports—have been able to invest with security and confidence in their and their family's future. The budget brings with it an enhanced focus on the family, which I am sure all agree is a most vital unit in our society.

speech.para: My constituents often remark that what they seek from the federal government is incentive—the incentive to work, the incentive to be active in the community—and the capacity to strengthen the foundations of our society, to provide for vital services and infrastructure while recognising that the great building block of our society, the family, must also be supported. Families do not seek an overburdening role for government, and they certainly do not need to be told how to raise their children. It is an insult to parents to be told that they must read to their children. It is stating the obvious. It is stating what many parents do without any prompting from a would-be nanny state. What families do need is a helping hand when it is needed most—a helping hand when having children, when raising a family and, importantly, when returning to work.

The family is a major focus of this budget. However, I find it unfortunate that some opportunistic members opposite would sink to the level of playing politics with the $19.2 billion that this government is investing into the family assistance package. It is disappointing that Latham's Labor is not prepared to commit to delivering the family tax benefits beyond this year. There are conflicting comments from the various frontbenchers of the Labor Party to attest to this.

The family focus of this budget is not only about managing the balance between work and family, it is about enhancing the faith in our young parents to rear their children. They play a vital role in the shaping of our nation. That being said, it is important to realise that early intervention by community specialists for families in crisis is equally important. The family incentives in this budget, such as the $3,000 maternity payment and the adjustments to the family tax benefit thresholds, complement the $800,000 of funding announced in February for the early intervention program run by UnitingCare Connections. I remind the member for Melbourne Ports, as someone whom I have a degree of warmth towards, that that program actually also runs in his electorate. Based from Deakin, in the eastern suburbs, this program targets young children that face the serious risk of their families becoming dysfunctional. It is imperative for responsible government to assist families that for various reasons are unable to function without the assistance of a qualified helping hand, such as that of the UnitingCare Connections program.

For the vast majority of families, however, the most valuable assistance that governments can give comes in the form of direct income assistance or direct cuts to their income tax. Claims by members on the other side of the House of tax cuts to the rich are ill-informed and play to the prejudice of those prepared to play the class card. While programs such as the early intervention program target families at risk, provisions in this budget also target families in need of a financial boost. This is what responsible fiscal management is all about—to be able to give back to those in need. When the family tax benefit is claimed through the tax system, a three-child dual-income family in Deakin with an income split of 80/20—that is, the father earns $40,000 per year and the mother earns $10,000 per year—will not pay net income tax until the family income exceeds $50,000. I believe that particular figure is not well understood out there: those lower income families with two incomes and three children will not pay net income tax until their family income exceeds $50,000.

This budget highlights not only the strengths of sound economic management but also the strengths of choice. I have been fortunate enough to represent a government that actively listens to and assists people in my part of the world. Sadly, for many of my constituents—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a question for the member.
(Mr Hawker)—Will the member for Deakin allow a question?
—Certainly.

—Does the member for Deakin acknowledge that the maternity allowance, rent assistance for families, the additional family payment scheme of 1988 and the home child care allowance were all efforts made by the previous Labor government to assist families?

—What I know is that the previous Labor government left this country in debt. The previous Labor government did very little to deliver real benefits to Australian families. I will get to the maternity allowance in a moment—it is in this budget. Sadly, for many of my constituents the federal government is the only level of government that listens to the people of Deakin. Contrary to the 2002 election campaign slogan of being a government that `listens, then acts', the Bracks state Labor government has shown contempt for the people of Deakin by ignoring the cries for vital infrastructure and service investments in Melbourne's eastern suburbs. Compounding the state government's inaction and its very poor budget for families, I also have in my part of the world the Whitehorse City Council, which directly represents half of my electorate and has allowed the blind Labor allegiance of majority councillors to dictate policy.

—There are some excellent councillors, but only some. Central to this issue is procrastination on road maintenance and no official position on the Bracks government's decision to toll the Scoresby Freeway. Acquiescence, obedience and silence are the hallmarks of the local ALP state MPs and the ALP aligned councillors in my area. In contrast, when the Howard government signed the Scoresby transport corridor memorandum of understanding with the Bracks Labor government in 2001 it committed $445 million. This figure represented a fifty-fifty split of the then construction costs for the project. The MOU stated clearly that the freeway, which runs right through Deakin, would be a toll-free road. This budget recommits federal government funding and gives the Bracks Labor government a rare second chance to do the right thing by the people of the eastern suburbs and reverse the toll decision. I take this opportunity to invite the local Labor state government and council representatives to join me, the Maroondah City Council, the local businesses and the overwhelming majority of the residents of Deakin in pressuring the Bracks government to honour the MOU.

speech.para: This budget has taken steps towards empowering our youth to get back into the vital trades sector. One of the most important goals of the Howard government since 1996 has been to arrest the decline in the availability of apprenticeships under the previous Labor government. I am proud of the positive effect that the New Apprenticeships scheme has had in Deakin. Just last year Starr Performance automotive, in Nunawading, hosted the Prime Minister for the launch of the New Apprenticeships centres program in conjunction with the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I am happy to say that this project, which includes a New Apprenticeships centre in Mitcham, received a three-year assistance contract from the government. These New Apprenticeships centres provide young school leavers with a valuable start in life and are pivotal in providing new blood to our trades.

It is heartening to read the statistics that the Minister for Education, Science and Training often states in this place, and rightly so. Since the creation of New Apprenticeships in 1998 more than 1,340,000 new apprenticeships have commenced, and there are currently 406,000 Australians training in new apprenticeships. These are new apprenticeships and lie in stark contrast to the allegations and criticisms from those on the other side who believe that there has been inaction by this government on apprenticeships.

We all know that more does need to be done to encourage young people to take up apprenticeships. Seventy per cent of our young people do not go on to university, and yet if you were to listen to the speeches and the contributions of members opposite you would think that higher education, tertiary education, was the sole destiny of all young people. We need to encourage school leavers into apprenticeships and traineeships, and we are doing that through various programs such as the one that I mentioned that was announced by the Prime Minister, and there are others in my area.

I draw the House's attention to research by Group Training Australia Victoria which highlights a falling demand for apprenticeship places, particularly among young people. The study focused on secondary school aged boys and detailed how training organisations in Victoria are having trouble filling vacancies for apprenticeships. Sadly, many positions often remain unfilled for months at a time. The biggest hurdle for trades to overcome is a growing cultural bias towards tertiary education over skills apprenticeship. Pam Jonas, the manager of policy and research for Group Training Australia Victoria, is quoted in the Herald Sun as saying:

quote.para: The school curriculum has been targeted towards preparing kids for higher education, so the status of trades has slipped.

speech.para: This budget is going one step further to tackle the decline in the number of school leavers seeking to enter an apprenticeship or traineeship. Over the past month—and indeed since the election in 2001—I have been working with Ringwood Secondary College, advocating the need to establish an automotive and manufacturing technological centre in the region. The centre, which I envisage to be located in Ringwood, would assist both the youth of the area and the local automotive industry, which has suffered a major skills shortage over many years. A major focus of this shortage has been a dwindling number of young people actively seeking a career in the automotive industry or in the manufacturing industry in general.

The proposed centre, which will operate in partnership with the Eastern Industry Education Partnership, will target auto skills and manufacturing technology skills, which includes robotics, to the transitional years between early adolescence and the end of secondary school. Importantly, the centre will be available to schools across the eastern region of Melbourne and will not discriminate between public and private school students. This is a program which has great merit and an initiative to which I am very proud to give my full support to ensure that it comes about.

Young learners and young families are not the only groups to benefit from this budget. Older Australians—the pillars of our community and vital contributors to our economy—are the focus of Australia's changing demographics and intergenerational platform. Mature age employment is a key tenet that Australia needs to embrace if we are to adapt to the requirements of our rapidly ageing population. At present, over 180,000 Australians are being assisted by Job Network providers. This number is set to rise in accordance with Australia's demographics. Over the last few weeks, I have been working with a local network of job providers, Swinburne University's division of business, work and ageing and the local area consultative committee. Together they have formed an umbrella organisation known as 45 Plus Workforce. Of specific relevance to this area is the project aim: 45 jobs in 45 days for people over 45. By working with employers and targeting mature age employees, the project seeks to engage and educate the entire sector to bring together jobs and often highly-skilled workers. The $12.1 million allocated in this budget to mature age employment and workplace strategy is a key step in tackling the issue of mature age unemployment. The package of measures works with local organisations such as the ones I mentioned before to address the entrenched view that mature age employees do not have as much to offer as their younger counterparts.

Finally, I would like to talk about another aspect of this budget, the significant increase in funding for aged care. Since coming to office in 1996, the federal government has increased aged care places by over 55,000. Not only has this worked in accordance with Australia's ageing population; it has also helped to gradually address the 10,000-bed shortage left by the Keating government and acknowledged in the Gregory report. The $2.2 billion allocated in 2003-04 over the next four years is the greatest investment in aged care by any Australian government. This major funding injection into the sector will take the government's commitment to aged care to $30 billion over the next four years.

The blueprint for aged care in this budget is a key achievement for this government and has far-reaching benefits for the aged community in Deakin. In line with the government's reforms since 1996, this funding takes into account quality, affordability, accessibility and sustainability in the aged care sector. Unfortunately, recent headlines in Deakin have not focused on the forward-thinking approach of the Hogan review. The proposed sale of Inala Village by the Salvation Army, coupled with the political scaremongering of local ALP figures, has caused some unease in the local senior community. But that was a decision by the Salvos for the southern region, and it stands in stark contrast with their decision to remain within the aged care sector for the eastern region. I have met with Inala management and its residents groups—as has the minister—to listen to their viewpoints. I will be keeping an observing eye on the on-selling process to ensure that the rights of the residents—the quality and conditions for the residents—and, of course, staff entitlements are maintained by the new owners.

The aged care sector in Deakin is a major focus of mine. Just this year I had the opportunity to establish the Deakin Aged Care Council, a representative body drawn from across the electorate. The body provides a forum for feedback on the government's aged care policy within Deakin as well as identifying solutions to social policy areas that will only increase in importance. The aged care council draws on the strength of local providers to discuss current and pending issues in the sector. One such provider is Coronella Retirement Village and Nursing Home at Nunawading, which I have had a long association with, having been a member of its capital development board for a number of years.

The centre's CEO, Ruth Welling, echoes the sentiments of many aged care providers in the Deakin electorate and the surrounding eastern suburbs of Melbourne. Mrs Welling states that this budget's increased funding has been of particular benefit to her establishment. In particular, she highlights a oneoff payment of $3,500 per resident as providing a significant boost to the centre. Mrs Welling supports the method of the government's approach to aged care funding, which places an emphasis on performance and staff. Furthermore, changes to allow ACAT assessments to be done inhouse for residents moving from low to high care, thereby reducing administrative costs and time wastage, have also been welcomed. The extra $877 million over four years through a conditional adjustment package will place aged care providers in a better position to pay their staff. Establishments such as Coronella add that this adjustment will help them to meet the recent eight per cent nurses' pay rise, which has been at the heart of some dispute in Victoria and across the country.

This budget is a testament to the premier economic management and strategic planning skills of the Howard government. In line with what responsible government should do, this budget builds upon the achievements of previous budgets. In particular, Australia's often overlooked middle-income earners have received tax relief which complements the tax cuts which targeted lower income earners in the 2000 and 2003 budgets. I firmly support the measures of this budget, as they offer real assistance to my constituents in Deakin. I urge those on the other side to support the family tax incentive measures as well as the tax cuts which have been outlined by the Treasurer.

talk.start.para: —Sadly, this budget is more to do with securing the Howard government's re-election than serving the needs of Australian families or securing Australia's future. It is a wasted opportunity because it ignores the services that millions of Australians believe should be the government's priority, in particular universal health care, affordable education and accessible child care and aged care.

speech.para: In an overwhelmingly cynical attempt to buy the votes it needs to cling to power, the government in this budget is spending a record $52 billion on tax cuts and one-off payments for families. The tax cuts fail to include middle and low-income families. No doubt the Prime Minister and the government now believe themselves unbeatable, especially when you consider that the government is cynically spending $108 million of taxpayers' hard earned money advertising on television screens and radio and in the newspapers, not to mention its glossy pamphlets, all trying to seduce Australians to vote for it in the forthcoming federal election.
In speaking in debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005, I support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Hotham, the Hon. Simon Crean, that:

quote.para: ... the House

speech.para: (1) condemns the government for its cynical election driven spending spree which - while spending a record $52 billion over the forward estimates - failed to deliver crucial services to Australians, including:
funding the pneumococcal vaccine for children
funding VET in schools so young Australians can either Earn or Learn
ensuring access to Higher Education without excessive fees or increasing student debt levels
ensuring all Australians can access bulkbilling services
ensuring adequate measures to respond to Australia's skill shortage, and
(2) also condemns the Government for failing to present a strategy to adequately address the long term fiscal challenges facing the nation.

The scandal of this budget is that 8½ million forgotten Australian families do not receive a single cent in either tax cuts or increased family payments—not a single cent for three out of five taxpayers. For example, in my electorate of Lowe, according to income levels measured in the 2001 census, 77,992 constituents do not get a tax cut in this budget. The government is spending a record $52 billion, yet 81 per cent of those in my electorate of Lowe do not receive any tax relief. In addition, the government is playing a confidence trick on the 600,000 Australian families who are likely to have their family payments eaten up by existing family payment debts. The government is only attempting to compensate families for bad policy and its inability to solve the family debt crisis. In budget estimates last year it was revealed that some 232,278 customers had their family tax benefit overpayments partially or fully recovered from their tax returns. For families who find it very difficult to estimate their annual income, such as part-time and casual workers, a $600 payment at best is a token form of compensation.

Yesterday we learned that the government will use public funds to advertise the one-off family payment but will delay the clawing back of overpayments until after the election. Compare this debt recovery strategy with the government's lethargy towards stamping out the tax avoidance industry. Since February 2002 I have asked over 100 questions associated with the rorting of our tax system. The government has shown a shameful lack of action, until belatedly announcing its draft legislation two weeks ago to crack down on the outrageous tax avoidance industry in Australia. The government is more interested in chasing after working families than the people who have quite improperly used family law and bankruptcy to avoid paying their fair share of tax. In many cases, they have paid no tax.

In October 2003 we learned that the Australian Taxation Office was pursuing $9.2 billion of disputed tax debt. There were 287 cases where barristers owed $51.6 million in tax debt. In addition to paying little or no tax, hundreds of other barristers were not up to date with the lodgment of their tax returns. For example, one QC had not even lodged a tax return for 45 years. Answers to my questions also confirmed that another QC worked for the tax office for eight years and did not even lodge a tax return in that period. The government has been very slow to deal with these cheats and has not adequately assisted the ATO in pursuing these parasites, who doubtlessly possess a Medicare card and enjoy other benefits that only honest taxpayers should enjoy.

Australians understand that the Howard government is the highest taxing government on record. Australians are paying an average of $9,000 more in Commonwealth tax, including GST, than they were when the Howard government came to office eight years ago. By the end of the forward estimates, Australians will be paying an average of $12,000 more. My constituents in Burwood, Drummoyne, Five Dock and Strathfield find it impossible to understand why, despite this heavy tax burden and high economic growth, they are struggling to access affordable health care and medicines. Why are so many hardworking families in my electorate of Lowe battling as they struggle against rising costs for basic services? Why are they having difficulty accessing a bulk-billing doctor? Why are so many families in my electorate unable to find the child-care places they need? Why do older children who are hardworking students have to incur enormous HECS debts to access a higher education? Why is affordable, quality aged care so difficult to find?

The real tragedy of this budget is that it is a wasted opportunity. The Howard government has run out of ideas and it chooses to underfund vital health services and education programs. The government continues to ignore the 18,028 constituents in my electorate of Lowe who signed my `save Medicare' petition—the largest `save Medicare' petition tabled in the House during the current parliament. My constituents understand the importance of a universal health system. They know that under the Howard government bulk-billing rates in Australia have taken a nosedive. They also know that if this alarming trend continues their credit cards are going to be more important than their Medicare cards.

Only Labor understand that Medicare is a universal health system. Basic health care should never be about one's ability to pay an up-front fee, and it should never require safety nets. If it is not universal, it is not Medicare. A Latham Labor government will get doctors bulk-billing again, restore bulk-billing rates to 80 per cent and make Medicare accessible for all Australians. Our Australian dental care plan will get half a million Australians off dental waiting lists and into dentist's chairs. We will fund a pneumococcal vaccine. We will bring Medicare teams of doctors and nurses into areas of urgent need. Labor are committed to a comprehensive health reform process, including prevention and primary care strategies, responding to the mental health crisis, unifying the funding of our health system and putting an end to the Commonwealth and state buck-passing on health care. This will also include unifying all information in the health system and linking important information across the health system. These are all important priorities the Howard government prefers to ignore.

Critical to a universal health care system are quality and affordable medicines underpinned by our Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Unfortunately, the Howard government is happy to put this at risk in its pursuit of the Australia-United States free trade agreement. The FTA changes the PBS process to allow American drug companies to seek reviews of PBS decisions. Why has the Howard government agreed to an appeals mechanism whereby industry can challenge the decisions of the committee that advises the government on PBS listings? Labor will not support a free trade agreement that harms Australia's PBS and burdens Australians with higher prices for medicines.

The Howard government does not understand that health remains a critical priority for Australian families, deserving greater attention than expensive, feelgood television advertising campaigns such as those we are currently experiencing. Australians want a government committed to a universal health system: Medicare. All Australians, especially the thousands of families in my electorate of Lowe who have grown up visiting doctors that bulk-bill and who enjoy reasonable access to essential medicines, know Labor has a plan to restore bulk-billing and protect the PBS.

My constituents also know that a Latham Labor government will grant Concord Repatriation General Hospital a licence to operate a much needed Medicare eligible magnetic resonance imaging service. On this important health issue for my electorate the Howard government continues to fail my constituents. Over the last two years, on numerous occasions I have asked the former Minister for Health and Ageing, Senator Patterson, and the current Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, to grant Concord hospital the Medicare eligible MRI licence, but to date the Howard government continues to refuse my request on behalf of my constituents and the staff of Concord hospital and the University of Sydney.

I have tabled eight petitions with a total of 8,759 signatures, demanding that the Howard government match the commitment of the New South Wales government, which has agreed to provide the MRI machine and grant Concord hospital a licence to operate a Medicare eligible MRI service. Concord hospital is still waiting while the sick, elderly and frail residents of the inner west of Sydney, who are admitted to Concord hospital and who require this important service, are forced to travel to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital at Camperdown, Westmead Hospital or the Royal North Shore Hospital for their MRI scans.

Our fight on this issue will continue. My constituents in Lowe are telling me the government's lack of action in this area is deplorable. Not only is Concord hospital critical to the residents of the inner west in my electorate, it also has a proud history serving the veterans community and is a teaching hospital of the University of Sydney. While the government is refusing Concord hospital a Medicare eligible MRI service and failing the patients of the inner west, it expects families to pay more to see a doctor. The consequence of this policy means more pressure on all public hospitals. So I will continue to fight for the families and patients of my electorate and to ensure that a Medicare eligible MRI service is soon available to Concord hospital on the election of a Latham government.

Unfortunately, it is not only in health that the government's priorities are misplaced.
