The lack of any new ideas in this budget in the area of education confirms the low priority the Howard government places on education. There is not one extra cent for new TAFE places, despite 15,000 young people missing out on a place every year and many industries facing serious skills shortages. This budget fails the 20,000 qualified Australians who are turned away from university every year because the Howard government refuses to fund enough places. Labor is committed to creating an extra 20,000 university places and 20,000 TAFE places each year.

Shamefully, the Howard government's Higher Education Contribution Scheme changes will cost the average university student an extra $25 a week. We also know the budget will ensure mortgage like student debt, including steep penalties when a student takes out a loan to pay fees. The Howard government's appalling education legacy is fewer public places and six-figure fees to secure a university degree. To the thousands of working families with young children that currently cannot access quality, affordable centre based child care, the budget brings little relief.

In one child-care centre in my electorate, the Abbotsford Long Day Care Centre, not far up the road from where I live, there is a waiting list of 200 for a child-care place. I recently received a letter from my constituent, Mr Aldo Crisafulli, President of the Strathfield South Shopkeepers Association, addressed to the Mayor of Strathfield but also copied to me and to the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, asking for help and support in the establishment of an affordable long day care centre at Strathfield South. Mr Crisafulli writes:

quote.para: Over the past one to two years we have been asking for this type of facility and have approached all three levels of Government. Although both Council and State Government representatives have offered support, in principle, we are no closer to the establishment of such a centre.

speech.para: The Howard government continues to ignore the key issues child-care advocates have been raising for years, including the fast-tracking of the National Early Childhood Strategy relevant to child care, preschools, early childhood development and parenting programs; reversing the cutbacks in centre based long day care places; highlighting the shortfall of 20,000 places for outside school hours care; and the poor industrial conditions that many child-care workers are facing, including the deplorable pay rate of $13 per hour.

I said earlier that this budget is a wasted opportunity. Day after day my constituents are asking me to explain why the most urgent community services are being neglected by the Howard government. Another example of this is the crisis in aged care. Adele Horin, in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, wrote `Elderly forced to wait as aged care crisis worsens' and reported:

quote.para: More than 20,000 elderly people are on waiting lists for nursing homes and aged care hostels in NSW and the ACT ...
They are waiting longer for a vacancy than they did in 2001.
In some cases, people could wait for two years or longer for entry to facilities that specialised in dementia.

speech.para: I believe there can be little doubt that far too many elderly people are waiting in public hospitals, again adding undue pressure to our public hospital system, because the Howard government does not believe aged care is a priority.

Sadly, I have received the same message of outrage and disappointment from many of my constituents in the veteran community. Revealed in the fine print of this budget is a cut for veterans of almost $4 million for 2004-05 to the Home and Community Care program. This will hurt over 65,000 veterans and war widows receiving services under the HACC program. This is madness. Veterans' home care was initiated to assist ageing veterans and war widows to remain in their own home rather than having to enter high-cost retirement or nursing homes—yet hours of domestic assistance and personal care have been cut across the board. It is no wonder so many feel cheated.

I keep saying that this budget is a wasted opportunity, but Australians would be wrong to think this was due only to the government's indolence. There is no doubt the Howard government believes its survival is assured by serving its most powerful benefactors whatever the cost to our community or the environment. Constituents in my electorate of Lowe understand this very well. There is no better example of the Howard government's betrayal of my electorate of Lowe and the electorates of Grayndler and Sydney than the government's decision to sell Sydney airport to its mates at Southern Cross consortium and Macquarie Bank—something the government promised it would not do until aircraft noise sharing problems were resolved—and then this year the decision to sign off on the master plan for Sydney airport.

The people of the inner west of Sydney, people living north of the airport, are still receiving twice the amount of noise promised by the government under its long-term operating plan for Sydney airport. The master plan for Sydney airport forecasts a massive increase in air traffic movements in and out of Sydney airport over the next 20 years. But the Howard government says that Sydney will not need another airport for at least 20 years—and both the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister this week reinforced that message in the parliament and in the media. The Howard government is more interested in ensuring that the new owners of the Sydney airport milk as much as profit out of their new purchase by maximising air traffic movements in and out of the airport, all at the expense of those residents living to the north of the airport in my electorate who are copping ever-increasing levels of aircraft noise.

Another example of the government's determination to look after its most powerful supporters is its plans to sell out Australia's democracy by changing Australia's cross-media laws, which will allow the largest media proprietors to own television stations, radio stations and newspapers in the same city. If this legislation goes through, it will lead to fewer newsrooms, fewer journalists, fewer opinions and irreparable damage to Australia's democracy. We need to guarantee media diversity in Australia, not allow it to be concentrated with the main players being allowed to buy more. It is just as important as maintaining our parliament and our courts.

My constituents understand that we should always adequately fund and support our public broadcaster, the ABC, for the invaluable contribution it makes to our democracy. We should also, as a matter of urgency, restore the credibility and public confidence in our communications regulator, the Australian Broadcasting Authority, by immediately removing from the board the hopelessly flawed chairman, Professor David Flint. I believe that, regardless of one's political persuasion, no-one can honestly support the government's agenda to concentrate media ownership and attack the ABC and believe that that is good for our democracy.

Again I say this budget is a wasted opportunity because it fails to address far too many of the basic concerns of Australian families. The budget is evidence of a tired and arrogant Howard government no longer serving the interests of my constituents or the majority of Australian families. I look forward to the people of Australia electing a Latham Labor government—a government that will provide opportunity for all and govern for all. People in my electorate are sick and tired of the government making decisions which are only in the interests of the most powerful people in Australia. That was evidenced in my referral to the sale of Sydney airport, which is a critical issue for my electorate at a time when aircraft noise is becoming even more unbearable. And, even more important for the future of our democracy, leading to the mortgaging of the public interest and the future of our democracy to Australia's most powerful media proprietors, is the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill, which is currently stalled in the Senate. It is a critical bit of legislation. I hope that the two government members here today, more than on anything else I have said this morning, take a message back to the Prime Minister that that legislation should be defeated. We want more diversity of media ownership in Australia. That is good for a democracy and good for the future of Australia, and I ask government members to take that message back to the government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I stand here today to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005. Many people in my local area have benefited from the Howard government's seventh budget. It is a budget that puts the interests of all families, in my electorate of Dobell and Australia wide, first and foremost. The Howard government has delivered on its promise to the people of Dobell to reform the tax and family benefit systems to allow mothers a genuine choice in being able to look after their families while going back to the work force. The budget includes the largest packet of assistance for families ever—an additional cost of $19.2 billion over five years, of which the Central Coast will receive $288 million. This figure includes a lump sum payment of $600 for each dependent child under changes to the family tax benefit. Most families in Dobell will receive $600 before 30 June this year and be eligible for a further $600 per child after their 2003-04 reconciliation of entitlement. That is an additional $1,200 per child over the next 12 months. Families under family tax benefit A will also receive an increase of $600 per child per year.

speech.para: Increases in size and eligibility for family tax benefit by relaxing the income test to give more families access to this benefit and at higher income levels will significantly help families with the cost of raising children and improve rewards for working. The budget includes measures to help families balance their work and family responsibilities, including increased direct financial assistance in the form of a new maternity payment of $3,000 without means test, rising to $5,000 by 2008, for every mother on the birth of a child. There are up to 500 new child-care places in Dobell, and the lowering of the income test for family tax benefit B means that more mothers can access this payment while still in part-time work.

Why has the Howard government invested so much in Australian families? Because the Howard government appreciates that the family is the greatest institution society has known. It is the greatest source of nourishment to children, as they are taught the values of life. The benefits that flow through to our society from united families are immeasurable. Even though families are Australia's most important unit block, Labor and the Leader of the Opposition continue to be lost on family benefits and taxation policy. As reported in the Herald Sun on 17 May:

quote.para: Labor's tax plans remained in confusion yesterday as Opposition Leader Mark Latham promised broader and fairer cuts but refused to guarantee everyone would receive extra cash.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition is still making policy on the run. Labor will not act to help families and simply cannot be trusted to build and secure Australia's economy.

The truth is that a strong economy greatly benefits families. Good economic management means that we can afford to give something back to hardworking Australian families, including those in my local area. Without job security for workers and low interest rates for home buyers, they and their families would have less security and fewer choices. Strong economic management is not a given. It is not something that comes about by accident or just exists, as Labor would have people believe. The reason this budget has been able to provide so much for so many is that our Prime Minister has made the hard decisions, the tough decisions, over the last eight years to protect and secure Australia.

This government has made decisions that have seen $70 billion of Labor's irresponsible $96 billion debt repaid. It has made decisions that have taken interest rates down to their lowest levels in a generation, making it much easier to pay off the family home. In 1996 Labor left office with official home interest rates of 10½ per cent—this is after they peaked at 17 per cent in 1989—compared to coalition home interest rates of 6.55 per cent. This means that under Labor the extra interest on a loan of $150,000 would be $493 every month. In my case my home loan peaked at 18 per cent, and the overdraft rate on small business was 22 per cent during the last years of the Labor government.

Responsible economic management has helped bring unemployment to under six per cent and has provided solid conditions for Australia's future in an uncertain world. Under Labor, unemployment peaked at 10.9 per cent in 1992 and remained high, at 8.2 per cent, when they left office in 1996. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham—Mr Magic Pudding—have no idea about managing the Australian economy. They have no idea how they are going to pay for their most vague ideas. In response to this budget, the Labor Party does not like to give detail. The Labor Party does not want to know about detail and is crying to anyone who will listen that the government has created a class of forgotten people—that is, those earning under $52,000 per annum. This is simply not true. The budget is part of a series of budgets and a comprehensive range of initiatives, and from all of these there have been a range of benefits provided to people in my electorate.

The government provided significant allowances for the lower income tax bracket in past budgets—when A New Tax System was introduced in 2000 and again in the 2003-04 budget when income tax thresholds were further adjusted. Major income tax reform since 2000 means that today taxpayers in Dobell earning $20,000 are paying $625 per year, or $12 a week, less now, representing a tax cut of 23 per cent. Taxpayers on $30,000 a year are paying $1,050 per year, or $20 a week, less now, representing a tax cut of 17 per cent. Someone on $40,000 per annum is paying $1,630 a year, or $31 a week, less now; that is a tax cut of 17 per cent.

All lower income earners will also get access to a generous matched government superannuation co-contribution. This is worth a maximum of $1,500 for somebody on $20,000; $1,400 for somebody on $30,000; and $900 for someone on $40,000. A reduction in the marginal tax rate by $14.7 billion over the next four years means that the majority of taxpayers that earn between $21,600 and $63,000 will not face any increase at all in their tax rate as their income increases. This means that when people do overtime they keep the benefit for the entire family.

The Howard government has also introduced a bill that aims to increase the Medicare levy low-income threshold for individuals and families, in line with consumer price index increases. The low-income threshold in the Medicare levy surcharge provisions will similarly be increased. These changes will ensure that low-income individuals and families will continue to be exempt from the Medicare levy or surcharge.

The coalition has also sought to address the shortage of GPs and practice nurses, with 1,500 more doctors and 1,600 more practice nurses, while providing GPs with an incentive to bulk-bill. We have already seen the incentive increase the rate of bulk-billing. These new measures will provide substantial support for the Central Coast GPs to provide patients with speedier medical services and a greater diversity of them. This means more hands on deck at the surgery to assist patients on the Central Coast. In fact, under the Australian government's More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas measure, five new doctors have just moved into underserviced areas in my electorate of Dobell. There will be one doctor to service Hamlyn Terrace, one for Berkeley Vale, two for Wyong and one for Ourimbah. This is a good start and a great indication that the scheme is working. I am confident that more doctors will be attracted to the coast under this scheme.

One project that I have been working on for many months now is jointly funding a new medical research centre at North Wyong. I have been working behind the scenes with the Central Coast Division of General Practice, Wyong Shire Council, Central Coast Area Health Service and health minister Tony Abbott for many months now. I have invited Minister Abbott to visit the coast in the next few weeks to discuss this issue with the Division of General Practice and assist me in finalising this matter.

I can confidently say that, through the combined efforts of a group of dedicated locals, things are definitely moving in the right direction. In this budget the government has also demonstrated its commitment to school funding by investing a record $32 billion over the next four years. That is an increase of $8.2 billion over the previous four years. Whether parents choose to send their children to a state, Catholic or independent school, the Howard government wants to continue to support parents for making the choice that they believe is best for their children. Every parent, having paid their taxes, deserves some level of public assistance to support the education of their child, regardless of which school the child attends. This is why the Howard government continues to fund state schools even though, under the Australian Constitution, state schools are the primary responsibility of state and territory governments who own the schools and have the responsibility of managing them.

Since 1985 Australian governments, Labor and coalition, have been the primary source of funds for Catholic and independent schools. But the Labor Party never acknowledge this. They would never acknowledge that 50 per cent of all the money that state governments raise in this country comes from the federal government. The Labor Party distort the truth. They do not think the general public deserves to know the real details. The New South Wales Teachers Federation has been used by the Labor Party as a pawn to exacerbate these campaigns of deception. Labor also like to ignore the fact that every time parents on the Central Coast decide to send their children to what the opposition pleases itself by calling `elite private schools'—although many of the parents of children at private schools are anything but elite in terms of their income levels—they are effectively saving the Australian taxpayer around $10,000 annually.

If state and territory governments had increased their funding to their schools at the same rate as the federal government did in the 2003 budget, there would have been an additional $667.8 million available for state government schools across Australia this year. The Labor Party are very good at distracting attention from the fact that the state governments are underfunding state schools that they have the primary responsibility for managing, regulating and funding.

The severe shortcomings of the New South Wales Labor government should be a very good indication of what a Latham Labor government would be like. The announcement in the federal budget of 34,000 new university places to be allocated Australia-wide, of which Ourimbah campus is set to greatly benefit, is good news for the Central Coast campus. We have a rapidly growing population, and the federal government is committed to ensuring that we have additional places to support this growth. While the deputy vice-chancellor of the University of Newcastle, Professor Brian English, has publicly expressed his delight with this package, Labor continues to express disappointment with it. Labor continues to moan with utter disappointment that the campus did not receive regional status, even though the deputy vice-chancellor of the university has publicly said that the new package would leave the Central Coast campus far better off than if it had received regional status. At a meeting with university officials and local MPs early this year, Professor English said:

quote.para: Under the new package we're talking about receiving an extra 10 percent places to meet demand. Regional loading would have only meant a 1.5 percent loading on current places.

speech.para: Labor are playing politics of the lowest kind and are taking residents in my electorate of Dobell for dupes. Unlike Labor, who have voted against these additional places in parliament, I have been fighting for these places, for which the first allocation of funding has been made in the 2004-05 budget.

Aged care provisions are also very important in my electorate of Dobell, with an ageing population on the Central Coast. The Howard government has announced a massive new investment of $2.2 billion over five years so that the aged care sector is able to continue to provide affordable and quality aged care for an increasing number of older Australians. I am particularly delighted with the one-off payment of $3,500 per resident to be made before 30 June 2004 to all nursing homes in Dobell. This measure, when multiplied by the number of nursing home patients, will equate to an immediate injection of $2.75 million to build new capital buildings to house those extra nursing home patients. While there is still more to be done for aged care on the coast, our current situation is a far cry from the massive aged care place shortages left by Labor—a 10,000 shortfall across the nation.

I also welcome the Howard government's decision to appreciate the value of the work hundreds of carers in Dobell perform every day in a selfless way. Nearly 1,200 carers across the Central Coast who provide constant care for a disabled person or a child are to receive an additional one-off payment of $1,000 from 1 July 2004.

I know that many people in Dobell are pleased that the coalition government is extending funding to the Natural Heritage Trust. This is the largest environmental restoration program in Australia's history, with an additional $300 million to be spent in 2007-08. My local area has already reaped the rewards of over $1.2 million spent on important environmental projects in Dobell over the last three years. The Leader of the Opposition does not seem to have any practical plan to protect the fragile environment. In fact, the Labor Party opposed the creation of the Natural Heritage Trust, and in 13 years of government Labor was unable to create or implement any national environmental protection measures.

Up until recently in Dobell the New South Wales Labor government, the New South Wales environment minister and the state member for The Entrance have refused to work with the council and the federal government to fund an environmentally friendly solution for disposing of 15,000 cubic metres of dredged sludge from a choked up Tumbi Creek. Up to this point the New South Wales government have actively supported dumping the silt into Tuggerah Lakes—a shallow estuarine lake that they have the prime responsibility for.

During the Leader of the Opposition's visit to the Central Coast some months back he promised that he would look into the issue and talk to his New South Wales colleagues. We have not heard from him since. It was very disappointing that the New South Wales Labor government have failed to acknowledge their responsibility for Tuggerah Lakes. However, I am hopeful that as a result of a recent meeting involving all levels of government the Labor Party will realise that this issue is an important one that will affect hundreds of residents of Dobell, our tourist industry and future generations.

One group that is vital to Australia's future and a strong economy is small business. Australia's 1.1 million small businesses employ 90 per cent of all workers. Under Labor's maternity leave scheme, small businesses will have to hold open a part-time position for up to five years. This would cripple small businesses, which are the lifeblood of the economy in my electorate of Dobell. But we all know who the Labor Party are beholden to, and it is not small business. Few workers in Dobell belong to unions. Labor are only interested in big governments, big companies and big unions. Why? Because they bring big dividends, just like the rolled gold rent rip-off rort of Centenary House in Barton—a $36 million gift courtesy of hardworking taxpayers.

In the Howard government's 2004-05 budget the compliance red tape for almost three-quarters of small businesses has been significantly pared back. Small businesses which have an annual turnover of less than $50,000 and voluntarily register for GST will be able to report and pay their GST annually. This means they will no longer be required to lodge a quarterly business activity and will allow them to complete all their GST requirements in one end-of-financial-year visit to the accountant.

With a background in both large and small business, I understand what this means for small businesses in Dobell. The Howard government is the only government that is committed to helping small businesses grow and develop and the only government that recognises that you cannot take the one-size-fits-all approach with small business, because each small business is so different.

Small business operators are ordinary, everyday people who are busting a gut to get from A to B. They do not sit all day within the confines of luxurious airconditioned offices overlooking the city with their secretaries at their beck and call. They do not hire and fire workers as they please because they are the workers. They are plumbers, bus drivers and dry cleaners who have been prepared to take a risk to create some wealth for themselves and their families and to actively climb the ladder of opportunity. We would not like to see them sliding down the snake of a Labor government. That is what the Howard government's seventh budget, and indeed our philosophy, is all about. It is about giving people incentive to work hard and rewarding them when they do. It is about fostering growth and helping people to help themselves. I commend these bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —In this House we get the opportunity to talk about those matters which directly confront people who live in our electoral districts. Today I want to talk about a group of people who are doing it very tough at the moment: the dairy farmers of Australia. People on the land are really finding it very hard at the moment where the dairy industry is concerned.

speech.para: In the dairy industry we have something very wrong in the market forces which are operating. We have very low milk prices being offered. Unfortunately, the milk prices which are being offered by the milk companies and the dairy cooperatives are almost uniform. So you have someone on a dairy farm in west Gippsland or south Gippsland who has worked hard, whose farm is producing more milk and is more productive this year than last year, getting paid substantially less than what they got in the previous year. If they want to shop around and look at who might purchase their milk, they have only a limited choice. The milk companies and dairy cooperatives are offering almost identical milk prices.

A government report just a month or two ago showed that the price that the consumer is paying at the local corner store for a litre of milk is $1.50 or $1.60, but the person who makes the milk—the dairy farmer—is getting about 24c or 25c a litre. This is the biggest disparity in history between what the dairy farmer is getting paid and what the consumer is paying for the product.

I say to the House that the milk processing task is not turning gravel into gold. It is not turning water into wine. It is turning milk into processed milk. The people who take the financial risk in running a dairy farm and who contribute, through their effort and their sacrifice, to creating the basic product should get a better share of that $1.60 than 24c. I say to the House that we need to make sure that people who take these financial risks and who do the hard work associated with being on a farm—often at huge personal cost to their family because of the impact it has on the amount of time they can spend doing other things—get a fair return for their work and their sacrifice. That is not happening right now.

I appeal to the members opposite and other country members in this place. We have a lot in common. If you have a look at us, whether we are in the Liberal Party or the Labor Party or The Nationals, the big thing that really joins the country members is the fact that we represent country districts. Our work is different. The industries in our electorate are different. On an issue like this we should be able to have a look at the common factor: the basic fact that the person who is on the farm is getting 24c and you and I buying it at the supermarket or the corner store are getting it for $1.60.

The farmers are telling me—and I am sure they are telling my colleague the member for Hinkler and other country members in this place—that 24c is not enough. It is not enough. If we want people to stay in the dairy industry we have to make sure that they get a fair return. I appeal, in a bipartisan way, to members opposite who represent country districts for them to try and get the message through that something needs to be done here.

It is my strong conviction that what needs to be done is to make sure that there are proper market signals and market forces working in this industry. They work in other places. We should make sure that they work here for dairy farmers, so they can get not just the risks and the downsides associated with market forces—which is what is happening now—but also the benefits in being able to have market forces working for them to create some competition in the milk companies and the dairy cooperatives. At present they are amazingly offering almost a uniform price and I do not think that works in the interests of country communities. I know that it does not work in the interests of dairy farmers. That is one issue that I wanted to mention today in my contribution to the debate.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek an intervention.
(Mr Mossfield)—Will the member allow a question?
—I will from the member for Hinkler.

—While broadly in agreement with the honourable member's thrust, could I ask him two questions: first, is it not true that the Victorian growers, by referendum of their own members, decided to deregulate and, second, could he suggest to me—and I do not say this with any malice; it is a genuine question—in what way he would re-regulate the industry to make that happen?

—I thank my colleague and friend the member for Hinkler for his question. If it had been anyone but him, I do not think I would have allowed it. I think it is a good question asked in the best spirit of this place and I would answer his question in this way: I think the dairy farmers had put before them the idea that the industry was going to be deregulated, `so take your choice—this package or nothing'. I think people had a gun to their heads in relation to that. On the second question, I do not think there is a serious argument for going back to the system of regulation that we had before. But I think that there is an argument, coming from dairy farmers themselves, that we want to end up with a situation where we get some civilising force into the planning associated with the industry.

speech.para: Right now what we have is the worst of market forces but none of the best of market forces. I say to my colleague the member for Hinkler that I think we can develop a plan and a model to try and make things better for dairy farmers. I just come back to where I started in this: I have dairy farmers in my electorate who are producing hundreds of thousands of litres more milk this year than they did last year and getting paid hundreds of thousands of dollars less. How can anyone say that that is a reasonable market signal? What that says is that, if you produce more—you work hard and are more productive—you get less. We are all talking about the dairy industry as being one of the great flagships of Australian trade and enterprise and one of the great agricultural industries in our country. How can we reasonably expect people to stay in the industry if we are not able to give them proper market signals which encourage them to produce more and generate more wealth for our country?

So I thank the member for Hinkler for his question—it is a good question—and I come back to the point I made before: between the country members of this place we should be able to create a better way for dairy farmers and for others in agricultural industries to be able to plan sensibly for their future knowing with some certainty what the likely returns will be and knowing that there are proper market forces operating. That is not happening now and it is to the detriment of our country and to the detriment of those people who make the financial sacrifices and work their guts out on farms, often for little or no return.

The next matter I want to raise is an unusual circumstance which has happened in another agricultural industry and is associated with the implementation of the GST. There is a company, Pureharvest, which operates in my electoral district with a factory in Drouin. They made a good point in a letter sent to me recently. They believe there is an anomaly in the list of foods which attract the GST. They point out that, whilst soy and rice milks are exempt from the GST, oat milk attracts the GST. They say that `the processes for manufacture are basically the same for all three products'.

I am not here to bang the government around the head about the GST; I think that that debate has been had, but it seems to me that we have an anomaly here. It does not seem fair on the basis of what has been pointed out by this company, Pureharvest, in relation to their product. I would urge the government to take on board the point made in this letter that it does seem like a genuine anomaly. It seems like a mistake that the government have made, and they should be big enough to do something about it and act to make sure that we have some sort of consistency in products that have the GST applied to them and products that are exempt. When you think about it, rice milk, soy milk and oat milk are really in the same family of products that people might have an interest in—non-dairy products. I guess they have much the same market, and it just stands to reason that the production process would be very similar.

So I say to the Howard government: `Please have a look into this, and please see whether you can give some clarity on it.' It would seem to me to be obvious that we need to make sure that oat milk gets the same exemption as rice milk and soy milk. So I would appreciate, and I am sure that Pureharvest and the people that they employ would appreciate, the Howard government having a look at that and trying to clear up this anomaly.

I also want to talk briefly today about the important issue of petrol prices. For those of us who represent country districts, this is a very important issue, because we do not have the range of public transport opportunities that are available to our good friends who live in the capital cities. We do not have the tram going past our front doors; we do not have the silver train close by, linked to a suburban rail system; and bus services are infrequent. How we get around in country districts is in our cars, and often we have to drive considerable distances just to do our ordinary business. Having a car is not a luxury in a country area.

I want to read out to the House a letter I saw written to the Herald Sun newspaper by one of my constituents which I think sums it up pretty well. It was written by Julie Ettery, who lives in Leongatha. She wrote, in the 50-50 section of the Herald Sun on 31 May:

quote.para: Petrol prices go up, and we are told to either walk or cycle. I drive 60 kilometres to Monash University three times a week. If I walk, maybe I could get there three times a month. If I could do it on a bike, I would be on my way to Athens.

speech.para: I think she makes a good point. Cars are not a luxury for people who live in country districts, and we have really been hurt by the very big increases in the cost of petrol which have occurred over the course of the last few months in particular.

There is a real opportunity for us to do something to try and create some fair dinkum competition in the petroleum industry. I know that governments have, for a long time, looked at this and had report after report into this but have not had the guts to really have a fair dinkum crack at this industry. My view is that we have at our disposal laws which could make a difference in terms of the way petrol prices are determined in Australia. Even blind Freddy could see that there is too much price collusion in the petroleum industry, and this is really to the detriment of ordinary consumers of petroleum products. In particular, it is of great detriment to those people who live in country districts. We often pay petrol prices which are considerably higher than those on offer in the big capital cities. Often we have to look at a very big price differential between what we pay and what people in town pay. We know that there is a cost associated with transporting petrol from the big cities out to where we are. We know that that is true, but we have a rough idea of what the cost is, and it is often about one-tenth of the price differential. We could accept that it costs 1c or 2c per litre to deliver out to somewhere in South Gippsland, West Gippsland or the Latrobe Valley, but it is often not 1c or 2c per litre more that we have to pay—sometimes it is 8c, 9c, 10c, 11c or 12c more. We think there should be some fairness in the system, and the Labor Party has a plan to try and do something about that. These high petrol prices are a huge problem for country people. We have seen over the period that roughly follows the course of the Iraq war a real increase in the instability of the Middle East region, which has led to increases in the petrol prices that people pay at the bowser in South Gippsland, West Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley.

The Howard government's approach to this issue is to say, `These are international factors; there is nothing we can do about them.' That is not good enough. The federal government is no paper tiger—it is not a weak outfit that is powerless to do anything in the circumstances. The federal government has the opportunity to make laws which will provide for increased competition. We think that that should happen. The Labor Party has put together a plan to try to create some fair competition in the petroleum industry and break the power of big oil companies and to try to help motorists, particularly those in country areas who depend on their cars just to get around to do the ordinary things that make up their daily activities.

Our plan includes amending the Trade Practices Act to guarantee independent wholesalers and retailers access to fuel supplies from the terminals of the major oil companies on fair terms. Our plan includes allowing independent wholesalers and retailers to bargain collectively when seeking fuel supplies from the terminals of major oil companies. Our plan involves the outlawing of predatory pricing under the Trade Practices Act and strengthening section 46, the abuse of market power provision. That will protect the independents against the market powers of big companies. Our plan also involves giving the ACCC the power to issue cease and desist orders to provide immediate relief against market abuse and anticompetitive behaviour.

We think that those parts of our plan will make a real difference in creating some fair dinkum competition in the petroleum industry. That will make a big difference to people living in South Gippsland, West Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley, and to people who live in the Pakenham district who are commuting big distances just to get to their jobs every day. You need to have regard for the effect of high fuel costs on people's weekly budgets. People often pay $100 a week for petrol. That is a huge cost. When petrol prices go up, as we have seen in the last few months in particular and particularly over the last eight or nine months, it has a huge impact on people's weekly budgets. That is why we have developed our plan and why we think that the government should take a similar line and do something about addressing this important issue.

In my remaining time let me mention one of the other great agricultural and horticultural industries of Australia: the apple and pear industry. It is a great industry in which people have made a great contribution to the nation's economy over many generations. Over the last four or five years we have had a big debate in this place about whether we should allow apples from New Zealand which are infected with fire blight to come into Australia.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.09 p.m. to 12.20 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The risk of fire blight affected apples coming into Australia is a very real threat to the apple and pear industry. I appeal to the government not to allow this issue to drag on any longer. We have had four or five years of apple and pear growers having to campaign to keep fire blight apples out of the country, instead of being able to focus on their businesses. Apple and pear growers have said to me that they feel this is a huge amount of time that they could be using for more productive purposes for their businesses—and, I am sure, for the apple and pear industry more generally.

speech.para: I say to the government: what right does anyone have to destroy someone's livelihood in the interests of trade? We have apple and pear growers in this country, in many cases second and third generation people, who have worked hard their whole lives and struggled to be part of an industry that has generated a lot of prosperity for Australia. They have been good contributors in our local communities, and I think the federal government owes them something better than what is going on now with the politicisation of the import risk assessment process.

We want a system which is based only on science. Under the Howard government, we have not seen a system which is based only on science. I appeal to the government to ban the importation of fire blight affected apples and give this industry the certainty they need to put this issue behind them and focus on growing their businesses and the industry in the best interests of our country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and to support this government's ninth budget. I wish to champion our efforts in repaying $70 billion of the $96 billion debt we inherited from Labor, which represents a saving of around $5.5 billion per year in interest payments. By repaying the debt and running budget surpluses, we have been able to redirect money that previously went to paying interest on Labor's debt into national security and defence, health, education and better lives for our families. Australia's fiscal outlook remains positive, and this government will maintain the budget in surplus after providing $36.7 billion in new assistance for families through family tax benefit arrangements; maternity payments and child-care funding; cutting income tax; boosting retirement savings; and providing for carers and aged care.

speech.para: Residents and businesses in my electorate of Forrest in the south-west of Western Australia—and, indeed, throughout Australia—have benefited from the continued sound economic management of this federal Liberal government. With such sound financial management, the benefits will continue to mean economic growth, low interest rates, low inflation and low unemployment. It is expected that a stronger world economy in 2004-05 will provide a renewed source of demand for our exports. This will rebalance our growth drivers from the internal to the external and assist in maintaining strong economic growth while keeping inflation low. Despite the weakness in the world economy and a drought, growth is forecast at 3½ per cent, with inflation at two per cent.

We now have the lowest unemployment in a generation, at levels only once touched briefly in the last 23 years. The rate of 5 per cent is amongst the lowest in developed countries, with the OECD rate around 7 per cent. The percentage of the working age population in employment is at its highest level for 30 years, and the prospects remain good for keeping unemployment below six per cent over the forecast horizon.

I enjoy explaining the economic background and debt reduction to my constituents so they can understand that reducing debt and reducing the interest payment burden gives this government opportunities to spend on other priorities. This government is about putting the dividends of good economic management back into the community, whether that be through more money for services, increased family tax benefits or tax cuts for individuals.

This budget ensures that spending on health has more than doubled under the Liberal coalition, from $17 billion in 1996-97 to $35 billion today. Medicare has been strengthened with a new safety net that protects Australians from high out-of-hospital medical bills and with funding for 1,500 more doctors and 1,600 more practice nurses, as well as more bulk-billing incentives. In this budget, help will be given to those who find it difficult to control diabetes with injections, and I am very pleased with the funding assistance provided for profoundly deaf children for cochlear implant speech processors.

This budget provides a range of measures to ensure aged care services are affordable, accessible, appropriate and of high quality into the future. The demographics of my electorate in the south-west of Western Australia indicate huge growth, but obviously with that growth comes higher demand for aged care facilities with a lot of people moving to coastal areas. Since coming to office in 1996, the Howard government has provided more than 55,600 new places in community care and residential care. In responding to the growing demand, we are on target to meet our aim of 200,000 places by June 2006.

This budget continues to provide increases in the number of aged care places—in fact, $58 million for 27,900 new places over the next three years, including 13,000 this year, which represents 770 aged care places for Western Australia. The quality of care in aged care homes will be improved by enhancing the skills of aged care workers, while 1,600 aged care nurses will begin training over the next four years to better prepare for the growth in our ageing population. These are important responses to our direct longterm problem of an ageing nation. But solving these sorts of problems is not a cheap or easy exercise. In 2002 the percentage of our population over 65 was 12.8 per cent; in 2042 it will be 24.5 per cent. This represents unique challenges.

Locally in my electorate of Forrest, in the south-west of Western Australia, we are doing pretty well with aged care, but that has not always been the case. When I identified there was a problem, I called in the local providers and assessed what needed to be done and we set about achieving outcomes. I am delighted today to be able to say that, over the last few budgets, many of our local providers' problems have been solved. There will be a 160-bed facility owned by Churches of Christ in Leschenault and we have addressed capital and bed requirements in Donnybrook, Bridgetown, Manjimup and Busselton. We are currently working on additional places for Harvey and a home in Dunsborough and we are fixing the problems in Collie. It again shows that, if you have the money to address these priorities, effective local representation and the necessary commitment, the results will follow.

Local carers who make a great contribution to our community have also been acknowledged in this budget with the one-off $1,000 lump sum bonus payment to be paid to eligible carers in June, in recognition of the approximately 80,000 people who carry out their role in caring for a person with a disability. Also a $600 bonus payment will be provided to 300,000 recipients of the carer allowance at the payment date. This bonus, I might add, is tax-free free and will not be treated as income when calculating social security payments. People who are devoted to caring for disabled people are Australia's unsung heroes; the budget can afford to deliver more help and there is no group more deserving. From 1 July 2005 the coalition will allocate $107 million to enable approximately 13,000 carers who provide substantial levels of personal care while not living with the recipient to receive the carers allowance. Also a further $99 million will be allocated to expand the access of carers to respite services.

What were not so well publicised were the extra childcare places to be allocated: an additional 40,000 family day care places and 40,000 outside school hours places. Since 1996, there has been an 85 per cent increase in the number of day care places. The south-west has been a major beneficiary of this increase. It was not so long ago that parents could not get places locally, either in a centre or in a local community, with some centres having waiting lists on which there were as many as 60 names. Now there is plenty of choice. Places like Pemberton and Harvey now have centres and we are working towards having a community centre in Walpole. I am acutely aware that we are still short on family day care locally, but with this budget announcement of new places and my working with the minister we should be able to solve this problem. The new maternity payment and the expansion of outside school hours child care and family day care places will assist families in balancing work and family commitments. These changes to family tax benefits will help women re-enter the work force after having children. Good economic management has a direct bearing on the services we are able to supply locally.

The government are committed to investing in our next generation by investing in education to ensure a skilled, productive and healthy work force and society. Funding for schools at $32 billion represents an increase of $8.2 billion over the last four years, conditional on the states implementing standards of reporting to parents on the progress of their children's literacy skills. The coalition will provide $2.6 billion over five years in new funding for universities and deliver reforms that allow universities to better tailor their courses to student demand. The coalition will further increase our focus on the 70 per cent of students who do not go directly to university by spending more than $725 million on new apprenticeships. Currently 406,900 Australians are training as apprentices.

In order to increase the efficiency and productivity of our economy, which naturally leads to increased demand on road and rail, the government is providing a further $1.1 billion over five years for our road and rail system. This is in addition to the $2 billion announced in January this year to upgrade our road and rail system. This will improve the safety of Australia's major highways and make it quicker and cheaper to transport freight. This funding is in addition to the funding already announced under the Roads to Recovery program, where my electorate of Forrest has seen high spending by the Commonwealth government, money going direct to local governments, for improving roads that the local community deem important. It is disappointing that, at a time when the federal government is putting more money into roads, the state government is not matching it and in fact is cutting its vital funding to road infrastructure.

Next week the minister will be making further announcements on specific spending proposals to be contained in the AusLink package, which is our road and rail infrastructure investment program. I am looking forward to the funding announcement this week of the Mandurah Bypass—or the Peel Deviation, as it is sometimes known—as part of the AusLink package. The Mandurah Bypass will mean faster road access from Perth through to the south-west regional centres like Bunbury, Busselton and Margaret River and further south to Manjimup, Pemberton, Northcliffe and beyond, and, obviously, better access for products and producers in the south-west to markets in the city and export destinations.

The small business community has not been forgotten, with numerous measures to help streamline the tax process, one of which will see businesses with sales of less than $50,000 able to keep and use the GST for a year. This will reduce the compliance cost for up to 740,000 small businesses, as well as 30,000 non-profit organisations. WET, the wine tax relief, is another important initiative for industry and small business in my electorate. I was heavily involved in lobbying the Prime Minister for WET relief for local wineries from Harvey through to Capel, Margaret River and Pemberton. The $290,000 WET rebate will mean that a vast majority of local wineries will not pay WET, which I know will make a huge difference to the industry.

I believe the south-west of Western Australia contains the world's premium wine-producing areas, from Harvey to Margaret River and through to Pemberton. This will make a big difference to their trading. I have worked hard for WET relief, along with a number of my colleagues. I brought the Treasurer to my electorate in 2002 to meet representatives of the wine industry and view these premium wine-growing areas. The WET relief for wine producers will effectively take some 90 per cent of wine producers out of the WET system. I am delighted that this proposal has been adopted.

I am also pleased with the additional funding of $54.4 million from 1 July 2005 for three years to boost ABC regional and local programming. This funding will allow the continuation of successful regional and local programming initiatives already in place and provide the ABC with certainty in developing its forward plans for local and regional programming and operations. Regional communities are the major beneficiaries of improved locally driven programs and content. I am pleased to hear that there will also be additional employment opportunities in Bunbury, with the ABC having funding for extra staff.

I am also very happy to report that the government has provided $15 million in this budget for the Western Australian forestry industry and its communities to help rebuild the once vibrant industry and to help offset the effects of the Western Australian government's decision to drastically reduce logging quotas. The Howard government is committed to providing those in the industry with the security they need at this crucial time. We have provided two funding streams for the industry. The first program will provide $12.5 million over two years under the forestry assistance program for Western Australia to promote investment and long-term job creation in the industry. The second funding stream will provide a further $2.5 million for Western Australian timber communities under the grants for forest communities program. The Australian government is determined to assist country communities to help themselves through a range of projects that can restore morale, and this program will provide grants of between $5,000 and $100,000 for eligible community based initiatives.

Some people look at budgets and say, `What's in it for me?' and, if they do not get a tax cut or a discount, conclude that it is not a good budget. The point is that they look at budgets in isolation—from year to year—when, in reality, the government must balance the priorities over an entire three-year term. More than balancing priorities, budgets must also be framed with economic circumstances in mind. You can spend money only when it has been collected—and that occurs only when people have jobs and businesses are doing well.

The 2001-02 budget focused on seniors and self-funded retirees as well as defence spending; the 2002-03 budget focused on national security, health and higher education; and last year's budget produced across-the-board tax cuts. This budget has seen the emphasis placed on families, tax cuts for those on incomes above $52,000 and wine tax relief as well as continuing our commitment to road funding and aged care. So, on the whole, people have gained some benefits from the last three budgets, while we have endeavoured to keep the economy strong and keep our borders secure.

I emphasise again that the government can and should provide dividends but only when they are affordable. This component of the budget has basically delivered ongoing tax reform from when we started the process on 1 July 2000. The tax cuts in this budget improve rewards for working overtime and for gaining promotion. They increase the income threshold for the 42 per cent tax rate to $58,000 in 2004-05 and increase it again to $63,000 in the 2005-06 financial year. The income threshold for the 47 per cent tax rate will be increased to $70,000 in the 2004-05 budget year and to $80,000 in the 2005-06 financial year. These reforms will mean that 80 per cent of workers will remain in the 30 per cent tax bracket for at least the next four years.

By boosting retirement savings we can better prepare our ageing population. The allocation of $2.7 billion will enhance the superannuation co-contribution scheme and reduce the superannuation surcharge, which will boost incentives for such retirement savings. We estimate that more than three-quarters of the benefits will go to low- and middle-income earners.

Although I have outlined only some of the major focuses of this budget, some people have said to me, `There's no tax cut in it for me,' or `I don't have a family.' To those people I say that you cannot view a budget in isolation; you must look at the budgets over the three years to see the full plan. Secondly, I say that the best education, tax and health policies come from a strong economy. The reason for that is that it gives you choices. Not having to repay, as we did, $8,700 million in interest payments on the previous government's debts, frees up money for other things—families, health, education and roads.

talk.start.para: —In the context of this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005, which I understand is a broad-ranging discussion on matters, I want to for a moment refer to the drivers of small business—and one in particular. I note that my friend the member for Holt, who is sitting in the chamber, is fully aware of these people, because his father has made a massive contribution to the economy of the Northern Territory, particularly in the mining industry where he was responsible for the development and running of Giants Reef, which is a magnificent resource in the Tennant Creek district. But it is not about that that I want to talk. I do however want to talk about someone who spent some time in Tennant Creek—although a long time before the time of my dear friend's father. I want to speak about Len Kittle, who passed away in Alice Springs early in the week at the age of 86. I want to use a small amount of the time that I have this afternoon to pay tribute to Len.

speech.para: Len arrived in Tennant Creek in Central Australia in the thirties. He went away to war and afterwards came back to Tennant Creek and set up a business, which flourished. That business still survives. He was awarded the General Motors franchise in November 1945. That business, Kittle Bros, flourished in Tennant Creek. Len and his wife Phyllis had a family and decided to relocate to Alice Springs, which at that stage, in 1958, had a population of around 3,000 and clearly more amenities than Tennant Creek. Len took over the GMH dealership in Alice Springs and since then Len's company, Kittle Bros, has been operating on a continuous basis selling vehicles in Central Australia.

It is important that we appreciate that Len and his family have made an enormous contribution not only to the economic life of Central Australia but also to the community generally. That has been earmarked by his involvement with the Rotary Club of Alice Springs, the Central Australian Show Society, the Alice Springs Town Council and the Alice Springs Youth Centre. This was all recognised in 1982, when Len was awarded the Order of Australia. It was very much deserved. Len was also a founding member of the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory at its formation in 1974. Whilst we may have shared different political allegiances, it is very clear that he and his family had an enormous commitment to Central Australia and to developing business opportunities in the Centre.

I pay tribute to Len and his family. He was a very devoted family man. He and his wife Phyllis had six children, which is an indication of their commitment to each other and also to the Centre. Len is survived by his family: his wife, Phyllis; sons Robert and Peter; daughters, Heather, Gwen, Sylvia and Shirley; and his 14 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. To these people, I offer my greatest sympathies. I want them to know that their father, their grandfather, made an enormous contribution to the life of Central Australia and made an enormous impression on all those people he came in contact with.

Now let me address some of the important items in the budget. One of the issues which I have already spoken about in this place or in the main chamber on a number of occasions is the Treasurer announced tax cuts in the budget. It is worthwhile noting that the ABS publishes income statistics for individuals aged 15 and over by electorate. These figures are bracketed into segments ranging from zero dollars per week to $1,500 or more. By eliminating the top brackets where individuals earn more than $1,000 per week—$52,000 a year—you get the number of income earners in the electorate who will get any benefit from the new tax thresholds that were announced in the budget. In my own electorate, 88 per cent of wage earners, salary earners, income earners, will get no benefit at all from these tax cuts. In the seat of Solomon, which is my neighbouring electorate to the north, 85 per cent of the electorate will get no benefit from these tax cuts.

I ought to point out that this is in contrast to some of the seats of my blue-blood friends in the Liberal Party. If you go to the seat of North Sydney, held by Mr Hockey, only 65 per cent of the electorate will not benefit from these tax cuts. Such electorates have a material advantage, which is no surprise, given the nature of this government. What we need to understand is that there are localities that benefit most from the tax cuts—by and large, metropolitan localities—although it is also true that some of those more depressed suburbs in Western Sydney do very badly out of this arrangement.

In my electorate a greater number are disadvantaged—with no tax cut. My electorate has less home ownership, fewer schools, and less access to health services than the electorates of North Sydney, Bennelong, Bradford, which I mentioned, and other electorates which I am sure people are aware of and understand what I am talking about in relation to my blue-blooded friends opposite. I wonder how many of the constituents of the member in the chamber, the member for Boothby, are going to be deprived of a tax cut. I am sure it will be nowhere near the number of constituents I have who are deprived of a tax cut as a result of this government's decisions.

But if there are a large number, let him say so. I do not hear many of the government members waltzing around the electorate saying so. Indeed, the member for Solomon has not walked into the electorate and said: `Hello, I earn just over a hundred grand a year; I've just got a tax cut. It's terrific! But you poor beggars who earn less than $52,000 a year'—85 per cent of my electorate—`are going to miss out.' I have not heard any Liberal member of this parliament or any member of the coalition—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to ask a question of the member for Lingiari.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—Will the member for Lingiari accept a question?
—No. As I am sure my good friend appreciates, he will have time to address these matters in his own contribution—if he has not done so already.
—I already have.
—Oh, you poor thing! Did you say in your contribution, `I have great sympathy for those people who did not get a tax cut'? Did you `out' yourself or `out' your party?
—The member for Lingiari will address his comments through the chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate your intervention. In the Australian Financial Review of 13 May this year, an item by economics editor Alan Mitchell referred to the issue of bracket creep. He said:

quote.para: Average tax rates will rise, even for those taxpayers whose top marginal tax rate remains constant at 30 per cent.
In fact, bracket creep will make quite a handy contribution to the financing of the Howard government's election-year spending promises.
Most ... spending programs are costed over four or five years. Over that period, bracket creep will claw back between $9 billion and $13 billion.

speech.para: I think the situation is very clear. On what electorates is this burden now falling at a greater rate—electorates with larger incomes and more home ownership? No; it impacts on electorates like Lingiari, where access to basic services such as education and health and infrastructure such as roads and telecommunications are not to a standard you see in the seat of Bradford—or I am sure in my good friend opposite's electorate—and certainly not in the seats of Bennelong or North Sydney. In the electorate of Lingiari, this budget has not delivered for, as I said, the 88 per cent of income earners who do not receive tax cuts.

There are a number of issues that clearly demonstrate the disadvantage faced by those people, particularly those who live in more remote communities, which have not been properly addressed in this budget. The first of those issues is roads. The previously announced next round of funding for the Roads to Recovery program reveals little for the electors of Lingiari. It is more of the same, and Territorians living in remote communities and travelling on roads in unincorporated areas will be disappointed. For them there is no relief from the winding-up of the Fuel Sales Grants Scheme.

There are a number of questions that need to be answered following the announcement by Ministers Anderson and Campbell of a new Roads to Recovery program. Question 1 is: is there any funding for bush roads in unincorporated areas? The government's argument is that Territorian road users need to be aware that any increase in fuel prices due to the winding-up of the fuel sales grant scheme will be compensated by increased road funding. That is the federal government's argument. If this is the case, the Territory should get a substantial increase in road funding. It would not be unreasonable for the Northern Territory to get an increase of at least $10 million to $15 million in road funding, given the fuel sales grant was worth in the order of $3 million annually to the Territory. Question 2: has the percentage of national funding allocated to the Northern Territory been increased? Remember that in the previous funding package the Territory's cut was reduced from 2.3 per cent of the national total to 1.7 per cent—a reduction of $8.1 million from $28.1 million to $20 million.

Question 3 is: under the new arrangements how much more will regional and remote Australians pay for fuel in comparison to their city cousins, and why are Territorians still paying the highest fuel taxes in Australia? In Alice Springs unleaded fuel is currently 115.9c a litre. Along the Stuart Highway it is as high as $1.30 to $1.40. In off-road communities it is probably $1.50 or $1.60. Question 4: a component of the new Roads to Recovery program is not formula based. How will the minister for transport decide how the non-formula component is spent? Of course he will just wind up the old marginal seats exercise. He will do as he has done previously. These are the basic questions that require answering. He should also tell us why he has not come good with the $20 million he offered the cattlemen in the Northern Territory for beef roads—$20 million over four years. It does not appear anywhere. Will they get it out of this new Roads to Recovery program? What is he going to do about providing appropriate funding for roads on unincorporated land?

Another important issue arises out of proposals in the Department of Education, Science and Training. In April the minister announced some major changes to funding the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program. The changes have come about following a review of the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program. The reform of the existing program is raising a number of questions amongst parents and school groups in the electorate and indeed in other parts of Australia. They are raising questions about the redirection of resources and they are concerned that Indigenous students in remote areas—those in greatest need of assistance—will continue to miss out under the new arrangements. An essential plank of IEDA since 1991 has been the development of Aboriginal student support and parent awareness committees. There are currently 3,900 of those committees around Australia. They have achieved great success in involving Indigenous people in education decision making. They have led to partnerships and better understanding across the community and this value adding has benefited Australian education across the board.

My electorate of Lingiari has an Indigenous population of around 45 per cent of the total population. I have been well placed to identify and see activities in action in communities over many years. I have seen greater participation and interaction with Indigenous parents in schools across the Territory and greater cooperation between parents, teachers and communities, both Indigenous and non-Indigenous, to improve the access of Indigenous students to education and bring about greater attendance and improved educational outcomes. These are long-term activities which go beyond the easily identifiable activities of ASSPA committees such as enabling Indigenous students to participate in school based education, sporting excursions and cultural activities. Parent representatives of ASSPA committees and school principals have contacted my office, expressing their concerns that the new arrangements for ASSPA committees will no longer formally exist and that the discontinuance of formula based funding will negatively impact on the progress that has been made during the last 12 to 14 years.

There is concern that the shift to submission based funding will remove the essential elements of parent participation and decision making from the hands of Indigenous parents at the grassroots level in the classrooms and schools and into the hands of skilled submission writers and bureaucrats who are removed from the areas of need. Concern has also been expressed again by teachers, principals and parents about the extent of the review of the Indigenous Education Direct Assistance Program and the conclusion that the government has drawn from the review in order to change the arrangements for direct assistance. There is a feeling that the consultation was not extensive and that opportunities for input were not extensively canvassed. Further, parents, principals and teachers are concerned that information about the changes is not reaching those most targeted by the changes: parents in Indigenous communities in remote communities.

I can speak with authority on these issues. There are communities in my electorate where English is a second, third or fourth language. How have these communities been informed about the changes that are to take place? Were they consulted? Why have they not been told of the changes? Or do they understand how the new arrangements will work? I fear not. In fact I know, because I had a meeting with a number of teachers and parents from the Walpiri Triangle schools, Willowra and Lajamanu, and recently at Yuendumu. I asked those present at the service whether they were aware of the changes. They had no idea of them. That is not surprising, because we learnt yesterday in estimates about the consultation process for this little exercise, which was clearly drummed up inside the department, notably, I suspect at the direction of the minister.

There were two internal discussion papers. A third discussion paper was distributed to 400 of the 3,900 ASSPA committees that exist. So, instead of having an extensive and wide consultation with all of the ASSPA committees around Australia, they selected 400 ASSPA committees. How many responses do you think they got from those ASSPA committees? Only 10. What percentage is 10 out of 3,900? I will get my colleague Mr Byrne, who is here, to work it out and in a moment he will tell me and I will come back with the answer. But it ain't a lot.

We also know that they only had 62 written submissions. That included the 10 from the ASSPA committees. This process of consultation with Indigenous Australians was a selective exercise. There was no going out and talking to parent communities, there was no talking to school communities, there was no talking to school principals and their committees together, there was no talking to teachers; yet here we have a government that says it is trying to do something to assist Indigenous Australians in education. What they have done, quite clearly and deliberately, in this budget is reduce the funding for ASSPA committees from $19 million across Australia to $15 million.

talk.start.para: —It is 0.25 per cent.

—The number of responses from ASSPA committees to this proposal was 0.25 per cent of the total number of ASSPA committees. How could that be seen as any serious attempt at consultation or even information sharing? There was no serious attempt. The people who are going to suffer as result of this pre-emptive action by this government are going to be Indigenous Australians, those people who most need assistance in education. I have spoken about that issue time and time again in this parliament. We also hear that the government are going to change the Tutorial Assistance Program so that you can only get tutorial assistance in years 3, 5 and 7. Why is this? Because it is after years of MAP testing. What they are saying is that they are not prepared to provide early intervention tutorial assistance for kids who start primary school.

speech.para: We know, in Indigenous education, that students need this assistance throughout their school lives. The additional assistance which is provided by these funds ought to be made available throughout the school lives of these students, not when they have fallen through the cracks. That is just not good enough. What the government are proposing to do is to identify those people who fail and then try to bring them up. Why would you not start at the very beginning and say: `We'll give you the best opportunity that we possibly can. We'll provide you with the best information, the best assistance, the best advice, the best support that is currently available,' instead of being selective about it? This is a shame and something which needs to be addressed by the government. It is something which I believe will have a serious impact upon the educational opportunities for many Indigenous Australians and certainly those Indigenous Australians who live in my electorate.

How can the government say that there is not going to be any material impact on these ASSPA committees? The government have cut the expenditure from $19 million a year to just over $15 million a year and have then said, as they have said in these proposals, that all the funds will now be submission based. They are expecting these small Indigenous schools in very remote communities to write submissions to the department to get access to these funds. What lunacy! That shows an absolute ignorance and an absolute neglect of the needs of Indigenous Australians, and particularly those who live in remote communities.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to talk on this Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and, in particular, about the federal budget and the huge win for Australian families. I also want to take this opportunity to talk about my electorate of Richmond and the benefits the budget will have there. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, I know you will be particularly interested, as a fine representative of Page, having spent all of you life on the North Coast. There is no doubt that this is a family friendly budget that will have enormous benefit to all Australian families. As the first ever Minister for Children and Youth Affairs I unashamedly have pushed for a greater family focus in this budget, which delivers real assistance where it counts. The budget will help local families to raise their children and manage the balancing act of work and home life. Over 13,000 families in Richmond will receive a $600 one-off payment for each child before July 2004. On top of this, to families receiving family tax benefit A we will be delivering an ongoing increase in the maximum base rates worth $600 for each child for 2004-05 and every year thereafter. In real terms, these changes mean that an eligible North Coast family with two children will be $2,400 a year better off in their hip pocket in 2004-05.

speech.para: To assist families with the cost of newborns, the federal budget will deliver a universal maternity payment of $3,000, rising to $5,000 in 2004. The real area of interest is child care, where there has been a very large boost in assistance. From 5 July 2004, almost 6,000 families in the Richmond electorate will receive an increase in their child-care benefit payment. Local families with one child in full-time care will receive an extra $3.50 per week and those with two children will receive $7.50 per week. Richmond families will have their share of the 40,000 outside school hours care places and the 4,000 family day care places that we have allocated in the budget.

There are tremendous advantages for Richmond families, but also for the carers, who I think have not been spoken about enough. One of the key components of the budget is the $255 million that will assist those on carer payment or carer allowance. The $1,000 bonus for recipients of carers payment will go to over 800 Richmond residents, and the $600 payment for the carer allowance will assist 2,500 recipients. I have to say that these people do a remarkable job looking after their loved ones. It might be a wife or husband looking after their loved one or a disabled child, or it could even be a child or a parent looking after a disabled grandparent.

The expansion of the eligibility criteria for the carer allowance is worth $470 million over four years. We have increased access to respite care, which is particularly important for older carers.
