Yet we have everybody focusing on environmental flows in the Murray River and ignoring all those other important indicators of catchment health.

The recent poli-pedal—so wonderfully led by Tony Abbott, our Minister for Health and Ageing, and supported by Kevin Andrews; the member for Parramatta, Ross Cameron; the member for Deakin, Phil Barresi; and other MPs from time to time—travelled through the electorate, and I made sure that they stopped for morning tea on the banks of the Murray at Tocumwal. I said to them as we rode our pushbikes up the hill: `You will be seeing the Murray shortly. Expect it to look absolutely dreadful, to be a dying sewer, to be full of blue-green algae and for the issue to be demanding instant remedial action.' What they saw was an extremely healthy river, flowing well—almost a banker—with lots of evidence of biodiversity; of animal, bird and wetland life in the region. They were quite surprised.

It is a point that I make over and over again. There are all sorts of reasons why it would be devastating to my electorate if a Labor government were to achieve office at the next election but the one that hurts me the most is the idea that a Labor government would put 1,500 gigalitres of water, regardless of any science, into the Murray River and would destroy the rural communities that I represent. And for what? For really not very much return at all.

I support the national water initiative and the icon sites approach. What our committee said was, `For goodness sake: let's put something in place that collects the physical data that demonstrates the case.' We cannot use models—as we have been doing—that rely simply on the opinion of expert panels, because if you are going to withdraw resources to that extent from rural communities you have to be able to say to them, `We're doing this for very good reasons and we're doing this because the catchment is in crisis if we don't.' The thought of going through all this pain and then finding that we have not really achieved a great deal at the end of it is pretty awful.

I am very supportive of the interim report that our committee brought down. I am very supportive of the irrigated agriculture in my electorate. I am not an environmental vandal and, believe me, none of the farmers that I represent are either. They simply would like somebody to come and do a socioeconomic study that says, `If you withdraw the water, these are the effects that there will be,' so that we can demonstrate what will happen to the communities. You cannot sacrifice communities and close down towns—I am not exaggerating.

A couple of other measures that I was delighted to see in the budget related to aged care. I have some wonderful non-profit aged care providers in the electorate of Farrer. They have fought a long, hard case with me. They have argued very well with our Minister for Health and Ageing, with the previous minister, with me and with anyone whose ear they could get into about the need for us to remember rural aged care providers in any package that we present, and I believe we have. We have injected cash into the sector and have made some changes that will make our aged care homes able to run a lot more profitably and in a lot better fashion. Nothing is more important for older people than knowing that they can retire to a home in the area where they have lived their whole lives and be looked after.

On this score, I must save the highest praise for the aged care nurses in those homes. They are struggling with limited resources and with low numbers. They are doing a marvellous job in caring for large numbers of older Australians, many of them suffering from dementia and many of them not long for this world. It is very important that in those final days and months they are comfortable, they are well looked after and they are happy. I think that our aged care nurses deserve so much for what they give every single day.

The WET relief we saw in this budget was also an important thing that I argued for in the electorate. That means that small to medium wineries will receive some relief on the so-called wine equalisation tax that they pay. I am committed to making sure that works its way through the system properly so that they are not overburdened with book work and it interacts sufficiently well with the state taxes that also have to be rebated for them to get the full 29c rebate on the wholesale sales that they make.

In concluding, the Farrer electorate has a prosperous and bright future under the Howard government and I look forward to important announcements by the Prime Minister that look to the future. We are not resting on our laurels, either—we have the lowest debt-to-GDP ratio in the Western world, we have paid back $70 billion of Labor's $90 billion debt and we look in good shape for the future.

talk.start.para: —In this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and cognate bills, I want to start by focusing on the general economic overview and move onto some of the social policy areas not contained in the budget, and then on to specific local issues for my electorate. In the second of his series of so-called headland speeches in the lead-up to the 1996 election, the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, said:

quote.para: The $2.9 billion—

speech.para: current account deficit—

quote.para: figure for May was not only bad news in itself but symbolised the utter failure of current policies to address this problem.

speech.para: Today, under the stewardship of the Howard-Costello government, the current account deficit has risen to $11.997 billion. This is 15.8 per cent worse than the current account deficit of a year ago. Whose policy failure is it now? In the same headland speech, the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, stated:

quote.para: When I left office, net foreign debt stood at a manageable $23 billion. Today, our foreign debt burden is a crippling $167 billion. That's nearly $10,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia.

speech.para: Today, under the stewardship of the current Prime Minister and the Treasurer, foreign debt is $373.778 billion. According to their preferred formula, foreign debt for every man, woman and child in Australia is now $18,668.

When I look at these figures I am reminded of the Hans Christian Andersen tale, The Emperor's New Clothes, where the emperor is sold a set of clothes by a scoundrel who tells him his new suit is invisible to fools. Because no-one wants to be thought a fool, the clothes are lavishly praised. The emperor travels the streets naked until a child exposes the truth: the emperor is wearing no clothes. I have listened with a sense of disbelief to those opposite praise lavishly the clothes of this Treasurer. Let me say what those on this side of the House know—the emperor has no clothes; the poor economic credentials of this government are exposed. They include record foreign debt, record current account deficit, record trade deficit, record household debt, record credit card debt, record pre-election spending spree, record pre-election spending spree on advertising to get re-elected, record low proportion of first homebuyers in the market and record tax take as the highest-taxing government in our history. The economic credentials of the government are yet another tale it likes to tell about itself.

Having already spoken on the tax and family assistance bills previously, I will keep my comments on both of these brief, but I want to reiterate the following points. In the government's record pre-election spending budget of $52 billion, taxpayers on less than $52,000 a year were the losers. They were the losers in terms of tax cuts, but they are also bearing the brunt of the government's services deficit. This is the group the Prime Minister was pretty quick to tell last year, `You should be grateful for the sandwich and milkshake tax cut'—a tax cut that has long since disappeared with the rising costs of seeing a GP and Telstra line rentals. These are Howard's forgotten people.

In my electorate of Ballarat 81,129 people reported in the 2001 census that they had incomes of less than $52,000. Only 6,769 reported that they had incomes higher than $52,000. That is 81,129 people who the government has determined have not worked hard enough to earn a tax cut. As a member who represents a regional seat, it would be remiss of me not to point out that the tax cuts are skewed against country people. People do not have as many options to earn high salaries in country areas. In fact, the Minister for Health and Ageing is on record as saying that this is a good thing and we ought to accept smaller salaries in regional areas. There are very few positions in my district that have salaries higher than $52,000.

Like other members of the House, I have had numerous complaints about the family tax benefit system. Under the current system one in three families each year has been slugged with debts. The latest family payments data shows that the government's family tax benefit is having a sharp financial impact on families whose income varies during the year, particularly families where a parent is returning to work after time out of the work force caring for a child. The government's refusal to correct the family payment system, which cannot pay families the right amount when they need it, limits parents' ability to balance work and family.

The government's work and family package was drawn up more than a year ago but not released, because it did not suit the government's election timetable. In that time families have been hit with 1.5 million family payment debts at a cost of $1.6 billion. They have been denied outside school hours places and other child-care places and they have had babies without the benefit of any baby care payment. The government has now increased family payments for some families without fixing the flaws in the system which for some will result in money being clawed back. To add insult to injury, the government is asking them to fund a $20 million campaign of television commercials so that it can tell families what a good job it is doing.

The government in the budget focused—I would have to say `failed to focus'—on a number of key social policy areas. I want to turn my attention to some of these. In particular, I want to turn to the area of women's policy. This was the first budget in 20 years where the government did not provide a women's budget statement, and it speaks volumes about the lack of commitment this government has to overall women's policy. I want to commend the adoption by the government of Labor's policy on what is in essence paid maternity leave for women in the paid and unpaid work force. But I want to put on the record how deeply offended I was at the Treasurer's comment that we should all go out and produce `one for the country'. It inspired a particularly blokey atmosphere in this place for the rest of the week, and for the first time in my time here women colleagues from both sides of the House were commenting at just how uncomfortable they felt during that week. It has been a long time in this country since the only context in which women have been the focus of policy attention is their reproductive capacity.

There has been a failure of this government to understand and address the complexity of women's lives. It was illustrated to me the week after the budget when I went to speak to the year 11 and 12 class of politics students at one of my local girls schools. These young women will probably at some time during their lives become mothers, but between them they also have hopes to go to university, to get a job that pays well, to achieve great things in sport, to have their families be proud of them, to travel, to write, to argue, to create, to contribute something to their community, to be well and to have fun.

The women in this place and those that came before us fought long and hard to get the vote, to stand for parliament, to achieve pay equity and to have our voices heard, and it is our voices that have demanded paid maternity leave, better child care, better education and better health services. It is our voices that have demanded that the balance between work and family be the centre of policy making. We know that the lives and aspirations of women and the girls who will follow us are much bigger, broader and more complex than this government can ever imagine. If you think women are going to be satisfied with what is on offer in this budget then you have got it wrong.

I want to mention a couple of areas where the government has failed women. Women are the biggest users of Medicare. In the crucial child-bearing and child-rearing years between 20 and 45, women use twice as many Medicare services as men. In the Ballarat region the shortage of doctors, coupled with the huge reduction of access to bulk-billing—we are at 42.3 per cent, according to the last figures we were able to access—has the potential to compromise the health and future health of women and their families. I do not think it is too much to ask that women have access to affordable and accessible health care.

It has been almost 30 years since the International Year of Women, and it is significant to celebrate the achievements of working women. Equal pay for equal work, affirmative action policies and antidiscrimination policies have all made it possible for women to engage in the work force. However, all the laws in the world cannot make up for lack of access to affordable long day care. The reality for many women that I talk to in my role as a federal member is that their lives are severely impacted upon by the lack of access to affordable child care and by work environments that do not support families. The government has failed to address these issues.

The budget failed abysmally in addressing another key social policy area, that of unemployment for young people aged between 15 and 19. Our estimates are that amongst this cohort of young people in the City of Ballarat the unemployment rate is 23.4 per cent. I am proud that Labor has put this lost generation back on the agenda with our youth guarantee, a youth guarantee that will see all 15- to 18-year-olds getting support to either be studying at school, TAFE or university or be in a job or apprenticeship. The government needs to recognise the value of Labor's proposal and, instead of trying to carp about where the name of the program came from or trying to argue on narrow definitional lines about who constitutes a young person and who constitutes a teenager, and somehow by doing that assume that it has no responsibility for a policy about them, it should work to actually fix the problem.

In terms of social policy and what was not contained within the budget for older people, I want to welcome the aged care funding. We have certainly been experiencing a crisis in aged care in my own electorate, with Hepburn Health Services operating with a $1 million deficit each year because of its aged care facilities and Djerriwarrh Health Services operating with a $250,000 deficit each year. You had to say that the crisis needed to be addressed. Look at what was in the budget for older people and look at what it was saying about older people. Three per cent of older people end up in nursing homes. We have to look after them, and we have to look after them well, but the budget did not talk about the rest of the older population.

What is happening for those people? What is happening for the over-65s who are socially isolated? You could be recognising the enormous contribution you can make through small amounts of money in community care; recognising the broader role that older people play within our community; recognising the mentoring role that they can play within our community; recognising that many older people, particularly those on pensions who do not own their own homes and are in public housing, are in terrible, desperate trouble; and ending some further age discrimination that we have within our current systems. All of those things are things that I hoped to see in the budget but which were not there.

In my remaining few minutes, I want to turn to some of the local issues within my electorate. I want to acknowledge the good things that were in the budget for my electorate. One thing was the extension of the national initiatives program for the ABC. This was initially announced in the lead-up to the previous election, and we managed to get a terrific radio station in Ballarat that the minister came to open. But until the budget there were no guarantees that this funding would continue from next year. Huge amounts of infrastructure have been poured in, there is local employment and there is obviously a loyal local listening audience, so it is terrific to see that that national initiatives program has been continued in the budget. However, I would also have liked to see the government try not to continue it and try to take—

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 5.47 p.m. to 5.59 p.m.

talk.start.para: —I was saying in relation to the ABC funding and the national initiatives program that I would have liked to see them try to take it off us, to be quite honest! I would have had a pretty riotous community on my hands had they done so. I certainly welcome the government's extension of the national initiatives program and, therefore, the ABC radio station in Ballarat.

speech.para: I also want to talk about the wine equalisation tax. As the chair of the Labor caucus wine industry task force—and I note the presence of the member for Burke who is a great member of that subcommittee—I can say that this is an issue we have been fighting for for quite some time. We have to remember that this is a tax of the government's own making. We welcome the fact that they have removed it from small to medium wineries. I understand that there is a slight problem in that the government have announced the policy without reference to the states and are now having to do a bit of a policy patch-up, trying to negotiate with them. We have not seen any legislation as yet, and I hope very much that the Winemakers Federation has not been taken for another election ride on this issue.

Small wineries in my electorate will certainly benefit greatly from this policy when it comes into effect. They have been struggling with the drought, they have been struggling with the production of their grapes and they have certainly been struggling under the burden of an incredibly unfair tax. I want to acknowledge particularly the work of Jane Lessock from Mount Beckworth Wines. Before I was elected—I think almost the day after becoming a candidate in the previous election campaign—she emailed me about this issue and made me aware of the impact it was having on small wineries in my district. She made me a passionate advocate for this as an area of policy that is vital for my district. So I certainly want to acknowledge Jane Lessock's role in teaching me about the wine equalisation tax and her tireless campaigning locally and with the regional winemakers federation.

I want to talk a little about what was not in the budget. This year we will commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Eureka Stockade. It is a very significant event in the history of not only Ballarat but also Australia. Most historians and those who know anything about the stockade will acknowledge that it did contribute significantly to the structure and system of democracy in Victoria and the extension of rights to people to stand and to vote for our parliaments. That rebellion is fairly significant. I know that John Malony, author of the book Eureka, does not like me to call it a rebellion but it is a word I sometimes slip into using. Certainly, when we look at the history of Australia, the Eureka Stockade is one of only two civil uprisings ever to occur in our entire history. The first event occurred in Darwin and is not widely reported, and the second is the Eureka Stockade. There was an uprising of prisoners at Vinegar Hill in New South Wales, which I note is also getting quite a bit of recognition this year.

To commemorate this incredible and significant part of Australian history, the state government has committed $1.5 million—but there is nothing in the federal budget at all. In December this year we will commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Eureka Stockade uprising. Obviously I have been campaigning on an issue that this parliament could do something about, which is flying the flag within the precinct. But I am also campaigning on the need to commit money particularly to the democracy conference occurring in Ballarat and also at VUT, which will be an important event at which to talk about the importance of democracy in Australia and the role that the Eureka Stockade played within it.

Also not within the budget was funding for the ex-prisoner of war memorial, which the ex-prisoner of war memorial committee in Ballarat have secured funding for. We had 10,000 people at the dedication of the memorial; it was an incredibly moving event. This is a national memorial, despite the government refusing to recognise it as such; it contains 35,000 names of ex-prisoners of war from all wars that this country has fought in. But there was no money in the federal budget to help the city of Ballarat and the ex-prisoner of war memorial committee to maintain this magnificent facility. It certainly will be something that I will be campaigning quite hard on.

The next issue is a little road that is down my way called the Deer Park bypass, which is pretty important. The Western Highway is a national highway; it is the main artery running between Adelaide and Melbourne. It carries over 40,000 pieces of freight each year and it is the main artery for goods and services for people from the western district both to Melbourne and to Adelaide. The Deer Park bypass is a 100 per cent Commonwealth project and, again, we heard no announcement in the budget speech that this project will get any recognition at all. I note that the Calder did get some mention, but the Deer Park bypass did not get any mention at all. Hopefully, with the AusLink announcement on Monday, we will see some funding for the Deer Park bypass.

I know that the minister has been performing a couple of stunts in my electorate of late. One was with my Liberal opponent when, on congratulating her on what a great campaign she has been running on this issue, he accidentally called her by my name. So it is good to note that, in fact, Minister Ian Campbell knows that `Catherine' has been campaigning incredibly hard; noone has worked harder to try and get the Deer Park bypass funded. Let us hope that he has heard our pleas.

I also want to talk briefly about drought funding. In my district we have had the lowest rainfall on record for the last eight years. You only have to go to Lake Wendouree, a pretty significant icon in my district—as a rower, I row across it—to see the evidence. At the moment, you can stand in the middle of it. If anyone can tell me why—with the level of water in that lake and in Lake Learmonth and the appalling circumstances being faced by farmers, small businesses and the community out at Learmonth—we cannot get exceptional circumstances funding, I just do not get it. We still have not heard any announcement about exceptional circumstances, despite having the lowest rainfall in my district in eight years. It is continuing. There is no evidence whatsoever that that is changing. They need drought funding.
I started my speech with some quotes, so I want to conclude with a quote:

quote.para: ... honesty is being swamped by cynical election campaigns based on fear, the big scare, the massive lie.

speech.para: That comes not from our side of the House or from any of those left-wing journalists that the government likes to rail against but from the then Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, in his first headland speech in the lead-up to the 1996 election. But I guess the question that remains for this upcoming election is: which fear or big scare will the government use? Will it be asylum seekers again or Indigenous people or, as we have seen debated today, same sex couples? Which massive lie will the Prime Minister rely on this time?

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and the cognate bills which are the result of the excellent budget brought down last month by the Treasurer. With federal budgets, I think the key issue we should talk about is the overall running of the Australian economy and not whether this road or that road got some funding or whether this little pet project for somebody got a guernsey. I think people often forget that this is a national budget that sets the framework for the nation. The nation then progresses one way or another, depending on the quality of the overall economic management of the government of the day.

speech.para: This is certainly an excellent budget when you put it together with the budgets since the coalition came to government. We talk about economic management—this is the seventh budget in a row that is in surplus. We have now paid off $70 billion of the debt we inherited when we came into government in 1996—$70 billion of the $96 billion is now paid. We have projected growth of 3½ per cent over the next three years. Inflation is running at about two per cent. Unemployment is below six per cent. Interest rates—the cash rate—were today kept at 5.25 per cent by the Reserve Bank Governor. These are very good figures. The economy is going so well because of good budgeting by the government, and all the other things that occur in our nation can progress as a result of that.

If you do not get these things right then you run into difficulties all over the place. Once again, we can contrast these sorts of numbers with what we remember having in the last few years of the previous government. I have spoken a number of times over the last eight years about that, but it is something you cannot remind people of too many times. The experience of the late eighties and early nineties will constantly haunt me and many other people. I think 21.75 per cent was the highest interest rate I paid on my business overdraft which, at the time, was a six-figure overdraft and was keeping 25 people employed during the recession that we had to have. They were interesting days, that is for sure. Those days taught me a huge amount, but it was a lesson that I hope nobody else has to go through in the future. When I compare those circumstances with what we have today and have had for a number of years it is quite incredible.

The real benefit that has come out of this good management is that many more people are in a job. If you are in a job, you can solve many other problems. If you are not in job, all sorts of issues and problems will arise. But getting people into work, from a government point of view, is by far the best thing that we can do. We see in Eden-Monaro at the moment, as a result of this good management, unemployment now down around the national figure. This is unheard of—it is historic—in Eden-Monaro. In parts of Eden-Monaro we still have high unemployment—higher than I would like. Down on the coast, where unemployment has traditionally been very high, it is still high but over the whole electorate it falls below the six per cent figure, similar to the national figure. That similarity has never been there before. Only a few years ago, the unemployment rate on the coastal parts of the electorate was up into the high teens. Now we are below 10 per cent on one part of the coast and below seven per cent in the other parts. So there are dramatic differences. You can see the changes: the shopping centres are full, the shops are no longer vacant and there is real activity, which is terrific.

This budget continues to address issues about jobs and it continues to make sure that interest rates are kept low. Home loan affordability remains at a good level. If interest rates took off, we would certainly see some problems for home buyers, but they are being kept low. Older Australians and families are targeted for assistance. We make no apologies for targeting families in this budget. Look at a number of budgets in a row and see how we have made various changes. If you package them together, which is what you have to do, you can see how various parts of our communities have been assisted over a number of years. You can never do everything at once. If you try to help every little aspect of the economy and the community every time you do your budgeting, you will never do anything substantial for anybody. One of those areas is obviously tax cuts.

Critics have made much about single people on less than $52,000 not receiving tax cuts but they ignore what has been done over a number of years. It is quite interesting to look at that. For instance, somebody on $20,000 is now paying $625 per year less than they were paying before the A New Tax System was introduced in 2000. We had changes to the tax system in 2000, changes in the 2003-04 budget and changes in the recent budget. Somebody on $20,000, because of those changes that have taken place over a number of years, is paying $625 per year less. Someone on $30,000 is paying $1,050 less, someone on $35,000 is paying $1,250 a year less, someone on $40,000 is paying $1,630 a year less, someone on $45,000 is paying $2,280 a year less, and someone on $50,000 is paying $2,930 less tax per year than they were paying before those first changes were made. Changing the tax scales, which we have done in this budget, is unfinished business from what we tried to do during 2003-04—substantial changes to the tax system which we have continued in this budget.

The other benefit to families is in the family tax benefit. We see a $600 increase in family tax benefit A, which means that the base rate goes up from $1,095 to $1,695. The income test has eased as well. This is a substantial issue. You can use all sorts of cameos, and families out there in Eden-Monaro can get some idea from some of the examples as to where they fall in. That is why I have given a range of different incomes. The phase-out for the maximum payment of the family tax benefit will be softened so that a family with three children will still receive some payment when earning up to $70,920 per year. The cut-off income for a base payment for a family with three children will be raised to $105,572. They are really quite substantial changes, so you can see that a lot of people are benefiting from those.

The other major change is with respect to a single income where you have a part-time second earner. Around 90 per cent of these families will receive the additional $600 per child that I mentioned before. That $600 is before 30 June. They will then receive another $600 once their tax is reconciled at the start of the next financial year. That is likely to be in around September, depending on when they get their income tax returns in.

We also have the maternity allowance of $3,000 on the birth of a baby after 1 July this year. That will rise to $5,000 by 1 July 2008. There are also extra child-care places. We have seen some big increases in child-care places. I have some very strong, growing areas in my electorate, and I have been pleased that we have constantly been able to provide additional child-care places in those fast-growing areas. The budget announced an extra 30,000 outside school hours care places and an extra 1,500 family day care places. That will mean that from 1 July there will be an extra 40,000 places for outside school hours care and 4,000 family day care places—all fairly substantial amounts.

Carers were well looked after. Eighty thousand people receiving carers payments will get a payment of $1,000 before the end of June. All members of parliament increasingly hear of either people who are caring for elderly people or, all too often, older people looking after younger disabled people. They are receiving carers payments, so they will certainly be pleased to receive that additional support.

There is $3.1 billion of additional money over the next five years going into roads, and that is on top of $5.6 billion that covers funding for the national highway system and roads of national importance. I know the two ministers responsible will be making further announcements about that money, but the key there is that the money is budgeted. I see the opposition running around in various places, including in my electorate of Eden-Monaro, making all sorts of promises about roads, but we have not seen what sort of programs they are talking about and where the money would come from. For the things that I have been able to talk about in my electorate that could be funded over the next few years, the money is there—it is in the budget. That is a key issue.

Aged care is a very important part of the budget, and certainly the changes to aged care have been well received throughout my electorate. We are looking at overall payments of about $3.6 million into Eden-Monaro by the end of June to all of our aged care facilities. Having spoken to many of those facilities, I can say they are certainly extremely pleased about the extra assistance that they will be receiving. I will go through the various aged care facilities because they are so important and are key to looking after our older people. It is really a key thing in our rural towns to have great facilities, and all of our facilities are superb. Most of them are community based in one way or the other, and they do a great job.

Banksia Village down at Broulee will be eligible for a $112,000 payment by the end of June. I took the Prime Minister down there the other day to meet those people, and he enjoyed the visit. Bimbimbie Retirement Village at Merimbula, $182,000; Casuarina Hostel in Bega, $108,500; Crown Gardens in Batemans Bay, $140,000; Currawanna Home in Bombala, $140,00; Dalmeny Retirement Village, $126,000; Edgewood Park facility at Batemans Bay, $269,500; the Eurobodalla Shire Residential Care Facility at Dalmeny, $192,500; George Forbes House in Queanbeyan, $297,500; Hillgrove House in Bega, $203,000; Imlay House at Pambula, $182,000; Keweree Lodge in Queanbeyan, $133,000; Maranatha Lodge in Batemans Bay, which was extended quite substantially recently, $332,500; Mariner Park at Tura Beach, $84,000; Moruya Hostel, $105,000; Nullica Lodge at Eden, 45,500; Queanbeyan Nursing Home $385,000; Sir William Hudson Memorial centre in Cooma $182,000; Snowy River Hostel, the small one at Berriedale $35,000; and Yallambee Lodge in Cooma $84,000. They are substantial payments to all of these aged care facilities which will really help them with what they do—not to mention the additional places that have been announced and the increase in the formula from 100 places per thousand people over the age of 70, to 108 per thousand. That will put substantial new places into our area.

There are just a few other key issues. The member for Ballarat mentioned the WET tax. The change was well received by all the small wineries in the greater Canberra area and down the coast. There was a $290,000 rebate for wineries up to $1 million. Across the nation, 90 per cent of producers will be eligible. I cannot absolutely confirm it, but I think 100 per cent of the wineries within my electorate will be eligible.

Drought assistance for exceptional circumstances will be forking out $73 million in income support and interest rate subsidies between 2003-04 and 2005-06, giving a total of $1.1 billion in drought assistance between 2002-03 and 2005-06. It is certainly well received and needed in many parts of my electorate. The drought has certainly not gone from the Monaro. People know that it is extremely dry around the Canberra area and in the far South Coast as well. Dairy farmers down there have been eligible for exceptional circumstances for some time, and I know the Monaro farmers are currently going through that application process also.

Small business will certainly benefit. In fact, I was quite surprised that 740,000 small businesses and 30,000 not-for-profit community groups will be eligible for the change in GST reporting to once a year. It is quite a large number that fall within the categories of turnover of less than $50,00 for small businesses and $100,000 for the not-for-profit groups, and certainly they will benefit from that.

While I am talking about GST, I want to reinforce the fact that all of the GST that is collected does go to the states. It was good to see the Treasurer announce in the budget that from this coming year all states now are in a bonus situation—that is, they will be collecting or being paid more in GST than they would have been getting under the old financial system between the Commonwealth and the states.

I was particularly amazed to be given a copy of a letter to a constituent from the Labor state member for Monaro, who tries to justify the New South Wales government's axing of the Mature Workers Program as part of their mini-budget. In that mini-budget, they also whacked an extra stamp duty on houses when you sell them and introduced all sorts of other incredible taxes. In trying to justify it—as the states always do, they just blame the Commonwealth—he says, `On top of this, we're yet to see a single cent of the money raised from the GST.' I could not believe that. Even if you want to argue about whether or not they are getting a bonus, they are getting all the GST and have done so ever since it started. But he writes to a constituent and says that the state government have never seen the GST. He—and I will quote it again—says, `On top of this, we're yet to see a single cent of the money raised from the GST.' These are the sorts of lies that seem to get thrown around by some people in the political process. It is an outrageous thing to say in a letter to a constituent. New South Wales not only have been getting every single cent but also this year—all the other states have already got this in past years—are getting more money than they would have under the old arrangements.

This is a very good budget. It continues the very sound economic management that the coalition have demonstrated ever since we came to government. That is the key to a national budget—to get all those national things right. We have seen the benefits of good economic management over the last number of years, particularly with the flow-on to falling unemployment. Eden-Monaro has certainly received this budget well and knows that it can grow into the future, as a result of that good management.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on that Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 in this cognate debate. This budget handed down on 12 May this year is the largest spending budget in our history. The budget will expend $52 billion, but somehow it leaves so many Australians in receipt of nothing. The budget targets income earners on $52,000 per annum—effectively $1,000 a week—or over, but it provides no income tax cut for those earning below that amount. The fact is that in my electorate—and I am sure in most electorates of both government members and opposition members—well over the majority of Australians will not receive an income tax cut.

speech.para: I estimate that almost 90 per cent of income earners in my electorate will not be in receipt of an income tax cut, and I think that is comparable to most electorates. In fact, once you get out of the capital cities, you find that that proportion grows. As we heard in question time today, when the opposition leader asked questions of the government in relation to this, it is clear that, in many seats held by The Nationals, the proportion of Australians not in receipt of income tax cuts increases. It is a sad day when a Treasurer can hand down a budget that is so large in total but so narrow in its application to beneficiaries.

It is a too-clever-by-half budget. This was an attempt by the Treasurer to niche target what he and the Prime Minister see as a certain demographic in marginal seats. This was designed purely to win the next election. They are narrowly targeted income tax cuts for those who are perceived by the government and their pollsters to be swinging voters in marginal seats. However, what it has done to the electorate of Burke is to ensure that, as I said, almost 90 per cent of PAYE income earners will be left with nothing in their pocket in relation to income tax cuts.

There has been some song and dance about the family tax benefit. I welcome the fact that there will be some relief in terms of the family tax benefit for families with children. It is certainly going to provide some relief, particularly to those who are struggling to make ends meet with the increased costs they experience in their daily lives. But the fact is that not all recipients of the family tax benefit will indeed receive the second instalment. We hear the Treasurer boast about the first instalment of $600 to be paid before 30 June this year. But we are also acutely aware of the many constituents who have complained about the system which has compelled them to find money to repay the Commonwealth because of the way in which income is assessed. What we are aware of is that up to one-third of recipients of the family tax benefit have an average debt of over $800—I think it is closer to $900. So in other words, one-third of recipients will in fact not only not receive the second instalment to be paid but also will still be in debt after that first amount is taken from their debt. It certainly will provide some relief but the view of the Labor Party and of other commentators is that this is not a good policy.

This is a two-part bribe by the government: pick up your $600 cheque, signed by the Prime Minister, on your way to the ballot box. That is the intention. That is the modus operandi of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer: to try and buy people's votes in the forthcoming election. We recall vividly how much fiscal and monetary responsibility went out the window prior to the 2001 election, when the Prime Minister and the government sought to buy themselves out of trouble. We see again this spike in expenditure that arises just preceding a federal election. What will occur in the event of a re-election of a Howard coalition government is that they will find ways to claw back and take back moneys that were expended. We are aware—and this has gone unchallenged by independent commentators—that this is the highest taxing government since Federation. In terms of proportion of GDP, the Commonwealth, whether it is through GST or through other means, has in fact imposed a greater tax burden upon Australians than any other government in history. That is not going to change if there is a re-election of this government.

While the Treasurer likes to boast about the income tax cuts, we see that they are confined to fewer than 10 per cent of income earners. Indeed, when it comes to the family tax benefit we see that many will not be in receipt of the second instalment. Despite the spending, despite the huge largesse that has been expended by the Treasurer, money does not go into the pockets of the majority of Australians. Indeed, those people not defined as family—and I presume under the Prime Minister's description that would be 2.4 children, a man and a woman as father and mother and probably a dog and a picket fence—and outside of that construct will not be in receipt of any income tax cut or other relief unless they earn more than $52,000.

I know many occupational groups and many people in quite deserving occupations who will not receive a cent. They do not have children, or they do not have dependent children—that is more important in relation to this budget—and they are contributing greatly to this country. But they will not be in receipt of any relief whatsoever. Many teachers, nurses, home carers and child-care workers will not be in receipt of any money at all as a result of this budget. The Treasurer has been too tricky about his application here. The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have gone into a room—it has taken them six months—with pollsters and asked, `How do we target a group that will get us over the line?' But I think the Australian community has seen this for what it really is: a bribe on the way to the ballot box by this government.

We should not be too surprised. When I was contacted by local media I indicated that this should not be a surprise because, in philosophical terms, this is a Liberal Party budget. There is no point feigning surprise when you see that the income tax cuts are directed at the top end of the income scale. Of course, the Liberal Party is in office and you would expect the Liberal Party to look after those at the higher income end rather than those at the middle or lower income ends. So I am not particularly surprised; I am just disappointed that there has been no effort to look after the majority of Australians.

It is also in accordance with Liberal Party philosophy to continue to pay elite non-government schools greater increases in real terms than public schools and very needy independent schools. This has been a trend now for some years. The fact is that we are aware that the old school tie applies to everyone, I suppose, except for the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister applied the old school tie he might look after public schools, because he is, I know, one of the very few people on the frontbench who went to a government school, although he does not seem to return and visit there often, if at all.

The fact is that this government has been paying increases in real terms to elite non-government schools like King's College, Geelong Grammar and others at the expense of public schools in my electorate and very needy independent schools that are not getting the increases. For example, the deal that was hatched recently to the Catholic school system provided approximately a three per cent increase, which was pretty much a CPI increase for that system. The Catholic school system is one of the very few systems where negotiations can be centralised, given the way in which the system is structured. I have to say that there were some that lauded it as a very good offer made by the Commonwealth. But, if you look at the amount each school in the Catholic school system receives and compare that with the elite category 1 schools, you find that, in fact, they have not received a good increase.

Most importantly, the public school system is in much need of injected capital. I do not think there is any concern shown in this budget for looking after schools like Deer Park Secondary College and Brookside college, which are public schools in my electorate that are doing it tough. They have fantastic teachers and wonderful students. I have had the great fortune of meeting many of them—that is, both teachers and principals of those schools and the students. What those students want is the same opportunity. Students who reside in Deer Park and the surrounding suburbs in western Melbourne want to be given the same opportunity as kids in the leafier suburbs of Melbourne such as Canterbury, Toorak, Hawthorn and Kew. They want the same opportunity and they are not going to get it if there is no effort to address the inequity in funding.

Again, I am not surprised—it is in keeping with Liberal Party philosophy, certainly in recent times, to look after the better off at the expense of those who are most in need. But it is disappointing to see a government in this day and age failing to realise that we need to invest equitably in our future. One of the best ways to do that is to invest in our young people and provide them with opportunities. That has not been shown. There has been no vision, no equity, no sense of egalitarianism and no fair go being exhibited by the Treasurer or the Prime Minister in relation to this budget. I think that is a major concern.

The other concern I have is that, whilst it is good in some senses that the government has followed Labor and decided to have some form of maternity payment, as it likes to call it, to women who have children and to provide some relief so that they can care for their children, we do not accept that the up-front payment is the most sensible approach to providing relief for those mothers. We believe that it is an inferior approach to the one that has been outlined by the Leader of the Opposition and others.

There are some grave concerns. Looking at the other side of the ledger, it is fair to say that there has been not only a failure by the government in the broader package but also a failure to really target those things that are most needed. For example, look at the lousy proposal in the area of dental care that has been put forward by the Commonwealth government as opposed to the opposition's proposal. The fact is that we now need a comprehensive dental program to look after those in need—not when their teeth and gums are so badly in need of care that it is an emergency situation. What we need and what Labor is proposing is a $300 million-plus proposal that will cater for people in need, particularly the elderly in our community. People who have already pitched in—people who have contributed to this country for many decades—should be the recipients of a decent dental care scheme. It is tragic to see elderly people in particular in my electorate who cannot get care for their teeth and gums that are clearly infected. It is a real problem and it is not being addressed by the government. It will be addressed by Labor.

It is the same story when it comes to expenditure on health. More money is being spent on advertising by this government than is being spent on dental care. Over $100 million will be spent on advertising—on propaganda. It would make Goebbels blush. Instead, that money could be expended on proper health care and indeed on targeting the problems of declining access to doctors who bulk-bill. The Prime Minister has been on the record wanting to destroy Medicare. He clearly knows that it is so popular that he cannot come out with a frontal attack, so he wants it to wither on the vine. He wants his favourite, Tony Abbott, to do his bidding for him. By comparison it is an inferior policy because it does not target saving Medicare. It is about dividing up the system into two classes: those who can afford it and those who cannot. It is an inferior system for those who cannot afford it.

Again, like the dental care proposal, the government missed an opportunity to properly look after infants. We know it is a lot of money to spend on pneumococcal vaccination. There is even a question mark over how many infant deaths there have been as a result of this disease. But I could not fathom the minister for education wishing to quibble whether it was 50, 20, 10 or 35. The fact is that one death is one too many. When we know that we can prevent those deaths, we should be expending in that area. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for health have rightly targeted that area as a special case in order to prevent more tragic deaths.

In relation to health and education the problem is that the government has got it wrong. It listens to the pollsters about demographics and possible swinging voters in marginal seats but it does not listen to the people. The difference between Mark Latham and John Howard going to a town hall is quite obvious: we know that there are no bouncers on the door when Mark Latham is speaking; there is no-one stopping people coming in to speak with him. He has an open-door policy when it comes to speaking to members of the public when he goes around Australia. We do not see that with the Prime Minister.

By comparison, we see a Prime Minister who stage-manages everything. I recall on one occasion in Melbourne recently—I think you were there, Mr Deputy Speaker Barresi—a woman whose name happened to be Latham was thrown out. That woman, who had no relationship whatsoever with the Leader of the Opposition, was ejected from that room—in fact, she was a Liberal Party voter, from what I understand—because they were too worried that she might cause a commotion. That is the difference between the way the Prime Minister operates and the way the Leader of the Opposition operates. One of the consequences of that behaviour is that, as we are listening to the cries for help from the community, the Prime Minister and Treasurer are focusing on pollsters. That is the big difference between the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister, and I think it is a real problem.

The last thing I wanted to touch on—I have managed to speak on these issues a couple of times, because there was a tax bill that went through recently and I spoke on that—is the Treasurer himself. We do not know, if the coalition wins government at the next election, who is going to be Prime Minister for that term. I do not think the Prime Minister or the Treasurer have been honest. I do not think the Prime Minister has been honest with the Treasurer and I do not think the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have been honest with the public. That is the position.

The Treasurer had a chance in 1994. If he had had the guts, he could have challenged—he could have taken up the leadership. But he thought he might lose so he did not. The Treasurer thought he might lose, so he did not; he waited. Last year the Leader of the Opposition thought he might win a challenge, and he did. The difference between the Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition is that the Leader of the Opposition took his chance—and the problem for the Treasurer is he may never get a chance. The fact is we do not know what is going to happen, because the Prime Minister and the Treasurer will not tell the public the truth. I think the public deserve an honest answer, but it appears we are not going to get one.

talk.start.para: —I am very happy to have this opportunity to speak today on the 2004-05 federal budget through the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and cognate bills. There are so many significant aspects of this budget, it is hard to know exactly where to start. We have witnessed yet another healthy surplus, and $70 billion of Labor's $96 billion debt has now been repaid, saving a massive $5.5 billion per year in interest payments alone. There are tax cuts that will make sure that more than 80 per cent of all taxpayers pay a top marginal rate of 30 per cent or less. There is a $2.2 billion aged care package to provide more places and better nursing-home care. There is an extra $1.5 billion in Defence spending to help increase our capability and upgrade national security. There is an extra $8 billion for schools over the next five years and more funding for new apprenticeships.

speech.para: The list goes on and on. There are also bonus payments to carers to recognise the great work they do. There is an increase in the government's contribution to superannuation for low- and middle-income workers. There is an extra $300 million for the Natural Heritage Trust, which delivers real, practical environmental solutions to local problems. There is an extra $3.1 billion to upgrade our local road and rail systems. These are really significant improvements and benefits for our nation. We are delivering on our commitment as a government to get on with the job and always do what is right in the national interest.

But the most important and most significant aspect of the budget in my view is that it delivers over $19 billion to Australian families—the largest family assistance package ever put forward by an Australian government. The significance of this lies not so much in dollar terms—although the financial support will be warmly welcomed—but in the recognition it gives to parents throughout the country that their work is important and that we realise the unique challenges that they face daily. It further reinforces the great truth that not only is the rearing of children one of the most enriching and important things that a person can do but it is also vital for the future of this country and it is a lasting contribution to our society.

That fact seems to have been sadly overlooked by those who are fuelling that `why should we pay for other people's children' debate. Can I say I think this is a particularly mean-spirited approach, to say nothing of the fact that it denies the clear economic importance of children to our nation. The fact is that our taxes pay for a range of things, including health care for people of all ages, age pensions, university education, scientific research, services and support to veterans, nursing-home care, roads, public transport and defence. To a degree we support and subsidise the arts, various community organisations and charities, and provide a very diverse range of other services through these taxes. Yet a modest increase in family payments to help families meet the costs of raising children is met with a `What about me?' response from some quarters.

I happen to think that is a very sad indictment on the way some sections of our community view parenting and the value of families to our nation. It is all the more reason why we should, wherever possible, increase government support to families and children to give proper recognition of the importance that we place on them as the cornerstone of our society. As someone who has raised a large family—I actually had two for myself, two for my husband and then a further four for the country—I know the challenges that parents face, not just financially. There are also the greater responsibilities and the joys and difficulties of family life at different stages. Knowing that your efforts are valued by the government and community and that you are helping contribute to the nation's future is, I believe, very important. Of course, that is not why anyone decides to become a parent. There is enormous personal benefit, fulfilment and satisfaction. Parenting equips you with important skills, personal values and emotional experiences you never knew possible—and I fully understand that those who have not had children yet cannot fully comprehend what I have just said.

There are so many negative messages these days about parenting and the costs of children that I believe it is important that, as a government, we provide tangible recognition that this is a worthwhile, important role to fulfil in life. I thought it was a very sad indictment several years ago when then Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett was roundly criticised for pointing out to a group of year 12 students that becoming a parent was a worthy aspiration and should form a central part of their plans for the future. Why this was such an outrageous suggestion is beyond me, but the outcry was loud and long at the time. I believe we have come a long way since then, and I hope that the Howard government's pro-family policies have helped raise the status, so to speak, of children and families.

This budget gives very practical and real assistance to families by increasing by $600 per child the rate of family tax benefit A. Each family receiving family tax benefit A will also receive a one-off payment of $600 per child before 30 June this year. Further, we have adjusted the withdrawal rate between the maximum and base rates of FTB A from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. In addition, we have reduced the income test withdrawal rate for family tax benefit B to help women returning to part-time work. To help families with the birth of a new baby, we will also provide a new maternity payment of $3,000, which will increase to $5,000 by July 2008. We do not pretend that this begins to cover the full cost of having a baby but, again, it is recognition that this is a time of change and adjustment for many families and a time when they need and deserve a little extra financial support. I really appreciate how the government has handled the child-care issues in the budget. This budget provides an extra 40,000 outside school hours child-care places and 4,000 more family day care places to provide families with help to juggle their work and family responsibilities.

I have been dismayed by the Labor Party's negative response to these important budget measures for children and families. While they have agreed to vote for these measures—because even they can see that they are deserving, practical measures that will help Australian families—they have done nothing but whine and complain from the sidelines, to the point where you wonder whether Labor will retain these benefits if they are elected to office. It is still anyone's guess what Labor will do if they are elected to office, apart from reading to and mentoring a very small percentage of disadvantaged young Australians. While that is a worthwhile task, there is certainly a lot more to government. But when Labor had the gall to criticise this generous, positive budget as having `forgotten some people', you just had to cast your mind back to the last few Labor budgets when they were in government to see what they meant. What exactly did Labor mean by `a budget for everyone'? It is true that there were no forgotten people in, for example, the Labor budget of 1993—their last budget. Everyone got slugged extra petrol excise, everyone got slugged extra wholesale sales tax, everyone missed out on the l-a-w law tax cuts that were promised but never delivered, and everyone ultimately paid the price for Labor's ongoing budget deficits. That was certainly a budget for all, and no-one was spared.

Those who have had this `what's in it for me' approach to the budget should cast their minds back to what budget night was like under Labor. It was never a question of `What do I get?' but of `How much more will I be out of pocket? Will deeming rates rise? Will I pay more for my beer and petrol? Will I continue to pay ridiculously high marginal tax rates?' Those were the sorts of budget night questions that continually confronted us under the Labor government. In between budgets we had the eternal worry of when interest rates would rise again, thanks to Labor's poor economic management. As someone who had to take out a second mortgage at that time, I know first-hand what a burden that was for families.

That was in the past, and Labor and some sections of the media would like us to forget all about it now, pretend it did not happen and look to the future. I am all for looking to the future, but the fact is that the best predictor of the future is the past. Given what we have seen of their `magic pudding' approach to economic management under the member for Hotham, you have to assume that that is what we will be facing again if Labor get into government. At the coming election it will be a very clear choice, as never before, between responsible government and strong economic management under the Howard government and a return to the big spending, high taxing, union led government of Labor.

When you look at the breadth and scope of the positive measures in this budget, you see a stark contrast to what Labor have to offer. The Leader of the Opposition seems to think that a few platitudes and warm and fuzzy statements will be enough to see him coast to victory. But do these election friendly statements ever reflect Labor's true position? Reading to children is of course very noble, and the vast majority of Australian parents already have the marvellous habit of reading to their children. The vast majority of children today are attaining excellent literacy and numeracy levels. But Labor in government let literacy and numeracy standards drop to dangerously low levels—in fact, 30 per cent of students did not meet basic literacy and numeracy standards. We had to fight the unions tooth and nail to introduce national literacy and numeracy standards and we are still fighting state Labor governments to make sure results are reported to parents. You have to believe that, despite their rhetoric about reading to kiddies, this would be at risk if Labor were in government.

Labor now have a catchy `earn or learn' policy for young people, yet Labor and their union mates opposed the whole principle of Work for the Dole. They still despise it. They admit they would scrap this successful program that brings real benefits for the community and put in place another airy-fairy, expensive scheme like the infamous Working Nation. Apprenticeships are another area where Labor are trying to claim the high ground, yet under Labor apprenticeships fell to the lowest level in 30 years, such was their elitist focus on university education above all else. Since we came to office we have been boosting apprenticeship and traineeship numbers so that now we have more than 406,000 Australians training as apprentices. This budget provides $725 million for new apprenticeships. Again, as with much of Labor's warm and fuzzy talk, it is a case of looking at what they do and what they really believe rather than what they say.

Labor have been grandstanding lately about pneumococcal vaccination, yet, when they were in office, ensuring children were vaccinated properly was such a low priority that only around 53 per cent of children were fully immunised. That is a lower rate than in Third World countries. Our government have worked hard to increase immunisation levels to over 90 per cent and we have worked in a very diligent and genuine way to ensure that the vaccination schedule is updated and upgraded as necessary. Again Labor are quick with the rhetoric, but again they have form that does not match that rhetoric.

The really big hypocrisy is in education. Labor say we should spend more money on education. This budget increases funding for schools over the next four years by $8 billion to a massive $31.3 billion. In fact, since coming to office the Howard government have increased school funding by over 60 per cent, while inflation during that time has been around 20 per cent. I must say that I am disturbed at the divide caused by the Labor members in this House and their constant misleading statements about state school funding. The results have been, especially in my electorate, mums and dads are taking their children out of public school and running off to private schools, thinking that is the only way that their children can get a decent education. I tell people throughout my electorate as often as I can how good state schools are. I have had eight children attend state schools and I currently have seven grandchildren attending state schools, and I can tell people that they do not miss out on anything. Their parents tell me how good their teachers are and what a top-class education they are receiving through them. I am pleading with Labor to stop this nonsense and let us get on with looking after our children.

We also know that the state Labor governments—who actually have the responsibility for school funding—have failed to match our funding increases. In fact, if state Labor in Queensland had matched our funding increase last year there would have been an extra $116 million for Queensland public schools. That is just by matching our increase and not by doing anything more. Like Labor claims, this should have happened. State Labor have failed to even match what we are doing. But where is the outcry from the opposition leader or Labor's union mates? Again with Labor it is all talk. What do they actually do in government? The rhetoric just does not match their actions. It would be laughable if it were not such a serious matter.

We all know that cheap jibes and glib comments are easy from opposition. Off the cuff comments like, `I'll bring the troops home by Christmas,' made without any real consideration of not just the situation on the ground but the wider political ramifications, may be just a silly mistake in opposition but in government the cost could be very high. Government is a serious business.

Balancing the budget is one of the most fundamental tasks of the government. No amount of responsible spending can take place unless the fundamentals are managed properly. In this, the Howard government's ninth budget, we have continued to deliver benefits where they are needed most without raising taxes and without cutting important spending but by responsible economic management. In fact, each year we are currently saving $5.5 billion interest that we would have been otherwise paying each year if we had not paid back $70 billion of Labor's $96 billion debt. And it is interesting to note that $70 billion is the exact figure that Labor managed to run up as debt in their last five budgets. Yes, it took Labor just five short years to saddle Australia with an extra interest bill of $5.5 billion every single year—a wasted $5.5 billion every single year because they ran up budget deficits. And I should point out too that most of the time they actually said the budget would be in surplus. The budget never ended up that way, though. That just goes to show that a lot of damage can be done in a short time if a government does not know how to properly manage an economy. And that is another reality from which the Leader of the Opposition cannot hide.

In fact, he has some personal experience and form, having saddled Liverpool Council with a huge recurrent debt during his time as mayor. Once again I point out that the best predictor of the future is the past. Labor have not learnt from the past. They will never admit they badly messed up the economy; they will never show any regret or remorse for home loan interest rates of 17 per cent. If they cannot learn from the past then, as the saying goes, they are doomed to repeat it—not if we on this side of the House can help it.

I am very proud of the government's economic track record, not because of raw facts and figures—excellent thought they are—but because having balanced the budget we have been able to deliver real, practical benefits: tax cuts, increased family benefits, more funding for schools, better aged care, more apprenticeships and reduced business taxes. And economic stability, which increases business investment, which in turn brings about a huge reduction in our unemployment figure. The list could go on and on. These are real, tangible benefits that make a difference in the lives of everyday Australians.

This budget builds on the work we have done and sets out a plan for the future—a plan that would all be at risk under Labor. I want to congratulate the Treasurer on another excellent budget. His contribution to Australia's future is undoubtedly significant and ongoing. My only hope is that Labor does not get the opportunity to ruin his years of hard work. I am pleased to commend the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005 and related bills to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2004-2005, and I am provoked into making a couple of comments by the honourable member for Forde. She raised the question of interest rates. There is no doubt that we had high interest rates at a time when there were high interest rates throughout the world. But the reality of what we are facing today is that, internationally, Australia has amongst the highest interest rates in the world. We are at world's best practice in terms of high interest rates. But that is not my big point. As a proportion of their salary and wages, people are paying far more on their mortgages today than they ever did under Labor. In fact, people now, particularly first home owners and those who have recently gone into a mortgage, are highly sensitive to the smallest interest rate increase.

—Yes, it wipes them out. Mortgages are so large that even a tiny increase in interest rates puts enormous pressure on struggling families. If you have paid your home off, you do not feel that pressure. But in my electorate of Chifley there are a lot of families feeling that pressure. In Western Sydney there are a lot of families feeling that pressure. For government members who keep on berating us about interest rates when we were in government, let me repeat: people are paying more in mortgage repayments today, in 2004—notwithstanding the historically low interest rates in Australia, which are high by international standards—than they have ever paid before.

speech.para: I was very interested in the comments about state schools. I have a belief that parents have freedom of choice and that schools, whether they are independent or public, need to stand by their own results. I am thrilled to say that at St Mary's Senior High School we actually attract heaps of students from the private sector. It is one of those schools that is reversing the trend. I find it funny that the honourable member for Forde stands up and says, `I support public schools,' when her Prime Minister says that they have no values and do not deliver. I have never thought that. I have always argued for education reform, particularly in my electorate. I do it today and I will do it tomorrow. But to suggest that public schools do not have any values is outrageous. About 75 per cent of all students in Australia go to public schools. We should cherish and value public schools, not deride them. Please, member for Forde, talk to your Prime Minister.

There is always the argument that the member for Forde used, as does the Minister for Education, Science and Training, that: `We've increased our percentage of money to schools'—primarily, I might say, to private schools—`so why don't the state governments do the same?' There is a very good reason. Take my own state of New South Wales. Over $8 billion of the state budget goes to schools. Of that $8 billion, only about $585 million goes to private schools, by way of interest subsidies and special programs. So states have a much higher proportion of money that goes to the public schools. If we were to increase the state budget to schools—and I wish we could—by 10 per cent, that would be $800 million. And this is from a state where the Commonwealth has recently cut out $356 million. I am not aware of any of my public schools getting extra money out of the budget, but I do know that King's School does very well. All the elite schools do very well. The group of schools in our society that has seen the highest increase in the percentage terms that the member for Forde wants to talk about is the elite schools. What a disgrace. I do not object to elite schools, but do not advance the argument to me that parents cannot afford them.

If, as the member for Forde says, the past is the best predictor of the future, let me say to my constituents in the Chifley electorate that the one thing that you can be sure about with the Howard government is that they will squeeze you dry like a lemon over two years and they will give something back in election year. Is this any exception? Of course not. There is not $20 billion in this budget, as we had before the 2001 election. This is the all time record. This is $52 billion, with $6 billion to be spent before the end of the financial year. If a Labor government did that, we would have all of the commentators saying, `What a profligate government this is—it has no financial responsibility and no concern for the future.' That would be just about the $6 billion. All up, it is $52 billion. Of course, they would be writing editorials about how irresponsible we were. But, as the member for Forde says, look to the past to understand the future. You are getting money back now but you will pay later.

On the tax cuts I have already said in another debate that 93 per cent of people in my electorate get zip. Do you know how much pensioners get out of it? Zip. If you are on a disability pension or an aged pension you get zip out of this budget. If you were to say, `Look, there is some money in there for aged pensioners and retirees and for aged care facilities, so each facility is getting $3,500 per bed,' then I know that those facilities that are operated by the not-for-profit sector would make good use of it. But there is absolutely no probity or tests associated with this windfall handout. Have a guess who is the biggest winner: of course, those well-known Liberal supporters, the Moran family. Do you know what accountability they are required to provide? In 2008 their facilities need to meet the new standards. There is absolutely nothing in the legislation to stop those proprietors from pocketing the money and then selling their facilities before 2008, and this government would have given them a windfall.

I did want to say that, in my electorate of Chifley, there is great concern about Mt Druitt Hospital. I would love to stand up here and say, `I am really pleased because the government is providing more nurses and doctors for Mt Druitt Hospital and—do you know—we are going to be able to reopen the intensive care unit,' or `There was some money in here for a dental program, so the state government's dental program is going to be able to be doubled to meet the demand and lower the waiting list.' I cannot say that.

There is real pressure on state hospitals. In fact, in my electorate there is a great belief that the Mt Druitt Hospital is going to close. Let me just put this on the record. I was the chairman, by invitation, of the local committee which was fighting for that hospital. I was the inaugural deputy chairman of that hospital. I might say that a want of ecclesiastical qualifications prevented me from aspiring to the position of chair. That was occupied by `Spud' Murphy, as some call him, but I would be more respectful and say Bishop Murphy. I have had a long and proud history and association with that hospital, as has my state colleague the Hon. Richard Amery, the member for Mt Druitt. That hospital will close over our dead bodies. It is not going to close.

It is true that, at the instigation of doctors, a discussion paper has been developed which is looking at what facilities should be centred at Mt Druitt and what facilities should be centred at Blacktown Hospital. To my constituents, particularly the people of Mt Druitt and all of those who look to the Mt Druitt Hospital with its very distinguished record of service, I will just say this: the department never wanted that hospital. Never, ever did the department of health want that hospital at Mt Druitt. We got it. It is there. It will continue to operate and we will not allow it to be converted to any other allied use. We will get the best deal for our constituents and for Mt Druitt Hospital. I just wanted to put that on the record. I might say that that is with no assistance from the federal government. There is nothing in this budget that will ease the pressure on state hospitals. We all know—everyone knows—what pressure those hospitals, doctors and nurses are under.

Perhaps a little unusually, I want to talk about the report Every picture tells a story. You will remember that the terms of reference for this inquiry were announced by no less than the Prime Minister. I think the committee and its chair, Kay Hull, did a terrific job. We were under a tremendous amount of pressure to bring down the report before the end of December—and we did; it was a unanimous report. The honourable member for Hinkler knows that family law, child support and counselling are difficult areas.

talk.start.para: —I gave evidence to that inquiry.

—As did a number of your colleagues. I know that, on the backbench of both sides of the House, there is a great deal of interest in getting reform and change.
