Madam Deputy Speaker Corcoran, I wish I could stand up before you and my constituents and say that the recommendations have been adopted. They have not been, and that is a real disappointment. If we are to get reform in this area, we need the cooperation of the major parties. It is no good the coalition going off on one track and Labor on another. We actually need bipartisan support, and I think a tremendous platform has been laid here.

speech.para: But the committee members have been under vicious attack from the media and the former Chief Justice that the proposition of a tribunal was unconstitutional. I resent that. It is not unconstitutional. The committee had access, in a private briefing, to the chief legal adviser of the Commonwealth. As the Australian reported—not through me, I might say—we have called him back and had another briefing, and he stands by his recommendations that the tribunal is constitutional. Anyone running around this parliament trying to suggest otherwise is causing mischief, giving the former Chief Justice of the Family Court his greatest victory in retirement and, I think, hindering progress.

Importantly, no-one should be under any illusions. It was said: `You won't lessen the case load, because anything involving domestic violence or sexual abuse will still have to be dealt with by the courts.' The tribunal can hear those cases, but you would not expect it to hear the majority of cases. Difficult cases involving domestic violence—and, in my belief, sexual abuse—should be dealt with by the courts and fast-tracked. But that does not stop the tribunal from having a once-only look in. Contact and residency are repeatedly brought up as the most difficult issues in the area of enforcement. There is nothing to stop the tribunal from making decisions and enforceable orders via conciliation and then arbitration. If those orders are not adhered to and a case is made out, the tribunal can vary those orders, which is always the greater sanction. But if they want to enforce it by way of incarceration or fines—and we have never argued that that would be the case—that has to be done by a court; that is judicial.

But there will be judicial review. If there is an error of law or a denial of natural justice, of course the courts will be involved. But if you get up on judicial review it is most likely that all the court will do is remit it back to the tribunal for further consideration. One of the things I am most keen about is that, if both parties agree, the tribunal can settle all matters. It is true that there are big losers in all this, and they are the legal profession. We have no idea how much money the parties to family law—or their parents or grandparents—are spending. A study on that has never been done, but I suggest that it is in the hundreds of millions of dollars. What we are doing for ordinary people—the majority of Australians—is giving them a no-frills, no-cost means of settling these difficult issues.

I just say this: Prime Minister, you announced it; you have exceeded the time to respond to the report; isn't it about time that you responded? We are running out of time for bipartisan cooperation in this parliament about it. You set up huge expectations about the report. The parliamentary committee system has delivered a unanimous report. Please show the people of Australia that you are interested, by way of action, by way of legislation, by way of initiative for families that are separated. These are Australians; they are no lesser Australians. There are one million children involved—the centrepiece of this report.

I also wanted to make a couple of points about youth unemployment. In Chifley, we have one of the highest percentages, I regret to say, of children living in unemployed families. The proportion of children aged 15 years or under living in families in which no parents are employed is 29.8 per cent. We could rail against those families, but that is a challenge to us in this place: to develop schemes that work with those families and those children to get them into the world of work. I have not given up, but I think as we move through society it is worth while spending money on people—investing in people, as I like to say—and getting them engaged in the economy. We should not try to count success as a full-time job, or even, necessarily, so many hours of a part-time job, but just get them engaged bit by bit. However, you have to spend the money.

I am really thrilled with the shadow minister for employment services, Anthony Albanese, the member for Grayndler, and his development of proposals for youth in the `learn or earn' policy. I like it. It is an appropriate challenge. We are spending nearly $700 million on these proposals. For example, we are abolishing TAFE fees for secondary school students. When I went around with the Western Sydney task force this was an issue for those students who were undertaking TAFE courses. I am disappointed at the low number of school based traineeships in New South Wales compared to other states. I think that we have got a long way to go. There is also the new support to keep 15,000 15- to 18-year-olds at school each year, and there are a whole range of other initiatives.

Last but not least, I asked a question in the parliament about Plumpton High, Glen Sargeant and the babies from Plumpton. Given what the Prime Minister said, I went back there last Friday. I have to say that Glen Sargeant has not changed his mind one iota. The real joy for me was that I spoke to one of the participants that was on the program. I think she is a tremendous young lady—a heroine, if you do not mind me saying so—showing great courage with two children, not in any way bowed in her ambition or her determination to do the HSC and go on to university. I was really uplifted by the experience. I do not want to go into the detail of it, but talking with her reinforced in my mind the proposition that it is folly to provide this lump sum payment. I do not believe the Prime Minister intends it for one minute, but I think he is being foolish in denying the reality that it may tempt some young, vulnerable teenagers into having a pregnancy to get that $3,000. Labor's 14 weekly payment system is an infinitely better proposition, especially for that vulnerable group of people that I spoke of.
There is much to be disappointed about in this budget. I am not sure that the people of Australia are going to reward the government in the way that they anticipate. (Time expired)
